HEADLINE: Albany Deal Eases Rules On Banking

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Just minutes before midnight, as state banking laws were about to expire, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo signed legislation that makes permanent a group of laws that give banks great latitude to create new financial products and to set interest rates for credit cards and most types of loans.
Banking officials said the agreement on the legislation, which ended more than a year of difficult negotiations, will help the state retain thousands of financial service jobs. But consumer advocates criticized the legislation, saying that it does not do enough to guarantee low-cost banking services for the poor or establish consumer protections for bank users. 
 The legislation makes permanent laws passed in the 1980's that deregulated banks by removing state-set caps on interest rates and allowing banks to create a wide range of new products, such as variable-rate loans and automatic teller machines.
 
Small-Business Fund
 Until now, those laws have expired periodically, setting off partisan debates in Albany over whether to amend, extend or scrap them. That process has created uncertainty in the industry, made long-term planning difficult and discouraged some banks from expanding their operations in the state, banking lobbyists have argued.
In addition, the legislation does several new things. It establishes a fund of $90 million for small-business loans intended for the poor, requires all banks to provide low-cost checking accounts and establishes a toll-free number on which consumers can get the latest information about interest rates.
It also requires long-term car leasing companies to disclose information about the total cost of leases to consumers. The Democratic-led Assembly had added the leasing provisions to the banking bill in a maneuver designed to win approval in the Republican-controlled Senate, which supported the banking legislation but had objected to aspects of the leasing bill.
 
Political Victory
 In an election year when layoffs and the economy are becoming major issues, the new legislation gave all three sides in the Albany power structure something to tout as a victory.
The Democratic-led Assembly said the auto leasing provisions would provide important protections in a growing and largely unregulated industry. Mr. Cuomo said the legislation "makes the state more hospitable to banks." And the Republican-led Senate claimed credit for authorship of the banking legislation, which they have championed for several years.
"This measure provides security and stablity for bankers and consumers alike," said Senate Majority Leader Ralph J. Marino, Republican from Oyster Bay.
 
Praise From the Industry
 It was also hailed by the banking industry, which said it would encourage banks to expand or establish credit card operations here. Banking lobbyists have said that the state's tight credit rules in the 1970's caused several major credit card operations to move to South Dakota and Delaware.
"This ends the uncertainty and conflict that have surrounded past negotiations over bank laws," said Michael P. Smith, executive vice-president of the New York State Bankers Association, which represents 160 commercials banks.
But consumer advocates said the Legislature should have demanded more from the banking industry before yielding the power to review the banking laws each time they expired.
"This was a gift to banks," said Travis Plunkett of the New York Public Research Interest Group.
The long-term auto leasing provisions are intended to address complaints that some leasing companies charge low monthly fees but later tack on extremely high charges for early lease termination and for "excess wear and tear."
The legislation requires leasing companies to disclose information about the total cost of leases, which theoretically will make it easier for consumers to know how much they will be charged if they end their leases early. It also establishes a process for customers to dispute extra fees for damage to their vehicles.
The $90 million small-business loan fund will be divided equally between two programs: one open to any small-business owner and one designed to assist communities with high poverty or unemployment rates. Loans from the second program will be available to working poor of any race, but priority will be given to members of minority groups living in poor communities.
The legislation will also allow banks for the first time to offer low introductory rates on credit cards as an inducement for new card owners and to charge for replacing a credit card the third time it is lost. Chemical Bank, which has the largest New York-based credit card operation, had lobbied particularly hard for those provisions.
Had the Legislature allowed the banking laws to lapse at midnight, the banking industry would have been thrown into turmoil.
But even though that possibility was thought extremely unlikely, legislative leaders and their aides circulated throughout the day detailed information about what banks might do if the laws expired, from closing down automatic teller machines to drastically restricting consumer loans.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Economy
The traditional haggling over the price of a new car or truck is fading somewhat. Pushed by auto makers, more dealers are experimenting with selling vehicles at a fixed price, hoping to keep customers by easing the anxiety in price negotiating. [Page A1.] 
 The Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision imposed a moratorium on the purchase of mutual savings and loans by commercial banks. The move came amid growing concern that executives and trustees of mutual savings and loans may be enriching themselves at the expense of depositors. [A1.]
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said the Fed had erred in the past by waiting too long to fight inflation. His testimony before Congress suggested that the central bank might break with custom and raise interest rates in a pre-emptive strike before a pickup in inflation becomes evident. [D1.]
Personal income grew slightly faster than spending in December, but spending outpaced Americans' paychecks for all of 1993, a sign that the economy could lose momentum. [D2.]
New York State legislative leaders agreed to extend a law that allows banks to set loan and credit card interest rates. [B4.]
 
Companies
BMW of Germany will acquire the Rover Group, the British auto maker, in a $1.2 billion acquisition. [D1.]
The F.C.C. approved the purchase of a radio station by Infinity Broadcasting, Howard Stern's employer. [D1.]
Wall Street waited in vain for QVC Network to improve its bid for Paramount Communications before yesterday's deadline. [D1.]
A Federal appeals court upheld the liability of Pan Am and its insurers in the bombing of Flight 103 over Scotland. [D2.]
I.B.M. said it would produce more of its own Intel 486 microprocessors, loosening its longstanding links with Intel. [D3.]
The chief executive of Neiman Marcus is the top candidate to become the No. 2 merchant at Federated Department Stores. [D3.]
United Technologies named a new chief executive. [D3.]
Xerox posted a $577 million fourth-quarter loss, but said its revamping program would save more than $1 billion. [D4.]
Mobil said its president and chief operating officer would succeed Allen E. Murray as chairman and chief executive. [D4.]
Mastercard International named a former Midland Bank executive as its new president. [D4.]
 The Hartz Group will sell Harmon Publishing, which publishes magazines of real estate advertising, for $100 million. [D7.]
 
International
Republican senators protested that the GATT agreement reached in December might encourage governments to provide more subsidies to industry. The senators' warning was a sign that the trade pact's trip through Congress might not be smooth. [D2.]
Five American military contractors have reached an agreement with Saudi Arabia to stretch out $10 billion in payments. [A6.]
 
Markets
Blue-chip stocks surged in heavy trading. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 32.93 points. [D8.]
Treasury prices declined. Comments by Alan Greenspan were interpreted positively, bolstering prices early in the day, but the market sagged after a wave of corporate borrowing. [D16.]
The dollar fell against most major currencies. [D18.] Gold prices rallied after hitting a two-month low. [D18.]

Today's Columns
The Super Bowl, with an estimated 134.8 million viewers, was a great opportunity for marketers. But many of the spots used celebrities who drew more attention to themselves than to the products they were pitching. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D1.]
Wall Street is having second thoughts about the merger of Bell Atlantic and Tele-Communications. Market Place. [D8.]

HEADLINE: UNEASY ALLIANCE OF BLACK GROUPS

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Recent bigoted remarks by a chief aide to Louis Farrakhan, minister of the Nation of Islam, and Mr. Farrakhan's failure to disavow them have interrupted the tenuous rapprochement between mainstream civil rights leaders and the Muslim group.
The discomfort being felt by some black officials reflects their continued inability to decide how to deal with the Nation of Islam, a group whose membership numbers are a mystery and whose ability to influence elections directly is slight. 
 Although black officials have been repelled by some of Mr. Farrakhan's more contention remarks and those of his aides, leaders of mainstream black organizations have been reluctant to criticize Mr. Farrakhan. They often praise his emphasis on black self-reliance and his group's statements on fighting crime and drug abuse.
"Black leadership has never before been willing to confront what Farrakahn and the Nation of Islam had been saying and distance themselves from it," said Milton Morris, vice president of the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a Washington research organization specializing in black issues. "They're always found a way to say it's not been our business."
Mr. Farrakhan's failure to disavow himself from remarks made by Khalid Abdul Muhammad, a spokesman for the Nation of Islam, has placed in jeopardy the fledgling political alliance that was announced with much fanfare last September between the Nation of Islam and the Congressional Black Caucus
At the time, Representative Kweisi Mfume, the Maryland Democrat who heads the caucus, said his group and Mr. Farrakahn's had entered into a "sacred covenant" and would work together on issues like drug abuse and crime in inner-city neighborhoods.
 
Declined to Criticize Aide
 Ten days ago, after several civil rights leaders denounced Mr. Muhammad's speech as bigoted, Mr. Mfume wrote to Mr. Farrakhan demanding to know if his aide's remarks represented those of the Nation of Islam. Don Willson, a spokesman for Mr. Mfume, said today that the Congressman had yet to receive a reply.
Several civil rights leaders, including the Rev. Jesse Jackson, condemned the remarks made by Mr. Muhammad, who in a speech in November at Kean College in New Jersey excoriated Jews as "blood suckers of the black community." These civil rights leaders urged Mr. Farrakhan to dissociate himself from the remarks.
But so far, Mr. Farrakhan has declined to criticize his aide. In a speech last week before 10,000 black men in Harlem, Mr. Farrakhan accused the Federal Government and some black leaders of trying to use Mr. Muhammad's words to divide his group.
Some black politicians have made a point of distancing themselves and the black caucus from the Nation of Islam.
Since the publication of Mr. Muhammad's remarks, senior members of the black caucus have emphasized that no joint programs were established with Mr. Farrakhan's group, and they point out that the full black caucus never ratified the partnership that Mr. Mfume had announced.
Some black officials say the problems of drugs, violence, high rates of teen-age pregnancy, poor schooling and poor discipline that are overwhelming low-income black neighborhoods are so great that some form of unity among black groups -- including the Nation of Islam -- is necessary. Mr. Mfume essentially made that argument in October when he met with leaders of Jewish groups who expressed concern about the announced alliance with Mr. Farrakhan's group.
But some students of black politics say achieving a rapprochement between Mr. Farrakhan and leaders of mainstream black groups involves each side taking some chances. When it came to the Nation of Islam, only the leaders of mainstream black groups took the risks. Mr. Farrakhan, who made no promises, now has them squirming.
"Everybody wants unity and nobody likes the idea of somebody who is not one of us to set the standard of relationships between us," said William Raspberry, a syndicated columnist who is black. "It's also understandable that Farrakhan wants to come to the table. After all, it's been a little bit lonely out there. But if you have been outside and you want to come to the family table, it's not asking too much to ask you to wash your hands first."

HEADLINE: Clinton Seeks Extra $1.5 Billion in Quake Relief

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
President Clinton will ask for at least $1.5 billion in additional Federal aid for victims of the Los Angeles earthquake, Administration officials said today, raising the proposed Federal commitment to earthquake relief to more than $9 billion.
At least $8 billion of that would be sought in a supplemental budget request officials are planning to send to Congress. The Government is now using $897 million in already budgeted money to aid victims. 
 An Administration official said the new request would be directed to the Federal Emergency Management Agency for aid in housing 25,000 people left homeless by the earthquake.
"The needs have turned out to be greater than expected," the official said.
 
Acknowledging Need
 In authorizing the new expenditures, Mr. Clinton conceded that Gov. Pete Wilson of California was right in arguing that the Federal aid for the earthquake would fall far short of the need.
Last week, Mr. Clinton said he would ask Congress for $6.6 billion in emergency money, a request that would make the earthquake the costliest natural disaster ever for Federal taxpayers. The earthquake, which measured 6.6 on the Richter scale of ground motion, killed 61 people and injured 8,000.
Leon E. Panetta, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, said at the time that he expected the figure to grow and has said since that the Federal Government should re-examine the way it pays for disaster aid.
"Somehow, we've got to do a better job in terms of preparing for disasters, either by setting aside some kind of fund to deal with disasters, or looking to insurance companies to try to deal with those areas that are particularly vulnerable to disasters," Mr. Panetta said in an interview on the Cable News Network.
At the same time, Mr. Panetta has maintained that victims of natural disasters should not be "held hostage" to budgetary constraints.
Congress must agree to waive budget limits when it approves new disaster assistance, and the White House has acknowledged that the earthquake relief will add at least $3 billion to the deficit.
Although states must normally match at least 25 percent of the Federal commitment, the Clinton Administration has relaxed that commitment for economically distressed California, requiring only a 10 percent match.
The Midwest floods last summer have cost the Government $4.6 billion so far, and hurricane damage aid in 1991 surpassed $8 billion, but that figure takes into account both Hurricane Andrew, which struck Florida and Louisiana, and Hurricane Iniki, which struck the Hawaiian island of Kauai.

HEADLINE: Fed Chief Implies a Pre-Inflation Rise in Rates

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, strongly implied today that the central bank would break with tradition and raise interest rates before revived inflation became clearly visible.
But Mr. Greenspan left unclear, as is his custom, how close or how large a "pre-emptive strike" might be. Wall Street analysts were divided in their interpretation of his remarks to Congressional committee members and answers to their questions. 
 President Clinton, commenting on Mr. Greenspan's testimony, said that while low rates were vital to continued expansion, he would not object to a modest increase if the move did not make mortgages and other long-term borrowing more expensive. If the Fed should "make that decision on short-term rates, what I hope is it won't raise long-term rates because there's no need to do it," the President said.
In financial markets, stocks continued to rally, with the Dow Jones industrial average up 32.93 points and approaching the 4,000 mark. The bond market apparently focused on Mr. Greenspan's failure to offer a timetable for taking action on inflation, and prices edged higher. The dollar eased on Mr. Greenspan's remarks.
Testifying before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress in advance of a policy meeting to set interest rate policy for the year, Mr. Greenspan said that "regrettably" the Fed had frequently erred in the past by waiting too long to combat inflation, which often accompanies rapid economic growth.
"Inflation tends to surface rather late in the business cycle and hence is not a good leading indicator of emerging troubles," he said. "By the time inflation pressures are evident, many imbalances that are costly to rectify have already developed and only harsh monetary therapy can restore the financial stability necessary to sustain" economic growth.
Some Wall Street analysts thought the Fed might act as soon as Friday if the Labor Department reported that employers' payrolls expanded by more than 200,000 in January. But others said the conditions for raising rates were nonexistent.
Mr. Greenspan further clouded the issue by noting that some of the Fed's traditional benchmarks, including the money supply, have become less useful as guides to policy.
Long-term rates are important because these are used for economy-spurring activity like buying homes and building factories. These rates are mainly governed by expectations on inflation that investors have over a long period, such as 30 years. The Fed can affect long-term rates by its attitude toward inflation, but its main control is over short-term rates, which are generally regarded as covering loans lasting from a day to perhaps a year.
Mr. Greenspan declared short-term rates "abnormally low" after adjustment for inflation, and he added that "at some point, absent an unexpected and prolonged weakening of economic activity, we will need to move them to a more neutral stance."
The 3 percent rate on overnight loans among banks is barely above the 2.7 percent rise in consumer prices over the last 12 months.
 
Not to Squelch Growth
 The Fed chief added that action "would not be taken in order to cut off or limit the economic expansion, but rather to sustain and enhance it." By this he meant that a demonstration of anti-inflation vigilance would reassure long-term investors that the Fed would not allow the value of the bonds or mortgages to be eroded.
While Mr. Greenspan did not mention a specific case of late response to inflation, which he said had "arisen too often," the most striking example in recent memory was in 1979, when Paul A. Volcker was summoned by President Jimmy Carter in near-emergency conditions to take over the Fed and arrest oil-fueled inflation that ended the year at 13.3 percent.
Mr. Volcker's harsh treatment led directly to the 1981-82 recession, with double-digit unemployment and a recession that ranks as the most severe since the end of World War II.
The four Republicans on the committee and the Democratic chairman, Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, praised Mr. Greenspan today for nurturing the current business expansion -- Mr. Obey requesting only that the rate rise be held in abeyance for "a few months."
But Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, disputed the notion that the Fed should act against a menace that had not yet appeared. "You can do anything on that basis," he said.
Private analysts were inclined to think Mr. Greenspan tilted toward a fairly early move today, mindful that his carefully hedged remarks came after the Government reported that the economy accelerated to a 5.9 percent rate of growth in the final quarter of 1993, the strongest in six years.
"The Fed is perhaps a little closer to moving" than had been thought, said Elliott Platt of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, predicting a one-quarter-point rise in the Federal funds rate between February and April.
David Greenlaw, economist at Morgan Stanley, said, "the evidence is building" and Mr. Greenspan appears "edgy," but the Fed still lacked a "trigger" to justify action.
But Cheryl Katz of Lehman Brothers offered a quite different conclusion. Citing what she called ample productive capacity, she said that it was "way too early" for the Fed to raise rates and suggested that it might go all year without doing so.
 
Importance of Price Expectations
 In his statement, Mr. Greenspan seemed to anticipate this argument by stating that the level of inflation "depends crucially on price expectations and not on the degree of slack" in the economy.
The Fed chief also made the following points today before leaving for London for a brief trip. On his return, he will convene the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee on Thursday afternoon:
*Canada and Britain seem to be emerging from severe recessions, but there is only scant evidence of improvement in Japan and continental Europe.
*Policy makers should consider the possibility that the American economy's growth potential is well above the 2 1/2 percent a year commonly assumed, a statement suggesting that the Fed would not automatically slow the economy if it started to exceed that level on a sustained basis.
*Low foreign labor costs have almost no effect on levels of inflation in this country, unlike low foreign commodity prices.
*Money supply figures have been distorted by increased escrow balances related to intense mortgage refinancing, stepped-up shipments of currency out of the country and mutual-fund activity. Also, the Fed has failed in its attempt to make its monetary base useful as a policy gauge.
*Fed researchers believe the Consumer Price Index overstates inflation by an even greater, but unspecified, amount than the half-point cited by the Labor Department.
Mr. Greenspan joined a consensus predicting that "further solid gains" for the economy could be expected in 1994, though "growth will almost surely slow appreciably" from the final three months of last year. So far, he added, the labor market has displayed only marginal inflation pressure.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, testifying yesterday before a Congressional panel, where he implied that the central bank would raise interest rates before inflation becomes clearly visible. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

ALLIANCE OF BLACK GROUPS IN JEOPARDY
Recent bigoted remarks by a chief aide to Louis Farrakhan, minister of the Nation of Islam, and his failure to disavow them have interrupted the tenuous rapprochement between mainstream civil rights leaders and the Nation of Islam. A10.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
GIULIANI NAMES HOUSING CHAIRMAN
Mayor Giuliani named Ruben Franco, the former president of the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund, as chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, concluding an appointment process that had been one of the most difficult for the Mayor. The prospect of Mr. Franco's appointment had created strong opposition among Hasidic leaders in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. B3.

The State Social Services Department has temporarily halted its support for the expansion of an important city program to house the homeless, Commissioner Michael J. Dowling said. B2.

A Federal appeals court ruled that a person has a constitutional right to privacy about whether he is infected with H.I.V. B3.

THE KINGDOMS OF HOME RULE
Dering Harbor, L.I., with just 32 houses, a puny water tower and a maintenance staff named Richie, is an incorporated village, the smallest in New York State, a locality with a budget of $115,000 a year and two major parties: the Independent Party, from which all candidates for village mayor and trustee are drawn, and the yearly summer cocktail party, to which all Dering Harbor is invited. A1.
 
AGREEMENT REACHED ON BANKING BILL
Less than two hours before state banking laws were scheduled to expire, Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders reached agreement on a bill that would make permanent the rules that give banks great latitude to create new financial products and to set interest rates for credit cards and most types of loans. B4.
 
ARGUMENTS ON EVIDENCE IN ABUSE CASE
The New Jersey Supreme Court heard arguments about the admissibility of evidence in the case of Margaret Kelly Michaels, who was convicted of sexually molesting 19 children during her seven-month employment at Wee Care Nursery in Maplewood. She served 5 years of a 47-year sentence before her conviction was overturned early last year. B5.

HEADLINE: Ex-Congressman Again Joining Hartford Race for Governor

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 31

 BODY:
John G. Rowland, a 36-year-old Republican who almost defeated Lowell P. Weicker Jr. in the 1990 race for governor but then virtually disappeared from the public eye, announced today his return for another run.
But despite the hopes of senior Republican officials that the party would quickly rally around Mr. Rowland, he faces what is shaping up as a major and perhaps bruising personal scrap with the Republican Secretary of the State, Pauline R. Kezer. 
 Mrs. Kezer, who declared her own candidacy for governor earlier this month, has not minced words in saying that she thinks Mr. Rowland, a former three-term Congressman from Waterbury, is no longer a big vote-getter among Republicans or Connecticut voters in general.
Mr. Rowland, who announced his candidacy in a series of appearances around the state, said that he had learned from his defeat and that Connecticut had changed as well after four years of recession. In 1990, he said, the issues were taxes and how to rescue a deficit-plagued state budget.
 
Tough Talk on Crime
 Today Mr. Rowland scarcely mentioned taxes at all. His new campaign agenda -- tough talk on crime, an overhaul of the welfare system and vehement opposition to forced busing as an answer to Connecticut's segregated school system -- will speak to an electorate living in fear, he said.
"They're fearful of losing their jobs, fearful of crime in the streets," he said.
Mr. Rowland spoke of Mrs. Kezer only in the most dismissive of terms, saying he believed she could be kept from obtaining even 15 percent of Republican delegates at this summer's convention, thus preventing her from waging a primary contest against him.
She immediately fired back.
"He ran that race and he didn't win it," Mrs. Kezer said, referring to the 1990 election. "He has done absolutely nothing in three years to further his agenda -- he has not been here -- then he comes waltzing back and says it's mine, I'm owed this."
Mrs. Kezer, who is 51, is the first Republican to win a statewide election in Connecticut since 1970, other than Mr. Weicker himself, who served three terms as a Republican in the United States Senate before losing in 1988 to Senator Joseph I. Lieberman. She pointed out in an interview that in the 1990 race, when Mr. Rowland lost by less than 33,000 votes out of 1.1 million cast, he still drew only 38 percent of the vote, compared with 41 percent for Mr. Weicker, who ran on his own independent ticket, and 21 percent for the Democratic candidate, Bruce A. Morrison. Mrs. Kezer got 52.3 percent in her race.
Mr. Rowland appears to be the last major candidate to announce plans to run for governor, party leaders say. As in 1990, it will be a three-way race, with a Democrat, a Republican and a major third-party candidate, Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark, whose name will appear on top line of the ballot by virtue of Mr. Weicker's victory in the last election. Mrs. Groark, also a former Republican, joined Mr. Weicker's party, known as A Connecticut Party -- in 1990 and declared her intention to replace him last year after Mr. Weicker declined to seek a second term.
Democrats have already said they expect to have a primary, and many say they hope to benefit from it as a way of increasing the name recognition of their roster: William E. Curry Jr., the State Comptroller; State Senator John B. Larson, the president pro tem of the Senate, and State Senator Richard J. Balducci, the former Speaker of the House of Representatives.
For the short term, however, the focus of the race seems likely to stay on Mr. Rowland and Mrs. Kezer, if only for the contrasts between them and the sparks that are likely to fly.
With endorsements already in his pocket from all three of the state's Republican members of Congress, including Nancy L. Johnson -- who had considered running for governor herself -- Mr. Rowland is expansive and confident. But he is also in the midst of a divorce that some Republicans fear could become a factor as the race develops. Mr. Rowland's wife, Deborah, was a constant and effervescent companion at his side in 1990, along with his three children.
 
Offering an Alternative
 Mrs. Kezer, by contrast, is positioning herself as the alternative Republican to vote for, if only to tweak the monolith of party allegiance. As Secretary of State, she has concentrated on increasing voter registration and participation and on upgrading her department's record-keeping and record-collection efforts.
As a candidate, she expresses surprise that members of her party find her needling of Mr. Rowland to be tiresome, but then she repeats her critique that Mr. Rowland's positions have fluctuated over time, and that it's only right to discuss the phenomenon.
"John has a history of not being consistent on the issues -- that will be pointed out because it's factual," she said. "All I'm asking for is an even shot."

With him were his parents, Sherwood and Cerie Rowland, and his brother Skip Rowland, right, accompanied by Brenda Mary Scully. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Clinton Offers Concessions On Health, Governors Say

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Governors who met with President Clinton today said afterward that he had shown new flexibility on two important elements of his health plan: spending limits and the structure of the purchasing groups through which most Americans would buy health insurance.
Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina, a Republican, and Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, a Democrat, said Mr. Clinton had agreed that participation in the purchasing groups, or alliances, might be voluntary, not mandatory, as the President initially proposed. 
 In an interview tonight, Mr. Dean, a doctor who is vice chairman of the National Governors' Association, reported, "The President said he was willing to be flexible on mandatory alliances and global budgets." The purpose of a global budget is to set an annual limit on health spending.
 
Defining Flexibility
 Mr. Campbell, who is chairman of the governors' association, confirmed Mr. Dean's account of the meeting with the President. Mr. Campbell quoted Mr. Clinton as saying that he knew of cases where the alliances were voluntary and small employers were "clamoring to get into them."
Under the proposal Mr. Clinton sent to Congress in late October, all businesses with 5,000 or fewer employees would have had to participate in the alliances. The alliances are intended to concentrate the purchasing power of hundreds of thousands of consumers so they can obtain the same type of insurance coverage and the same type of discounts as large corporations.
In the past, President Clinton said he was willing to discuss virtually any element of his health care proposal except the goal of guaranteeing coverage for all Americans. Today Mr. Clinton was more explicit than in the past about his flexibility on the structure of alliances and spending limits.
 
Universal Availability
 Jeffrey L. Eller, a White House spokesman, said: "The President is inflexible on the goal of universal coverage, but he is flexible on the details of how to achieve that goal. His bill calls for mandatory alliances because he believes that approach is the best way to achieve universal coverage. But the President has also said, and he told the governors today, 'We have heard your concerns and we are willing to be flexible on this question of alliances.' "
After meeting with Mr. Clinton, the governors adopted a health care policy that supports the idea of a standard package of health benefits for all Americans, an important part of the Clinton plan. But the policy remains neutral on the critical question of whether employers should be required to pay for their workers' insurance.
The policy says: "All employers must make the core benefits package available to those employees who wish to purchase it. While governors do not agree on whether employers should be required to pay for any portion of the premium, governors agree that coverage should be available."
 
'Naysayers and Nitpickers'
 Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, said today that Congress would not pass a comprehensive health bill this year "if we don't address it on a bipartisan basis."
Speaking to the American Hospital Association, Mr. Dole endorsed Mr. Clinton's goal of providing health insurance coverage for all Americans, but he urged the White House to be flexible and open to compromise.
"The Administration is attempting to sell price controls and global budgets and Government monopolies as answers to very real problems," Mr. Dole said. "They call us naysayers and nitpickers because we oppose turning one-seventh of the economy over to the Federal Government."
But Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, defended the President's proposal, saying, "No other plan provides a credible guarantee of universal coverage."
 
Slowing Drug-Price Increases
 In a separate development, Senator David Pryor commended prescription drug companies for "an honest effort to restrain price increases in 1993." While 18 drug companies voluntarily made some commitment to hold down prices last year, he said, "these pledges may not be resulting in meaningful price restraint, especially at the retail level, where most Americans buy their drugs."
Most discounts go to hospitals and health maintenance organizations, not to consumers who buy drugs at local retail pharmacies, said Mr. Pryor, an Arkansas Democrat.
The overall Consumer Price Index rose 2.7 percent last year. Medical care in general rose 5.4 percent. Prescription drugs rose 3.3 percent, the lowest increase in 20 years.
But Mr. Pryor said that drug companies were still raising prices more than other manufacturers. Last year, he observed, the producer price index for prescription drugs rose 3.1 percent, while the index for all finished goods rose just 0.2 percent.
Richard J. Pollack, executive vice president of the American Hospital Association, praised President Clinton's effort to guarantee health insurance for all. But, like many governors, he said Mr. Clinton's original proposal gave too much power to the regional health alliances.
 
Budgets vs. Needs
 Likewise, Mr. Pollack expressed doubts about Mr. Clinton's proposal for limits on health care spending, to be enforced through limits on health insurance premiums. Such limits, he said, "may force choices which are not practical or realistic from a political, economic, social or moral perspective."
Moreover, Mr. Pollack said: "Hospitals are prepared to talk about how much we spend on health care. We are prepared to talk about targets and goals.
"But we will not talk about global budgets that are imposed from the top down based on an arbitrary number pulled out of thin air. We will not talk about a global budget enforced by a rate-setting guillotine tied to the Federal budget process."

HEADLINE: U.S. Moves to Halt S.& L. Sales Amid Concern on Insiders' Profits

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The Treasury Department imposed a moratorium today on commercial bank purchases of most mutual savings and loans, citing concerns that insiders may be enriching themselves at the expense of depositors.
But regulators have closed the barn door very late: all but one of the nation's big mutual savings and loans have already been sold or have converted to shareholder ownership. 
 Coupled with recent moves by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to review executive compensation at mutuals that sell stock in themselves to investors, the moratorium is likely to halt the disappearance of mutuals, a trend that has been reshaping the nation's savings and loan industry, banking experts said today.
"It looks like the party is over -- this is the beginning of the end," said Scott M. Winslow, the research director at SNL Securities, a financial research firm in Charlottesville, Va.
 
Not Many Are Left
 Low interest rates have made hundreds of mutuals quite profitable, so many banks and investors want to buy them. A wave of deals cut the number of mutuals last year by almost 10 percent, from 1,343 at the beginning of 1993 and 2,000 a dozen years ago. Most of the 1,231 remaining mutuals are tiny institutions in small towns.
Green Point Savings Bank, a $6 billion institution based in Flushing, Queens, issued stock on Friday, leaving only one large mutual, Pomona First Federal Savings and Loan Association in California, which has $1.65 billion in assets.
The rest of the big mutuals have already converted into shareholder institutions, said Brian P. Smith, the policy director at Savings and Community Bankers of America, the industry's Washington-based trade group.
According to a study by SNL Securities, in each of 16 small deals in December and early January, an average of $5.3 million in free stock or stock discounts was awarded to the directors and corporate officers as a group. That works out to 13 percent of the value of the stock sold and does not count the executive salary increases and the generous retirement plans that usually accompany these transactions. Depositors, who technically own the institutions but typically buy few of the shares when the institutions sell stock, got very little.
The Treasury and the F.D.I.C. are both paying particular attention to whether mutual executives have issued stock at unusually low prices and bought large blocks of shares at those prices. Last year, shares in mutuals soared by an average of 28 percent on the day they were issued.
In imposing a moratorium on commercial bank purchases of mutuals, the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision said that it would continue to accept applications from mutuals that want to convert to stock ownership. But the office said for the first time that its limits on executive compensation for these transactions would be reviewed. Leaders of the Senate Banking Committee introduced legislation last week to force the office to tighten these limits, which do not currently cover stock options.
 
'At a Standstill

 
 David S. Schaefer, the head of the banking practice at Loeb & Loeb, a New York law firm, said that close regulatory scrutiny would bring to a halt all sales of mutuals to investors or banks. "Applications which have been filed have come to a standstill," he said. "It also prevents other institutions, which have wanted to take advantage of the market, from acting."
The moratorium will last while the office reviews its regulations on the transactions. Treasury officials declined to estimate how long that would take; the F.D.I.C. has been reviewing the issue for nearly a year without reaching a decision.
Two Congressional hearings in the last 10 days and proposals for tough new Federal legislation have left regulators red-faced and wishing that they had acted sooner. This is particularly true at the F.D.I.C., which oversees state-chartered savings banks, unlike the Office of Thrift Supervision, which oversees federally chartered savings banks and state and federally chartered savings and loans.
Managers at state-regulated savings banks awarded themselves some of the largest multimillion-dollar compensation packages in exchange for approving the sale of their institutions to banks or investors.
 
Some Regrets Expressed

 
 "It's not our shining hour in terms of raising the issue; in hindsight, I wish we'd done more earlier," said a senior F.D.I.C. staff official who insisted on anonymity.
Andrew C. Hove Jr., the acting chairman of the F.D.I.C., declined to comment.
Jonathan L. Fiechter, the acting director of the Office of Thrift Supervision and a member of the F.D.I.C.'s board, said last week that he had sent memos to the F.D.I.C. over the last year urging it to be more aggressive. "I probably should have been more aggressive on the board," he said.
Mr. Hove told a House Banking Committee panel last week that his agency would start closely reviewing sales of state-chartered mutuals and would propose new regulations that would make it easier for depositors to benefit from the sale of mutuals. Until recently, the F.D.I.C. relied heavily on state regulators to determine whether compensation packages were excessive.
 
A New York Case

 
 Green Point Savings issued stock last week after a long legal struggle in which the New York State Banking Commission forced its executives to give up the stock and stock options that they had planned to award to themselves. Estimates of the total Green Point compensation packages started at $40 million, and ranged up to $85 million or more if the bank's stock had doubled after it was issued.
Savings banks differ from savings and loans only in that savings banks are allowed to hold a slightly lower percentage of their assets in real estate loans.
The Office of Thrift Supervision put some limits on executive compensation in these transactions but had not limited stock options. Dozens of savings and loans have converted into state-chartered savings bank before issuing stock, thereby avoiding the thrift office's limits. Mr. Fiechter of the thrift office called for the F.D.I.C. to impose its own moratorium on commercial bank acquisitions of mutuals that it oversees.
The ownership of mutuals is fiercely disputed. The thrift office said today that depositors "are considered the owners of a mutual thrift." Mr. Hove of the F.D.I.C. made a similar comment at a Congressional hearing last week, as did the top regulators from Ohio and Wisconsin.
But many savings and loan executives and some state regulators, including regulators in New York and North Carolina, contend that the ownership of mutuals is murky. The Federal courts have ruled that while a mutual's depositors may divide up its net worth if the institution is liquidated, they may not take their stakes out of an active institution.
Mr. Schaefer at Loeb & Loeb, who has represented mutual executives in past conversions to shareholder ownership, said he did not think depositors had any ownership rights. Since the 1930's, Federal deposit insurance has protected depositors against financial loss if a mutual fails, he pointed out. So depositors do not meet a legal test of ownership that requires owners to prove possession of something that can be lost, he said.

HEADLINE: Stocks Climb in Heavy Trading, With Dow Rising 32.93

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks surged in heavy trading yesterday, as good demand for auto stocks and aluminum stocks helped equities extend their record setting pace of last week to new closing highs on the last day of the month.
Some of the follow-through buying from last Friday's rally was focused on General Motors and the Aluminum Company of America. 
 General Motors' chief executive, John F. Smith, in an interview that was reported in The New York Times yesterday, hinted that 1993 earnings will be better-than-expected. Alcoa, along with other aluminum stocks, was up amid news that major aluminum-producing nations have agreed to cut annual production by one million tons. A production cutback in aluminum would put upward pressure on prices and that translates to greater profits for aluminum makers, traders said.
The Dow Jones industrial average, while setting its 12th closing high of the year, approached yet another of those psychological barriers that traders and investors watch so closely -- the 4,000 mark. The industrial index finished at 3,978.36, up 32.93 points.
Analysts said an afternoon upward spike in the Dow, which pushed the index up as much as 40 points, might have been caused by positive comments on inflation made by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, in Washington.
Other positive economic news came with the report that personal income rose six-tenths of 1 percent in December, close to market expectations.
The other major stock indexes also set new highs for the second day yesterday. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, another measure of blue-chip issues, was up 2.91 points, to 481.61, while the Nasdaq composite gained 3.94 points to close at 800.47 and the American Stock Exchange index rose 2.46 points to finish at 485.68.
 
Heavy Trading Volume
 Volume on the Big Board was heavy, with 322.9 million shares changing hands. The number of issues making gains on the day outpacedthose that declined by a margin of 1,396 to 733.
Joseph V. Battapaglia, managing director of Sterling Advisors, a division of Gruntal & Company, believes that if interest rates stay down and inflation remains low, the market will take care of itself, which means stock prices will continue to move higher.
"The market entered the year with questions about valuation and questions about the White House. And even with an earthquake, a deep freeze and two new legislative initiatives, equity prices are at new highes," Mr. Battapaglia said. "Overriding those challenges are very strong economic news and a growing sense that the Fed will not raise rates at this time."
He says mutual fund cash continues to pour into the market, which is fresh fuel for the rally. "The only thing left that may stop the market in its tracks would be an unexpected event, such as a political upheaval in Russia," he added.
While marveling at the January rally, traders and investors are also remaining cautious because of a concern that the market could be overextended and ready for a a correction. For the month, the Dow is up 224.27 points, or about 6 percent.
Birinyi Associates, a Wall Street research firm, says the Dow's gain in January is the ninth-best January performance since 1915, with the best in 1975, when it was up 14.2 percent.
Lawrence R. Rice, a chief market strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, sized up the market this way: "This market is finishing the month the same way it started, very strong and very positive, with good volume. Even though we are over extended near term, it still looks positive for intermediate term."
Xerox reached a new 52-week high, closing at 98 1/8, up 5 1/2. The large copier maker outlined details of cost reductions including layoffs that will be achieved from a previously announced restructuring.
Investors bought CBS as Brown Brothers Harriman upgraded the stock to buy from neutral. Traders said the analyst, John Nelson, had said: "It's a soft cyclical company, and the ecnomic cycle is right. CBS is holding its audience levels and you've got a relaxation of regulations." The stock was up 9 3/4, to 306 a share, on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bonds Retreat in Price

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices ended lower yesterday after rising earlier on suggestions from Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve chairman, that inflation remained under control for now.
The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond dropped 5/16 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 6.23 percent, from 6.21 percent on Friday. Prices of short-term Treasury securities fell 1/16 to 3/32 and intermediate maturities were off 1/16 to 1/8, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported. 
 Market analysts traced part of the decline in Government bond prices to a wave of corporate borrowing, including a $1 billion deal from the Province of Quebec. As part of corporate bond transactions, underwriters typically sell Treasury securities as a way to hedge against potential losses.
 
Expected Corporate Borrowings
 Yesterday's sales were the first in a flood of expected corporate borrowing by foreign countries in the United States market this week. China, for instance, is expected to sell at least $1 billion in 10-year bonds.
Mr. Greenspan, speaking before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, reiterated that the central bank was prepared to raise short-term interest rates to keep inflation pressures from worsening.
"Short-term interest rates are currently abnormally low," he told Congress. "At some point, absent an unexpected and prolonged weakening of economic activity, we will need to move them."
Typically, such talk would drive bond prices lower. But because the market expects the Fed to nudge up rates at some point, investors apparently focused on Mr. Greenspan's failure to offer a specific timetable for taking action, and prices edged higher.
"If anything, Greenspan seemed to hint there are some considerations that may act to delay any movement toward restraint," said William Sullivan, director of money market research at Dean Witter, Discover & Company.
The Fed's policy-making panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, is scheduled to meet on Thursday and Friday to map its monetary strategy for the next six months.
The early gains were set back after the market for corporate bonds picked up pace. Quebec priced its $1 billion sale of 30-year bonds to yield 7.167 percent, or 0.82 percentage point above the comparable Treasury bond.
In another deal, the USX Corporation expanded a planned $250 million sale of 10-year notes to $300 million after strong demand. The steel company priced the securities at 1.60 percentage points above the comparable Treasury note.
Mr. Sullivan of Dean Witter said Treasury bond prices might also have been depressed by investors' anticipation of new United States Government borrowing in coming weeks.
The Treasury is to announce tomorrow a sale of $40 billion in 3-year, 10-year and 30-year bonds next week. More notes are scheduled for sale later in February.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 3.02 percent as the discount was up 0.04 percentage point, to 2.97 percent. Six-month yields were up to 3.23 percent as the discount was up 0.04 point, to 3.15 percent. One-year yields were up 3.50 percent as the discount was up 0.03 point, to 3.38 percent. Yields are the interest bonds pay by maturity, while the discount is the interest at which they are sold.

HEADLINE: BMW Will Buy Rover of Britain

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Seeking both an entree into the small-car business and lower-cost automobile production plants, BMW of Germany said today that it would acquire the Rover Group of Britain for about $1.2 billion.
The deal, which puts the last big British auto maker under foreign control, advances the strategy of the Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G. of reducing its reliance on its home market in Germany, where labor and production costs are among the world's highest. 
 In Rover, BMW gets an efficient producer of small cars, notably the Metro and Mini and its 200 and 400 series. Rover also builds more expensive cars, like its 800 series coupes, and it has built its Land Rover division into a high-quality and fast-growing producer of large four-wheel-drive utility vehicles sold under the names Land Rover and Range Rover.
 
Labor Costs at Issue
 For Germany and Britain, the deal also suggests the economic forces that are at work reshaping European industries including automobiles. German companies, which for decades enjoyed a reputation for unparalleled industrial craftsmanship and engineering, now find it difficult to compete because of labor costs.
At $24 an hour, labor costs in the German car business are double those in Britain, where social welfare levies on employers are lower and unions are not so strong as in Germany. That is forcing many Germany companies to build or acquire new production capacity abroad.
BMW said it had considered building its own small-car manufacturing operations, but that it was faster and cheaper to acquire Rover from British Aerospace P.L.C., which has owned the marque for the last five years. The deal will roughly double BMW's share of the European market to 6.5 percent.
BMW's chairman, Bernd Pischetsrieder, said at a news conference here that there was little overlap between the companies' car lines and that BMW would be able to distribute Rover cars more widely, particularly in Germany and America, than had British Aerospace.
He said Rover would continue to be run by its British managers and that the Rover brand name would be maintained. There are no plans to produce BMW cars in Britain, Mr. Pischetsrieder said, but he added he was interested in reviving some of Rover's famous but now-dormant name plates like Austin Healey.
British Aerospace has been eager to sell Rover and concentrate on its aerospace and defense businesses. The deal, however, brought a sharp protest from Honda of Japan, which owns a 20 percent stake in Rover's car-making operation and has been integral in Rover's efforts to cut costs and improve quality.
Honda had been seeking to increase its stake to just under 50 percent, but had been unwilling to meet British Aerospace's demand for a full buyout. Now, BMW will be able to use and study Honda's technology and production techniques up close.
In Tokyo, Honda's president, Nobuhiko Kawamoto, said in a statement that British Aerospace's decision "negates Honda and Rover's long-term efforts to establish a firm future for Rover as a British company with its own brand identity." Honda said it had no immediate plans to sell its stake in Rover.
Mr. Pischetsrieder said he hoped that Honda would continue its association with Rover, under which Rover also has a 20 percent stake in Honda's British operations. In response to questions at the news conference, however, Rover's chairman, George Simpson, said, "Today's development may suggest some change in that relationship."
Rover sold about 368,500 cars and about 73,500 sports utility vehicles last year, primarily in Britain, and was the only European auto maker to sell more cars than in 1992, reflecting Britain's recovery from the recession that lingers elsewhere in Europe. Rover had a pretax operating profit last year of 56 million, or $84 million, on sales of 4.3 billion, or $6.45 billion. In 1992, Rover had an operating loss of 49 million, or about $73.5 million at today's exchange rates.
BMW sold 534,000 cars of its luxury cars worldwide, including 78,000 in America, where its sales have been rebounding, aided by an improving economy, a fresh ad campaign and limited price increases. BMW is building an assembly plant near Spartanburg, S.C., which is expected to begin producing models from the smaller 3-series line next year followed later by what is believed to be a sporty new two-seater. Until today's Rover deal, the South Carolina plant was BMW's only significant production outside of Germany and Austria.
Mr. Pischetsrieder said BMW saw considerable opportunity to sell more Land Rovers around the world, including in the United States, possibly by distributing them through BMW's dealer network. But analysts said the real motivation for BMW was to establish itself in the market for smaller, less-expensive cars.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Prices for Gold Rise Strongly As a Slide's End Is Forecast

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures prices posted strong gains yesterday after snapping back from a two-month low. Some analysts said the performance marked the end of the market's recent decline.
Silver prices also rose sharply. 
 On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery settled at $381.60 an ounce, up $4.70 from Friday. The rally came late in the session after the February contract bounced off $375.50, its lowest price since Dec. 3.
March silver rose 11.5 cents, to $5.135 an ounce, also on the Comex.
 
Inflation Fears Ebb
 Gold's drop of $18.70 since Jan. 20 was motivated in part by fading inflation fears. The market's disinflationary mood was reinforced yesterday morning when the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, said the central bank would need to raise short-term interest rates "at some point" to guard against inflation.
Mr. Greenspan's comments set off an immediate drop in gold prices, which is often perceived by investors as an inflation hedge. The market then settled into a tug-of-war between players trying to push it below $375 and those looking to buy back contracts they had sold at higher prices. The latter forces won.
"It was a case where everyone who wanted to sell had sold, and it kind of left a vacuum above the market," Tom Griffo, an analyst with Cargill Investor Services in New York, said.
United States investment funds and floor traders were the most active players, Bette Raptopoulos of Prudential Securities said. She said the strength of global stock markets suggested the world economy was reviving. As for gold's recent decline, "it's over," she said.
Peter Cardillo, an analyst with Westfalia Investments, agreed that the market had touched bottom but did not foresee gold surpassing recent highs any time soon. "The market's going to remain in a tight range between $375 and $390," he said.
Elsewhere, cotton for March delivery soared the permitted daily limit of 2 cents on the New York Cotton Exchange to 77.86 cents a pound, the highest settlement for near-term deliveries since June 25, 1991. The move accelerated a powerful rally that began in mid-November with prices below 60 cents a bushel.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off Over Uncertainty On Interest Rates and Trade

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar eased against other leading currencies yesterday as traders' expectations of a near-term increase in American interest rates were replaced by uncertainty about the Federal Reserve's monetary policy.
Traders were also uneasy about the trade talks between the United States and Japan. 
 In statements to the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, disappointed the market because he failed to disclose when monetary tightening would take place.
He said the top item on the agenda at this week's Federal Open Market Committee meeting starting on Thursday would be deciding when to push up interest rates. He added that real short-term interest rates were "abnormally low" and that at some point the Fed must move them to a more neutral stance.
"Greenspan didn't say anything that sounded like imminent tightening and so the dollar fell off," said Richard Koss, director of foreign exchange sales for the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce.
 
Dollar Firm Recently
 The dollar has firmed recently amid growing expectations for higher American interest rates. Higher rates make dollar-denominated assets relatively more attractive than foreign investments, as the economy grows.
The dollar also weakened in the absence of evidence of new progress toward an American-Japanese trade agreement. Without an agreement, the United States is likely to push for a stronger Japanese yen, and thus a weaker dollar, in order to narrow the American trade deficit with Japan. A stronger yen would make Japanese goods more expensive in the United States, while reducing the effective price of American exports to Japan.
In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 108.65 yen, from 109.90 yen on Friday. The dollar also fell to 1.7330 German marks in New York trading from 1.7427 marks.
The British pound rose to $1.5065 in New York, from $1.4950 on Friday.
The Canadian dollar weakened sharply against most leading currencies except the United States dollar. Dealers attributed the decline to futures-related selling and liquidation by foreign investors. The Bank of Canada bought Canadian dollars to try to smooth the slide.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
President To Become Mobil Chief

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Lucio A. Noto, the president and chief operating officer of the Mobil Corporation, was named on Friday to succeed Allen E. Murray as chairman and chief executive in a move that analysts said might bring some change in the management style but not in the direction of one of the world's leading oil companies.
Mr. Noto, 55, grew up in Brooklyn, and as did Mr. Murray, came up on the financial, rather than the production, side of the company. 
 "I would like to express my own deep personal satisfaction with the board's decision," said Mr. Murray, who was born in Queens and will retire on March 1 after 41 years at Mobil, which is based in Fairfax, Va.
Mr. Noto made his career largely overseas, running Mobil's refineries and gasoline stations in Italy and Japan. From 1977 to 1985 he built Mobil's presence in Saudi Arabia.
 
Close to Saudi Leaders
 Mr. Noto moved to Jidda, Saudi Arabia, in 1979 and became close to many of the Saudi leaders while helping to set up joint ventures in petrochemicals and a big refinery.
The overseas experience will serve him well, some analysts said, because Mobil, like other big oil companies, faces the challenge of finding new oil and gas deposits to replace fields that will run down this decade. Most of the new exploration will be in areas like Russia, Kazakhstan, East Asia and Africa.
"The challenge for Mobil is the challenge facing all major oil companies," Constantine Fliakos, oil analyst for Merrill Lynch, said. He said Mr. Noto and his company would have to find large new fields to replace the highly successful ventures like its natural gas business in Indonesia, where Mobil has a liquefaction plant from which it supplies gas to Japan.
 
Formed Management Team
 "It's not easy to find such projects," Mr. Fliakos said. But he added that Mr. Noto would have a good team that had been formed by himself and Mr. Murray.
Both executives have long worked in tandem to shed extraneous businesses and refocus Mobil on its core oil and gas business. Both have sought to cut costs and increase the efficiency and profitability of its refineries and huge chain of stations.
Mr. Murray sold Montgomery Ward and the Container Corporation of America, which were distracting management, to reduce debt. Acquisitions like a Tenneco refinery in Chalmette, La., were made to build up the core business.
Analysts said they expected Mr. Noto to move faster to shed operations in areas where Mobil has a weak market share, and he may keep a tighter hold on the purse strings when financing new projects.
 
Holds Degree in Physics
 After graduating with a degree in physics from Notre Dame in 1959, Mr. Noto got an M.B.A. at Cornell University in 1962. He worked as a summer intern for Mobil that year and then was hired as a member of its regional planning analysis group.
Four years later Mr. Noto went to Italy to work for Mobil Oil Italiana. He then worked in Japan for five years and came back to Italy as an executive vice president.
After building up Mobil's presence in Saudi Arabia, Mr. Noto was brought back to the company's headquarters in 1985; he was made vice president of planning and economics a year later.
He became a contender for the top job when he was elected a director in 1988 and was made the chief financial officer a year later.

HEADLINE: An Israeli Anxiety: Should Charity Stay at Home?

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Jewish lore has a soft spot for the shnorrer -- in Yiddish a beggar, even a moocher, but a mendicant with wit and brass.
"I don't have a cent right now," a man says to the shnorrer. "Come back tomorrow." 
 "My friend," the shnorrer says with a sigh, "if you only knew what a fortune I've lost by extending credit."
Less humorously, the word "shnorrer" dominates a rekindled political debate here over whether that is what Israel has become.
Some ask whether a country that is ever more prosperous, with pockets of great wealth, should continue its decades-old practice of asking Jews abroad for cash donations totaling hundreds of millions of dollars a year.
 
A Sensitive Relationship
 Even as they accept the money, much of it going for programs for new immigrants, some Israelis are resentful about the relationship. They sense that they are patronized by their overseas Jewish cousins as a people who may win wars but who would be unable to hold themselves together economically if not for outside help.
And increasingly, in speeches, books and articles, some of them are telling fellow Jews: Keep your gifts. If you want to feel kinship, increase your business investments instead, and send your children on work and study trips. The donations amount to less than 1 percent of Israel's annual gross domestic product of $65 billion.
Although not new, the debate has resurfaced with the intensity and occasional nastiness of a family dispute, which is what it basically is. The catalyst was a speech this month by Yossi Beilin, the outspoken Deputy Foreign Minister, who appeared before Zionist fund-raisers and told them that their dollars were no longer needed.
 
Beilin's Bombshell
 "If our economic situation is better than in many of your countries, how can we go on asking for your charity?" he said at a gathering of the Women's International Zionist Organization.
When delegates protested, Mr. Beilin replied: "You want me to be the beggar and say we need money for the poor people. Israel is a rich country, I'm sorry to tell you."
His remarks did not sit well everywhere, especially with Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin. Not one for sugarcoated observations, he called the Beilin speech "completely moronic."
Israel considers itself responsible for Jews around the world, Mr. Rabin said. But by the same token, he added, those Jews have a duty to share the burden of tending to nearly 500,000 newcomers who have poured into Israel since 1989, most from the former Soviet Union. "I don't feel like a shnorrer when I demand that world Jewry help the Israeli Government and people to absorb immigrants," he said.
Besides, he argued, if Israelis stop calling on fellow Jews for help, "what right do we have to ask the American taxpayer to give us $3 billion every year" -- Israel's total of United States military and economic aid, by far the most for a single country.
 
Fund-Raisers Displeased
 No less unhappy were pro-Israel groups. While no one may like "checkbook Zionism," they said, cash contributions enable diaspora Jews to show solidarity with the Jewish state. "It's the glue that holds the whole thing together," said Harry Wall, Israeli director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith. Michal Modai, international chairwoman of the Women's International Zionist Organization, the group that Mr. Beilin outraged, added that the money was in fact needed because "so much poverty" seemed to be beyond Government solution.
Israel, poor? On one level, yes.
Government figures show that more than 600,000 people in a population of 5.2 million -- and at least 20 percent of the children -- live below the official poverty line, defined as a monthly income of $675 for a couple with two children.
Israel, rich? On another level, also yes.
Its per capita gross domestic product for 1992 was $12,610, putting it on a par with Hong Kong and well ahead of some European Union members like Portugal and Greece. There certainly is no shortage of expensive cars or consumer products.
The problem, Mr. Beilin says, is not an absence of wealth but uneven distribution.
Merits of the argument aside, he clearly touched a raw nerve in the symbiosis between the 4.2 million Jews in Israel and the nearly 9 million Jews in the diaspora, two-thirds of them in North America.
Even before the creation of the state in 1948, Jews here expected overseas brethren to help settle the land, if not with their bodies then with their purses. A multi-tier network of contributions developed. Unfortunately, says Avraham Avi-Hai, a Canadian-born Israeli writer who has worked with several fund-raising groups, "many ambivalences in the Israel-diaspora relationship" also developed.
"There is the love of Israel, pity for Israel, respect for the heroic Israel, condescension for the poor and backward Israel," Mr. Avi-Hai writes in a new book, "Danger! Three Jewish Peoples."
Virtually no important Israeli organization gets by without overseas cup-rattling.
There is also direct government-to-government aid, conspicuously Washington's $3 billion.
And there is money from groups like the United Jewish Appeal, the main fund-raiser in the United States. In tandem with scores of local federations, it collected $841 million in 1992.
Much of it stayed home, for Jewish education and social programs. Less than 40 percent, $313 million, was sent on to Israel, through the Joint Distribution Committee and the Jewish Agency, lately under attack by critics as bloated and obsolete.
The fact that such private aid comes to less than 1 percent of their gross domestic product persuades many Israelis that they could live without it. Israeli universities and museums have their own elaborate fund-raising mechanisms abroad. So do big cities like Jerusalem and Tel Aviv. So do the major political parties. So do Jewish settlers in the territories. So do the settlers' Jewish opponents.
Politicians, former generals, professors, journalists -- all join this money circuit.
 
Biting the Hand?
 Especially irksome to some American Jews are the Israeli politicians of all ideological stripes who barnstorm the United States and then slap down their hosts, saying that their money does not buy them the right to tell Israel what to do because they do not share the risks of living here.
At the same time, Israelis have their own grievances, including a complaint that overseas Jews use them as bait to bring in money that largely stays home and never makes it here.
"Everybody's out there shnorring," said Matti Golan, editor in chief of Telegraph, a business daily, and a critic of the overseas circuit. "But many Israelis don't want to hear it. And the Americans don't want to hear that we don't need charity. It's not that I don't want their money. I want it in a more suitable way, with investments."
Mr. Beilin, somewhat chastened by the criticism he received, explained last week in remarks to a Hadassah convention from the United States that he wanted money-raising groups to re-examine their missions, not to go out of business. In New York, Rabbi Brian L. Lurie, executive vice president of the United Jewish Appeal, says soul-searching is already under way.
"The noblesse oblige that we once thought to be our role is gone," Rabbi Lurie said. "We have to look on this now as voluntary taxes to help the entire Jewish people in partnership with the taxpayers of Israel."
But that does not mean misunderstanding will disappear, Rabbi Lurie warns. "The dichotomy between those inside and those outside," he said, "goes back to Babylon."

HEADLINE: U.S. Asks Allies to Help Speed I.M.F. Aid to Russia

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has proposed to its Western allies that they work more closely with the International Monetary Fund and the Russian Government to help both sides work out loans for Moscow, which have been stalled for months over Russia's reluctance to meet I.M.F. terms.
The United States has also proposed speeding the amount of money available through the World Bank for privatizing and repairing state industries, as well as trying to get some hard cash into the hands of Russia and Ukraine by having international financial institutions lend money to other former Soviet republics that have not been able to buy Russian oil or goods now that they must pay real world prices instead of subsidized rates.
 
Essential for Agreement
 All of these proposals are part of an evolving American response to events in Russia that officials say will be driven by three imperatives: 
 *First is a desire to prove to Russians that Western-backed economic reform is not all pain and no gain by getting more concrete benefits to people on the ground.
*Second is a willingness to press ahead with the $4.1 billion in purely American aid programs aimed not at the central Government but at small grass-roots programs promoting capitalism and democracy in towns and villages.
*Third is a refusal to weaken the conditions the I.M.F. has set before any more large-scale aid promised to the Russian Government by the Group of Seven is disbursed by the fund.
American officials say they not only endorse these conditions, but they believe that without firm I.M.F. targets for lowering Russian inflation and Government spending neither their partners in the Group of Seven industrialized democracies nor the Congress would go along with aid for Russia.
But where American officials believe the I.M.F. may be faulted is that when Russia has adopted economic measures that run contrary to I.M.F. advice, the fund has not worked hard enough to persuade the Russians of the right course. Instead, they say, it has let negotiations lapse for long periods while it waited for the Russian authorities to return to their senses. American officials concede that the Western allies have entrusted the I.M.F. with important elements of the aid effort to Russia without paying close attention.
What the United States has proposed to the other Group of Seven members -- which is almost sure to be accepted -- is that their deputy finance ministers meet with greater frequency to monitor the discussions between the I.M.F. and Russia to insure that Moscow was taking seriously, and understood, the fund's conditions.
"The idea is that the G-7 would be asking how things are going, not letting time lapse, and making sure that everyone is getting together to discuss the situation," a senior American policy maker said. "The fund can be faulted for a certain lack of urgency at times, but they have had the right instincts about demanding that the Russians control inflation as a condition for aid."
The managing director of the I.M.F., Michel Camdessus, said last Friday that an I.M.F. team will leave for Russia on Tuesday to reopen discussions with the Russian Government about how it can meet conditions for another $1.5 billion in economic assistance.
Talks between the fund and the Russian Government have been interrupted as a result of several surprises by Moscow -- ranging from July's decision to recall all rubles printed before 1991 to the announcement last month that Belarus would become part of the Russian Economic Union, under terms viewed as inflationary by the West.
"This took us, the G-7, the I.M.F. and the World Bank by surprise," a senior American official said. "So each time this happens the I.M.F. says, 'We'd better sit back and see what the Russians are going to do.' This causes delays. The idea is that when Russian policies become inconsistent with economic stability, the G-7 would step in and engage the Russians and the I.M.F. -- not just let everyone go home."
The United States has proposed to its Group of Seven partners some other concrete steps that they might take to encourage economic reform in Russia -- despite its new go-slow, conservative Cabinet.
 
Privatization Fund
 At the Tokyo summit meeting last July, the Group of Seven -- the United States, Japan, France, Britain, Italy, Canada and Germany -- promised Russia a $3 billion Special Privatization and Restructuring Program to help break apart and privatize the huge state-owned Russian industries that dominate whole towns.
One of Russia's problems is that these companies provide all the social services for their workers, everything from health care to resorts for recreation. The Russian Government does not want to close them down because they constitute the country's social safety net. Of the $3 billion promised, the World Bank was supposed to provide $500 million to help these companies shift their social service responsibilities to the municipalities.
The Administration has proposed to its Group of Seven partners that they intensify their efforts to speed up delivery of this loan, which the Russians have been resisting because they do not want to go into debt for anything that does not generate income. The Americans also want the World Bank to move ahead with more structural assistance for specific Russian industries.
The idea, American officials say, is that while it may make no sense now to be supporting the Russian Government budget when the country is in hyperinflation, it does make sense for the World Bank to help repair Russian oil wells that will earn hard currency.


GRAPHIC: Of the $28.4 billion in aid promised by the West to Russia in 1993, $8 billion has been disbursed.

Chart: "Promises, Promises: Moscow Waits"
 Of the $4.1 billion in short-term currency stabilization support from the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, $1.8 billion has been disbursed. The rest still awaits Russia's meeting lower inflation targets.
 Of the $10.1 billion in long-term currency stabilization funds, none have been disbursed; this depends on comprehensive economic reforms, which the Russian Government has not even begun negotiating wiht the I.M.F.
 Of the $14.2 billion in export credits pledged by various members of the Group of Seven, about $6.2 billion has been disbursed. This money was to allow the Russians to buy goods on credit and obtain technical assistance to revamp various segments of the Russian economy.
