HEADLINE: Man in the News;
The I.R.A.'s Advocate: Gerard Adams

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

 BODY:
After long years of ostracism by Washington, Gerry Adams, the political head of the Irish Republican Army, was permitted onto American soil yesterday and immediately predicted that Northern Ireland's 25 years of urban guerrilla warfare would enter a climactic stage toward peace.
"Let me be quite clear about this: this generation of republicans is going to see peace in Ireland," Mr. Adams said upon arriving for a conference about the intransigent politics and deadly troubles of Ulster. 
 Mr. Adams, an articulate and enigmatic partisan leader in a centuries-old struggle, commended President Clinton for reversing his visa ban. At an airport news conference, he expressed optimism in the long run but made no predictions of a peace breakthrough during his New York visit.
"It's a small step," he said of finally reaching America, with its influential political and news media institutions. "But it's also a small victory for free speech." As president of Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political arm, Mr. Adams has been subject to censorship in Britain and, until recently, in the Irish Republic.
His supporters were busy yesterday booking him onto television news shows, most likely guaranteeing him more exposure in his two days in New York than he has been able to achieve in years of muted coverage at home.
His very arrival, after eight earlier denials of a visa, was hailed by his jubilant Irish-American partisans as a historic step of recognition for his side in the agonizing warfare that has long afflicted Northern Ireland and British mainland targets.
 
'A Legitimate Force'
 "He's been brought out of the shadows by Clinton," said Representative Peter T. King, the Nassau County Republican and staunch Adams ally.
"This finally recognizes Sinn Fein and the I.R.A. as a legitimate force in Northern Ireland -- not bad for an ex-bartender from Northern Ireland," said Mr. King, who predicted that the visitor would make the most of his visit in explaining the I.R.A.'s position in 25 years of violent resistance to British rule in Ulster.
Some British and American diplomats were complaining that Mr. Adams had made no real change, as the White House insisted, in his long-standing defense of I.R.A. violence. They contended that President Clinton was mainly yielding to domestic political pressures.
But Mr. Adams's supporters argued that the President had belatedly recognized the I.R.A.'s central role in the troubles and that the inclusion of Mr. Adams improved the chances for productive negotiations.
"I think what we have to do, in the words of Albert Reynolds, is to produce a demilitarized society," Mr. Adams declared at Kennedy International Airport, referring to the Prime Minister of the Irish Republic.
Mr. Adams, lean and darkly bearded, is the central figure in one of the most promising but delicate peace initiatives in years, one in which the British and Irish Governments have offered him a position at the negotiating table in return for a cessation of I.R.A. violence. The violence lately has lessened but not ceased, producing some qualified optimism.
 
A Veteran of the Troubles
 A 44-year-old veteran of the troubles, Mr. Adams has not yet committed himself to the formal peace proposal. But his arrival in this country for a separate discussion of Northern Ireland is considered a significant step both in this initiative and, even more, his own long fight to win greater understanding and legitimacy for the I.R.A.
Mr. Adams is to attend a conference on Irish peace prospects today at the Waldorf-Astoria, sponsored by the National Committee on American Foreign Policy, a private organization.
"I think we are at a very critical point in the peace process," Mr. Adams said, comparing its complex and lethal dimensions to the Middle East peace talks currently making progress.
The brutal war in Northern Ireland has involved military and civilian targets and seen 3,114 killed since 1969 -- an estimated 1,400 attributed to the I.R.A. and the rest to Protestant paramilitary fighters organized against the predominantly Roman Catholic I.R.A. and to British troops.
Mr. Adams denies that he is de facto general of the I.R.A.'s street campaign. But his supporters here and in Ireland say he is the only figure with enough stature and credibility to take up the offer from London and Dublin and lead the more militant members of the I.R.A. toward peace talks.
"This makes him a major player," Mr. King said of the visit, contending that it was easing a long and unfair foreign policy tilt toward London by Washington. British and Northern Ireland officials and other Adams critics consider the visit an implicit victory for urban terrorist tactics.
In this latest endeavor, his precise position on violence has been called into question, and Mr. Adams has offered some fresh language now being scrutinized by critics and supporters.
His long-held view is that without "the cutting edge" of the I.R.A. guerrilla campaign, "Ireland would not even be an issue." Lately, he has also said he wants "to bring an end to the Irish Republican Army, to be taking the gun out of Irish politics." This is language that foresees an I.R.A. triumph in reuniting Ireland, a possibility that chills the Protestant majority of Northern Ireland.
On the "Larry King Live" television program last night, Mr. Adams once more called for the "demilitarization" of the issue -- a call in effect for the withdrawal of British troops who are looked on as vital protectors by the Northern Protestant majority.
The program also offered Americans a taste of the complex acrimony of the issue as Mr. Adams was questioned and rebutted by Dr. John Alderdice, a Protestant rival and leader of the Alliance Party, and accused of engaging in the words but not the actions of peacemaking.
The awful lesson of Mr. Adam's winning a visa, Dr. Alderdice said, is that "violence on the republican side has gotten them credits," so that loyalist violence is now rising among the I.R.A.'s Protestant enemies.
Gerard Adams grew up in the Falls Road slum of Belfast, where bombings and sniper warfare have raged for a generation, and he suffered neck and shoulder wounds in an attack by his enemies 10 years ago. He is one of 10 children, the son of a laborer also convicted as an I.R.A. partisan. His first efforts were in the peaceful civil rights protests of the 1960's against British rule.
In 1972, he was freed from imprisonment as an I.R.A. leader and flown to London for peace talks, which failed. Elected to the British Parliament from Northern Ireland, Mr. Adams never took his seat as part of the I.R.A. protest of British rule. He lost the seat in 1992 to the North's more popular and moderate Catholic faction, the Social and Democratic Labor Party.
Mr. Adams is a history student more aware than most of the many false starts toward peace in the Irish struggle. "It is a bit of a grind and it would be wrong to say that one doesn't get despondent," he admitted four years ago.
For him, the cause is for an Ireland reunited and resurgent enough to undo the economic underpinnings of the struggle, which he finds rooted in the two parts of the Belfast underclass, the impoverished, embattled Catholic and Protestant ghettos.
In recent years, Mr. Adams, who is married to the former Colette McArdle and has a 20-year-old son, Gearoid, has expressed concern that "what I've gone through and my father has gone through is going to be the same for our children and grandchildren." He added: "We have to end it. And I think I can."
But in the face of all the killing, Mr. Adams's critics have branded him a terrorist and a hypocrite for his expressions of regret and apology for some of the more wayward I.R.A. bombings and civilian casualties. His supporters -- including a pro-I.R.A. faction of Irish-Americans -- hold that he is the only "hard man of destiny" now on the Ulster scene who might have anything approaching the resources needed to bring about peace.

HEADLINE: FIGURE SKATING;
Lawyer for Skater's Ex-Husband Says He Has Tied Her to Attack

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 31

 BODY:
Jeff Gillooly, the former husband of Tonya Harding, has told investigators that Miss Harding helped plan the assault on her figure-skating rival, Nancy Kerrigan, Mr. Gillooly's lawyer said today.
Ronald H. Hoevet, the lawyer, said Mr. Gillooly told Federal investigators last week that Miss Harding had given final approval for the Jan. 6 attack in Detroit, where Miss Kerrigan was struck above the right knee and kept from competing in the national championships. The lawyer said Mr. Gillooly's account was fully detailed, and included many points that could be corroborated by phone logs and bank records. 
 Miss Harding, who initially denied any knowledge of the plot, said last week that she had learned several days after the attack that several people close to her had been involved. However, in more than 10 hours of interviews with investigators on Jan. 18, she consistently denied knowing anything in advance about plans for the attack.
Mr. Gillooly identified Miss Harding as an important figure in planning the attack only after he learned that she had told the authorities that he had played the central role, his lawyer said. She had been telling him privately that she did not implicate him in her statements to the investigators, Mr. Hoevet said.
Miss Harding's lawyer, Robert C. Weaver Jr., did not return several telephone messages left for him.
Mr. Gillooly, a 26-year-old former warehouse worker who is currently unemployed, is scheduled to appear in court Tuesday morning to accept a plea bargain offer from the Multnomah district attorney's office. Mr. Hoevet said that his client has accepted a proposal of pleading guilty to a single count of racketeering and a fine of $100,000 in exchange for telling his version of what happened and a maximum jail term of two years, one year less than he could have received on the original charge of conspiracy to commit assault.
As part of any plea bargain agreement in Oregon, the court routinely makes public reports by law enforcement agencies, including the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which interviewed both Miss Harding and Mr. Gillooly. Norman W. Frink, the deputy district attorney, said he assumed that those statements would be released on Tuesday.
Mr. Hoevet said he was speaking out now to send a message to United States Olympic officials that Miss Harding should be "eliminated from the Olympic team." "She is entitled to due process, for sure," Mr. Hoevet said of Miss Harding. "But we would be a morally bankrupt nation if we send to the Olympic games as teammates, Nancy Kerrigan and Tonya Harding, a woman who helped get her whacked."
Skating officials are making their own inquiry. They had no comment on Mr. Hoevet's statements. Mike Moran, spokesman for the United States Olympic Committee, said it would be inappropriate to comment on the Harding matter.

 
 
Evidence Includes Videotape
 In a 30-minute interview today, in which he revealed many of the details of Mr. Gillooly's 17 hours of testimony over two days last week, Mr. Hoevet made these general points, based on his client's assertions:
*Miss Harding, who lived with Mr. Gillooly at the time despite their divorce, was involved with Mr. Gillooly in planning the assault from a point in early December after she finished fourth, a disappointment, at a skating competition in Japan.
*Mr. Gillooly identified a Pennsylvania woman well-connected in figure-skating circles who Miss Harding called to ask for help in learning Miss Kerrigan's home address in Stoneham, Mass., and details of her training schedule at her practice rink on Cape Cod.
*Investigators have compiled a wealth of corroborating evidence that bears out much of what Mr. Gillooly told them, including telephone logs, money transfers and videotape surveillance of movements around Portland by Mr. Gillooly and Miss Harding after they returned to Portland from Detroit on Jan. 10.
On one tape, Mr. Hoevet said, Federal investigators have pictures of the couple driving back and forth in front of the home of Shawn E. Eckardt, Miss Harding's one-time body guard, at a time they knew Mr. Eckardt was being interviewed by the authorities.
Mr. Eckardt is one of three other men charged in the case. The authorities say he confessed to arranging with the two others, Shane M. Stant and Derrick B. Smith, to carry out the attack.
Mr. Frink said he would have no comment on any aspect of Mr. Gillooly's statement, other than to say the investigation was continuing.

 
 
Olympics Issue Unresolved
 The United States Figure Skating Association and the U.S.O.C. are monitoring the case and are waiting for a five-member panel from the skating association to complete its own investigation. The group is scheduled to meet for the first time on Tuesday and make a recommendation by the weekend whether there is reasonable cause to bring Miss Harding before a disciplinary panel.
But the ultimate decision of whether she would be allowed to skate in the Olympics belongs to the U.S.O.C., which certified Miss Harding as a member of the Lillehammer team today. The women's figure-skating competition in the Lillehammer Olympics is scheduled to start on Feb. 23.
William J. Hybl, chairman of the skating association panel and a former U.S.O.C. president, said from Colorado Springs that whatever evidence arises out of Mr. Gillooly's court appearance "would be weighed along with all the other evidence. Obviously, if there is any indication of prior knowledge on Miss Harding's part, that would be weighed very carefully by the panel."
Mr. Hoevet said that Mr. Gillooly's statements to investigators about Miss Harding "implicated her in the plot from the beginning. He told them that Tonya gave the final O.K. for the attack."

 
 
Concern About Politics
 The motivation for the couple to initiate an attack of Miss Kerrigan, he said, came from Miss Harding's poor performance in Chiba, Japan, and their fear that judges in the United States would hold it against her at the national championships, from which only two women would make the American Olympic team.
"They viewed Kerrigan as the clear favorite, the fair-haired girl," Mr. Hoevet said. "They thought what happened to Tonya in Japan was politics and that would hurt her in Detroit."
As a result, he said, reflecting the statement Mr. Gillooly gave the authorities, Miss Harding "gave the final O.K." to devise a plan that would remove Miss Kerrigan from the national championships. "It was up to Tonya," Mr. Hoevet said.
Through statements of Mr. Eckardt, Mr. Stant and Mr. Smith, the authorities patched together an outline of what they say happened, with Mr. Gillooly giving Mr. Eckardt $2,000, and Mr. Stant initiating his attempt to commit the assault in one of several Massachusetts locations. The assault was later carried out as Miss Kerrigan left a practice rink in Detroit.

 
 
Denial Changes to Confession
 But even after all four men were charged, Mr. Hoevet said that Mr. Gillooly would not have implicated Miss Harding had she not misled him in their "personal contacts" after her interview with investigators.
Mr. Hoevet and several other people familiar with Miss Harding's interview said that after hours of denying any knowledge of the plot, Miss Harding finally changed her story to say that Mr. Gillooly was deeply involved but that she only found out about it days later. In her first public comments on the case last week, she apologized for her delay in informing the authorities of what she learned. "My first reaction was one of disbelief,' she said. "The disbelief was followed by shock and fear."
Yet Mr. Hoevet said that Miss Harding and Mr. Gillooly were in contact after Miss Harding gave her statement to investigators, and in those conversations, he said, Miss Harding assured Mr. Gillooly that she had not told the authorities that he helped plan the attack.
Mr. Hoevet, who had maintained his own conversations with prosecutors and the district attorney's office, said he knew that what Miss Harding was telling Mr. Gillooly was false. He told his client. "But at that point," he said, "Jeff knew in his head, but not in his heart." He was still reluctant to say that Miss Harding had helped plan the attack, Mr. Hoevet said.
Finally, Mr. Hoevet said he offered to show his client the actual F.B.I. reports, a 46-page document, from its interview with Miss Harding. It even included what Miss Harding ate during a break, a turkey sandwich.
"That convinced him," Mr. Hoevet said, and in another conversation with Miss Harding, he quoted Mr. Gillooly as saying, "Tonya, you're not telling the truth. I saw the notes."
Mr. Hoevet said that Mr. Gillooly was also willing to go forward because he knew that the statements by the other three men had tied him tightly to the crime.
"The case against him was overwhelming," Mr. Hoevet said. "When he finally had his interview, he didn't minimize anything. Not even his own role."

Nike Gives $25,000 to Harding
 PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Nike contributed $25,000 today to help Tonya Harding defend her place on the United States Olympic Team.
Philip Knight, the chief executive officer of the company, which is based in Beaverton, Ore., said he feared that Harding, who does not have a contract with Nike, would be forced off the team before the criminal justice system has rendered judgment on whether she had a role in the attack on Nancy Kerrigan.
"If she wins and is guilty, you can take her medals away, but if, in fact she is innocent and doesn't get to skate, you can never repair that damage, ever," Knight told ESPN.

HEADLINE: Home Rule's Exclusive, Costly Kingdoms

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DERING HARBOR, L.I., Jan. 28

 BODY:
Sitting on a gently sloping hill of elm and locust trees that leads to a rocky beach, Dering Harbor offers virtually none of the amenities of a modern municipality. No post office. No playground. Not a single quaint country shop. Just 32 houses, a puny water tower and a maintenance staff named Richie.
Still, it is an incorporated village, the smallest in New York State, a locality with a budget of $115,000 a year and two major parties: the Independent Party, from which all candidates for village mayor and trustee are drawn, and the yearly summer cocktail party, to which all Dering Harbor is invited. 
 "We're just doing on a very small scale what other places are doing on a larger scale," said the Rev. Stewart W. Herman, the village historian, a retired Lutheran minister who comprises nearly 4 percent of Dering Harbor's official population of 28. (Some of the 32 houses are occupied only in the summer, when the population swells to 90.)
While Dering Harbor's size is singular, there is nothing unusual in these parts about its tight embrace of self-determination.
Dering Harbor, on Shelter Island in Suffolk County, is only one of 94 incorporated villages within the 13 towns encompassed by the two counties that make up Long Island. And that is not to mention the hundreds of other governmental bodies with the powers to tax and set fees -- the street-lighting districts and fire districts, water districts and sewer districts, park districts and sidewalk districts and garbage districts and, in one Nassau County hamlet at one time, a railroad-station escalator district.
Long Islanders, like their suburban brethren in Westchester County and much of New Jersey, are locked in an embrace with home rule, a devotion that has created a fragmented and often duplicative system of local control of streets, parks and schools, a system that has helped make property taxes in New York's suburbs among the highest in the nation.
It is a system that some critics say has also fostered a sense of separateness and racial and ethnic exclusion in many suburbs, a way of government that lets some communities tightly control the kinds of businesses and people who can live there.
Home rule has also inspired a veritable cottage industry of blue-ribbon panels issuing multi-volume reports and calls for streamlining and reform. But the calls are rarely answered, for as anyone who has ever studied the phenomenon will acknowledge, home rule is as securely anchored in the soil of suburbia as a swimming pool or a backyard deck.
The New York suburbs are not the only area of the nation where home rule is treasured. A 1987 Census survey showed that Illinois ranked first in the nation in the number of local governments; New York ranked eighth. But officials in the metropolitan region say that few localities compare with Long Island for the multiple layers of local government. Along the 32 miles of Fire Island's coastline, for example, seven separate entities -- two villages, two towns, Suffolk County, the State of New York and the Federal Government -- regulate the beaches.
John V. N. Klein, a lawyer and former Suffolk County Executive, says he makes his living today as a kind of municipal Sherpa, navigating the various levels of local government for out-of-town businesses seeking to locate on the Island.
"These people with headquarters in Texas, California or Michigan, they end up in my lap because they just discover they are at the edge of a governmental Okefenokee Swamp, and they can't even get across without a guide," said Mr. Klein. "They are absolutely dumbfounded by the multiplicity, the regulations and agencies that have a voice in the simplest of projects."
 
'Fantasy' in New Jersey
 The latest salvo against home rule occurred two weeks ago, when Gov. Jim Florio, in his farewell address, proclaimed New Jersey's patchwork approach to local government -- 567 municipalities and 610 school districts -- wasteful and outmoded. He told the Legislature it was time to end what he called "a fantasy where we think small is automatically better," and even uttered a word that strikes fear in the hearts of those who cherish home rule: "regionalization."
It was the echo of a complaint that has been lodged again and again by political scientists, business leaders and officials of higher levels of government, a complaint that rarely earns a politician points with voters.
"Isn't it interesting?" observed Clifford Zukin, a professor at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University. "We had a Governor who was willing to take on raising every tax and never looked away, and even with that Governor, he mentioned home rule only when he was going out, not when he was coming in."
In the end, it may not matter what Mr. Florio says: where home rule is concerned, no one seems to listen. In 1966, the Committee for Economic Development, an independent policy research group in Manhattan, studied local governments in the United States and recommended that 80 percent of them be eliminated. Twenty years later, the Census Bureau found that the number of local governmental units had grown by about 3,000.
 
'Out of Control' on L.I.
 To some on Long Island, where more than 1,000 separate government bodies have the power to reach into taxpayers' wallets, home rule has got out of hand. "With four tiers of government and hundreds of separate taxing units, it is to a large extent out of control," said Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board.
Mr. Koppelman, who also heads the Center for Policy Studies at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, is the Don Quixote of local consolidation, forever tilting at the excesses of home rule -- and never getting very far. In 1992 he and his staff produced a three-volume report for the State Temporary Commission for Tax Relief on Long Island, offering recommendations for privatization and consolidation of services.
Mr. Koppelman said that if his recommendations were adopted -- from merging school districts to cutting duplicated services -- the savings to Long Island taxpayers could total more than $500 million.
In a time when voters were expressing frustration over high taxes, he hoped the report would be received enthusiastically. "What I thought this time was the Island was facing such a crisis that it was impossible for them to ignore the work," he said. "And I thought, 'This time something is going to come out of it.' "
 
Mostly More Committees
 Nothing much did. A few recommendations were adopted; other committees were formed. Mr. Koppelman is not pleased. "The more we looked into it, the more it was clear there was bloat in government," he said. "That's precisely what it is: bloat."
In some parts of Long Island, in fact, creating more levels of government is still in vogue. Last year, owners of houses along a section of erosion-wracked Dune Road in Westhampton Beach, where summer cottages wash away with each new storm, voted 87 to 0 to form a new village, Westhampton Dunes, in hopes of gaining influence to remedy their problems. And earlier this month Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed in his new budget to give $50,000 to a Long Island institute to determine whether five East End towns should leave Suffolk County and form a new one, Peconic County.
"It's out of control, and nobody knows how to put the genie back in the bottle," said Patrick Halpin, a former Suffolk County Executive. He traces the suburbs' infatuation with home rule to the postwar generation that fled the cities in search of a different way of life. "They wanted to have some control over their community, their destiny, which they felt they didn't have in the city," he said.
Mr. Halpin learned about the dangers of challenging home rule the hard way. In his 1988 State of the County address, he observed that half as many children were being educated in the county as had been 20 years earlier.
 
'Have You Gone Mad?'
 "I asked a simple question: 'Why do we need 72 school districts?' " Mr. Halpin, now a local political commentator and businessman, recalled. "And all hell broke loose. I heard immediately from all the school districts, who said, 'How dare you tread on our turf!' And then I heard from my friends in the teachers' union, who said, 'Have you gone mad?' "
There is perhaps no place that practices a homier home rule than Dering Harbor. It is so small that when 11 lots in the 200-acre village went up for sale a few years ago, village residents suddenly had to scare up a planning board; there hadn't been one before, said the Mayor, Tim Hogue. (The land was never developed.) It is the kind of place where the landscaping that surrounds village hall comes from taxpayers' gardens and where the one full-time village employee, Richie Surozenski, does everything from mowing the lawns to plowing the roads.
"It's to give people some extra services and control," said Mr. Hogue, a financial consultant who divides his time between an apartment in Manhattan and a white Victorian house a block from the water. The village budget pays the salaries of Mr. Surozenski and a part-time village clerk as well as the costs of trash disposal and a water district. The village pays the Town of Shelter Island for police and fire protection.
Mr. Herman, the retired minister, and his wife are two of a handful of year-round residents of the community, a place he described in his privately printed 1976 history of Dering Harbor, "The Smallest Village," as "no more than a good-sized farm." It was founded in 1916 by the well-to-do owners of the summer homes that dotted the hill overlooking the harbor at the northern end of Shelter Island, and was incorporated for much the same reasons other Long Island municipalities have organized: to keep something out.
 
Nothing Much Comes In

In his book Mr. Herman wrote that there had been "whispered fears" among the founding fathers about the potential encroachement by "concessions that degenerate into some kind of Coney Island Boardwalk."
The concessionaires never came, and neither did much of anything else. Dering Harbor has remained out of the way and largely unnoticed, so anonymous that occasionally the part-time village clerk, Margaret Gibney, receives letters addressed to the village with checks and requests for reservations that were intended for the nearby Dering Harbor Inn. Which is not in Dering Harbor.
"Very little happens here," sighed Mayor Hogue, after explaining that the village does not encourage the inquiries of the curious. "We're such a boring group of people."
Even in Dering Harbor, it occurs to inhabitants like Mr. Herman that perhaps the $2,500 he pays in village taxes each year is a bit steep for what amounts to garbage pickup and the privilege of living in a municipality operating separately from the Town of Shelter Island (Pop. 2,265).
But eventually, as with all things in this laconic village, the concerns seem to recede with the tides.
"There's been some discussion as to whether it is outmoded," Mr. Herman said as he tooled around the village in his station wagon, pointing out sights like the water tower. "But we stop to think about it. And then the inertia sets in."

HEADLINE: U.S. BLOOD SUPPLY HITS LOWEST LEVEL SINCE WORLD WAR II

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

 BODY:
Once again, the nation's blood supply is perilously low. But this winter the shortage has been the worst and longest since World War II.
The situation was so bad, blood bank officials said, that if more people had been injured in the earthquake in Los Angeles on Jan. 17, there might not have been enough blood to treat them, increasing the death toll. 
 At that time, the supply around the country was down to less than a day from the preferred five to seven days.
"The blood supply in Los Angeles and surrounding areas was in incredibly bad shape, and there was no blood to send in from anywhere," said Marcia Lane, a spokeswoman for the American Association of Blood Banks in Bethesda, Md. The association represents 2,400 blood banks, including those in the American Red Cross, that collect and process 80 percent of the blood transfused in the United States.
 
Dangerous Levels in 40 Cities
 Officials offer a number of explanations for this year's shortage, ranging from severe weather to the flu outbreak to potential donors' irrational fear of contracting AIDS. But the severity of this year's shortage combined with the predictability of seasonal shortages in general raises an underlying question about the reliability of the blood collection system.
Transfusions of blood and blood products are crucial to the repair of many injuries and to much modern surgery as well as to the treatment of heart disease, cancer and other conditions.
Some 4 million patients in this country receive transfusions each year, using 14 million units of blood collected from 8 million volunteer donors drawn from among the 189 million Americans who are 17 and older. The blood must be used within 42 days or discarded.
In the last month, blood supplies reached dangerous levels in more than 40 cities and resulted in postponement of elective surgery in several areas. In an unusual action, the blood bank association and the Red Cross made a national emergency appeal for blood donations. Americans responded, easing the crisis. Now the supply has a two-day margin.
Nevertheless, the threat of shortages will not disappear quickly. The demand has increased in recent years, while the donor pool has been shrinking, despite attempts to increase it by, for instance, eliminating the upper age limit for donors. In recent years, doctors have been urged to transfuse blood more judiciously.
Why is such a crucial and long established component of the health system in trouble?
Blood bank officials offer several explanations. One is that too few younger Americans are replacing their elders as blood donors. Second, a series of tests introduced in recent years to screen out the viruses that cause AIDS, hepatitis and other infections have removed people from the donor pool, although the numbers are unknown.
Third, fear of contracting AIDS from needles apparently keeps many people away. Twenty-five percent of respondents to a poll said they would not give blood for fear of catching AIDS. But that fear has no basis, since blood banks use new disposable needles every time they draw blood. Many experts suspect it is an excuse to avoid getting a needle stick or to take the time to donate blood.
Several other factors affecting supply and demand led to this winter's crisis, blood bank officials say. They cite arctic temperatures, snow storms, a heavy flu season and an unusually low turnout at holiday blood drives, partly because of layoffs. And they say violent crime has increased demand for blood.
 
Critics Fault Management
 Few would dispute that running blood banks is difficult. But critics contend that blood bank officials blame the public instead of themselves for the shortages. The critics say the shortages could be eased, if not prevented, through improved management. Many of the problems cited, like bad weather and the flu, tend to recur each year.
Granted, this year's bad weather struck at a time of extraordinary vulnerability. A large scheduled blood drive in Washington two weeks ago, for example, was called off when bad weather closed the Government.
Drives were also canceled elsewhere, and officials said they were left with no quick way to make up the shortfall.
But critics note that the blood shortage in some cities began before the cold weather struck, and several of the metropolitan areas affected by the shortage are in Florida, Puerto Rico and other areas that escaped the severe weather.
As for the flu, while it did strike in many areas, over all it was not as severe as Federal health officials had predicted. Nevertheless, an outbreak of flu in an area that is usually self-sufficient and exports blood to chronically short areas can have an enormous impact on blood supplies thousands of miles away.
Blood bank officials have also blamed the economy, saying that as large companies have laid off employees, fewer donate at work, the source of much of the blood supply. Blood bank officials say some production-minded companies are reluctant to give employees time off to donate blood.
The blood bank officials also say the closing of military bases has contributed to the shortage as military personnel and their families leave. But officials say they have no national statistics measuring the effects of either of these economic changes on declining donations.
At least one city that might be expected to need extra blood for all the reasons cited, including violence, has not issued an emergency appeal for blood. New York City juggled collection schedules in the workplace before the Christmas and New Year's holidays and helped prevent a crisis, said Dr. John W. Adamson, who heads the New York Blood Center. His organization, which imports blood from Europe to supplement the local supply, did not need to increase imports this season.
In San Diego in early January, when blood collections dropped by half from the usual 400 units a day, six people were shot in drive-by shootings and in a movie theater. They needed 118 units of blood. (A unit is slightly less than a pint.) Three other accident victims needed 192 units, straining the supply.
But although blood bank officials cite such anecdotes, they do not have national statistics to back up the contention that such trauma has suddenly increased demand.
 
Using One's Own Blood
 One complicating factor is that many people have heeded advice from health officials, doctors and blood banks to donate blood in advance of undergoing elective surgery.
"We want people to give their own blood" whenever possible, "and we have worked hard to convince people that it is the safest thing to do," said Dr. Arthur J. Silvergleid, who directs the blood banks in San Bernardino and Riverside Counties in California and who is a former president of the blood bank association.
Giving, and later receiving, one's own blood is called an autologous transfusion. An estimated 8 percent of donors nationally participate in autologous transfusion programs, Dr. Silvergleid said. But some people may also end up getting blood from community sources because it is not always possible to estimate the amount of blood needed in an operation.
But, Dr. Silvergleid also said, encouraging autologous transfusions "is a double-edged sword." By emphasizing the benefits of autologous blood transfusions, Dr. Silvergleid said, "we realize we are giving out a message that the alternative of community blood is not as good; it is not a large degree worse, it is different."
Since the advent of AIDS, blood banks have asked donors more probing questions in interviews about their personal behavior, including sexual preferences and use of intravenous drugs. Those in groups at high risk for AIDS are asked not to donate blood. But most blood banks also give all those who do donate an opportunity to indicate that their blood must not be used for patient care. They do allow such blood to be used for research.
While the practice increases the safety of donated blood, it has created problems.
Blood banks code the identity of potential or actual blood donors who are found to be unsuitable on the basis of medical history or laboratory testing and enter the information into what is known as a donor deferral registry, Dr. Jeffrey McCullough wrote in The Journal of the American Medical Association.
Dr. McCullough, who is from the University of Minnesota Hospital in Minneapolis and Clinic and American Red Cross Blood Services in St. Paul, also wrote:
"The increasingly specific questioning of donors, the increasing number of laboratory tests done on donated blood, and the use of donor deferral registries have created a new type of adverse consequence of donating blood."
Dr. Silvergleid said that "what we need is a pool of regular repeat donors."
 
Problems of Credibility
 The image and credibility of blood banks was seriously damaged in the early 1980's, when it was discovered that AIDS could be transmitted through contaminated blood. Many blood banks at first denied a link between blood and AIDS, and later played down the risk of contracting AIDS from donated blood. Only after pressure from Federal health officials did the blood banks take steps to discourage donations from those at high risk of AIDS and other infections.
Federal pressures to improve the safety of the blood supply continue. Last May the American Red Cross, which collects and processes about half the blood transfused in the United States, agreed in a consent decree to demands by the Food and Drug Administration for a timetable to establish clear lines of managerial control over quality assurance in all 47 regions of its blood program.
Under the accord, the Red Cross will establish a comprehensive quality assurance program and will enhance its training program for all blood program employees, including an annual competency review. It also agreed to improve its computer systems, record management and policies for investigating and reporting errors, accidents and adverse reactions.
In imposing good management processes on blood banks, officials of the food and drug agency say they are invoking a new philosophy that views blood banks as part of the pharmaceutical industry and not simply a service. But many blood bank officials criticize the agency's position as further taxing an already burdened system.
They say the effort needed to meet F.D.A. regulations reduces the time they have to try to increase the donor pool.
"Clearly, a blood shortage can make us uncomfortable," said Dr. Silvergleid. But, he went on, a violation of the Federal regulations "or the release of a contaminated unit can put us out of work, so our energies are directed toward what we consider more pressing concerns right now."
The Commissioner of Food and Drugs, Dr. David A. Kessler, said there was no evidence that the consent decree had contributed to this season's blood shortage.
 
Ignorance About Donor Pool
 As blood bank officials face more lawsuits and are subjected to considerably greater scrutiny than they were accustomed to in the days before AIDS, they complain that reports by news organizations of violations of F.D.A. standards, contaminated units that have slipped through the system and crises have contributed to a falling off in blood donors. But they know far less than they would like about the potential donor pool.
For example, the percentage of Americans who are eligible to donate blood is not known, although Dr. Silvergleid said that "we do know that the eligible donor pool is a lot smaller than everybody had thought for a long time."
Blood banks also have an inadequate understanding of what motivates people to donate blood.
"We need sociologists and anthropologists to do the studies to learn why we are not replacing with younger donors the aging generations that regularly gave gallons of blood over their lives in a community spirit that grew out of World War II and the Korean War," Dr. Silvergleid said.
Donations through high school programs in his area of California have dropped by 15 percent over recent years, in part because parents have advised their children not to donate at school, Dr. Silvergleid said.
Most blood bank officials agree that advertising, particularly on television, would lead to adequate supplies, and in fact there is no shortage of donors who respond to blood drives after earthquakes and other crises. Dr. Silvergleid said the problem was how to come up with the money for advertising.
The introduction of new screening tests and Federal regulations have undoubtedly made the nation's blood supply safer than ever. But critics say that blood banks need to be more aggressive in stimulating people to donate blood. Ultimately, it seems, only development of an artificial blood would fully solve the blood shortage. But until then, anyone might need blood unexpectedly at any time, and Americans remain dependent on the good will of others to provide it.

HEADLINE: SUPER BOWL XXVIII: NOTEBOOK;
Super Headache: Keeping the Stars

BYLINE: By FRANK LITSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Now that the Dallas Cowboys have won their second straight Super Bowl and the Buffalo Bills have played in (and lost) their fourth straight, they must try to keep their teams intact. Or at least they must seek to keep the players they want despite the tricky paths of unrestricted free agency compounded by the introduction next season of a salary cap.
Of the 1,680 players on team rosters at the end of 1993, the National Football League Players Association expects there will be 499 unrestricted free agents this year. All of them have played in the N.F.L. at least four years and their contracts have all expired. On Feb. 18, those players can sign with any team, no holds barred. On the same day, 155 restricted free agents -- those with three years in the league and whose contracts have expired -- can also sign, but their old teams can match those offers. 
 The unrestricted free agents include cornerback Deion Sanders of the Atlanta Falcons, wide receivers Tim Brown of the Los Angeles Raiders and Anthony Miller of the San Diego Chargers, linebackers Rickey Jackson and Renaldo Turnbull of the New Orleans Saints, tight end Eric Green of the Pittsburgh Steelers and the National Football Conference's three Pro Bowl guards -- Nate Newton of the Cowboys, Randall McDaniel of the Minnesota Vikings and Guy McIntyre of the San Francisco 49ers.
 
Kosar Expected to Go
 The Cowboys have 19 unrestricted free agents. The backup quarterback, Bernie Kosar, will probably leave, kicker Eddie Murray and fullback Daryl Johnston will probably stay and defensive tackle Tony Casillas will probably test the market. But the Cowboys' biggest worry is the offensive line, where they could lose Newton, center/guard John Gesek, tackle/guard Kevin Gogan and center Mark Stepnoski, all full-time or part-time starters. Wide receiver Alvin Harper is a restricted free agent, and the Cowboys will probably match any offer he receives.
"I'd say we're in better shape than any other team in the league in signing our free agents," Coach Jimmy Johnson said of the Cowboys.
Not really. As quarterback Troy Aikman of the Cowboys said, "I hope everyone is back, but the reality of it is probably that not everyone will be." But of the key Cowboys, only Kosar, who knows he will not start ahead of Aikman, may choose to leave.
 
Simmons and Joyner Available
 The Bills have 14 unrestricted free agents, including cornerback Nate Odomes and the offensive linemen Howard Ballard and John Davis. The Philadelphia Eagles' two best remaining defensive players are available, and their agent, Jim Solano, wants big money for each -- $3.7 million a year for end Clyde Simmons and $3.3 million for outside linebacker Seth Joyner.
The Giants have 15 unrestricted free agents, including the unhappy cornerback Mark Collins, safeties Greg Jackson and Myron Guyton and almost all of the offensive line -- William Roberts, Doug Riesenberg, Bart Oates, Bob Kratch, Eric Moore and Brian Williams. The Jets have 14, including offensive linemen Dave Cadigan, Jim Sweeney and Roger Duffy.
This is not college football, where players may do or die for dear old alma mater and never think of moving. Many pros will move anywhere for money, which is fine because this is their business. Some, like tailback Lorenzo White and linebacker Al Smith of the Houston Oilers, may move because they are getting less playing time.
 
Turner to Visit Redskins
 Norv Turner, the Cowboys' offensive coordinator, flew home to Dallas today. On Tuesday, he is expected to be in the Washington suburbs to discuss the Redskins' head-coaching vacancy, which is apparently his for the asking.
"I think the Redskins were very positive on me," Turner said after the Super Bowl, "and I'm real excited about them. And there've been rumors that Phoenix is going to contact me, so I'm just going to see what's going to happen over the next three or four days."
The Redskins said they had no announcement on a timetable for meeting with Turner, although a Redskins source said that "the wheels are in motion." A Cardinals spokesman said he had no word from Bill Bidwill, the owner, on a possible meeting with Turner. The Cowboys concede that Turner will leave.
"He's going someplace," said Jerry Jones, the Cowboys' owner.
Turner's players are unhappy about losing him.
"I promise you I'd give up part of my salary to keep him here," said Michael Irvin, the Cowboys' wide receiver.
 
Is There a Team in San Juan?

 
 One major coaching job was filled Monday when the Green Bay Packers named the 61-year-old Fritz Shurmur as defensive coordinator. Shurmur held that job with the Phoenix Cardinals from 1991 until last week, when Coach Joe Bugel and his staff were swept out.
Shumur replaces Ray Rhodes, who resigned Thursday after two years with the Packers, saying it was a family decision. He did not give reasons, although he conceded that cold weather (the temperature dropped to 29 degrees below zero one day this season) was a factor.
 
 
Galloping Inflation

 
 Ah, American business ingenuity.
All last week, a Super Bowl XXVIII cap was available in Atlanta for $10.99. Two hours after the game, a similar cap saying "Dallas Cowboys, Super Bowl Back-to-Back Champions," was being sold for $19.99.

HEADLINE: U.S. Incomes Outpaced Spending for December

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Americans increased their personal incomes slightly faster than their spending last month, but their spending outpaced their paychecks for the year, a Government report showed today.
For December, incomes increased six-tenths of a percent, while spending rose a more modest five-tenths of a percent, the Commerce Department said today. 
 But for all of 1993, personal income climbed 4.7 percent after rising 6.1 percent in 1992. Consumer spending, meanwhile, advanced 6.1 percent for the biggest gain in three years, the Commerce Department said.
Some economists saw the report as a sign that the economy could lose momentum this year.
"It seems difficult to envision how the consumer can keep up this pace" of spending, said Kevin Flanagan, an economist at Dean Witter Reynolds in New York.
Cary Leahey, an economist at Lehman Brothers in New York, said, "If income continues to lag, then the economy slows down."
Wages and salaries increased last month along with Government subsidies to farmers. The income figures were also bolstered by retroactive Social Security payments.
December's increase in income, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $5.542 trillion, followed a five-tenths of a percent gain in November, initially reported as six-tenths of a percent rise.
The increase in spending, to an annual rate of $4.505 trillion, followed a two-tenths of a percent gain during November, previously reported as an increase of four-tenths of a percent.
Disposable personal income, or money left over after taxes, increased six-tenths of a percent in December after rising five-tenths of a percent in November. The savings rate edged up to 4.2 from 4.1 percent.
The implicit price deflator, a measure of inflation tied to the report, was unchanged in December after showing a one-tenth of a percent increase during November.
In a separate report, the Purchasing Management Association of Chicago said today that its gauge of Midwest manufacturing activity slowed in January, sliding to 59.6 from 62.2 in December.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 4, 1994, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day on Tuesday with an article about the growth of Americans' total personal income in December mislabeled the most recent month. It was December 1993, not January 1994.

HEADLINE: Billions for School Are Lost In Fraud, Waste and Abuse

SERIES: Looting Student Aid: Public Money, Private Gain -- First of three articles

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

 BODY:
For several years, the Federal Government has been losing $3 billion to $4 billion annually to waste, fraud and loan defaults in its higher education student-aid programs. That is more than 10 percent of the Education Department's annual budget of $29 billion -- enough to finance the nation's entire Head Start project.
Education officials, both inside and outside the Government, are well aware of the problem. The Education Secretary, Richard W. Riley, recently called his department's management of its main scholarship program "worse than lax." Robert Atwell, president of the American Council on Education, representing 1,600 colleges and universities, terms the fraud and abuse "an intolerable embarrassment."
 
Students Are Hurt
 In the most dramatic cases in recent years, directors of for-profit trade schools and colleges have looted the budgets of these loosely regulated Federal student aid programs to buy themselves Mercedes-Benzes, travel the world, subsidize a drug habit, invest in religious causes or pay themselves million-dollar salaries. 
 Instead of promoting education, some Federal student-aid programs have been used to victimize students. Representative Maxine Waters, Democrat of California, describes the misery the Federal Government's well-intentioned student loan program has caused many of the poor in her Los Angeles district: they enroll at for-profit, fly-by-night trade schools using Federal loans, get no useful training, cannot find jobs and wind up defaulting on the loans, ruining their credit rating and their hopes of escaping poverty. And it is the taxpayer who foots the bill for those defaulted, federally guaranteed loans.
Yet even now, as the Education Department issues regulations intended to improve oversight, forces are at work in Washington that threaten the biggest effort in years to revamp its loan program and main scholarship program, the Pell grant. Last year, 4.4 million students, most with family incomes below $25,000, received Pell scholarships of up to $2,300 each.
The Clinton Administration is talking tough on enforcement, but because of budget priorities, no growth in staff is expected at the Education Department, a place with a longstanding reputation as an understaffed, bureaucratic dumping ground. Trade school lobbyists have recently won passage of an amendment that will weaken one of the department's stronger enforcement tools. And the nation's major colleges are threatening a lawsuit over a new Federal law that expands states' regulatory authority.
As the lobbyists jockey in Washington, prosecutors across the nation try to put out the fires. "In these programs there's a naive presumption of honesty on the Government's part," said Larry H. Colleton, the United States Attorney in Orlando. "When Congress opened the doors of opportunity to benefit students, it really opened the door for cons."
The Government's system for distributing $6 billion in Pell grants annually to schools or colleges is essentially a system of trust. A school tells the Education Department how many students it has qualifying for scholarships, and the department electronically wires that money straight to the school's bank accounts. The school then has nearly two years to justify its requests, and it is during that time that money is easily defrauded by school officials.
Whether it is a Pell grant or a loan, students typically don't even touch the money -- they are given a tuition credit. The Education Department's inspector general, James B. Thomas Jr., does not pursue fraud by individual students any more. "We don't have time to do that," he said. He is too busy trying to make a dent in his backlog of 300 cases involving for-profit trade schools and colleges suspected of misusing Government money.
 
Small-Scale Loss
Dollars Disappear At a Trade School
 Two Florida cases, one small and one large, illustrate the difficulty the Education Department has had trying to police these programs and how far Federal aid to higher education has strayed from its original mission.
Case No. 1. In the late 1980's, Earl Shomber, a salesman with no experience in education, decided that a for-profit trade school would be a nice investment. Mr. Shomber, whose criminal record includes convictions for auto larceny, burglary and indecent exposure, opened PRS Career Academy in a cinder-block building along Highway 434 in Longwood, Fla., offering classes in word processing, "travel agency" and other vocational trades.
It was slow going at first, but once his school was accredited, and therefore qualified for Federal loans and Pell scholarships, "business picked up," Mr. Shomber's lawyer, Steven Mason, said recently. "You need that Government money to get the students in."
Soon, that Government money began disappearing into someone's pocket at PRS. Exactly who was responsible is not clear. According to court documents, Mr. Shomber told Federal investigators he did not take it; he said his financial aid officer did. When investigators asked why he had not reported the man, Mr. Shomber explained that he was afraid to, because, he said, the financial aid officer belonged to a motorcycle gang.
Federal prosecutors concluded that the school's directors had falsified documents, including filing loan forms for former students, to obtain $107,000 unlawfully. Though the case was small, prosecutors needed two years to ready it for a grand jury.
 
Forms in Order, Yet. . .
 "It was a disaster," said Mr. Colleton, the prosecutor. "Education made so many screw-ups." The Education Department had required the school to file reams of paperwork, he said, yet no one reviewed it. "This school's 1990 recertification paperwork looked perfect on the face of it," the prosecutor said. "Yet not one student listed was eligible for aid, and Education never picked it up."
Several months ago Mr. Shomber pleaded guilty to one felony count of a 21-count indictment. The Government is unlikely to recover its money; he has filed for bankruptcy.
This is not unusual. In 1993, Federal audits of student aid programs verified $480 million in refunds that schools owed the Government; $29.8 million was recovered in 1993.
When student-aid fraud is mentioned, many people think of selfish students walking away from their financial obligations. But students are the least of the problem.
"Some of the biggest abuses within the Pell grant program are being perpetrated not so much by dishonest students, but dishonest schools," said Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat, who is chairman of the Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations. He has led several hearings on the abuses in recent years and plans more this year.
The for-profit trade schools are the main problem, a target of three-fourths of the department's enforcement activity, said Dr. David Longanecker, an Assistant Education Secretary. In the last three years, these schools, also called proprietary schools, received 25 percent of Federal student loan revenue, but they accounted for 76 percent of defaults.
 
Large-Scale Loss
One School Sees Its Fortunes Jump
 When the Government Student Loan Program was begun in 1968, 90 percent of the money went to four-year colleges; 3 percent went to trade schools. In recent years, trade schools have collected as much as 36 percent of all loan revenue and last year received 19 percent. About 5 percent of the United States' 15 million students in higher education attend trade schools.
Which brings up Case No. 2. The centerpiece of 1990 Senate hearings on Federal student-aid abuses was American Career Training Corporation, or A.C.T., a residential and correspondence school based in Pompano Beach, Fla., for training travel agents and secretaries.
Students, employees and investigators testified at the Senate hearing that the main goal of A.C.T.'s owners was to maximize Federal student loan revenue. They said the school employed only 23 instructors but 70 loan processors and 109 commissioned salespeople, who frequented welfare and food stamp offices to recruit students.
They also testified that the year before qualifying for Federal loans, A.C.T. lost $91,000, while three years after being certified, the school was collecting $46 million in Federal loan money annually for 18,000 students. Its owners, Joseph and James Calareso, paid themselves over $1 million apiece in yearly salaries.
And, they said, only 10 percent to 20 percent of A.C.T. students actually found jobs in their fields. When Federal guaranteed loans came due, regulators could not find a large percentage of the school's students because many loan forms listed phony addresses, like "403 Cant Read, Pritchard, Ala."
At the time of the 1990 hearings, the Federal Bureau of Investigation began a criminal inquiry, renting three trucks to haul away files from A.C.T.'s Pompano Beach campus.
Four years later, the inquiry continues, with no charges yet filed. A crucial reason, law-enforcement officials agree, is that the Education Department's inspector general could not free up the staff to investigate even such a high-profile case. "They're just getting back to it now," said David Buckley, a Senate investigator. "It's pathetic. This case has floundered."
Even Rebekah Poston, a defense lawyer who until recently represented A.C.T., was surprised by how poorly the Education Department has run the investigation. "It was not the amount of manpower I would have expected," she said. The school's current lawyer, Greg Baldwin, would not comment on issues raised at the hearing, except to say that witnesses had serious credibility problems. At the hearings, Joseph Calareso cited his Fifth Amendment right to remain silent.
Stephen Blair, who as president of Career College Association is the main lobbyist for trade schools, says significant efforts have been made in recent years to correct problems like those at A.C.T. and many of the worst offenders are now out of business.
 
Little Oversight
Fraud Rampant In System of Trust
 The Education Department in recent years has heavily relied on default rates as a sign of trouble, singling out these schools for more frequent reviews. But Mr. Blair says this is unfair because the higher default rates may not actually reflect corruption, but rather a school's willingness to take a chance on a poor, high-risk, inner-city population.
Government officials say there is no way to calculate what percentage of student loan defaults is due to fraud and what is a result of legitimate risk taking.
In 1993 student loan defaults cost the Government $2.5 billion, down from a high of $3.6 billion in 1991, but still alarming enough to motivate Congress and the Clinton Administration to revamp the program. Since the student loan program's inception 25 years ago, $22 billion has been lost in defaults, $14 billion of it in the last five years.
Mr. Thomas, the Education Department's inspector general, estimated that additionally "several hundred million dollars" a year is being defrauded from the $6 billion Pell grant program, and Senator Nunn said, "Based on what we've seen, if it's that amount we're fortunate."
No one knows the true figure. The taxpayers' guardians are outgunned. There are 7,400 schools certified for Federal student aid programs; the inspector general's office audited just 25 in 1993. When a case is identified as high priority, Mr. Thomas said, "it means we hope to get to it in the next year or two."
The schools presenting the biggest problems, department officials say, get almost all their revenue from these Federal aid programs and spend a fraction of that money on education, enabling their owners to walk away with large profits.
 
Opening the Coffers
 Sara Schenirer Teachers Seminary in Brooklyn is one of 21 Orthodox Jewish schools in New York State suspended from student aid programs after Senate hearings last fall. In 1991 the school collected $3.2 million in Pell grants for 1,500 students, more than doubling its enrollment in a year. It spent $21,000 on educational materials and supplies that year, according to its tax returns.
To obtain grants and loans, students send financial aid statement to a Federal processing center, which determines the students' economic need, and then notifies the school. In the case of loans, the school contacts the student's lender, which transmits the loan revenue to the school. The problem is that the lender does not have much incentive to worry about whether the student or the school is a good risk, since the Federal Government guarantees to make good on any defaulted loan.
Once a school is certified for the Pell program, it is given a "PIN" number and obtains money much the way a bank customer does from an automatic teller machine -- except in this case the bank is the Federal Government. The system has a few computer triggers to identify questionable withdrawal patterns, but it is a system based on trust; the school is wired the money up front and then has up to 21 months from semester's end to complete the paperwork justifying its withdrawals.
When auditors from the Education Department's program-review section finally arrive on the campus of a problem school, what they sometimes find is files of fictional students and fabricated biographical information, created years earlier to keep that automatic teller machine producing cash.
For some it is a way to rob a bank without a gun.
Gerardo Tirado Torres, owner of Advanced Business College in Puerto Rico, and his top officers used the school's PIN number to make at least seven improper Pell grant withdrawals totaling $3.3 million and then bought several Mercedes-Benz cars, a Volvo, a Peugeot, new businesses and real estate. Miguel Prendes, owner of Michigan Paraprofessional Training Institute, used some of the $1.1 million in Pell and loan money he stole to travel to Miami, Mexico and Europe.
An administrator in the University of Miami's athletic department, Anthony Russell, falsified Pell grant applications worth $220,000 and spent his share on a $100-to-$200-a-day crack cocaine habit. At one point, the line of swimmers, football and tennis players outside Mr. Russell's office door waiting for grant applications grew so long, extra chairs had to be placed in the hallway.
Mr. Torres, Mr. Prendes and Mr. Russell each pleaded guilty to Federal fraud charges. Mr. Torres and Mr. Prendes are serving prison sentences; Mr. Russell is to be sentenced on Feb. 18. The student athletes who lined up outside his door -- 63 of them -- were placed in a community service program and will not be charged with a crime if they complete the service.
 
Sudden Wealth at Religious Schools
 Still under investigation by Federal prosecutors are two dozen Jewish religious schools in Brooklyn and upstate New York, the newest wave of suspected abusers of Federal student aid. The schools were described in last fall's Senate hearings as "Pell mills" that siphoned off much of their student-aid revenue to pay for the Orthodox Hasidic sects' religious operations here and in Israel.
In the 1988-89 school year, Sara Schenirer seminary received 51 Pell scholarships worth $105,000. That year on its Federal income tax return, in the section that asks for names of all employees earning more than $30,000, the school listed no one. By 1991-92 Sara Schenirer had jumped to $3.2 million in Pell grants and could list four officials' salaries on the tax form, including the director, Rabbi Michael Meisels ($69,000), and his wife ($42,400). It also listed $1.3 million in mutual funds. And the school, which specializes in religious education courses, was able to pay off its $650,000 mortgage.
The school is appealing its suspension from Federal programs. Michael Goldstein, its lawyer, said that once a school is approved for Pell grants and provides the coursework, Federal law does not restrict how it invests its money or pays its staff. "As the institution grew," he said, "administrative complexity grew, and people involved were paid a wage commensurate with their responsibilities." It was not necessary to spend more than the $21,000 on school supplies in 1992 because larger investments had been made in earlier years, he said.
Bais Fruma, another Brooklyn school, offered independent study courses with no classrooms, teachers, books or supplies, Senate witnesses said. In 10 years the Brooklyn school collected $22 million in Pell grants; in 1992, 97 percent of its 2,000 students received Pells. Alan Edelman, a Senate investigator, testified that Bais Fruma's treasurer and financial aid director filed 700 currency transaction reports reflecting bank withdrawals and deposits of over $10,000 each in the last five years.
"We cannot explain these transactions at this time," Mr. Edelman said. "However, we do feel that they are very unusual transactions for employees of a nonprofit tax exempt religious organization."
Calls to the school were not returned. Bais Fruma was recently terminated from Federal aid programs.
 
Easy Target
'Invitation' to Take Federal Money
 At the hearings on the Pell program last fall, Senator Nunn commented to the inspector general, "It is a program that is almost an invitation for people who are not honest to rip it off, isn't it?"
"That is right," answered Mr. Thomas.
Once a problem school gets its privileges to withdraw money from the Government, the chances of the Government's recouping its money are slim.
In 1987, the Education Department began investigating Continental Training Service, a national trucking school chain based in Indianapolis. Virtually all the school's $64 million annual budget came from Federal scholarships and loans. In 1988, the department filed a lawsuit alleging that Continental's training programs were of poor quality, were justified with falsified documentation and should never have qualified for the $117 million in Federal aid the school received. The lawsuit sought $360 million in refunds and damages.
In December 1992 the department settled its $360 million case with Continental, by then in bankruptcy, for $50,000.
Dr. Longanecker, a Clinton appointee who last June became the assistant secretary overseeing student aid, says he believes that the worst of these problems are in the past. He points to the decrease in student loan defaults, to $2.5 billion from $3.6 billion over the last two years.
Major gains will be achieved by making better use of computer monitoring, he says, adding that the department will take advantage of new enforcement tools provided by the 1992 Education Act, like more stringent standards for new schools wanting to participate in aid programs and tougher oversight by state regulators.
Senator Nunn agrees there have been improvements but said, "The default rate is still way too high." At the hearings, Mr. Thomas, who has been inspector general since the Education Department was elevated to Cabinet level in 1980, was asked whether he was skeptical of the new Assistant Secretary's assessment. "Absolutely," he answered.
Mr. Colleton, the Orlando prosecutor in the case involving the school with the motorcycle-gang member as a financial aid officer, said: "The Government's being had. And the public doesn't understand what's going on."
The owner of that school, Mr. Shomber, told investigators that his financial aid officer suddenly disappeared on May 8, 1990. Prosecutors have not been able to locate the gentleman either, and he has not been charged with any wrongdoing. Mr. Shomber hired another financial officer, but it turned out she was wanted by the police on a charge of passing bad checks. "One day she was arrested out in the school parking lot on an outstanding warrant," said Mr. Shomber's lawyer, Mr. Mason.
The 66-year-old Mr. Shomber was sentenced to three years probation last summer and ordered to make restitution. His lawyer describes him as a decent man who got in over his head. "He's completely out of the education business now," his lawyer said. "This has been hard on him. He had to sell his home. He's in bankruptcy. I think all he has is the '76 Cadillac I see him driving around town in."

HEADLINE: CLINTON REPORTED TO BE READY TO END VIETNAM EMBARGO

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
President Clinton plans to lift the 19-year trade embargo on Vietnam within a few days, senior Administration officials said today.
While the President has not yet formally signified his assent, a senior Administration official said Mr. Clinton had concluded that the time had come to begin normalizing relations with Vietnam by taking the highly sensitive step of resuming trade. Mr. Clinton's avoidance of military service during the Vietnam War adds to the political peril. 
 A second senior official said: "It's a done deal. The President has made up his mind."
It could not be learned whether the United States had informed the Government of Vietnam of its decision.
 
No White House Confirmation
 The President is also expected to approve the opening of a formal liaison office in Hanoi to help American business ventures there, a senior State Department official said. The United States has only a very low-level diplomatic office in Hanoi now and a recently opened military mission to deal with the issue of service personnel missing since the Vietnam War.
White House aides refused to provide confirmation of the end of the embargo, and other Administration officials said there was a reluctance to make an announcement until veterans' groups and others opposed to the decision had been briefed.
John Sommer, executive director of the American Legion, called the impending decision a betrayal of Mr. Clinton's past promises to veterans and family groups.
 
A Betrayal, Legion Says
 "If the President decides now to lift the trade embargo on Vietnam," he said, "he will have broken the promises made to the American Legion, the family members of missing servicemen and other Vietnam veterans, and he will have betrayed those who are missing and their families.
"As a candidate for President, he told the delegates to the 1992 national convention of the American Legion, in essence, that he would not lift the embargo or move toward normalization until the fullest possible accounting of our P.O.W.'s and M.I.A.'s had been received."
 
Announcement Within Days
 Administration officials said tonight that Mr. Clinton hoped to make his announcement by the end of the week. But they cautioned that it could slip until early next week, depending on how long it takes to consult with opponents of the move.
"It's just a timing thing," an Administration official said.
The reported decision follows months of debate within the Administration on whether Vietnam had cooperated fully in determining the fate of more than 2,200 United States service personnel who are still officially listed as missing in the war, which ended in 1975.
At a meeting at the White House in late December, senior officials reached a broad consensus that the embargo should be lifted. But Mr. Clinton held off making a final decision until his Administration could take the political temperature of Capitol Hill and public opinion.
 
Senate Resolution Helped
 Mr. Clinton's decision was made much easier when the Senate voted Friday, at the Administration's urging, to ask that the embargo be lifted. The vote was 62 to 38.
After an emotionally charged debate about the lessons of Vietnam and the fate of the missing, a majority agreed with the bill's chief sponsor, John F. Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat and Vietnam veteran, that it was time "to put the war behind us."
Although the resolution is not binding, it enjoyed broad bipartisan support and gave the President sufficient political cover to close a chapter on the war, in which more than 58,000 Americans died.
Mr. Clinton, who has made the economic security of the United States a pillar of his foreign policy, had come under increasing pressure from business executives to end the embargo so they can compete with Europeans and Japanese who have been scrambling to secure business in Vietnam.
 
'Time to Move Forward'
 Senator John S. McCain, an Arizona Republican and a navy pilot who was shot down over Vietnam and imprisoned for almost six years, said tonight that ending the embargo would be "a natural consequence of the vote in the Senate, which gave the President sufficient political cover to move forward."
"And I think it's appropriate," Senator McCain went on. "I think it's an appropriate time to move forward and I think it's in the United States' national interest to have an economically strong Vietnam as a counterweight to the growing economic and military strength of China.
"I think it will help rather than hinder our efforts to obtain further accounting of the M.I.A.'s. And more importantly than that, perhaps, the Vietnamese are in compliance with the road map that the Bush Administration laid down for them."
 
'It's Wrong'
 But Senator Robert C. Smith, a New Hampshire Republican who has made the cause of the missing service personnel the focus of his Senate career, said it was wrong to lift the embargo.
Mr. Smith, one of the most outspoken Senators on the issue, said: "We do not have a full accounting, we have not been provided all the information that the Vietnamese can unilaterally provide us. Now it's 'lift and hope,' hope that the Vietnamese by their good graces will give us that answer. I do not agree with that.
"I just think that it's wrong to reward the Vietnamese for the 20 years of intransigence, when they have grudgingly given us 200 sets of remains, when all the intelligence we have shows that they're holding back. I just don't think that the Vietnamese should be rewarded for that.
"He wanted to do it all along," Mr. Smith said of the President. "Now he has the political cover.
"I think it's a mistake and I regret it, but I lost the fight and I know when I'm whipped. The only problem is I think the families lost as well."
 
Political To and Fro
 After the Senate vote, it became only a matter of time before the President would make the announcement.
The Administration had debated lifting the embargo since Mr. Clinton came into office. During the debate, the Administration offered Vietnam incentives to for its cooperation on the M.I.A. issue, while pressing for still more assistance in finding air crash sites, remains and documents related to the missing.
For weeks, White House officials have made no secret that Mr. Clinton was leaning toward lifting the embargo. But they had also expressed concern about opposition from veteran's groups, and acknowledged that Mr. Clinton's avoidance of military service could leave him open to particularly harsh criticism.
But the mood changed sharply after Winston Lord, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, returned from Vietnam in December with a favorable report on Hanoi's increased cooperation.
In a Dec. 21 briefing, a senior State Department official said Mr. Lord's trip had proved that "Clinton's policies have paid off and we have made progress."
 
A Year's Worth of Pressure
 Referring to the situation since Mr. Clinton came into office, the official added, "We have had a high degree of cooperation from Vietnam, whether it is measured in the numbers of remains returned, which is about the third-highest since the war; the documents that we have been provided, the files we haven't gotten to before."
While some officials urged that the White House take more time in sounding out likely critics, the stronger view among Mr. Clinton's advisers was that he should move quickly.
Among the gestures Mr. Clinton made toward Vietnam was ending Washington's opposition to development loans by the World Bank and modifying the embargo to allow United States companies to bid on projects.
Even after the Senate vote, in which 42 Democrats and 20 Republicans voted to end the embargo, the White House was cautious on predicting what the President would decide.
 
Always, the M.I.A. Issue
 Asked about the vote last week, Dee Dee Myers, the White House spokeswoman, said, "We welcome the Senate's sentiment on that," but added that the Administration was still considering whether Vietnam had made sufficient progress toward providing information about M.I.A.'s.
And Mr. Clinton put himself into a political box by telling family members of service personnel still unaccounted for that their fate was a "moral" issue.
As recently as Dec. 10, Mr. Clinton wrote to Senator Smith, the New Hampshire Republican, that he was "deeply committed to resolving the cases of all personnel missing since the Vietnam war."
"For this reason," the President wrote, "I have made achieving the fullest possible accounting for our P.O.W./M.I.A.'s the test of our relationship with Vietnam. Like you, I seek an honorable solution to this issue."
But that was before Mr. Lord made his tide-turning trip to Vietnam.
 
A Final Warning
 A senior Administration official cautioned that the lifting of the embargo did not mean that Washington would rush to restore diplomatic relations, which he said would not enjoy widespread domestic support and would not be an appropriate signal to send to the Vietnamese.
"No one is talking about normalization,"the official said.
The United States imposed the embargo against North Vietnam in 1964 and extended it to cover all of Vietnam after the fall of the South Vietnamese Government on April 30, 1975. The President of the United States has always had the authority to lift it by executive order.
