HEADLINE: Clintons Campaigning to Scuttle Endorsement of Rival Health Plan

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Senior Administration officials started an intense lobbying campaign today, including a White House meeting between business leaders and Hillary Rodham Clinton, to derail a potentially damaging show of support for a health care plan competing with their own.
While President Clinton met today with hospital officials and governors to promote his plan, his top aides sought to persuade members of the influential Business Roundtable not to back a less comprehensive one sponsored by Representative Jim Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee. The Cooper plan, unlike the President's, does not require employers to pay any of the costs of their employees' health insurance. 
 The policy committee of the Roundtable is scheduled to vote on the competing health care plans on Wednesday. The Roundtable, established in 1972, consists of chief executives from 200 companies, including A.T.& T., I.B.M. and Pepsico.
The White House charge is being led by Mrs. Clinton, who has been meeting with business leaders for weeks. She has been joined by Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the White House chief of staff; Roger C. Altman, the Deputy Treasury Secretary; Robert E. Rubin, the chairman of the National Economic Council, and Alexis Herman, who runs the White House Office of Public Liaison.
Executives of large corporations have objected to the breadth of the Clinton proposal, which they say could slow the economy because of its high cost and could give the Government too big a role in the private health care system. They have also been skeptical of its financing, which would rely on taxes and savings from a predicted reduction in the growth of Medicare.
"We're not asking them to endorse our plan," said a senior Administration official who took part in the White House meeting today, which was attended by about a dozen members of the Business Roundtable. "We're asking them to keep their powder dry. That's it."
White House officials are hoping to keep the business leaders neutral in the health care battle so they will not devote resources and political muscle to portraying the Clinton plan as unworkable.
"We're simply saying that it is too early to engage the dialogue of one bill over another bill," a White House official said. "We want the Congressional process, which is just getting started, to have time to lay our course."
As officials worked the phones today, several others, including Harold M. Ickes, the deputy chief of staff; George Stephanopoulos, the senior policy adviser, and Pat Griffin, the Congressional liaison, went to Capitol Hill for a dinner meeting with business leaders arranged by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means Committee.
Among those chief executives at the afternoon meeting in the Roosevelt Room of the White House were Edgar S. Woolard of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, Robert L. Crandall of American Airlines and Joseph T. Gorman of TRW.
"They're all making tactical decisions," the official said of the executives. "I don't think any of them want the Cooper plan as it is. They're trying to figure out whether it's tactically intelligent to start there."
The White House offensive underscores the delicacy of the moment for President Clinton, who is trying to shore up support among his natural allies and dampen any opposition before it has a chance to solidify. Business groups have proved to be a valuable ally for the President on issues like deficit reduction but they could support an expensive campaign against him if they chose to.
A spokeswoman for the Business Roundtable would not comment on the organization's position today, but in meetings over the last several weeks, several business leaders whose companies already provide generous benefits to their own employees have told Administration officials that they are troubled by the Clinton plan's approach. They say it relies too heavily on Government regulation and bureaucracy and might prove too costly for businesses.
In a preliminary tally last month, the policy committee of the Business Roundtable, which has the final say on policy for the group, voted 45 to 14 to support the Cooper bill as "the starting point for health care reform."
 
Provisions of Cooper Plan
 Mr. Cooper's plan would establish purchasing cooperatives to reduce the cost of insurance coverage but would not require employers to pay for it. Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, introduced a companion bill in the Senate.
"They've got the big guns," Mr. Cooper said. "I don't even have a pea shooter in this debate. All I've got is a good bill."
In response to such arguments, Mr. Clinton has sought to emphasize that his plan is not a Government solution, that alternatives will cost state governments more and that those who have suggested that a health care crisis does not exist or must be solved incrementally are out of touch with reality.
"You know that the most complex system that could ever be designed is not the one in the Administration's bill," Mr. Clinton said to a meeting of the American Hospital Association. "It's the one you're living with right now."
Lisa Caputo, Mrs. Clinton's press secretary, said the meeting today was part of an effort to sway business leaders on elements of the health care plan. But the Administration has stepped up its efforts to signal compromise. Governors who met with Mr. Clinton on Monday said he had suggested that he was willing to relax provisions that call for the establishment of regional purchasing alliances.
Those signals irked even some of Mr. Clinton's most loyal supporters. Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, a West Virginia Democrat who is a member of the Senate Finance Committee, said that Mr. Clinton's comments, as relayed by governors leaving the meeting, were "not particularly helpful."
But Mr. Clinton is playing on a bigger stage these days, engaging in an escalating war of words with members of Congress, including Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, and Mr. Cooper, over the scope of his health care plan.
"Our approach is not to tell you how to deliver health care, not to build barriers or bureaucracy," Mr. Clinton told the American Hospital Association today. "What we want to do is establish a framework in which people are covered, provide the right incentives, help to remove the barriers to access and get out of the way."
 
'Tinkering' With Reform
 In his public remarks today, Mr. Clinton dismissed many of the disputes that have sprung up around his health care plan as "linguistic battle" and an effort for less courageous politicians to "tinker at the edges" of reform.
But Mr. Clinton is reassessing some of his language as well, emphasizing the need for "guaranteed private insurance" instead of "universal coverage." Last week, Mr. Clinton vowed to veto any health care bill that did not provide universal coverage, and his opponents have suggested that the White House is promoting a complicated and bureaucratic Government remedy.
Mr. Dole, who has aimed many of the harshest broadsides at the Administration plan in recent weeks, sounded distinctly more conciliatory today. Speaking to the National Governors Association meeting before Mr. Clinton arrived, he said there was a "growing consensus" among Republicans and Democrats about the need for a restructured health care system.
On Monday, the governors endorsed a proposal that falls short of the Administration's plan. While calling for core benefits to be made available for employees who wish to buy insurance coverage, the governors could not agree on whether employers should be responsible for paying part of that cost.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. HEAD DEFENDS RUSSIA LOAN POLICY AGAINST CRITICISM

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
The head of the International Monetary Fund complained today that his institution was being made a "scapegoat" by the Russians, Western governments and various experts for Russia's faltering economic reform effort. He said the responsibility lies with the Russians themselves.
In a rare public defense, the I.M.F.'s managing director, Michel Camdessus, summoned reporters to deliver a feisty rebuttal to charges that his organization has been unrealistic or too slow in negotiating with the Russian Government the terms for more Western aid. 
 The Fund, which has provided Russia with $2.5 billion in loans since 1992, has been holding up an additional $1.5 billion loan until Russia adopts more measures to control inflation and the runaway Government budget.
 
A Lack of Basic Data
 Mr. Camdessus insisted that the I.M.F. has bent over backward to maintain a constant dialogue with Moscow. The problem, he said, is with Russia's leaders, who too often have not been willing to impose the sort of basic economic policies that would justify further I.M.F. assistance or even to show up at meetings with the most basic economic data needed to negotiate loans.
If the amounts of promised Western aid have fallen short of the amounts actually delivered, said Mr. Camdessus, "it is essentially because Russia has not been in a position to deliver the policies Russia has committed to adopt."
Critics of the I.M.F. say otherwise. After the Russian elections in December demonstrated the strength of anti-reform forces, Vice President Al Gore lambasted the fund for being too tough on the Russians and thereby helping to bring about a nationalist backlash.
 
Criticism by Sachs
 Jeffery Sachs, a Harvard economist and a former adviser to the Russian Government, published several criticisms of the I.M.F., saying that it has been far too timid, averse to risk and just plain slow in mobilizing aid for Russia to bolster the reformers. And on Monday, Administration officials said that the I.M.F. had not met regularly enough with Russian officials.
"We have not engaged enough the Russian authorities?" asked Mr. Camdessus, with more than a hint of exasperation. "This is the latest of the criticism I hear about, and I see that criticism change according to the circumstances. From time to time I ask myself: 'Which will be the next one in order to kill the scapegoat?' "
"We have been permanently in dialogue with the Russian authorities, taking every occasion to exchange information with them.
"One of our frustrations," added Mr. Camdessus, "is that in many, many occasions our invitation to the dialogue has been just turned down or the basic data which were needed to discuss seriously were just not provided" by the Russians.
"How can you discuss the balance of payments of 1994 when you don't have the balance of payments of 1993?" he asked. "I don't want to harshly criticize the Russian authorities. We are possibly more knowledgeable than many commentators of their difficulties, because they just don't have the administration, the people, the basic knowledge."
"But to tell us that we have not worked with them is to ignore the reality in Moscow," he said.
 
First Major Loan
 Much of the I.M.F.'s initial $2.5 billion in loans was delivered almost immediately after Mr. Yeltsin won a referendum on his presidency in April 1993 and started speeding up the privatization of the Russian economy.
What is now being asked of the I.M.F. is to provide Russia with another $1.5 billion promised by the Group of Seven industrial democracies to help the Government there stabilize the ruble, pay for imports and restructure some antiquated industries. The big Western democracies use the I.M.F., which they control, to provide the jumbo loans to Russia that their individual governments would not want to undertake on their own.
The I.M.F. and the World Bank have been entrusted with negotiating with Moscow the conditions for the disbursal of about half the $28.4 billion in grants and loans pledged by the Group of Seven for Russia last July.
Mr. Camdessus said that the I.M.F. would not back down on its conditions for providing latest $1.5 billion installment. Those terms include Russia getting its inflation rate down to about 10 percent a month, half the current level. The I.M.F. also insists on a reduction of government subsidies to inefficient state industries, a phase-out of price controls, privatization of state companies and a reduction of the budget deficit, now running around 8 percent of Russia's gross domestic product.
 
'Appropriate' Policies
 Mr. Camdessus said that according to its bylaws, the I.M.F. can "only extend financing conditional on appropriate economic policies." If there is a desire to "provide assistance unconditionally," he added, Governments can do that directly on their own, but "for us, the amount of assistance will depend on progress with economic reforms."
A new I.M.F. mission began work in Moscow today to hammer out with the Russian Government the economic policies that would enable the fund to grant the pending $1.5 billion. But Mr. Camdessus said he is not optimistic given Moscow's willingness to print more money to support state-owned industries and to tolerate an inflation rate of about 20 percent a month.
"What we hear from the new Government -- and every day we have new statements of one or the other -- seems somewhat new or distanced from the course of reform on which we agreed with the previous government," he said. "But we are of an open mind to address these issues."
If there is one reason for the failure of reform in Russia so far, Mr. Camdessus said, it is the absence of "that basic minimal consensus" between the Russian Parliament and Government over how to proceed.
 
Stabilizing the Ruble
 "We all know that without adequately strong monetary and budgetary policies," he said, "no efforts to reduce inflation and stabilize the ruble will be successful for long."
The Russian Government provides huge subsidies to state-owned industries, in part because they provide social services, health care and even clothing for their workers. The Government is afraid to take away the subsidies because it does not want to leave the public without a social safety net and because these state-owned industries are a powerful lobby. The I.M.F. is urging Russia to halt the subsidies, use some of the savings to close the budget deficit and use the rest to assist the jobless with unemployment insurance, pensions and job retraining funds.

HEADLINE: Economic Quarrels Retake the Spotlight in Japan

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Japan's Government pulled itself back from the brink last week by passing landmark political reform legislation after a bitter five-year struggle, but the success only cleared the way for a battle on a potentially even more complex and divisive issue -- reviving the economy.
Some top Cabinet members have already clashed over the matter, with the Prime Minister scolding his chief Cabinet secretary in public on Monday in a dispute over tax policy. 
 Adding to the problems is the fact that the Clinton Administration has taken sides, making it clear that it favors strong action from Tokyo to pull the economy out of its worst recession in the postwar era. A recovery would be likely to reduce Japan's trade surplus, which has soared to record levels in the last two years, straining Tokyo's relations with Washington.
 
Heading for Washington
 With Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa scheduled to meet President Clinton in Washington on Feb. 11, and trade likely to dominate their talks, there is a great sense of urgency to the debate that is expected to unfold over the next 10 days.
While the list of difficulties is a long one, the stock market expressed its delight that at least the Government was finally addressing the economic slowdown after months of neglect.
In the first two days of the week, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks jumped a total of 1,658.46 points, or 8.8 percent. Monday's gain for the Nikkei was its fourth-highest on record in terms of percentage, an extraordinary rise of 1,471.24 points, or 7.84 percent, to 20,229.12. Some profit taking set in today, traders said, and the Nikkei closed down 166.31 points, or about eight tenths of 1 percent, at 20,250.03.
The Government has lost no time in setting out the battle lines. Nearly everyone agrees that a huge emergency package of tax cuts and public- works spending is required. The news media have been filled with reports that the total package could amount to as much as 16 trillion yen, the equivalent of $146 billion -- which would come on top of $260 billion of similar emergency packages enacted over the last 18 months.
But there is little agreement yet on how to finance such a package. The more conservative members of Mr. Hosokawa's coalition Government have insisted that any income tax cut must be offset by an increase in the 3 percent national sales tax, perhaps after a delay of a year or so.
 Behind this approach is a fear of running up large Government budget deficits, a concern that is prevalent at the Finance Ministry.
The Socialists, the largest party in the coalition, have insisted that a big sales tax increase would fall disproportionately on salaried workers, and that the Government should just incur a deficit to be covered by the sale of bonds.
The United States has said there should be no increase in the sales tax, or at least not an immediate increase, because that would all but negate the benefits of the income tax reduction. The Americans say that since the Japanese Government has been running budget surpluses in recent years, there is plenty of room to use deficit spending to stimulate the economy.
The Finance Ministry issued a lengthy statement to foreign reporters on Monday to counter Washington's arguments, point by point.
 
Reworking the Numbers
 It argued, for instance, that Japan only had a budget surplus if contributions to its social security fund were added in -- something the United States Government does not do in its accounting. Without those funds, Japan actually has a proportionally larger budget deficit than the United States, the ministry said.
Japan's deficit will equal 5.5 percent of the gross domestic product this year, the ministry said, compared with 3.6 percent in the United States.
"They don't appreciate the extent of the deterioration of Japan's fiscal balance," a senior ministry official said, referring to American officials.
The official, who insisted on anonymity, acknowledged that the ministry had been wrong in its forecast that the economy would begin to recover last spring or summer.
But, he said, in a sort of trial run of what the Government was likely to be explaining to President Clinton on Feb. 11, the fiscal package being discussed should be sufficient to finally get economic growth back on track.

HEADLINE: Ecuadorean Nominated as U.N.'s New Human Rights Chief

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 1

 BODY:
The United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali today nominated Ecuador's representative, Jose Ayala Lasso, to be the first United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, a post created by the General Assembly last year.
But his choice dismayed several American human rights monitoring organizations who said Mr. Lasso lacked experience and served as Foreign Minister under the repressive military Government that ruled Ecuador in the late 1970's 
 "The challenge for Ayala Lasso will be to prove he can overcome his past as an official of an abusive military government and become a forceful advocate for human rights" said Kenneth Roth, executive director of the Human Rights Watch, based in New York.
Charles Norchi, director of the International League for Human Rights, also drew attention to Mr. Lasso's service under Ecuador's military government and said he must be "a vocal champion in the cause of human dignity otherwise the office of High Commissioner will become marginalized."
 
'Denigrated Human Rights'
 Reed Brody of the International Human Rights Group in Washington who was spokesman for over 3,000 private human rights groups at the United Nations World Human Rights Conference in Vienna in 1992, which called for the post's creation, said the Secretary General has "denigrated human rights by appointing someone who will need on-the-job training" because the General Assembly resolution requires him to nominate someone with human rights "expertise."
But the United States Representative to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, supported the choice, saying that as chairman of the General Assembly's Third Committee, which deals with human rights issues, Ambassador Lasso played a key role in crafting the resolution that created "this vital position" and repeatedly demonstrated his "commitment to the protection of universal human rights."
The Clinton Administration, she said, will give him "our full cooperation and support."
As first High Commissioner for Human Rights, Mr. Lasso faces a difficult task because the United Nations showed during last year's General Assembly debate that it is deeply divided over what the job should be.
 
Powers of Office Debated
 Many developing world governments, already angered by the West's growing insistence that they meet its standards of human rights and democracy as the price for economic assistance, sought to limit his powers to initiate independent inquiries saying he should only carry out tasks given him by United Nations organizations on which they are represented.
But human rights advocates and most Western governments want the new High Commissioner to play a more active role, investigating alleged abuses on his own initiative in between the annual sessions of the Human Rights Commission and pressing offending governments to mend their ways.
In a news conference today, the Secretary General also said he was appointing Hans Axel Valdemar Corell, a Swedish lawyer, as his legal adviser and named a French officer, Gen. Bertrand Guillaume de Sauville de Lapresle, as new commander of the peacekeeping force in the former Yugoslavia. But he has not yet found a successor for Jan Eliasson of Sweden, who resigned last week as the United Nations' first relief aid coordinator, or for the American official Melissa Wells, whom he fired as his director of management and budget after a year on the job.

HEADLINE: In Mexico's Poor South, Coffee Now Blights Lives

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EL NUEVO MOMON, Mexico

 BODY:
Across the remote highlands of Mexico's deep south, where pine trees seem to snag the clouds and Indian rebels maintain a stronghold, unharvested coffee berries are turning wine dark and rotting.
The coffee is a casualty of the violent uprising that began in Chiapas State on Jan. 1. Poor farmers have been too afraid to enter their fields to harvest the crop and some have even fled the wooden shacks they call home. 
 "We had to sacrifice everything -- our pigs, our chickens, our coffee," said Misael Perez de Leon, who has taken refuge in a coffee warehouse in Comitan, near the Guatemalan border, with his wife and six children.
 
An End to Controls
 But coffee growing in this region, which once offered the promise of a better life, has in recent years made life hard for the peasants. Their anger and frustration contributed to the rebellion.
As recently as five years ago, international coffee prices were rising and the Mexican Government encouraged the people of the region to move into the forests and plant thousands of coffee bushes. The future looked so assured that in 1989 the Government dismantled its huge system of controls, saying it no longer needed to be involved.
But within months prices collapsed and the people here suddenly felt abandoned.
"They have hardly helped us at all," said Humberto Velasco, a 25-year-old coffee farmer in El Nuevo Momon, 40 miles east of Comitan, asserting further that the Government was indifferent to most needs of the poor. "The schools, the medical care, everything is less than we need. And now practically the entire harvest is lost."
 
Victims of the Changes
 Many of the Indians who took up arms in January are believed to have come from the dirt-poor regions that were encouraged to plant coffee and then were left on their own. They view themselves as victims of the very economic changes that President Carlos Salinas de Gortari had once pushed to help them.
Other Government policies, which were intended to make it easier for the wealthier people to accumulate land and grow coffee and other products more efficiently, also caused economic anxiety here. But the way coffee has raised expectations and dashed hopes may be the best example of why the people here have directed their anger at the Salinas administration.
The economic pressures have made life in the isolated coffee-producing communities a constant struggle. Some field-workers joined the revolt to fight for a better life. Some stayed, giving their sympathies to the rebels. Still others packed their few belongings and headed down the road, refugees from violence and deprivation.
Even the Government's top officials now concede that coffee is in crisis. Some experts estimate that 20 to 30 percent of this year's crop has been lost because of the war. If the conflict drags on, and more producers abandon their crops, it could be worse.
Corn is the staple of the Mexican diet, but in Chiapas coffee has been the crop of dreams, encouraged by land and credits made easily available by the Government.
 
Most Live in Poverty
 Chiapas is Mexico's poorest state and also its leading coffee producer. Sixty percent of the 72,000 coffee producers in Chiapas are Indians and as many still live in extreme poverty.
One of those facing difficulties is Mr. Perez de Leon, a 35-year-old coffee grower with six acres and 3,000 coffee plants, who contends that coffee is still a good crop, better than any other for making money.
But last year was a very bad year. After all costs were accounted for, he ended up making just 1,000 pesos -- about $320, or less than a dollar a day. By the time he harvested his coffee the money was already gone; he had taken out credits on his crop earlier in the year to buy food.
He lives about 60 unpaved miles from Comitan in San Jose de la Revancha, a community of field-workers called an ejido that is a legacy of the land reform goals of Emiliano Zapata, the Mexican revolutionary leader. After the revolution, the Government promised to break up large landholdings and give small parcels to poor farmers, a process that has been going on for 50 years.
But in Chiapas large landholders have managed to keep control, and this has led to endless conflicts and periodic violence, of which the uprising in January was the latest chapter. About 30 percent of the unresolved land disputes in all of Mexico are in Chiapas.
[In a communique from the delivered to reporters on Feb. 1 in San Cristobal de las Casas, rebel leaders said that peace talks were imminent but that neither a time nor a place had been set.]
 
 
Small Plots in a Harsh Land
 Despite their dreams, few if any peasants have ever made much money growing coffee. Another harsh reality of Mexican agriculture saw to that: most of the land is hilly and unproductive, and most farms are small. More than two million people in Mexico grow coffee and most barely make a living. Seventy percent of coffee producers have less than four acres of land each and produce only about 30 percent of the yearly crop of 275,000 tons. Larger, more efficient farms produce the rest.
Still, the poor somehow scraped by, encouraged by a Government that viewed coffee as an export crop that could bring in foreign exchange -- nearly $600 million in 1989. Forested land was turned into ejidos and given to poor coffee producers, and later the Government pushed organically grown coffee, for which buyers pay higher prices.
The dismantling of controls in 1989 was part of a much-applauded effort by Mr. Salinas's administration to sell off state-owned businesses and end Government intervention in the economy.
For the previous 30 years, the Mexican Institute of Coffee had warehoused, processed and merchandized the farmers' coffee, and since 1973 had also provided credits and loans. After 1989, most of those functions were ended or turned over to the private sector.
Few people mourned the institute's demise because Government agents had often cheated small farmers. But people suffered because of the loss of safeguards as the privatization took place and coffee prices tumbled.
The Government did not completely abandon the poor farmers. But the few programs that replaced the Mexican Institute of Coffee -- including part of Solidarity, Mr. Salinas's cherished antipoverty program -- provided only a small percentage of what had been available before.
 
Away From the Violence
 People are leaving because life is bleak and the violence has been uncomfortably close. Candido Santiz Lopez took his wife and family away from his communal farm at El Nuevo Momon after he heard bombs dropping and his three children crying.
Even though his wife, Zenaida, was almost ready to give birth to their fourth child, he still thought it best to go. They walked west, away from the deep forest, hoping to find help. After camping on the side of the road for three days, a truck took them to the same warehouse in Comitan where Mr. Perez de Leon and more than 100 other coffee growers and their families have sought refuge.
Last Wednesday, after 15 days at the warehouse, Mr. Santiz Lopez and his wife returned to El Nuevo Momon, carrying the 4-day-old baby girl who had been born in the coffee warehouse and still did not have a name.
Expressionless except for the deep fatigue of the dislocated, he walked down the rocky path to his mother's house. He had no money, not a centavo, and the only food he had was a few packages of pasta and a sack of animal-shaped cookies given him by a relief agency.
 
'Everything Else Is Good'
 His coffee beans were rotting in the fields -- the rains had seen to that. Someone -- rebels belonging to the Zapatista National Liberation Army? Federal soldiers? Resentful neighbors? He does not know -- had stolen a pig, a few chickens and a corn-grinding stone.
"But everything else is good," he said. "It's good. Now I want to have something to eat."
Every one of the 117 families in El Nuevo Momon lives on coffee. By this time of year, when the afternoon sun warms the air to 75 degrees or more, blankets of beans should be drying on every porch or on top of the concrete patios made for that purpose. Mr. Santiz Lopez's brother Mario has managed to pick half a small basket, but when army helicopters buzz overhead, looking for guerrillas, everyone hurries home.

HEADLINE: State Dept. Castigates China on Rights Record

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
The Administration issued its long-awaited critique of China's human rights record today, painting a grim tableau of political prisoners, torture and forced confessions. The report outlined a long road that it said Beijing must travel to have its preferred trading status renewed this year.
As expected, the State Department's annual review found that China's "overall human rights record in 1993 fell far short of internationally accepted norms as it continued to repress domestic critics and failed to control abuses by its own security forces." 
 Department officials had made it clear weeks ago that the report would be highly critical. But although the report found that China had made some progress, the criticism was even tougher than many human rights experts had expected. Some said it left President Clinton little room to renew China's trade status, a step that has been advocated by some in the Administration.
 
'Much More Is Necessary'
 The 3,000-page report, which is not yet available to the public, surveys 193 countries. But State Department officials acknowledged that they had paid special attention to China because one of Mr. Clinton's most important foreign policy decisions this year -- whether to renew China's preferred trading status -- turns on whether Beijing shows significant progress on human rights.
Pointing out that Beijing has freed some political prisoners, Timothy E. Wirth, State Department Counselor, who oversees human rights policy, said: "Limited progress was made in 1993. More progress was made in early 1994." But, he added, "much more significant progress is going to be necessary."
The report and the official comments appeared to be intended in part to turn up the heat on China to improve its human rights performance before the President decides in June whether to extend its most-favored-nation trade status. Some senior officials worry that denying Beijing the trade privileges would be an economic disaster for China and the United States alike.
 
Tying Rights to Economics
 In recent weeks members of the Administration and Congress who are alarmed at the prospect of sanctions against China have suggested that the annual review of its trade status be dropped, breaking the link between human rights and economics.
But Administration officials, noting that the report looked only at last year's events, were quick to assert that the jury is still out, especially in light of some of Beijing's recent moves. China recently promised to release two Tibetan political prisoners and to let the Red Cross visit jails and labor camps.
Assuming the role of watchdog for human rights around the world, the State Department had lots of criticism for dozens of other countries, including Mexico, Israel and Saudi Arabia. The report was highly critical of Syria and especially Iraq and Iran.
"Iraq's abysmal record on human rights did not improve in 1993," the report said, in describing mass executions and the widespread use of torture. The report said Iran's Islamic Government continues to reinforce its hold on power through arrests, summary trials, executions and assassinations.
 
A Look at Bosnia
 This year's report, like last year's, condemned Serbs for pursuing their policy of "ethnic cleansing" in Bosnia, and included lesser criticisms of the Croatian and Muslim factions in the Bosnian war.
Accusing the Bosnian Serbs of "acts of genocide," the report lambasted them for fire-bombing mosques, raping and threatening to rape Muslim women and killing and mutilating civilians.
But some foreign policy experts criticized the report for describing the Bosnia situation in less urgent terms than were used in last year's report.
"This is nothing short of a political dodge by the Administration," said Marshall Freeman Harris, executive director of the Action Council for Peace in the Balkans. "It hopes the genocide and horror in Bosnia will simply go away." Mr. Harris resigned from the State Department in August to protest its policy in Bosnia.
 
Other Key Areas
 Other sections of the report dealt with these countries:
MEXICO The State Department said that while human rights violations had declined, the security forces "continued to commit serious human rights violations," with numerous prisoners killed in custody. Security forces torture prisoners with beatings, asphyxiation and electric shocks, but the National Commission for Human Rights is working, with mixed results, to end these violations, the report added.
ISRAEL The State Department said there were credible reports that Israel had mistreated and in some cases tortured Palestinians during interrogation, and had used undercover units disguised as Palestinians to kill 27 Palestinians last year. Pointing to some improvement in human rights, the report noted that 49 Israeli soldiers and civilians had died in attacks in the territories.
SAUDI ARABIA Reports continue that Saudi authorities torture and abuse detainees, including some women. Defendants are tried in closed courtrooms, without lawyers. "The Government's failure to punish human rights abuses is a salient factor in the climate of impunity that prevails," the State Department said.
SYRIA The Government is holding thousands of political detainees and has engaged in arbitrary arrest and systematic torture, the report said. But it praised Syria for granting exit visas to most of the nation's Jews.

HEADLINE: No. 2 Official Is Resigning From the Fed

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
The vice chairman of the Federal Reserve announced his resignation today, giving President Clinton a rare chance to fill two seats on the seven-member board within several months.
The vice chairman, David W. Mullins Jr., said in a statement that he would leave on Feb. 14 to join a new money management firm led by John Meriwether, a former vice chairman of Salomon Brothers who was forced out for his role in a Treasury bond scandal in 1991. 
 Mr. Mullins and Wayne D. Angell, another governor who will be leaving the board on Feb. 9 because his term has expired, will not take part in the Fed's review of monetary policy on Thursday and Friday.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, who heads the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said she did not think Mr. Mullins's departure would affect Fed policies. "I really don't anticipate much of a shift in policy," she said by telephone. "On the other hand, I think it's a wonderful opportunity for the Administration to name two members to the Federal Reserve board."
The departure will allow Mr. Mullins to sharply increase his current $123,100 salary. But Mr. Mullins said his resignation was not motivated by personal gain or policy differences.
Mr. Mullins, a 47-year-old former finance professor at Harvard Business School, said he thought that the country had emerged from a series of financial crises in the late 80's and that it was time for him to pursue an entrepreneurial career and "return to my financial economics roots."
Mr. Meriwether's firm, Long-Term Capital Management, is raising several billion dollars. It will use complicated, computer-driven trading techniques designed by Mr. Mullins and others to seek arbitrage profits from discrepancies among interest rates and currencies in financial markets.
Mr. Mullins said he did not see a conflict in joining Mr. Meriwether's firm, despite Mr. Meriwether's difficulties in the Treasury bond trading scandal. After he was forced out of Salomon, Mr. Meriwether paid a $50,000 fine to settle a civil complaint by the Securities and Exchange Commission that he did not report to the Government his knowledge of phony bids in Government bond auctions. Mr. Mullins said he was satisfied with Mr. Meriwether's integrity.
The effect of the absence of Mr. Mullins and Mr. Angell from this week's Fed policy review is unclear.
Mr. Mullins, and particularly Mr. Angell, have developed public reputations for supporting higher interest rates to fight inflation. Indeed, Treasury bond prices fell and yields rose slightly after Mr. Mullins's resignation was announced this morning, although the link between the two events was uncertain.
But a senior Fed official said recently that both men had been less aggressive in the privacy of board meetings, neither pushing for higher short-term rates to prevent the rekindling of inflation nor resisting higher rates to protect economic expansion.
Mr. Mullins said he did not expect any changes in American monetary policy as a result of his departure. "We have a pretty broad consensus here," he said today, while declining to discuss when the Fed might make a widely expected move to nudge up short-term interest rates.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, strongly implied during Congressional testimony on Monday that the central bank would raise rates before signs of a revival in inflation became clearly visible.
 
Talks on a Successor
 Ms. Tyson said she would be meeting with Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and Robert E. Rubin, the head of the National Economic Council, to decide on whom to recommend the President should nominate to succeed Mr. Angell. She declined to discuss what qualities the Administration would be seeking.
Another senior official said no one should assume that the Administration would look for someone to keep inflation rates down. "We're looking for people who have outstanding reputations, believe in the independence of the Fed," said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Ms. Tyson, Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Rubin have already recommended that President Clinton appoint George L. Perry, a Brookings Institution economist, to replace Mr. Angell, but Mr. Perry has not been nominated. Officials are trying to determine whether the work of his wife, Dina Perry, as a mutual stock fund manager, poses a conflict of interest.
The Administration has signaled that it may not object to an increase in short-term interest rates, the area over which the Fed has most control. Such an increase could lower investors' expectations of longer-term inflation and, same economists think, hold down long-term interest rates.
Mr. Bentsen said early in January that Administration interest-rate forecasts included a rise in short-term rates, possibly during the first quarter. Ms. Tyson summarized interest-rate comments by President Clinton on Monday as meaning that "there is room in the yield curve for an increase in short-term rates without causing a change in long-term rates." The yield curve shows the relationship of yields on debt securities to the amount of time until the securities mature.
Mr. Greenspan hinted at a similar view in his testimony Monday, saying that because of lingering expectations of inflation, long-term rates are still higher than they might be.
Wall Street experts, who have predicted that the Federal Reserve would nudge interest rates slightly higher, said today that they did not expect Mr. Mullins's departure to affect monetary policy. "I think it means very little," said Robert T. Falconer, an interest-rate analyst at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. "I don't think his absence or Wayne Angell's absence is going to make any difference at the meeting this Thursday or Friday." Other Fed governors said they did not see signs of a policy split in Mr. Mullins's resignation.

HEADLINE: Forget Vietnam? No. Forgive? Perhaps.

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Leo Thorsness spent six years inside a prisoner of war camp in North Vietnam. Now he is building a home on Puget Sound in a state whose leading industries are poised to make billions of dollars trading with the former enemy.
If anyone seemed likely to be angry over lifting the two-decade-old embargo on trade with Vietnam, it would be Mr. Thorsness, a former Air Force fighter pilot. But he favors dropping the economic barriers. 
 "The passion is gone," Mr. Thorsness, a conservative leader of this state's Republican Party, said earlier this week. Last year he returned to Vietnam with five other former prisoners of war. And, like many visitors, he was astonished by the rush to capitalism there.
Twenty-one years after the Paris peace accords ended the United States's involvement in Vietnam, the question of whether Americans can do business seemed ripe for resolution even before reports that President Clinton would life the trade embargo in a few days. To some, Vietnam is the century's last gold rush, a potential mother lode of American prosperity. To others, it is a storehouse of shame, duplicity and secrets that have haunted families for more than a quarter of a century.
 
Big Untapped Market
 Last week, in a surprisingly strong bipartisan vote of 62 to 38, the Senate passed a nonbinding resolution favoring an end to the embargo.
In this state -- whose economy depends on exports and which is home to a large retired military community and the national headquarters for an influential P.O.W. support group -- all the major political forces in the debate are clashing in what may be the final days of the final conflict over Vietnam.
The Boeing Company, America's leading exporter, says it could reap $3 billion to $5 billion in passenger aircraft sales to Vietnam, enough work to sustain up to 50,000 high-paying jobs here on factory lines and in support services elsewhere.
The company lost a deal to sell four 737 passenger jets to Vietnam last fall when rumors that the embargo would be lifted proved false. Now Vietnam's airline, Hang Khong Vietnam, could become one of the major carriers in Asia, said Rob Laird, a Boeing sales director.
 
Healing Effect of Time
 East of the Cascade Mountains, the farmers who grow more than 60 percent of the nation's apples look on Vietnam as one of the last big untapped markets for American fresh fruit.
But this state, which has tied its future to expanding Asian trade, is also the national headquarters for the strongest opponents of lifting the embargo, the families of P.O.W.'s and M.I.A.'s.
Volunteers at the headquarters of the National Alliance of Families for the Return of America's Missing Servicemen, in the Seattle suburb of Bellevue, were alerting veterans groups around the country this week.
The vote in the Senate last week "betrayed the wishes of all the nation's major veterans groups," said Dolores Apodaca Alfond, the group's national chairwoman. "Shame on the U.S. Senate; they put business before morality."
But business, and the softening effects of time, appear to have priority.
 
Political Cost Diminishes
 Ms. Alfond's brother, Maj. Victor Apodaca of the Air Force, was shot down in North Vietnam in 1967. His remains have never been found, and he is one of more than 2,200 American servicemen listed by the Pentagon as missing or unaccounted for.
If Ms. Alfond's efforts to influence her senior senator are any indication of the power of the P.O.W. movement here and in the other Washington, then lifting the embargo would not appear to be much of a political liability.
Senator Slade Gorton, a Washington Republican who is considered one of the nation's most vulnerable incumbents, voted to push for an end to the embargo. If the vote had happened a year ago, he would probably have gone the other way, he said.
But the issue has lost much of its political power, he said. Before the vote, Mr. Gorton was lobbied by Ms. Alfond and veterans groups. After the vote, he said, there was very little reaction, which surprised him.
 
Poll Shows Support
 A supporter of the American war in Vietnam and a proponent of veterans causes, Mr. Gorton said he believed that most Americans were ready to normalize relations.
"Having American business there now is more likely to accelerate the original reason why Americans were there to begin with," he said. "We have gotten everything we are going to get by not normalizing relations."
A New York Times/CBS New Poll conducted two weeks ago indicated that while 57 percent of those surveyed believed that some American soldiers missing in action were still alive, ending the embargo was favored by a slim margin. In the poll of 1,146 adults interviewed by telephone from Jan. 15 to 17, 46 percent favored an end to the embargo, while 40 percent wanted to keep it. The poll had a margin of sampling error of three percentage points.
Over the weekend, Mr. Gorton attended a celebration of the Vietnamese New Year in Tacoma. Washington has the largest Vietnamese population, by percentage, of any state -- with nearly 20,000 people who moved here from Vietnam since 1975. But no one at the festival voiced an objection to Mr. Gorton's vote, he said.
 
'No-Holds-Barred Campaign'
 For President Clinton, his biggest problem in relaxing the trade embargo may be with the nation's 27 million veterans, many of whom are suspicious of him for his lack of military service and his opposition to the war.
In the last month, veterans groups turned up the heat. Bruce Thiesen, national commander of the American Legion, which has more than three million members, called on veterans to wage "a no-holds-barred, call-in-every-chip, twist-every-arm campaign" to prevent lifting the embargo.
"American veterans aren't going to forgive or forget about the businesses that put their profit margins ahead of the interests of our P.O.W.'s and their families," he said in a statement.
But random interviews with other veterans here before the reports of Clinton's decision reveal more diverse feelings. In part, that may explain why senators like Mr. Gorton have not felt a strong backlash from their vote.
"We should learn to forgive and forget," said Wayne Collie, a retired Army sergeant who lives among thousands of retired military officers south of Tacoma. "I don't see anything wrong with starting new."
 
Making It an Issue
 No matter how many Senate investigations or official inquiries of the M.I.A.'s are conducted, a small percentage of veterans will not be satisfied, said Sherwood Dickie, leader of a Seattle charity group for Vietnam veterans. Mr. Dickie served in Vietnam and now works as a police officer.
"I think the majority of veterans groups that are not active in P.O.W.-M.I.A. campaigns will be supportive" of lifting the embargo, said Mr. Dickie.
But Ms. Alfond, with her photographs of the men who never came back, has vowed that she will make it an issue in the fall, for Mr. Gorton and anyone else who voted to normalize relations.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Baybanks Is Bouncing Back, And Takeover Talk Can Only Help.

BYLINE: By Saul Hansell

 BODY:
IF you've never been to Boston, it is easy to overlook Baybanks. With less than $10 billion in assets, Baybanks is only the country's 56th-largest bank. In New England, it is fourth after Fleet Financial, the Bank of Boston and Shawmut National.
And Baybanks' stock certainly would not have attracted any attention. The stock collapsed in 1989 and 1990, along with the New England economy. It rebounded in 1991 and 1992, moving from about $10 a share in January 1991 to more than $40 two years later. But for the rest of 1993 it reached a plateau, trading between $42 and $50. 
 Yet to anyone who has ventured within the confines of Route 128, Baybanks' cash machines are nearly as ubiquitous as the Celtics' leprechaun-and-clover logo (and both, not so coincidentally, the same shade of green). For 15 years, Baybanks has pursued the area's affluent and educated consumers with aggressive marketing and extensive deployment of 1,000 automated teller machines.
In Boston and its suburbs, 25 percent of families say Baybanks is their primary bank, more than Fleet, Bank of Boston and Shawmut combined.
"Baybanks ranks with Wells Fargo, Bank One and Barnett Banks as one of the top retail banks in the country," Thomas McCandless, an analyst with Paine Webber, said.
So, finally, a growing number of analysts are paying attention. And they say the company is poised to complete its recovery, paving the way to its eventual acquisition at a premium that reflects its dominant retail franchise.
The company earned $67.7 million, about $3.57 a share, in 1993, up 14 percent from 1992. But three-quarters of the 1992 earnings were one-time securities gains, so the actual operating earnings more than tripled last year. The stock closed unchanged yesterday in Nasdaq trading at $53.75 a share.
Dennis F. Shea, the regional bank analyst for Morgan Stanley, has made Baybanks his top recommendation and estimates that earnings will rise to more than $6 a share by 1996.
That increase is largely predicated on the continued improvement in the bank's loan portfolio. Not only is the New England economy rebounding, but Baybanks has also moved to avoid future problems by centralizing its credit approval function.
The bank has also continued to increase its market share. It has very successfully offered 24-hour customer service with sales spurred by an L. L. Bean-style catalogue of financial services.
Moving beyond traditional banking, Baybanks has used its marketing muscle to gather more than $1 billion in a family of no-load mutual funds. And unlike its hometown rival Fidelity Investments, Baybanks will let customers buy mutual funds at 1,000 automated teller machines.
For now, Baybanks stock represents a good way to bet on the recovery of the Boston area. "Economic activity is showing signs of springing to life in Boston, and Baybanks is a pure play on the region," Mr. McCandless of Paine Webber said.
The bigger opportunity for investors, however, would come if and when Baybanks is acquired by another bank. Until now, the bank has stood curiously apart from the industry's merger mania. Its last merger was in the 1960's.
As with most banks, the fate of the company rests as much with the personal preference of the chief executive as with its financial condition.
The bank's crusty and driven 60-year-old chairman, William M. Crozier Jr., who has served in that position for 20 years, has consistently rejected acquisition proposals. In particular, he has spurned overtures from Shawmut and the Bank of Boston because such a combination would put many Baybanks employees out of work.
Analysts said Mr. Crozier had recently expressed interest in being acquired by an out-of-state institution once the bank fully recovered from its loan problems. This could make Baybanks an attractive outpost for expanding regional banks like PNC Financial, Banc One, Norwest or Nationsbank, analysts said.
If Baybanks was acquired by such a bank, which could cut its expenses by 15 percent, it could pay $75 to $85 a share, Thomas F. Theurkauf Jr. of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods estimated.
"I don't think that a takeover of Baybanks is imminent," he said, "but over the next three years, any bank that has national aspirations will have to look at it."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Plan Seeks to Raise Productivity

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is to unveil a fiscal plan today that calls for substantial increases in worker productivity and government efficiency, with a large portion of the money saved to come from the Sanitation Department.
Administration officials said the Sanitation Department would be called on to achieve about $45 million of the expected $300 million in productivity savings, which would probably require sanitation employees to cover longer routes and to work full eight-hour days. Now, sanitation workers are often able to finish their routes in as little as six hours. 
 The productivity measures are the third leg of a strategy of pressure on the municipal work force, which has emerged over the last few days, with the Giuliani administration also planning to eliminate up to 18,000 jobs over 18 months. The administration is calling as well for $200 million in benefits concessions, intended to make the benefit packages of city workers commensurate with those of state employees.
 
'Test' for Union Members
 Aides to Mr. Giuliani said the four-year fiscal plan would be filled with hard choices for the municipal unions, in which they can work more and make concessions to protect jobs or else face even greater job reductions and possibly outright layoffs.
"The test for union membership is, 'Do you want to have more people working or have fewer people better paid?' " said John S. Dyson, the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development.
Mr. Giuliani, the first Republican Mayor of New York in a generation pledged repeatedly during the mayoral campaign to reduce the scope of the city's vast municipal government and to cut certain taxes in an effort to stimulate the private sector of the economy. Despite a $2.3 billion budget gap projected for the fiscal year that begins in July, his proposal would make good on those pledges, aides said.
 
To Dismantle a Department
 The plan will outline the consolidation or elimination of numerous small offices and agencies that have sprung up over the years, including moving the school safety force of the Board of Education under the jurisdiction of the Police Department, administration officials said. The Taxi and Limousine Commission would also be merged into the Police Department, officials said.
The Consumer Affairs Department would be dismantled, with its functions distributed to other departments. The Department of Records and Information Services is to be rolled into the Department of General Services.
In other areas of city government, the Mayor's plan will call for initiatives to contract out more government work and to increase competition among agencies and the private sector, yielding $65 million in savings in the next fiscal year.
Mr. Giuliani will also call for $35 million in cuts in the city's hotel occupancy tax and the commercial rent tax in the coming fiscal year. And officials said the four-year plan anticipates reductions in tax revenues to reach nearly $800 million by the end of his term, when he will be up for re-election.
The most significant cut envisioned would come in the 1997 fiscal year, when the city would allow the expiration of a personal income tax surcharge that amounts to about a 12.5 percent tax increase for most residents except those in the lowest income categories. The expiration of the tax would ultimately amount to $400 million in annual tax reductions. The fiscal plan also will offer a proposal to end the city's 4 percent sales tax on clothing purchases of under $100 in October 1995, just as the Christmas shopping season begins.
 
Reaction From Green
 Although the full fiscal plan will be disclosed today, the lobbying against it has already begun. Mark Green, the Public Advocate, who had formerly been the Consumer Affairs Commissioner, held a news conference in the rotunda of City Hall yesterday along with members of the City Council to denounce the plans to dismantle the Consumer Affairs Department, arguing that it actually makes money for the city by collecting fines and licensing fees. "Don't mess with success," Mr. Green said.
The Institute for Puerto Rican Politics released an analysis arguing that the elimination of up to 18,000 jobs would "disproportionately impact" Hispanic residents, an important constituency for Mr. Giuliani.
Quick confrontations were also expected with the municipal unions, with a big test looming with the sanitation workers, whose contract has already expired and who are being asked to make productivity changes. During the campaign Mr. Giuliani often said the city might turn to private companies to handle some of the sanitation routes if the union does not agree to eight-hour days.
 
'Just Small Talk'
 The president of the sanitation workers union, Peter Scarlatos, said yesterday that he had already had a one-hour meeting with the new Labor Commissioner, Randy L. Levine, but described it as "just small talk" and would not elaborate. He said he had not been told of the fiscal plan's call for productivity savings.
"I haven't the slightest idea until I hear of it from the Mayor," he said. City officials said that if the union would not meet the productivity goals, the savings would have to be found another way, and they pointed out that more than 1,000 jobs could be at stake.
Other union leaders were also waiting to see the full budget plan. But Stanley Hill, executive director of the city's largest municipal union, District Council 37 of American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, has already warned that "we're not going to take the whole brunt here of balancing the budget."

HEADLINE: New York City Women Edge Closer to Men in Pay

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN

 BODY:
Women in New York City came a lot closer to matching the earnings of men during the 1980's than elsewhere in the nation, according to a new study released yesterday.
The study, which covered New Yorkers over 25 years old, found that except for women who lacked a high school diploma, working women gained on men of comparable education during that decade. And those income gains are likely to continue in the 1990's, experts said, although probably at a slower pace. 
 In New York, women who worked full time in 1989 earned 77.5 cents for each dollar earned by men -- up from 71 cents on the dollar in 1979. Comparison with men's earnings is considered the most basic measure of women's status in the work force.
What's more, at the end of the 1980's women had become a majority in the city's labor force for the first time. Many more women went to work full time rather than part time than did so a decade earlier.
"I think that New York is an easy place for a woman to get a job," said Christina Lind, who assists a research analyst at C. J. Lawrence, a Wall Street investment firm. "But it is still difficult to get the job you want."
Ms. Lind, who is 27, wants to become an analyst herself. "Women have gone a long way on the upper levels," she said, "and once a woman reaches the middle, her talent can bring her to the highest levels. But it is very difficult to get to that middle."
 
Among the Economic Winners
 In 1989, American women in general were paid only 66 percent of their male counterpart's earnings, according to Census data. For the previous three decades that level had hovered around 60 percent.
Indeed, despite a common contention that the 1980's represented a backlash against women in society and in the workplace, the evidence is strong that women, particularly those who are well educated, were among the major economic winners of the 1980's expansion.
The research, conducted at Teachers College of Columbia University, was based on United States Census data gathered in 1980 and 1990. Other experts on labor markets said the Columbia findings were consistent with recent studies showing strong economic gains for women in the 1980's. But they cautioned that some conclusions about New York City may be less reliable because of the difficulty of gathering hard data about incomes, particularly among poorer people.
"The gender gap in New York narrowed considerably in the 1980's," said Dr. Francisco L. Rivera-Batiz, author of the new study. Dr. Rivera-Batiz is director of the Institute for Urban and Minority Education at Teachers College. And more recent evidence, while not as detailed, indicates "that these changes that occurred during the 1980's have not been reversed by the impact of the recession."
Women who work in New York City fared better than most women elsewhere largely because the jobs so numerous here -- white-collar, professional and managerial service-sector employment -- tend to be much more open to women. At the same time, the sharp decline in manufacturing jobs in the city, much greater than in the nation generally, tended to hit men harder than women.
Beth Gordon, executive vice president and director of media services at N. W. Ayer, a New York advertising firm, typifies the women whose careers leaped ahead in recent years.
"Advertising has been a field more open to women in New York than many others," she said. "I would say that in the publishing world, you are dealing with more and more women. In our industry, women have learned to work well as equals. In New York and in advertising, I think we've come a long way."
Nevertheless, researchers say women still face substantial obstacles to achieving full equality with men.
"The world of work in the 1990's is geared to the world of the home of the 1950's and the 1960's," said Claudia Goldin, a Harvard economist and author of a leading work, "Understanding the Gender Gap: An Economic History of American Women." "If you want to make partner in the law firm, for instance, you are supposed to work 70 hours a week or more in your 20's and early 30's. If you have a wife, you can have both a career and a family, but not many women do."
Younger women and well-educated women fared exceptionally well. In New York, those aged 25 to 34 in 1989 earned 88.3 percent of what men of the same age were paid. And women between the ages of 35 and 44 made the greatest strides, raising their earnings from 69.5 percent of the men's wage to 79.3 percent, according to the Teachers College report.
Women who graduated from college earned 25.4 percent more, adjusted for inflation, at the end of the 1980's than they did at the beginning of the decade. Their average earnings in 1989 amounted to $35,677, up from $28,451 in 1979. Similarly educated men saw their average earnings rise by 21.9 percent to $42,057.
Poorly educated women and immigrants, however, did not share so much in the progress of other women.
Women in New York who never graduated from high school actually lost ground, according to the report, with their incomes slipping 4 percent. By contrast, similarly under educated men saw no gain or loss. High school graduates achieved marginal gains, with women reporting a 4.8 percent gain in real income while men showed a 2.1 percent increase. All these changes lagged well behind those enjoyed by their better educated counterparts.
Women from minority groups, who often find it easier to get jobs than their male counterparts, fared much better than the men did. Real incomes of black women rose 20.8 percent compared with a 9.8 percent rise for black men's pay. Hispanic women gained 24.7 percent; Hispanic men, only 13.7 percent.
And neither did as well as non-Hispanic whites. Among that group, women reported income gains of 37.7 percent over the 1980's while men's incomes rose 28.1 percent.

HEADLINE: Asbury Park Mayor Held On a Drug-Buying Charge

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ASBURY PARK, N.J., Feb. 1

 BODY:
In recent months, Mayor Dennis Buckley has been a regular at the Tap Room. And for nearly that long he has been watched. On Monday, in the early afternoon, Mr. Buckley's regular visit took a decidedly irregular turn when he was arrested and charged with buying cocaine at the bar across the street from his office at City Hall.
The Mayor's arrest, a blow for any city, was particularly bad news for this one. Once a jewel of the Jersey Shore, it has struggled for decades to rejuvenate its beachfront, now filled with rundown rooming houses and few tourist attractions. 
 Mr. Buckley, 42 years old, took office July 1 after winning a Council seat with a reform platform in a nonpartisan election, and being named Mayor. His arrest resulted from a joint effort of the Monmouth County Prosecutor's Tactical Narcotics Team, the F.B.I. and the Drug Enforcement Administration as part of an continuing narcotics investigation, the Prosecutor said.
"Our information tells us he has been a cocaine user for five years and has been buying it at this location since taking office," said the Prosecutor, John Kaye. Mr. Buckley was questioned by investigators for two hours after his arrest, Mr. Kaye said.
 
Both Sad and Shocking
 For Asbury Park, which has been in decline since racial disturbances tore the city in the 1960's, and which later was associated with Bruce Springsteen, the rock star, the word of Mr. Buckley's arrest was as sad as it was shocking.
City Manager Alan Feit, released a statement saying the city was "saddened by what has happened and knows how badly the Mayor feels."
Mr. Buckley is a former president of the local Chamber of Commerce. His family owns a local funeral home.
Like his predecessors, Mr. Buckley was confronted with the nagging problems of moving this city of 17,000 out of a three-decade rut of unemployment and decay, crime and the loss of white, middle-class residents as well as businesses. He succeeded Tom Smith, a Republican Assemblyman, who gave up his city job to concentrate on state issues.
 
'Great Guy, a Proud Guy'
 "The man is a great guy, a proud guy," said Henry V. Vaccaro, who was a partner in an attempted $500 million-plus project to redevelop the city's 1.2-mile oceanfront in the 1980's. That project, like many other plans to reclaim the old resort's "Gem of the Jersey Shore" reputation from its glory days of a half-century ago, sank in a whirlpool of bankruptcies and litigation.
"I think he took the job of redevelopment so seriously it started to destroy him," said Mr. Vaccaro, who described himself as a friend and political supporter.
Mr. Buckley had also been outspoken as Mayor against drugs, Prosecutor Kaye recalled. "He was elected on a strong law-enforcement platform and he cooperated with us to get our tactical narcotics squad into Asbury Park," he said.
That same squad, the Prosecutor continued, was tipped by the F.B.I. and Federal Drug Enforcement agents involved in continuing narcotics investigations: word on the streets of Asbury Park was that Mr. Buckley had a personal cocaine habit.
 
'Make His Weekly Buy'
 Agents had sat with a cocaine dealer in the Tap Room for the better part of four days waiting for the Mayor "to come in and make his weekly buy," the Prosecutor said. In exchange for $50, Mr. Buckley was given two packets of a substance that resembled cocaine, Mr. Kaye added.
Mr. Buckley's wife, Catherine, 38, who had accompanied him into the bar, was also arrested when agents found about 2 grams of cocaine in her purse, the Prosecutor said at a news conference today in Freehold, the Monmouth County seat.
The Mayor was formally charged with possession of cocaine and conspiracy to possess cocaine. Mrs. Buckley was charged with possession. Although the charges each carry a possible penalty of three to five years in prison and a $7,500 fine, the Prosecutor said it was highly unlikely that first offenders, like the Buckleys, would be jailed if convicted.
 
Office Lost on ConvictionXxx
 Conviction, however, would automatically cost the Mayor his office under state law, Mr. Kaye said.
After being questioned in Freehold on Monday, the Buckleys were released on their own recogizance, the Prosecutor said. The Buckleys could not be reached for comment today.
"This man has a serious addiction problem and needs treatment," Mr. Kaye said. A hearing is likely later this month, he said, and the matter will be presented to a grand jury.
But at least one town resident today was questioning the motives of conducting such a long investigation to catch one alleged drug user -- even if it was the Mayor.
"It stinks," said William T. Murray, a private land surveyor. "The Mayor was elected to try to keep this town from going down the tubes. He may have been a party-going kind of guy, but if he ran for office tomorrow, I'd vote for the guy."

HEADLINE: Stocks Retreat on Interest Rate Concerns

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
After four days of record-setting highs, stock prices turned down yesterday as weakness in the bond market raised investors' concerns about interest rates and their effect on corporate profits.
Hugh A. Johnson, the chief investment strategist for First Albany, said it was normal to expect some profit taking after a big move in the market. But clearly, he added, "the big reason was the decline in bonds prices and the rise in interest rates." 
 The price of the 30-year bond was down a full point, while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, jumped to 6.31 percent, from 6.23 percent on Monday.
Higher interest rates on fixed-income securities can draw investor cash away from the stock market, traders said. In addition, higher interest rates can cut profits by raising a company's debt-service payments.
Most of the selling pressures were reflected on the broader market indexes like the Nasdaq composite, which was down 3.23 points, to 797.24. Traders said the decline in the Dow Jones industrial average was not steeper because the main market index included several cyclical stocks that resisted yesterday's selling downdraft. The index closed down 14.35 points at 3,964.01.
Volume on the New York Exchange was heavy at 322.5 million shares, and off only slightly from the strong 322.9 million pace set on Monday, when the markets hit new highs all across the board.
Losing issues outnumbered stocks showing gains in trading by 1,148 to 961. The only index to cross into positive territory was the American Stock Exchange composite, which was up 0.31 point, to a new record close of 485.99.
Analysts at MMS International said the flow of bullish economic data had been well received by the market to date. But the outlook could change in the near future if traders and investors begin to worry about the warning on interest rates given by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, on Monday. Mr. Greenspan said the central bank would probably raise short-term interest rates even before it was readily apparent that inflation was on the rise again.
Mr. Johnson of First Albany said the decline in bond prices was fueled by a report from the National Association of Purchasing Management for the month of January. The report, which is a measure of manufacturing activity, said that activity rose to 57.7 in January, from 57.1 in December, when most economists had expected it to register a decline, to 56.6.
In addition to the rise in the overall index, Mr. Johnson said the report showed other signs of strength, including the change in vendor performance, which measures the percentage of purchasing managers who are experiencing slow deliveries. This measure rose to 55 percent from 51.7 percent.
Mr. Johnson said some bottlenecks in distribution might develop, which would create shortages and exert upward pressure on prices.
Another disturbing part of the report, Mr. Johnson said, was the increase in the percentage of managers who have seen higher prices. That index jumped to 59.8 percent from 51.3 percent, the largest monthly increase since January 1990.

HEADLINE: Donors Respond to Reports of Lag in Neediest Cases

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
With less than four weeks remaining in The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund's 82d annual appeal for donations, hundreds of donors have responded to reports that the campaign is lagging dangerously behind last year's.
But despite the additional giving -- which has come from the corporate world, from repeat donors, from first-time donors and even from the unemployed -- the fund still needs more than $130,000 just to maintain the assistance it provided last year for services such as medical examinations for children and emergency rent help for immigrants and single mothers. 
 While the average individual donation has been higher than ever before, the campaign is still suffering because fewer people have contributed this year -- 10,478 compared with 11,705 last year. Additionally, gifts from 205 estates and trusts, the same number that gave last year, have declined by about $90,000. The appeal ends Feb. 28.
 
Moved by Disasters
 Those who have given in the last two weeks to help reduce the shortfall are a testament to the compassion and responsiveness that New Yorkers often show in a crisis. One, Senior Judge Bernard Newman of the United States Court of International Trade, wrote to apologize that he had forgotten to give in a flurry of contributions to other charities.
"As I look back, I recall having contributed to your splendid fund but once or twice in the past," Judge Newman wrote. "However, I solemnly promise to contribute to The Times Neediest Cases Fund annually and without deviation." He sent a check for $100 and promised to send another before this year's campaign is over.
His check and all other donations go directly to support seven social-service agencies in the city because The Times pays the administrative costs of the campaign.
Another donor, Lynn Oberlander, an attorney in Manhattan, decided to give for the first time to help out. "I've been thinking about giving for so long," Ms. Oberlander said yesterday. "And when I read that the fund was behind, I decided that this was definitely the year to sit down and write a check."
She said she was also moved by stories of suffering after the earthquake in Los Angeles and, along with her $100 check to the Neediest Cases Fund, gave a donation to the Red Cross. "I guess you'd say I was feeling lucky on that particular day."
Other people, like Carol Karasick of Manhattan, have continued to pitch in even as they find themselves decidedly down on their luck. "As one who joined the ranks of the unemployed this year, I give this 1993 donation with a new sense of empathy for the needy," Ms. Karasick wrote, sending a check for $250. "Though my employment prospects may be bleak, I do not have to worry about housing or other necessities."
Donna L. Lavins of Manhattan also found herself out of work but believed her situation made it more imperative that she continue her tradition of giving to help others. "As I am temporarily not working, I cannot match my former years' contributions," she wrote. "Nonetheless, I welcome the opportunity to share the good fortune I continue to have."
Even contributors who are generally thought too young to read the newspaper every day, such as 9-year-old Nicholas Lawrence of Manhattan, are aware that additional help is needed to fill the gap.
"I read the article on the Neediest Cases Fund and how this year people didn't donate a lot of money," Nicholas wrote. "So I want to donate some of my savings account." He sent $75 along with his letter.
"These people need this money more than I do," he added. "I want to see these people living in houses, have new clothes and also these children going to school. So please help these people."
