HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bonds Take Sharp Fall

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell sharply yesterday on evidence that the robust economic expansion of late 1993 continued into 1994.
The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond dropped 13/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, jumped to 6.31 percent, from 6.23 percent on Monday. Short-term maturities fell 1/8, and intermediate maturities fell 13/32 , the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported. 
The National Association of Purchasing Management reported yesterday that its monthly index of manufacturing activity surged to 57.7 percent in January from 57.1 percent in December. It was the highest level since a 58.2 percent reading in July 1988. An index reading of more than 50 shows that manufacturing is expanding.
 
Strong Survey Results
 William Dudley, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said he was surprised by the strong survey results considering January's harsh weather, which was expected to hamper manufacturing activity.
Particularly worrisome to fixed-income investors was the potential for higher inflation in the survey, which found that the rate of manufacturers' price increases rose in January for the second consecutive month to the highest level since November 1990.
That hinted of higher prices trickling down to consumers in coming months.
Bond investors worry about inflationary conditions because higher prices in the economy diminish the value of long-term bonds, which pay a fixed rate of return.
The market's skittishness was particularly evident after Monday's Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve.
Mr. Greenspan reiterated the Fed's willingness to raise short-term interest rates to keep inflation pressures from worsening. Higher rates on new securities would hurt the value of short-term government securities that are already sold.
The fall in bond prices also came after the news of the unexpected resignation of David W. Mullins Jr., the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Mr. Mullins was viewed as an anti-inflation hawk, meaning he championed reduction of inflation as a primary goal. Another hawk, Wayne D. Angell, a Fed governor, had previously announced plans to leave shortly after the end of his term, which expired Monday.
Both moves could have indirect implications for Treasury market prices, possibly as early as tomorrow and Friday, when the Federal Open Market Committee meets to set monetary policy.
If the the committee decides against favoring higher short-term interest rates as a way to curb inflation, that could help the value of shorter-term maturities.
But a less aggressive inflation-fighting posture by the Fed could also hurt the value of long-term bonds.
 
3-Month Bill Yields Up
 Yields on three-month Treasury bills issued at Monday's auction rose to 3.08 1/2 percent as the discount gained 0.04 percentage point, to 3.03 percent. Six-month yields issued at Monday's auction rose to 3.29 percent as the discount gained 0.04 point, to 3.20 percent. One-year yields rose to 3.55 1/2 percent as the discount rose 0.05 point, to 3.43 percent.
The rise in Treasury bill yields can reflect market expectations about the near-term prospects of rising short- term interest rates. Yields are the interest bonds pay by maturity, while the discount is the interest at which they are sold.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 10414/32 , down 9/32 from late Monday. The average yield to maturity was 5.43 percent, down from 5.45 percent.

HEADLINE: Manufacturing Activity Reported Up in January

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The National Association of Purchasing Management, whose monthly surveys reflect trends among the nation's manufacturers, reported yesterday that manufacturing activity continued to expand in January, for the fifth consecutive month, but not as rapidly as in the fall.
A separate index measuring the prices that purchasing managers pay for materials and supplies used in manufacturing jumped to 59.8, from 51.3, the highest level since November 1990. The jump, mainly a result of rising steel prices, prompted Wall Street traders to drive up interest rates. That is the usual Wall Street response when traders interpret a new piece of data as signaling inflation. 
 In a separate report, the Commerce Department said construction spending rose in December for the eighth consecutive monthly gain.
The American economy's surprisingly strong fourth-quarter growth has been largely a manufacturing phenomenon and the association's overall index has reflected this. It has risen by roughly two points each month since September, reaching 57.1 in December, and then 57.7 in January.
The January rise, small as it was, still came as a surprise to many economists, who had predicted that the index would fall, not rise, because of the subfreezing January weather that slowed auto production, among other problems.
 
Upswing in G.D.P.
 "It is a better number than we had expected, suggesting that the economy won't slow down as much in the first quarter as we had thought," said David Wyss, director of research at Data Resources Inc., an economic consulting firm.
The gross domestic product, representing the dollar value of all the goods and services the nation produces in a given year, rose at an annual rate of 5.9 percent in the fourth quarter, a huge upswing from last year's first three quarters. Mr. Wyss said he had expected economic growth to slow to an annual rate of less than 3 percent in the first quarter, but now he and others are raising their forecasts to 3.5 percent. They noted the rise in the association's index as a reason for their optimism.
"What we are seeing in the index is a surge of orders to replace merchandise and supplies that were depleted as a result of the heavy consumer buying in November and December," said Robert J. Bretz, the purchasing manager for Pitney Bowes and the chairman of the association's business survey committee. "The question is, will this buying be sustained in March and April? I will be very surprised if it is."
 
A Key Measure
 The association's monthly survey, covering 300 purchasing managers in 20 industries, is the first big statistical measure of economic activity in a given month. Any index reading of more than 50 denotes an expanding manufacturing sector, and the readings have been higher than 50 since August, with the January reading of 57.1 being the highest level since July 1988.
According to the survey, the big January jump came mainly from substantial rises in new orders placed with manufacturers, in backlogs of unfilled orders and in longer periods needed for deliveries -- all signs of strong factory activity.
Inventories declined, which means new orders are likely to be filled from new production rather than from supplies on the shelves. Employment at manufacturing companies continued to decline in January, reflecting layoffs. But the decline in employment was at a slower rate than in the fourth quarter.
The Commerce Department's construction report said spending in December rose 2.6 percent, to an annual rate of $513.1 billion. Big spending on housing, evident since last summer, has spread to public buildings, schools, factories, highways and sewers.
 
A Different Conclusion
 Many economists and forecasters say the nation's strong economic growth in the fourth quarter cannot be maintained in the first quarter, although the slowdown probably will not be as great as it was a year ago, when strong fourth-quarter growth in 1992 -- reaching nearly 6 percent -- turned into economic growth of less than 2 percent in the first half of 1993.
But the Purchasing Managers' report for January does not support this conclusion. While stronger than expected, the January jump in the index was not nearly as big as the one in January 1992, when the index reached 57.3, from 55.1 in December 1992 -- only to lose nearly seven points by April.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Retrofitting Old Cars With Driver's-Side Air Bags

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Auto manufacturers are luring buyers into showrooms by offering air bags. But what about people who would like air bags but are not ready to replace their cars?
A large maker of air bag components has begun offering an "after market" driver's-side air bag -- actually, a replacement steering wheel that contains an air bag. The company, Breed Technologies Inc. of Lakeland, Fla., says that the technology it is using in its used-car version represents an advance that may eventually be adopted for new-car air bags. 
 In new cars, the crash sensors -- of which Breed is already a leading supplier to Detroit -- are in several places under the hood. This forward placement of the sensors gives the air bag as much warning as possible that a crash is occurring, but the complex wiring needed to link the sensors to the air bag makes it difficult to install after-market air bags.
 
Available for 26 Models
 That's why the Breed air bag, which is available for 26 car models produced in 1987 or later, is self-contained, with the sensor housed in the same steering-wheel compartment as the bag itself.
Richard M. Stolbach, executive vice president of the company, conceded that the bag was not quite so good as the factory-installed bag that comes in a new American car. Because the sensing equipment must be crammed into the steering wheel, too, the bag itself is only a little more than half the size of a factory-installed bag. As a result, the use of a combination lap and seat belt is even more crucial with the after-market bag than with the factory-installed versions, Mr. Stolbach said.
 
To Reduce Facial Injuries
 But even the smaller bag, when used with a seat belt, would help reduce facial injuries, Mr. Stolbach said. He expects anyone safety-conscious enough to install such a bag -- at a cost of $700 to $900 -- would also wear seat belts.
The company says it has had "several thousand" orders so far through its two main distributors: Applied Safety Inc. of Ventnor, N.J., and Wynn's Climate Systems Inc., an air- conditioner maker, of Fort Worth. Installation of the bags is being done at new- or used-car dealerships through companies like the Auto Action Group in Union, N.J.
In a frontal collision at 35 miles an hour the driver hits the steering wheel about 100 milliseconds -- one-tenth of a second -- after impact. Engineers figure they have about 50 milliseconds to get the bag inflated before the driver begins to move toward the wheel. Because inflation takes about 20 milliseconds, the air-bag system has only the first 30 milliseconds to sense the crash and decide to inflate the bag, and that is why factory-installed units rely on sensors near the front of the car.
 
Mechanical Sensor Used
 Breed, however, uses a single mechanical sensor in the steering wheel that senses the abrupt stop of a head-on crash. When that happens, a ball is jolted loose and rolls down a tube to trigger a firing pin, inflating the bag with the same type of mini-explosion used in factory-installed air bags.
Breed contends that its sensing system would be superior for original equipment, too, because there is no under-hood wiring to be damaged by the heat, gravel and other insults of daily operation, and no electric signal is required for the air bag to inflate.
But auto makers still tend to favor the advance-warning feature of the underhood sensors, which allows the bag to be inflated a bit more slowly, to avoid punching the driver in the face.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Follows Bonds Down After a Fed Official Resigns

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar eased against other major currencies yesterday, following United States Treasury bonds lower in reaction to the resignation of an important Federal Reserve official.
Treasury bonds fell after the news of the resignation because the official, David W. Mullins Jr., the vice chairman of the Fed, was perceived as a hawk on inflation. 
 Dealers worried that his departure could make the central bank less vigilant about inflation. That could lead to easier credit, which would make the dollar less attractive compared with other currencies.
The dollar has firmed recently amid growing expectations the Fed will soon tighten rates to fight inflation. A growing sense that higher rates may be delayed, however, held sway in the currency market.
Dealers also fretted about tomorrow's meeting of Germany's central bank, although few expect the Bundesbank to cut rates to stimulate the economy.
"All eyes will be on the Bundesbank meeting," said Angelo Evangelista, dealer with the Bank of Boston, adding that he expected the German central bank would refrain from cutting rates until strikes at 600 industrial companies in Germany had been settled.
Nearly 150,000 industrial workers across Germany walked off the job yesterday to protest calls for a wage freeze and cuts in holiday bonuses.
Gold bullion rose $2.50 on the New York Commodity Exchange, where the most-active April contract settled at $386.10 an ounce. A late quote from the Republic National Bank put spot gold at $384.25, up $2.50 from Monday.
Gold for February delivery settled at $384.10 an ounce, up $2.50 from Monday. Gold prices rose sharply on Monday after bouncing back from a two-month low. Silver prices also rose yesterday.
In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 107.66 yen, from 108.55 yen late Monday. The dollar rose to 1.7338 German marks, from 1.7330 marks on Monday. The British pound fell to $1.4995, from $1.5065 on Monday.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
A new subcompact car from Kia Motors in South Korea is happy to play follow the leader.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
THE newest nameplate in the American automotive market is more than willing to have Honda or other rivals declare themselves "a car ahead," as long as it can be perceived as following closely, and doggedly, behind.
In Las Vegas, Nev., and Portland, Ore., Kia Motors America, a unit of the Kia Motors Corporation of South Korea, will begin advertising tomorrow for the first cars sold under its name in the United States. A print, broadcast and dealer-showroom campaign, produced by Goldberg Moser O'Neill Advertising, uses humor and whimsy in seeking to create an image for the newcomer as both affordable and reliable, characteristics that might seem mutually exclusive in a four-door sedan starting at $8,495. 
 The strategy to establish a populist persona for Kia that would combine spunkiness with thriftiness is typified by a television commercial from the introductory phase of the campaign, which carries the theme "It's about time everyone had a well-made car."
"We were obsessed with building a car that's as well made as the Honda Civic," an announcer says, "so we actually followed a Civic around for 100,000 miles." Filmed and videotaped footage shows a Civic pursued cross-country by a Kia Sephia, a front-wheel-drive model that is Kia's initial American entry.
Only when the Civic drives through a tall, imposing gate does the Kia stop playing shadow. Kia "followed the Civic everywhere," the announcer declares, "except into the neighborhood of $12,000." At that, the Kia's driver brakes and waves.
"The typical way others would have done it would have been to put their car in front and have the Civic try to keep up," said Mike Moser, a partner and co-creative director ofGoldberg Moser in San Francisco.
"Well, we're not the leaders," he added. "We're basically the little car that could, not another blowhard trying to tell people how great we are."
Necessity was the mother of that invention.
"Consumers told us quite clearly, 'If you come from Korea, you've got a lot to prove,' " Dick Macedo, the marketing director for Kia Motors in Irvine, Calif., said.
"We started out with a campaign that addressed durability, but people could care less," he added. "What they were concerned about was a high-quality, reliable, dependable car at a low price."
So the campaign emphasizes those issues, using Japanese automobiles as a point of reference. A series of teaser ads, showing a giant reptile from a Japanese monster movie, asserted: "There's only one thing more frightening to Japan. Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaagh! A well-made car for under $9,000."
"What people are really looking for is an economy car that will not make their neighbors giggle or their mechanic rich," Mr. Moser said.
"You have to get realistic," he added. "If money wasn't an issue, people would buy a Civic and we wouldn't have a place in the American market. We have a place because there's a hole left there" by the recent steep price increases in models built in Japan, he said.
Even so, the client and agency confront daunting challenges. The economy subcompact market is extraordinarily competitive. Consumers are unforgiving and fickle; witness how they dispatched makes like Daihatsu and Yugo and sent sales of makes like Hyundai rising and plunging.
And competition is intensifying as American auto makers re-enter the market. The Chrysler Corporation poses a significant threat with a new subcompact, the Neon, to be sold by Dodge and Plymouth dealers at prices starting at $8,975.
Sometimes, though, a giant stumbles, as Chrysler did with its Neon commercials during the Super Bowl last Sunday. Rather than giving the fledgling model a sweeping send-off before the game's record estimated 134.8 million viewers, Chrysler ran two short, lackluster spots. (The rest of Neon's introductory campaign, by BBDO Worldwide in Southfield, Mich., will be described tomorrow at a news conference in New York.)
Another factor favoring Kia Motors is its track record with American drivers through the Festiva, a two-door subcompact it has manufactured for the Ford Motor Company. (Ford is replacing the Festiva with another Kia-built model, Aspire, in two- and four-door versions.)
Kia Motors plans to spend $30 million a year on advertising through Goldberg Moser, which in July was awarded the account -- its first automotive assignment -- after a 13-month review. The company has mapped out a region-by-region rollout: 11 Western states by the end of 1994, the Southeast and East next year, and the Midwest in early 1996. By the end of 1996, it hopes to be selling 250,000 units annually in three model lines, including a four-door sport-utility vehicle called Sportage.
Audaciously ambitious plans, to be sure. Perhaps overly ambitious. But Kia Motors is trying to keep its perspective.
"I wouldn't put us down as the high-technology comer of the world," Mr. Macedo acknowledged. "But we're a very good company with a very good price advantage."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Crude Prices Move Higher As Oil Inventories Slip a Bit

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Crude oil prices surged to their highest levels in more than two months yesterday on expectations that the longest cold snap in the United States in 15 years is finally eating into stockpiles.
Stockpiles of distillate fuels, which include home heating oil, have fallen 11 percent in the last four weeks. Stocks are now almost 10 million barrels below their levels a year ago.
 
'It's Been Cold'

 
 "The spark still comes from heating oil," Jerry Samuels, a trader with Arb Oil in Los Angeles, said. "Everybody knows it's been cold and everybody's impressed with the draws in stockpiles." 
 On the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil for March delivery soared 73 cents to settle at $15.92 a barrel, while March heating oil jumped 2.28 cents, to 51.83 cents a gallon. Unleaded gasoline rose 2.33 cents, to 45.55 cents a gallon.
Despite yesterday's surge, crude oil prices are still 20 percent cheaper than last year, when crude traded at about $20 a barrel, and heating oil is still 8.5 percent less than last year, when it was trading at about 56.6 cents a gallon.
"The prices aren't as high and this year's cold hasn't been as damaging as 1989, but the demand for heating oil sure is there," a British Petroleum trader said.
Cold weather has returned to the East Coast, with snow falling in New York City yesterday. Temperatures in the East are expected to drop as low as 25 degrees below normal by Monday.
The rally in crude oil may taper off in the next few sessions. Traders said expectations about lower supplies were already reflected in yesterday's price rise and supplies of crude oil and gasoline remained high.
Late yesterday after trading ended, the American Petroleum Institute issued its weekly report on inventories. "There's plenty of crude oil around, and while that may not be significant, eventually we'll have to deal with it," Al Levine, an oil economist with Smith Barney Shearson in Maryland, said.
Gasoline prices also surged, as traders bet on a seasonal increase in prices before the summer driving season begins in June.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
The Business District in Wilmington, Del., Is Reviving, With Commitments From Four Companies

BYLINE: By Maureen Milford

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del.

 BODY:
WEAKENED by corporate cutbacks and a flat economy, the business district here is bouncing back, thanks to some help from the city government.
The year-old city administration under Mayor James H. Sills Jr. won commitments from four companies last year to bring their operations to the downtown office center. 
 One new arrival will be the MBNA Corporation, a big credit card company. The company announced late last year that it would build a 350,000-square-foot building on a corner of Rodney Square.
MBNA, a large Delaware employer, has never before had a presence in the state's largest city. MBNA is based in suburban New Castle County, near Newark.
Work has begun on the nine-story building. The construction managers, the Bellevue Holding Company of Wilmington, expect the project to be completed by late this year.
Designed by Heery International Inc. of Washington in conjunction with Homsey Architects Inc. of Wilmington, the building's neo-classical style was chosen to blend with other buildings on the square.
Long considered the most desirable site in the central business district, Rodney Square is home to the headquarters of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the chemical giant, and the Delaware Chancery Court, where many corporate takeover battles are fought.
When MBNA completes the building, it will house 1,500 to 2,000 workers in individual banking and support operations. Its headquarters, however, will continue to be in New Castle County.
The credit card company was able to move so quickly with construction plans in part because of Wilmington 2000, a downtown-development group made up of representatives from the area's most powerful businesses.
Tax-abatement programs have been the centerpiece of the city's economic recovery efforts. But in the case of MBNA, the city had an additional sweetener.
Part of the package put together for the company included the donation of $6 million in land on Rodney Square or about two-thirds of the building site.
The city had become the reluctant owner of the land after another publicly backed real estate deal involving a Wilmington savings institution went sour in 1990. Land had been assembled and buildings razed in the late 1980's to make room for an office tower, but with the downturn in the economy the institution abandoned its plans, leaving the city and another public agency with an expensive and embarrassing hole.
When MBNA went looking to expand operations, the city saw the land giveaway as a way to recoup some of its financial losses and bring in much needed jobs for disadvantaged city residents. The city even offered to buy the remaining third of the building site from the savings institution for $4.2 million. But Charles M. Cawley, president of MBNA, refused, insisting the credit card company buy it privately.
Other enticements for MBNA included a five-year tax abatement on the real estate; an additional five years of real estate tax relief of 50 percent, and a five-year break on the head tax, a city tax on employers, which is assessed at $6 an employee a month.
Even with the tax cuts, the Sills administration estimates the city will realize a $900,000 net gain over the next 10 years from the deal.
There had been concerns the city central business district would go the way of other deteriorating midsized industrial cities. With vacancy rates in downtown Wilmington at 24.7 percent, the fear was that business would look to other more vigorous markets outside Delaware.
"We just can't stand by and let the city go backward," said John E. Stapleford, director of the Bureau of Economic Research at the University of Delaware. "It's all to our benefit to see this sort of thing happen. This influx of jobs into downtown is very, very important for everybody."
Du Pont announced in November that it would bring 1,500 jobs to its downtown buildings. The Beneficial Corporation, a giant lender that had been based in New Castle County, decided in May that it would relocate its headquarters in a city-state redevelopment project, the Christina Gateway. The American Express Centurion Bank also moved its headquarters from near Newark to the Christina Gateway.
All three benefited from the head-tax abatement, since any employer who creates at least 100 new positions in Wilmington gets a five-year break on the tax.
As part of its deal, MBNA also insisted on a commitment by the city that it would move forward with the creation of a business improvement district, similar to those in Manhattan, Baltimore, Philadelphia and other cities. In such a district, property owners agree to assess themselves to pay for supplemental services like extra security, sanitation and marketing. The businesses in the district determine which extra services are necessary. Wilmington 2000 is now working to have the district in operation by this summer.

HEADLINE: Kitchen Computer: Promising Steak, Serving Burgers

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS

 BODY:
MY computer is talking to me.
"Now this recipe has been a secret for years," it says. 
 Imagine my excitement.
Up pops Martha Stewart's recipe for a salad of bibb lettuce, garlic, olive oil, lemon and pepper.
Imagine my disappointment.
Welcome to the world of CD-ROM cooking disks. When plugged into personal computers, these compact disks can present reams of information complete with videos and music. They are the latest effort to take recipes out of cookbooks and put them into the modern language of multimedia communications. Cooking videos, the previous effort, were a flop. Not many kitchens are equipped with VCR's and there has been no rush to put computers in the kitchen, either. For now, the printed page has nothing to worry about. But what does the future hold?
CD-ROM's (ROM stands for "read only memory," meaning the disk cannot be changed) take the idea of the cooking video a step further. The screen of a computer with CD-ROM capabilities and speakers can not only display written recipes but also provide oral directions while visually showing how to truss a chicken; it can provide a menu for serving the chicken and print out a shopping list for the meal, all of this with background music. One disk can hold the contents of hundreds of cookbooks without photos or videos, or the recipes of a large cookbook complete with photographs and video.
But so far, the voice that promised me so much and delivered a lettuce salad is in pretty exclusive company. A foray into the world of electronic cooking has produced only seven CD-ROM's that work with I.B.M.-compatible computers. A couple of others are for the Apple Macintosh only. The disk with the lettuce recipe is from Robin Leach, who has turned "Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous" into a CD-ROM cookbook. The others span the spectrum of cooking styles, from a disk with more than a million recipes, where Velveeta and canned mushroom soup run rampant, to "The New Basics Electronic Cookbook," a CD-ROM version of the cookbook from the "Silver Palate" duo, Sheila Lukens and Julee Rosso.
These are a taste of what may lie ahead. Last year, 4.8 million CD-ROM computer drives were sold worldwide, and 1.5 million were sold in 1992, said Patty Chang of Dataquest, which tracks the high-technology industry, in San Jose, Calif.
Dan Norton-Middaugh said, with the enthusiasm appropriate for his job as marketing manager of Multicom Publishing, a Seattle company that produces CD-ROM disks: "Everyone will have a CD-ROM in the next five years. We are moving toward something that will have real utility for a broad spectrum of people. We are making an investment now, coming up a steep learning curve, for a time when the equipment will be more ubiquitous. We are tapping into visual responses, but whether it's for the novelty or real utility, I don't know."
Putting aside the question about the practicality of setting up a computer, even a laptop, in the kitchen, where it might become a convenient receptacle for sauces, salad dressings and cake batter, why would the cook want one? What indispensable help does an interactive CD offer that an ordinary cookbook can't?
Recognizing that I am skeptical of technology's ability to make everything easier, I decided to speak to the most likely audience for these disks. A colleague in the office electronically posted questions about the value of CD-ROM cookbooks to users of the Internet, the global labyrinth of computer information networks.
Among the information exchanges on the Internet are electronic bulletin boards for people interested in food, in which users post questions (tahini: can it be frozen?) and ask for recipes (low-fat cookies, Chinese steamed buns). All eight people who responded had yet to use a CD-ROM cooking disk, which is probably because so few have been sold. Companies declined to supply exact figures on their disk sales, but none claimed to have sold as much as 25,000.
But some people who market the disks have also used them. "The Better Homes and Gardens Healthy Cooking CD Cookbook," produced by Multicom, has Mr. Norton-Middaugh enthusiastic. "The disk has both photographs and recipes," he said, "and that allows me, as a relative novice, to browse for inspiration. The computer does the initial sorting for me. I had a lot of zucchini this summer, and I could ask for the recipes using zucchini. I also sort by preparation time. I don't want anything that takes more than half an hour."
One man who replied through the Internet does have a computer in the kitchen and uses a Mangia software program, which performs many of the same functions of a CD-ROM but with no pictures or voice. He said it was a "fairly painless way to locate recipes, scale amounts, prepare shopping lists, etc."
Scott Fisher, who has written a book on programming CD-ROM's, "Multimedia Authoring," to be published by AP Professional, and also writes about food for The San Jose Mercury News, said, "The biggest downside, of course, is that pouring sauce Espagnole into your Macintosh is unlikely to improve either the sauce or the Mac."
Another Internet respondent said that he thought a CD-ROM would be useful if it offered advantages that a book did not, like cross indexes, the ability to search, color photos of ingredients, video for unusual techniques, the ability to make and organize notes, a section with descriptions of ingredients, suggestions on accompanying dishes and drinks, the history of a dish, the capacity to add recipes and comments, and the ability to print out recipes.
Is it significant that seven of the eight people who responded are men? The woman who responded said, "I prefer being able to curl up with a stack of cookbooks rather than sitting down at a computer."
Women cook while men compute?
After watching hours of CD-ROM cooking disks, punctuated with frequent calls to the technical experts in my office to fix this or that, I'm with the curler-upper. For now, at least. Never mind that a $2,000 piece of equipment is needed to play the disks, and that the disks list for $30 to $70. When the disks are able to do all the wonderful things that potential users would like them to do, then they will be useful. Mr. Fisher agrees that there are too many glitches. "It will be quite some time before they make economic sense," he said. "No one has bothered to do it properly."
David Pogue, who has written two books about computers and is a contributing editor of Macworld, the Macintosh publication, agrees. "CD-ROM is very, very hot," he said. "They are being gobbled up by millions, and that has been an incentive of software companies to put together something as quickly as possible -- shovelware -- just to get something on the market. Cookbooks still beat them."
Technically speaking only -- never mind the recipe content -- the cooking disk that comes within hailing distance of its potential is the BETTER HOMES AND GARDENS HEALTHY COOKING CD COOKBOOK.
It searches, it scales recipes up and down, it provides nutrition information, it prints out a shopping list. There are videos of techniques, but does the cook learn anything about separating yolks from whites when computer shows an egg separator and says, "Buy an egg separator"?
There's music, but it can become tiresome. The biggest drawback, though, is the length of the transitions from one subject matter to another. This program is slow. The screen goes black for a long time between searches.
COOKBOOK U.S.A. , on the other hand, doesn't sing or dance. But it has amillion recipes, lots of them with Velveeta and canned chicken soup. Does anyone really need 8,882 recipes just for brownies? Based on the contents of 4,000 cookbooks, the disk seems to be thrown together without much thought. The differences among recipes under a title may be no more than the amount of salt.
There are plenty of glitches. How, for example, did a recipe for cream-cheese brownies end up under appetizers? The most annoying feature is the program's inability to search properly. Ask for rice pudding under the recipe search function and nothing comes up. Ask for rice pudding by listing the ingredients it should contain and 443 recipes come up. Then go back and ask for rice pudding under recipe search and voila! -- it comes up with 443 recipes.
The computer specialists I consulted were not able to install THE NEW BASICS ELECTRONIC COOKBOOK so that it worked completely. It was possible to use the recipes, but my technical experts were not able to get the user guide or the video demonstrations to function. The disk offers the same recipes that have appealed to hundreds of thousands of people who have purchased the "Silver Palate" cookbook. But in an effort to differentiate the CD from a book, to jazz up the product, it provides some silly pictures with each recipe. Does anyone really need to see what a bag of sugar or an egg or a carton of milk looks like? And searching for recipes is time consuming.
The minute that serious cooks look at DIGITAL GOURMET, which has no pictures or sound, they are likely to be turned off: the ingredients in each recipe are listed in run-on fashion, not individually. Lots of molded salads and maraschino cherries do not make this program any more winning. But one appealing features is its ability to combine all the ingredients on the shopping list and alphabetize them so that if onions, for example, are called for in two recipes, the onions are listed next to one another.
JOHN SCHUMACHER'S NEW PRAGUE HOTEL COOKBOOK is simply the printed pages of a cookbook about Mr. Schumacher's restaurant in New Prague, Minn., transferred to a disk. A few pictures are thrown in, including one showing a visit to the restaurant by the former Czechoslovak leader Alexander Dubcek to the restaurant; there is also the voice of Mr. Schumacher explaining why he became a cook.
THE HEALING FOODS COOKBOOK , which surprisingly includes no sound or video but has "100 delicious recipes with curative power," is another disk that needs to go back to the drawing board. It supplies no more than is found on the printed page.
For those who love to hear Robin Leach talking about Elizabeth Taylor's wedding or want to watch Ivana Trump cavorting on a fashion runway, LIFESTYLES OF THE RICH AND FAMOUS COOKBOOK is a must. And at last, the secret of Miss Taylor's ability to remain full-figured is revealed: the disk offers recipes for four dishes from the wedding feast at her marriage to Larry Fortensky, and all of them contain cream.
As an alternative, if you want to organize your recipes electronically and you own a Macintosh, try the Mangia software. It has its own set of faults, but none as annoying as those on the CD-ROM.
For those who are not 100 percent computer literate, stick with the printed page. You can buy a lot of cookbooks for $2,000.
 
CD-ROM Buffet: What's Available
 THE following CD-ROM cooking disks require a computer with a CD-ROM drive and speakers. With I.B.M.-compatible computers, some can be played through Microsoft Windows software, some through DOS alone. Some come in versions compatible with Apple Macintosh computers.

HEADLINE: It's Not Yellow Journalism, but Red, White or Rose

BYLINE: By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

 BODY:
JOHN PAUL of Dundee, Ore., thinks wine is a laughing matter. In Bung, the newsletter of Cameron, his winery, he mimicked a supermarket tabloid. "Exclusive!" shouted a page 1 headline. "Bill Clinton Drank Pinot Noir in College! 'I Never Swallowed,' He Now Claims."
By contrast, a whiff of academe greeted subscribers to the sophisticated Simi News, published by the Simi Winery in Healdsburg, Calif. The main article: "Wild and Cultured Yeasts in Wine: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly." 
 The simple Rooster Tales from Sakonnet Vineyards in Little Compton, R.I., peddled America's Cup Red and Spinnaker White.
And a recipe for tournedoes of venison served with Norton wine, made from America's most underappreciated red grape, tantalized readers of the untitled publication of the Stone Hill Winery in Hermann, Mo.
These newsletters and hundreds of others (some drenched in prose as purple as grapes) form a backwater of wine journalism known by the industry's hoariest pun, the wine press. The quarterlies, semi-annuals, seasonals and every-so-oftens are informative, gossipy and entertaining in content, as well as formal, old shoe or whimsical in style.
They are free. Labels carry a winery's hometown and often list its phone number and address. If a winery has a newsletter, a phone call or postcard can put the customer on the mailing list.
"The highest use of the newsletter is to communicate the personality of the winery -- its values, its wines -- in a way that goes one-on-one with the customer," said J. William Moffett, editor in chief of Vineyard & Winery Management, a trade publication.
In an industry besieged by health issues, labeling rules, so-called neo-prohibitionism and Darwinism in a shrinking marketplace, the economics of survival focus on making wine daily fare. Thus, recipes abound.
Fetzer & Food, published in Emeryville, Calif., offered features like "Marrying Chilies With Wine" and "Enjoy Wine With Salad." Eric Miller, the wine maker at Chaddsford Winery in Chadds Ford, Pa., gave readers of his unnamed newsletter an intricate chart that matched wines with foods by leaning heavily on dominant flavor characteristics.
For those craving relief from chardonnay and cabernet sauvignon, the vanilla and chocolate of wines, the Latah Creek New-News Letter in Spokane, Wash., recommended alternatives: muscat canelli and lemberger.
The harvest is usually the year's top story. In Bethel Height-Lights, Terry Casteel, the wine maker at Bethel Heights Vineyard in Salem, Ore., analyzed grape-growing problems frankly: "Many people are not psychologically capable of thinning grapes. To a grower, a large crop . . . is like money in the bank."
Since newsletters promote current releases and prices, medals are a staple. The 1990 chardonnay "Grabs Gold & Double Silver at International Competition," said a headline in the Cinnabar Winery Press from Saratoga, Calif.
Technical-minded customers snacked on rootstock, vine spacing and trellis-management data in the Sutter Home Newsletter from St. Helena, Calif., and on an explanation of dosage (the sweetening of sparkling wine) in the untitled publication of Glenora Wine Cellars in Dundee, N.Y.
To read David Ramey on sauvignon blanc, barrel aging and fermentation in Chalk Board, published by Chalk Hill Winery in Healdsburg, Calif., is to appreciate the subtlety of a virtuoso wine maker.
Noshers have a newsletter, too: the Quady Dessert Wine Digest. Quady, a Madera, Calif., winery, specializes in ambrosias confected from black and orange muscat grapes, and in ports. Even the printer's ink used to report a Quady contest's prize-winning recipe -- chevre fromage blanc tart with summer fruits -- seemed caloric.

HEADLINE: Despite Successes, Kirov Opera Finds Reasons for Gloom

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Before the Kirov Opera made its much-admired visit to New York in the summer of 1992, the company seemed suffused with a kind of guarded optimism. Yes, the Russian economy was in disarray. But changes were in the works, and in the meantime the company's performances were at a high level of achievement and freedom promised much for the future.
Today, as the Kirov begins a weeklong Rimsky-Korsakov Festival here that has attracted many Western critics and visitors, that optimism seems frayed. Both Valery Gergiyev, the artistic director of the opera and music director of the Maryinsky Theater, which also houses the Kirov Ballet, and Anatoly F. Malkov, the administrative director of the theater, sounded grim and pessimistic compared with their mood in 1992. But they were hardly ready to give up the fight for artistic quality and financial independence, a fight that has solidified the Kirov Opera's reputation as Russia's best. 
 "There is bigger freedom, much bigger than even two years ago," said Mr. Gergiyev (pronounced GAIR-ghee-yev) on Monday before a performance of Rimsky-Korsakov's opera "Sadko." "Some parts of the economy are slowly improving. But it is much more difficult for us now than in 1992. It's almost impossible to expect serious financial support from the state. What we must count on is our own energy, our own ability to create something that will support our artistic plans."
 
Sources of Income
 Mr. Malkov agreed. "I can't see now any stability or improvement in the financial situation in this country," he said. Eighty percent of the theater's income is from outside the traditional Russian state-support system, he added, most of it from the West. He cited audio and video recording arrangements with Philips Records in the Netherlands, NHK in Japan and the BBC in Britain; co-productions with European and American companies; tours (including the company's first to Japan, last year) and lowest on the list, corporate and private sponsors both Western and Russian.
He said that in addition to three wage increases last year to keep pace with Russia's runaway inflation, the theater's 1,240 employees had gained a 50 percent raise in real terms when the Maryinsky Theater was named to the short list of Russian cultural treasures by President Boris N. Yeltsin, with an increased subsidy to match.
The company's artistic accomplishments since Mr. Gergiyev, now 40, took over in 1988 are internationally recognized. Its production of Prokofiev's "Fiery Angel," seen in New York in 1992, was voted best opera production in Japan for 1993, Mr. Malkov said. Mr. Gergiyev received Russia's highest musical honor from President Yeltsin on Dec. 29. He was named conductor of the year at the Classical Music Awards in London on Jan. 21. And the company's audio and video recordings have been highly regarded by critics and the public.
 
A Heavy Schedule
 The ambitious Rimsky-Korsakov Festival, which began with a concert on Sunday night, seems to be stretching the theater's hard-working staff to its limits. Within one week there will be four operas by Rimsky-Korsakov: "Sadko," "The Maid of Pskov," "Kaschey the Deathless" and a new production of the monumental "Legend of the Invisible City of Kitezh."
"Kaschey" is being paired with his tone poem "Scheherazade," and there are four other concerts, some of Rimsky-Korsakov alone, some offering his orchestrations of other composers and some intended to place the composer in the context of his predecessors, contemporaries and successors, including Stravinsky, Debussy, Ravel, Respighi, Prokofiev and Messiaen. Mr. Gergiyev said his next festival would be devoted to the music Stravinsky composed while still in Russia.
The current festival, which follows similar celebrations of Mussorgsky in 1989 and Prokofiev in 1991-92, has attracted several star Russian singers who have active careers in the West. They include the soprano Galina Gorchakova, who has just flown in from a run of "Fiery Angels" at La Scala and who will sing the leading roles in both "Kitezh" and "The Maid of Pskov."
"The more the importance of our projects, the more chances are that major singers will want to come here," Mr. Gergiyev said. "Importance" includes, of course, the opportunity for audio and video exposure; Philips is recording the entire festival for possible future release.
 
Keeping Audience Russian
 Still, the constant struggle for money sometimes seems to wear down both Mr. Gergiyev and Mr. Malkov. Especially when Western sponsors and artists are frightened by the country's political turmoil.
"People could be scared off by the political tension," Mr. Gergiyev worried. "Not to speak of tanks in the streets of Moscow."
A major concern is keeping ticket prices within reach of the increasingly impoverished Russian public; by one international estimate, 40 percent of all Russians are now below the poverty line. As in all major Russian theaters, tourists are expected to pay $50 and more for their tickets, while comparable seats sell to Russians for less than $3 at current black market exchange rates.
"It's a moral issue," Mr. Gergiyev said. "We could raise prices and play for foreign tourists and the new rich, which is a new class here, although they are not all serious music lovers. But our public can't afford any more; even $3 is a lot for them."
Despite Mr. Gergiyev's assurances that the Rimsky-Korsakov Festival is proceeding exactly as he planned it, some recent Kirov stars are absent, and Mr. Malkov admitted that money was a problem.
Without specifically conceding the issue, Mr. Gergiyev had a veiled warning for his missing stars. "Singers know that if they are too often absent here, that empty places must be filled," he said. "We had wonderful singers, and it looked as if they were irreplaceable. But there are superb young voices, and no one is irreplaceable."
Unable to afford the regular fees of Western artists, Mr. Gergiyev hopes to win them through personal contacts and the pleasure of working with his forces in this opulent, acoustically flattering theater. Placido Domingo, whom Mr. Gergiyev will conduct in Verdi's "Otello" at the Metropolitan Opera in March, has already been here for the same opera and is president of the international Friends of the Kirov Opera.
 
The Company's Mission
 Mr. Gergiyev said he wanted to persuade Mr. Domingo to appear in Verdi's "Forza del Destino" and Wagner's "Parsifal," the latter linked with "Lohengrin" in one abstract production. He said he would also like James Conlon, Esa-Pekka Salonen and Christian Thielemann to conduct here, either at the opera or as part of the White Nights music festival from May through July, which Mr. Gergiyev took over as artistic director last year.
For all the explorations of Italian and German repertory, the Kirov remains a Russian company, the primary preserver and revitalizer of the Russian operatic tradition. In his frequent excursions to the West, Mr. Gergiyev seeks to assert his company's claims on that repertory and not to succumb to Western promoters' insistence on the same tired round of war horses: "Boris Godunov," "Eugene Onegin" and maybe "The Queen of Spades."
"You can't let commercial concerns overcome artistic priorities," he said, speaking obliquely of the many Russian performing institutions that have done just that. "I had to fight to get Paris to accept 'Kitezh.' The promoters are right: they want to sell tickets. But I am right, too: we can't always do the same things."
A judgment of the Rimsky-Korsakov Festival, reflecting both the current state of the Kirov company and the long-suffering reputation of Rimsky-Korsakov as a composer, must await its conclusion this weekend.
"When it's over, we can all together decide if it was really needed," Mr. Gergiyev said. "Then, the importance of this festival will become clearer."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Valery Gergiyev, artistic director of Kirov Opera and music director of the Maryinsky Theater. (Valentin M. Baranovsky)

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
With Perfect Timing

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
Bill Clinton gives a good speech. There is in him a bit of the preacher, some of the earnest high school orator, a little carnival barker and some door-to-door salesman. You could tell how well his State of the Union address played by how fast his political opponents rushed to judge it empty rhetoric.
Before, the Gallup poll found that 67 percent of those they surveyed thought the President was on the right track. Afterward the number rose to 85 percent. 
 And that wasn't only because Mr. Clinton can deliver a speech as though he were the Fuller Brush man and you were out of dusting rags, or because he sometimes sounded more Republican than Bob Dole, with a million times the charm. It's that his timing's right.
Let's go back to George Bush's first State of the Union, and to Ronald Reagan's too, 12 years ago. Mr. Reagan's proposal for a New Federalism -- remember that? -- made only a casual and condescending mention of the growing deficit. "Raise present taxes to cut future deficits, they tell us -- well, I don't buy that argument," said the man who would preside over Jurassic deficit, huge and out of control.
Here's a blast from the past: The first big applause line in Mr. Bush's first State of the Union was "Panama is free!" He went on to devote five sentences to the deficit, and informed the American people that the Secretary of Health and Human Services would be studying the subject of "the quality, accessibility and cost of our nation's health care system."
But before Bill Clinton even gave his first official State of the Union Message last week, he'd given two other substantive, nationally televised speeches, one on deficit reduction and the other on universal health care. Mr. Clinton's opponents will say these issues are straw men, tell you that the economy will take care of the deficit, and that the health care system has problems but no crisis.
But they cannot use charts and statistics to will away the fact that millions of Americans, even those who don't fully understand Federal spending or managed competition, have come to perceive both deficit reduction and health care provision as long-overdue areas of reform.
They can't will away the fact that, by the time Governor Clinton became President Clinton, both government and health care spending had become so monumental that the time was precisely right to showcase both. And Mr. Clinton did just that.
Some of Mr. Clinton's greatest failures have come when, as with gay men and lesbians in the military or an end to the H.I.V. exclusion for immigrants, he's been challenged to be an unreconstructed liberal on social issues. Now reconstructed, he came down heavily on crime and welfare reform in his first State of the Union.
He's too smart to think either issue is as simple as people would like or as he made them sound. For a start, you can't reform welfare unless you reform child care. And mandating sentences without addressing the root causes of crime just guarantees that America's biggest growth industry will be the manufacture of felons.
But violent crime and welfare dependency have become problems so pressing that the time is right not only for a President to attack both, but for a Democratic President to do so, co-opting Republicans. And without reprisals from the usual suspects. Liberals will never be swayed by either "two years and out" for welfare or "three strikes and you're out" for felons. But the timing is bad to restate bromides about the cycle of poverty, even if they happen to be true.
Mr. Clinton's first State of the Union was a little like the story of the blind men and the elephant, in which each man feels the animal and then constructs something wildly different, in his mind's eye, from disparate parts: part new Democrat, part old Republican, part progressive and populist and Perot. Vision as Chinese menu, column A and column B.
But maybe the timing is right for that, too, for the President who insists that pragmatism is the only useful ideology. Now there will be negotiations, and concessions, and horse-trading, and in the end reducing the deficit and providing universal health care and crafting a crime bill and reforming welfare may owe at least as much to Republican legislators as to Democratic policy wonks.
But no one will remember that. Bill Clinton named and claimed them. His timing was impeccable. And in politics, as in so much else, timing can be everything.

HEADLINE: Powerful Business Group Backs Rival to President's Health Plan

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
The Business Roundtable, representing about 200 of the nation's largest companies, struck a blow against President Clinton's health care plan tonight by endorsing a rival proposal that would not guarantee universal insurance coverage.
Despite urgent last-minute lobbying by Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary, the policy committee of the Roundtable voted to treat the rival bill as a "starting point" for legislation on health insurance. 
 The rival bill, sponsored by Representative Jim Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee, is the only major health care measure with the support of Democrats and Republicans alike.
 
Hopes for Competition
 John Ong, who is the chairman of the influential Roundtable and the chief executive of the B. F. Goodrich Company, said the policy committee preferred Mr. Cooper's plan because it believed that his proposal would foster competition and bring down the cost of health care.
The White House expressed disappointment over the vote, although its effect on Capitol Hill was uncertain. While the endorsement is bound to help Mr. Cooper, his supporters and opponents alike said the vote would hardly be decisive in the swirling legislative journey that awaits the health care issue.
"I am humbled by their support," Mr. Cooper said of the business group's decision.
Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, said: "We're disappointed but not surprised. We think it's a mistake, obviously. But they say it's a starting point, and we look forward to a constructive debate about it."
Mr. Ong said the Cooper plan had been approved by "a significant majority" of the committee, "but I won't give you the specific vote."
Despite the endorsement, Mr. Ong said business was wary of a feature in the plan denying employers tax deductions for anything beyond the cheapest health insurance.
The Roundtable made it clear that it liked Mr. Cooper's approach of creating cooperatives so small businesses could join in buying insurance, saying this would foster competition. Under the Cooper plan employers with fewer than 100 workers could join cooperatives and would have to offer their employees insurance but would not have to pay for it. Bigger companies would not have to join alliances but would have to make insurance available to their employees.
Under the Clinton plan, all employers would be required to pay most of the cost of such insurance.
The Clinton plan would also limit how fast health insurance premiums rise, aiming to reduce increases to no more than the nation's overall rate of inflation. That position is opposed by the business group.
Mr. Cooper argues that his plan would offer all Americans access to insurance and would lead to universal coverage without costing jobs, as he argues that Mr. Clinton's plan would.
The President, who has said access to insurance coverage is insufficient, has threatened to veto any plan that does not provide universal coverage.
Mr. Ong said the Clinton plan had "the potential, if enacted in its current form, to create additional unfunded, off-budget entitlement programs." Mr. Clinton has proposed creating a prescription drug benefit for the elderly under Medicare and some long-term care guarantees.
"It also seeks to control costs, which is a very worthy objective," Mr. Ong said, "but to do that not through harnessing market forces but rather through Government regulation of the health care industry and what are in effect price controls."
 
Bipartisan Support
 The Cooper plan is sponsored by 30 other House Democrats and 26 House Republicans, as well as three Democrats and one Republican in the Senate. While three other alternative health care measures have more supporters, the bipartisan character of the Cooper camp gives the plan's supporters a tactical advantage beyond their numbers.
The Roundtable brings together chief executives of the nation's largest companies like General Electric, General Mills and General Motors. The head of its task force on health, welfare and retirement income, which drew up the position before it was voted on by the policy committee, is Robert C. Winters, chief executive of the Prudential Insurance Company of America.
The Roundtable, meeting here, would not make Mr. Winters available to reporters. But Mr. Ong said there was no conflict of interest for the insurance executive.
"We try to take a broad view that emphasizes the health of the nation's economy and the overall competitiveness of U.S. industry," Mr. Ong said. "We try to ignore as much as we can the interests of our companies. I don't think there is any merit in supposing that Mr. Winters or anybody else had any bias or prejudice."
 
Reaction in Congress
 Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, the West Virginia Democrat who has been the Administration's chief liaison with business on the health care issue, took a different view. He said the most active members of the task force came from the insurance and drug industries.
"They don't want the people to get insurance at a better price," Mr. Rockefeller said. "I think business did themselves a disservice in this. I think they let their peers in the insurance industry snooker them."
Mr. Rockefeller said big business liked Mr. Cooper's plan "because he does not change the status quo." The Senator said big business was so conservative that if the Administration had won its support "it would have been the upset of the decade."
Mr. Rockefeller's view that the Roundtable decision did not matter much was shared by one of Mr. Cooper's allies, Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, who is the plan's leading backer in the Senate.
"I don't think it makes a lot of difference," Mr. Breaux said. "We've got to have 60 votes, and the only way we're going to get it is through a realistic compromise."
Earlier in the day, Mr. Cooper had a harder time with his colleagues on the House Committee on Energy and Commerce. Representative John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who heads the committee, as well as Representative Henry A. Waxman, the California Democrat who heads the health subcommittee, led a critical questioning of him. The session focused on the absence of any guarantee of universal coverage in his bill.
Mr. Waxman said the measure offered a "hollow promise" of access to health insurance that would be meaningless to people who could not afford it.
Mr. Cooper's chief co-sponsor, Representative Fred Grandy, Republican of Iowa, said, "Mr. Cooper and I use a different mechanism than the Administration to achieve universal coverage, but I believe we share the same underlying goal."
 
Seeing Savings for States
 The Clinton Administration, in defense of its plan, made public today a study showing that reduced spending for Medicaid, the government health program for the poor, would save the states $47 billion from 1996 to 2000, and that in their role as employers they would save $6 billion more.
The study was not broken down by state.
At a panel discussion on health care here, sponsored by American Health Line, a political information service and two foundations, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the No. 2 Republican in the House, put distance between himself and the Republican camp that contends that there is no crisis in the nation's health care system.
Referring to health care, Mr. Gingrich said, "I think it's silly to describe it as anything other than a very serious problem."
But he went on to attack the Clinton plan as one that would lead to a huge Government intrusion into the health care system. He said Republicans were willing to work with the Administration and Democrats on producing a bipartisan bill, but he said the Administration would have to set aside the premium price controls and mandatory alliances in its plan.
David R. Gergen, counselor to the President, was also on the panel and characterized Mr. Clinton's position in these words, "The President believes that his way is the best, but he is willing to listen and talk to people who may have better ways."
He said the Administration would continue to have reqular discussions with Mr. Cooper and Mr. Breaux.

HEADLINE: GIULIANI OUTLINES A BUDGET TO CUT GOVERNMENT SIZE

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
Saying New York City faced "a fiscal emergency," Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani outlined a budget plan yesterday that would reduce the city's spending for the first time since the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, eliminating at least 15,000 municipal jobs, consolidating departments and slashing agency budgets by more than $1 billion.
The Mayor's cuts would fall heavily on the city's Department of Sanitation, on social services and on the school system, which alone would face a reduction of 2,500 jobs, or more than half, from its administrative staff. 
 Overall, in those departments and others, the plan would have the greatest impact on the city's unionized work force, which the Mayor plans to cut over the next 18 months by 15,000 people, or 7 percent, through attrition, severance packages, or if they fail, layoffs. Mr. Giuliani warned the unions that they would face even more cuts by layoffs if he does not win concessions on health benefits and productivity gains totaling about $500 million.
 
Wide Range of Cuts
 And while the Mayor and his aides say they have attempted to produce a financial plan that would minimize pain, it includes a wide range of cuts that will be felt by many New Yorkers, including less money for museums, fewer pickups of recyclable trash and delayed renovations of subway stations. [Page B3.]
The plan, a preliminary version of the budget he is to submit to the City Council in April, highlights the new Mayor's campaign pledge to create a leaner, more efficient government that lives within its means and provides essential services -- all without tax increases for businesses or the city's seven and a half million residents.
"We are going to cut the size of government so that we live within our means," the Mayor said in a speech broadcast on radio and television last night.
Arguing that the government had in fact grown so large that it was strangling an economic recovery, Mr. Giuliani included tax cuts that would total $783 million over the next four years -- despite his facing an immediate deficit of $2.3 billion for the fiscal year that begins in July.
 
Two Tax Reductions
 He said he would reduce two taxes -- the commercial rent tax and the unincorporated business tax-- to help businesses, especially those in the city's neighborhoods beyond Manhattan. He also promised to cut the city's tax on hotel rooms by December and the city's sales tax on clothes under $100 by next year as a way to stimulate the economy.
The Mayor's plan also detailed the first steps of his effort to "reinvent government" by turning over some city services to private companies or by trying new approaches now used in other cities. For example the administration hopes to save $7 million next year and $88 million each year after that by fingerprinting recipients of public assistance to reduce fraud and waste, a program that the Mayor said has had success in Los Angeles and in a pilot project in Rockland and Onondaga counties.
The reaction to Mr. Giuliani's plan varied widely. Allen J. Proctor, the executive director of the Financial Control Board, the state agency that oversees the city's fiscal management, called it "bold and courageous." Richard P. Larkin of Standard and Poor's Corporation, a bond rating agency, described it as "a good start" that needed "the test of time."
But others, from elected officials to union leaders to advocates of particular programs argued that the cuts would fall hardest on those who could afford it least. Una Clarke, a City Council member from Brooklyn who is a member of the Council's 22-member black and Hispanic caucus, said the preliminary budget plan would create not "a leaner city, but a meaner city."
"As this plan is presented," she said, "the poor will bear the brunt of it."
The plan, which Mr. Giuliani outlined for elected officials and reporters at City Hall yesterday, is required by law to show that the city's budgets over the next four years are balanced. While it offers a broad strategy, it is not the Mayor's budget, which he will present on April 26.
Mr. Giuliani said that between now and then he would put into his budget any "better ideas than those proposed" to help close the deficit or make the city more efficient. "This is the beginning, not the end of the process," he said.
Many of his proposals require approval from the City Council or the State Legislature, many of whose members owe a great deal to the unions that Mr. Giuliani intends to take on.
The Council's Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, responded positively to the budget proposals, though he said there were some concerns, particularly with the depth of the cuts at the Board of Education. The council's black and Hispanic caucus opposed the cuts in the schools budget unless a thorough review of the impact on children was conducted.
In fact, the Mayor's cuts at the Board of Education could prove the most controversial. While the city provides $3.5 billion, a little less than half of the board's total budget, the seven-member board has final say over how to use it. Mr. Giuliani's proposal would cut the board's budget by $291 million, primarily through the reduction of 2,500 administrative positions.
Through a spokesman, the Schools Chancellor, Ramon C. Cortines, signaled the board's unhappiness, saying the Mayor's proposal included "many unrealistic assumptions and appears to take a scattergun approach to the budget problems."
It also remains to be seen whether other assumptions in the Mayor's plan, including the receipt of about $400 million in added state or Federal aid, will come to pass. In addition, the Municipal Assistance Corporation has not yet decided whether to approve the use of a $200 million surplus fund to pay for severance packages for workers asked to leave their jobs.
 
Union Leader Is Opposed
 And still other proposals require at least some agreement from the unions, which have vowed to fight. "He can't just come in here and tell us, 'We want to take your benefits.' " said Stanley Hill, the president of District Council 37, the city's largest municipal union. "I can't negotiate that way."
The budget for next year is expected to total $31.2 billion, a reduction of $516 million from the current year's budget of $31.7 billion. The decline in revenues reflects a drop in the value of the city's real estate, on which the city bases property taxes, the largest share of the city's revenues.
That decline in value -- nearly $200 million -- reflects the lingering effects of the recession on the city's real estate markets. Mr. Giuliani's revenue estimates for coming years are based on expectations of an economic upturn, including modest increases in sales, banking and personal income taxes, which fiscal monitors said were realistic estimates.
Still, the Mayor went to lengths to say that he would not simply use future increases in revenues to raise the city's spending again. He argued that the size of the city's government started to climb again after the fiscal crisis, when the city slashed its work force and spending after flirting with bankruptcy.
Mr. Giuliani said the growth of government had stalled the city's economic recovery; as the city lost jobs due to recession, he said, more of the burden fell on taxpayers and businesses, forcing even more to leave the city.
"We have budgeted on the theory that we were unique for the last 10 or 15 years," he said, "that we could just increase spending and that we didn't have to take into account the tax burden, the fee burden, the fine burden we were placing on businesses, including small business."
Mr. Giuliani's plan identifies only 4,089 of the jobs it plans to reduce through the severance package, as well as the 2,500 cuts it proposed for the Board of Education. The administration plans to eliminate an additional 9,600 by June 1995 through a combination of severance, attrition and, if necessary, layoffs.
In the case of the Department of Sanitation, he said, layoffs could be avoided if the city wins concessions on the amount of garbage sanitation workers collect each day. Of the jobs already identified for elimination, almost 1,500 fall in that department.
"It's an offer to sanitation workers and everyone else in this city," Mr. Giuliani said of his plan. "Help us to make you more productive. If you do, then this massive change doesn't have to take place. If you don't then the massive change is inevitable."
The Mayor's plan also detailed the first steps of his effort to restructure the city's agencies -- for a savings of $28 million next year, with larger savings in the future.
He said he would consolidate the functions of the Department of Consumer Affairs, the Human Rights Commission, the Taxi and Limousine Commission and other smaller agencies into other departments. And he said he would also merge the Board of Education's security division into the Police Department.
The plan also called for competition in government services, allowing companies to bid for some functions including street resurfacing and the water pollution control plants.
Under the plan, the administration would also eliminate services it no longer considered essential, selling for example, 85 of the city's 500 gas stations. It also calls for selling either all or part of WNYC, the city's radio and television stations, as well as selling the city's parking garages and the land under the U.N. Plaza Hotel on First Avenue across from the United Nations.
While these steps would save the city only $28 million next year, they are symbolic of the administration's belief that it can continue to offer essential services for less money.
"The city cannot be in every business," he said. "We cannot afford it."
Mr. Giuliani's supporters said that the Mayor's plan addressed the city's real problems -- its recurring deficit because of increases in spending -- without resorting to fiscal gimmickry or one-time revenue proposals that the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins used.

HEADLINE: Taking On the Unions;
With Few Debts to Labor, Giuliani Offers Budget Plan With Cutbacks in Work Force

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
Rudolph W. Giuliani, New York City's first Republican Mayor in a generation, swept into office last November with less support from municipal unions than any other mayor in recent memory. Most of the city's labor movement backed David N. Dinkins. The teachers remained neutral. Only the firefighters, correction officers and police rallied to Mr. Giuliani's side.
Now Mr. Giuliani has shown what it means to owe few debts to labor. For his fiscal plan makes quite clear that the new Mayor intends to force down the size of the city work force by 15,000 employees from what he calls a "historic high" and also to wrest productivity savings, new work rules and benefits concessions from the workers who remain. 
 "He's clearly targeted the municipal employee unions," said Raymond D. Horton of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private watchdog group, "and he's constructing a political strategy designed to put as much pressure on them as possible."
Mr. Giuliani's $31.2 billion budget plan offers most of the unions a series of hard choices. They can agree to accept severance packages as buyouts for up to 8,000 workers that Mr. Giuliani wants off the payroll by July, or face layoffs. They can make $200 million in benefits concessions, or face more layoffs. They can agree to millions of dollars in productivity savings -- everything from smaller bridge repair crews, to fewer guards in some parts of the prison system, to longer workdays and routes for sanitation workers -- or take more layoffs.
Posing the severance package as the alternative to layoffs, Mr. Giuliani said, "We're very hopeful that this will work. We think this is the best way to do it. We think it's the most humane way to do it. But if the end result is that we have to do it the other way, I'm prepared to do it."
 
An Uncomfortable Position
 Mayors have talked tough like this before. In the depths of the city's recession, Mr. Dinkins made threats to lay off 11,000 workers, and ultimately in one year the work force did drop by about 12,000, but only about half of that reduction came through layoffs.
But such actions always left Mayor Dinkins in an uncomfortable position, caught between the constraints of a tight budget and the debts owed his allies in the labor movement.
As soon as times got better, the city staffing levels climbed up again. And Mr. Dinkins was generous at the bargaining table. He negotiated a high -- and widely criticized -- wage settlement with the teachers in 1990. And in 1993, despite tough talk of productivity, he reached a settlement with a coalition of the city's largest nonuniformed municipal unions that granted a modest wage without winning any direct productivity gains or work-rule changes.
Mr. Giuliani has made clear that he is a different man with a different constituency and agenda. Though he promised to minimize service reductions, he has no ideological or political commitment to expansive government. Yesterday he made impassioned arguments that the city work force must shrink, that New York City employs more workers than the states of California and New York.
Even as he called for layoffs, he also proposed nearly $800 million in tax reductions by the end of the fiscal year of 1998, a move he said would assure that the city did not have the revenues to allow the work force to creep up again.
While he urged the unions yesterday to negotiate with him and to choose productivity gains and cooperation, Mr. Giuliani has signaled in many ways that he would stand up to a confrontation. He often cites Philadelphia's Mayor, Edward G. Rendell, as a model. And Mr. Rendell is best known for staring down his once powerful unions and winning concessions despite a brief strike.
 
'On the Backs of City Workers'
 Some of the unions yesterday indicated that they saw the budget plan as a virtual declaration of war. "Especially when you look at proposals as they reflect on our colleagues in the Sanitation Department, I think this is being balanced on the backs of city workers," said Arthur Cheliotes, president of Local 1180 of the Communications Workers of America, which represents administrators throughout the city government.
And union members expressed frustration that Mr. Giuliani did not seem to appreciate their work.
"He just doesn't understand what we do," said Nicholas D. West, an assistant principal at A. Philip Randolph High School in Harlem, responding to Mr. Giuliani's call to cut the administrative staff of the school system by more than half. "He is advocating reducing the number of administrators and support people in the schools, but he just doesn't understand how much that will hamper meeting the needs of the students. It's just not a good idea."
A sanitation worker saw in Mr. Giuliani, the Federal prosecutor turned Mayor, a deep-seated bias against all city workers except those in law enforcement. "For him, it's easier to get on the Sanitation Department's case than the police," said Charles Amoraso, a sanitation worker, speaking at a department garage in Maspeth, Queens. "If I were a politician, I'd do the same thing."
 
'Too Much at Stake'
 Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said the Mayor was inviting a confrontation by calling publicly for vast concessions and changes in working conditions that challenged the existing contracts. "He's saying to hell with your contract," said Mr. Hill, who heads the city's largest municipal union. "He can't operate this way. We won't allow it. There's too much at stake."
A confrontation between Mr. Giuliani and the unions does pose some risks to him. If Mr. Giuliani is forced to turn to layoffs, the work-force cuts could be less controllable under union rules, leading to even more noticeable reductions in city services. It is also not clear how long New Yorkers would endure, say, a garbage strike without blaming the Mayor.
But Mr. Giuliani's financial plan presents at least as much of a challenge to the municipal unions and a test of how much clout they still have. The fiery personalities and iron-fisted bargainers who reigned in the 1960's and 1970's are long gone.
Would the municipal unions' many allies in the City Council support them if it meant the Council had to call for tax increases to save jobs? Would workers follow union leaders if confrontations loomed? In a time when unions are being forced to give back hard-won gains at bargaining tables across the country, would New Yorkers sympathize if the municipal unions didn't bow to the same trend?
The first test could come with the sanitation workers' union, which has been working without a contract since October 1991 and has been singled out for many of the layoffs and productivity gains in Mr. Giuliani's budget plan, even threatened with privatizing of routes in future years.
Yesterday, Peter Scarlatos, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, was being cautious. "The biggest thing is sitting at the table," he said. "I'm not getting overexcited now. I'm ready to sit down and talk."
