HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Special interests on the attack. In this case, they're beekeepers.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
TO bee or not to bee: That was the question facing Congress last fall when it dropped subsidies for domestic honey producers, sacrificing the most easily lampooned symbol of profligacy in the Federal budget. But do not underestimate the political tenacity of America's 2,000 commercial beekeepers. They are now asking the White House to substitute hidden subsidies, collected directly from consumers, for the traditional kind dunned from taxpayers.
The question is whether President Clinton will risk the wrath of E. (Kika) de la Garza, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee and loyal friend of the honey makers, by saying no. The more important question, perhaps, is whether Washington can stand up to special interests, or will simply pass the buck. 
 Uncle Sam got interested in bees during World War II, when beeswax was in military demand and everything sweet was considered a morale booster for the boys at the front. After the war the habit stuck: Congress enacted a price support system to insure a steady supply of the bee's precious bodily fluid. Happily, the program cost little since the free market price of honey rarely fell below the support price.
That changed in the 1980's, however, with the arrival of lower-priced imports. From 1980 through 1988, Washington spent $525 million buying up surpluses -- and in the process warehoused enough honey to supply the nation for two full years in the event of nuclear war. Since then, both the cost of the program and the embarrassment of the Federal honey glut have been eased by a combination of higher world prices and a shift from price guarantees to direct subsidies.
The world may not long remember the fate of the honey money: The Congressional Budget Office estimated that the total savings from eliminating supports would amount to a mere $60 million over the next five years. But the small number of beneficiaries and the frivolous nature of the product made the program a perfect foil for politicians seeking to prove that this time they meant business about deficits. After the requisite jokes about sweet deals that stung the taxpayers, Congress axed all honey subsidies from the 1994 budget.
That, however, is not the end of the story. On Sept. 20, 1993, President Clinton wrote to Representative de la Garza to make amends. In the letter he acknowledged the industry's "grave concerns" about the adverse impact of honey imports from China, inviting an investigation of same. And last month the United States International Trade Commission (a Federal agency with close ties to Congress) recommended that the beekeepers be given relief under a cold war statute allowing the President to reduce imports from centrally planned economies that "disrupt" the American market.
Just how much the stiff tariffs recommended by the commission majority would affect average honey prices is unclear since China shares the world export market with Mexico and Argentina. What is clear, though, is that China is the world's low-cost supplier of the lower-grade honey going to industrial uses for products like cookies, breakfast cereals and cough drops. And the American companies that process industrial honey are worried that in the face of prices raised by tariffs, buyers will switch to corn- or fruit-based sweeteners.
Economists have broader complaints. For one thing, tariffs are widely seen as a more pernicious way to aid domestic producers than direct subsidies because they distort prices and production, rather than simply transferring money from one pocket to another. For another, tariffs appear in no Government budget and are thus far less likely to be scrutinized in the future than taxpayer outlays. "If we are going to help honey producers at all, surely subsidies are better than import protection," concluded Lynn Daft, a Washington consultant who served as President Jimmy Carter's adviser on agriculture.
Gary Hufbauer of the Institute for International Economics offers yet another concern. The logic behind Section 406 protection, he notes, is to prevent state-dominated industries from trashing their American counterparts. But there is little reason to believe that China's beekeepers are dancing to Beijing's tune. Last year the United States Department of Agriculture's representative in the Chinese capital reported that "the general honey policy of the central Government is to let the market set the price."
Hence the impact of restricting imports of Chinese honey could be perverse, at least from the perspective of foreign policy. "It would invite China to impose bureaucratic controls," Mr. Hufbauer said -- controls that set back the process of decentralizing the Chinese economy and weakening the power of its authoritarian elite.
President Clinton is not obliged to follow the trade commission's recommendation; he could just decide to leave the bees out in the cold. But don't bet on it. As Representative Harris W. Fawell, an Illinois Republican, put it during the Congressional debate: "If one dies and goes to heaven and wants to come back to earth and have eternal life, come back as a Federal program."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
Traders seem to prefer Viacom's latest bid for Paramount because it offers more protection against stock market uncertainties than a rival offer from QVC Network. [D1.] Paramount will record a loss of $18 million from its share in the USA Network. [D8.]
Capital Cities/ABC formed a joint venture with Brillstein-Grey Entertainment, a management company that handles Dana Carvey, Carol Burnett, Garry Shandling and Mike Myers. [D1.] 
Stratton Oakmont will pay $2.5 million in penalties under a settlement with the S.E.C. on charges that the Lake Success, L.I., penny-stock brokerage defrauded investors. [D6.]
Disney will rehabilitate and reopen the landmark New Amsterdam Theater on 42d Street in Manhattan in 1996. [B1.]
 
The Economy
A new wave of resorts and theme parks in Las Vegas has investors wagering that family entertainment will draw crowds now that casinos around the country provide Americans with opportunities to gamble closer to home. [D1.]
The prospect of higher interest rates has failed to alarm the business people who worry about them most, reflecting a feeling that any tightening of monetary policy will be modest. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Japan Socialists Threaten to Quit Coalition in Dispute Over Taxes

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa pushed his governing coalition toward collapse today by announcing that he would only reduce income taxes to revive Japan's stalled economy if the cuts were offset by an even larger increase in sales taxes in three years.
While the decision touched on arcane issues related to tax policy, it quickly created a political crisis that could affect Washington as well as Japan. 
 The Socialists, the largest party in the coalition, have fought the sales tax increase and threatened to quit the Government this morning. It was the second time in a week that policy differences have left the frail coalition divided.
The Government was forced to reconsider its decision only hours later because of the Socialsts' threat. "If the Socialists' stance stays unchanged today, I am afraid the situation will be serious for the ruling coalition," said Masayoshi Takemura, the chief Cabinet secretary, who added that the Prime Minister might still be flexible.
 
Victory for Finance Ministry
 The announcement was a major victory for the bureaucrats of the Finance Ministry, who with conservatives in the Government were the principal backers of the sales tax increase. They say that without it the Government will run huge budget deficits.
The Socialists favor a big income tax cut to try to jump-start the Japanese economy, which is caught in its worst recession in the post-war era. Mr. Hosokawa said this morning that he wanted to reduce income, business and local taxes by the equivalent of $55 billion. Some of those reductions would be retroactive to Jan. 1. That would be part of a larger package to revive the economy, including as much as $82.5 billion in increased public works spending and low-cost Government loans to businesses.
But Mr. Hosokawa said the sales tax would be increased by an even larger amount, beginning in 1997. The Socialists adamantly oppose such a big increase, arguing that it will fall disproportionately on salaried workers, whose overall tax burden has been climbing in recent years.
The Clinton Administration has also argued for a big tax cut to stimulate the economy, since rapid economic expansion would attract more imports and reduce Japan's huge trade surplus. Some American officials have suggested that a coordinated increase in the sales tax might negate the positive effects of the income tax cut and thus do little to adjust the trade surplus.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen issued a statement in Washington describing the proposal as "a step in the right direction," but he also said he needed more details before making a final judgment.
 
A Tax by Any Other Name
 Mr. Hosokawa said the current 3 percent sales tax would climb to 7 percent, as of April 1, 1997, and be renamed a national welfare tax.
The name change was intended to convey the idea that the tax was needed to cover some of the growing social welfare costs the Government is facing as Japanese society ages. The percentage of the population 65 years or older is expected to more than double, from 12.1 percent in 1990 to 25.5 percent in 2020, according to Finance Ministry figures.
However, Mr. Hosokawa refused a Socialist demand that he write into the law a clause requiring that all the tax be used for social welfare programs, such as pensions and health care. That means, in effect, that the money would be used for whatever the Finance Ministry deems appropriate.
The increase is expected to generate the equivalent of about $73.4 billion a year in new revenues. That would more than offset the proposed reductions in income taxes.
 
Bureaucrats Win Again
 Mr. Hosokawa had hinted at times in recent months that he was willing to reduce income taxes as a way of igniting the economy without the sales tax increase, because individual consumers would benefit most from such a policy. But this morning's announcement made it clear that the Finance Ministry had won.
Tomiichi Murayama, the Socialist Party chairman, said his party was considering pulling its six ministers from Mr. Hosokawa's Cabinet and voting against the new tax proposals when they come up in Parliament. That could force the whole Cabinet to resign.
Just last week the Government was also threatened over the divisive issue of reforming the electoral and campaign financing laws. In that case, too, the Socialists lost the struggle, but decided to remain in the coalition in hopes of winning the tax battle.
"I told the Prime Minister that his administration should include wording in the new tax legislation that would obligate the Government to use all the revenue from the new tax for expenditures related to welfare," Mr. Murayama said. "However, the Premier turned a deaf ear to our party's request."

HEADLINE: Report Finds Pills Cost More in U.S. Than Britain

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Top-selling prescription drugs typically cost much more in the United States than in Britain, where drug company profits are limited as part of a national health insurance program, the General Accounting Office said in a report today.
Drug company executives challenged many of the findings, but members of Congress cited the report as evidence that the Government should impose some restraints on drug prices, as President Clinton has proposed. 
 The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, said factory prices for 77 frequently dispensed drugs were 60 percent higher in this country than in Britain in 1992. For 47 of these drugs, it said, prices in the United States were more than twice as high as those in Britain.
Auditors and economists from the accounting agency said the price differentials were smaller for new drugs than for older products. In bringing new drugs to market in recent years, manufacturers say they have tried to set similar prices in all the industrialized countries.
Representative Henry A. Waxman, chairman of the Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health, said Britain's experience showed it was possible to have lower drug prices and a "thriving research-based pharmaceutical industry." Mr. Waxman, a California Democrat, requested the study.
Drugs in the study were chosen from a list of the 200 prescription products most frequently dispensed in the United States in 1991. The auditors focused on 77 products available in the same form and strength in Britain and the United States. They compared prices charged by manufacturers to wholesalers for drugs distributed to consumers at retail pharmacies. These consumers account for most prescriptions but generally do not benefit from discounts, the report said.
The main yardstick used by the accounting agency did not measure the effect of drug discounts available to big buyers like hospitals, some health maintenance organizations and mail-order pharmacies. Nor did it measure the effect of generic drugs, the low-cost copies of brand-name products whose patents have expired.
But the investigators concluded that the large differences between American and British drug prices "persisted even after accounting for generic drugs and manufacturers' discounts."
In an interview last month, Dr. Sheldon G. Gilgore, chairman of G. D. Searle & Company, who is also chairman-elect of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, said: "The fact of the matter is, prices in the United States are higher than in the United Kingdom or France or Germany or Italy or Spain. We cannot deny that they are higher. But you cannot fuel the research engine that discovers and develops new drugs on the profits that you make in countries outside the U.S."
Joseph E. Smith, a vice president of the Warner-Lambert Company, said the G.A.O. had overstated the differences in American and British prices because it did not take into account the discounts available here.
The accounting agency said there were generic equivalents for 21 of the 77 drugs in its study. Even if American consumers purchased generic drugs whenever available and British consumers purchased brand-name products in all cases, the study said, the market basket of 77 drugs would still cost 50 percent more in the United States than in Britain.
Likewise, the auditors said, when they took account of the discounts available to hospitals and H.M.O.'s, they found that manufacturers' prices were, on the average, still 51 percent higher here than in Britain.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Same Pill, Different Price" shows the cost of a tablet for the five most commonly prescribed drugs, listed in order of popularity in the U.S. and Britain. (Source: General Accounting Office)

HEADLINE: North Korea Threatens to End A-Arms Talks

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 2

 BODY:
North Korea threatened today to break off its talks with the United States over nuclear inspections, asserting that the Clinton Administration had shown in recent days that the talks were only "a pretense for strangling" the Government of Kim Il Sung. The statement was the latest in a series of increasingly belligerent warnings.
North Korea also said Washington's proposal to deploy Patriot anti-missile batteries in South Korea, combined with the recent visit to Seoul by R. James Woolsey, the Director of Central Intelligence, was evidence that the United States has moved to "the full-scale stage of the war preparations." 
 American and South Korean officials said they were concerned about the tone of the North Korean dispatches, which were broadcast today and also handed over to the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna. Some suggested that the North was trying to use the missile deployment as its newest reason for refusing go along with any detailed inspection of its nuclear installations. The North is suspected of being near construction of a nuclear weapon.
"Sometimes they are bluffing and sometimes a steady buildup in the rhetoric indicates we have a real problem on our hands," a United States official who monitors the North said today. "Frankly, this time we can't tell."
In recent days American, South Korean and Japanese officials have said they would give North Korea until Feb. 21, the start of a meeting of the I.A.E.A.'s board, to allow international inspectors to resume their visits to Yongbyon, North Korea's nuclear complex. If there is no progress by then, a senior Japanese official said today, "I think everyone is now ready to move to the United Nations Security Council for sanctions." A formal deadline has not been presented to the North.
The statement came a day after the United States Senate adopted a non-binding resolution urging President Clinton to take a harder line with the North. North Korea has not yet responded to that resolution.
Only a month ago, the Administration exuded optimism about the progress it appeared to be making. In late December it struck an agreement with the North to resume high-level negotiations on the nuclear issue. At those talks the United States was to cancel its annual military exercise with South Korea and offer diplomatic and economic incentives to the North. In return, North Korea was to agree to regular nuclear inspections.
But so far Mr. Kim's Government has refused to agree to inspections, which are intended to make sure that no nuclear material has been diverted to military projects since inspectors were last permitted in last summer. The automatic cameras and other security devices at seven sites in Yongbyon have run out of film and batteries.
In its statement today, North Korea's Foreign Ministry denounced the I.A.E.A., accusing it of conspiring with Washington to force North Korea into far more intrusive inspections.
The international agency, saying its reputation for thoroughness and integrity is at stake, has refused to negotiate over the terms of its inspections. "There is a fundamental disagreement between their side and what we heard from the United States" on inspections, said David Kyd, the agency's spokesman. "We have told them that a limited inspection is not enough. We can't just look over the fence."

HEADLINE: Disney Seals Times Square Theater Deal

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company, the giant of family entertainment, will introduce Mickey, Goofy and lots of surprises to a street with a reputation as perhaps the nation's sleaziest.
Government leaders immediately hailed Disney's announcement yesterday that it will rehabilitate and reopen the landmark New Amsterdam Theater in September 1996 as a major push to reinvigorate the long-stalled effort to revitalize 42d Street in mid-Manhattan. They promise other announcements soon. 
 "If a match were made in heaven, this is it," said Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who predicted that Disney's move would "jump start" the redevelopment project.
"You're going to get rid of the filth," said Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who called 42d Street a sewer. "It's the beginning of a whole new era."
The deal, which has been under negotiation for several months, calls for the city and state to lend Disney $21 million at 3 percent interest, and to receive an undisclosed share of the profits. Disney has agreed to spend $8 million of its own to renovate the 10-story Art Nouveau theater.
 
Other Companies Express Interest
 Vincent Tese, chairman and chief executive of the State Urban Development Corporation, said many other entertainment companies had expressed interest. Asked whether one of them was Time Warner, he called that suggestion "not far from wrong." He said talks with Tussaud's Group of London to install a 1990's version of its wax museum were moving rapidly.
"By this time next year, all the deals will have been made," he said. "Forty-second Street has the potential to be a major, major tourist attraction in the United States."
Already the Victory Theater, across 42d Street from the entrance to the New Amsterdam, is being readied for opening as a children's theater, the first of nine historic theaters to be renovated. A New York Information Center with the latest on sightseeing tips, theater openings, museum exhibitions and the like will be created from space in two or three of the theaters.
But the Disney move has rekindled a debate that has simmered since the collapsed market for office space led a private developer in 1992 to delay plans for four huge new towers. The developer has invested more than $250 million to retain the right to build when the real-estate market allows. This money has already been spent on buying condemned buildings, among other things.
 
Some Doubt Need for Towers
 But some people contend that the Disney and other deals have now made the towers, which depend on city and state tax abatements whenever built, unnecessary.
"Today's reality is that you can do it without the office towers," said Kent L. Barwick, president of the Municipal Art Society. "There is no more powerful magnet than Disney for bringing other entertainment uses to 42d Street."
In an interview, Mr. Tese strongly disagreed, saying, "It's a little absurd to say we don't need them anymore and they can leave. We have not only a contractual obligation, but a moral obligation."
Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Development Project, said the office towers and entertainment work together because office workers supply more audiences for theaters and more customers for retail stores. "This is a step in the process," she said.
But Mr. Tese did point out the Disney deal gave him leverage in negotiations with the developer. He said the developer had declined to sign a final deal because of disputes over a number of issues, including signs that the state wants to require on the buildings. He said the developer has until August to make a deal before losing its right to build on the sites, which are owned by the state.
The developer, Times Square Center Associates, a private real-estate partnership of Park Tower Realty and the Prudential Insurance Company of America, said through a spokesman that it "has invested substantial sums in the project, has agreed to do an interim plan and hopes to finalize its agreement shortly."
 
Out of the 'Cocoon'
 Michael D. Eisner, chairman and chief executive of Disney, appeared to enjoy being treated as a hero in his hometown, calling the occasion "a thrill." For all their enthusiasm, however, the various dignitaries declined to wear the Mickey Mouse ties that Mr. Eisner had thoughtfully supplied.
Mr. Eisner said Disney was moving beyond the concept of people sitting on couches being entertained by increasingly sophisticated electronic systems, "a cocoon in the house," in his phrase. He said, "We are going to go the other way and bring people outside of their homes and be part of an urban community."
The New Amsterdam, which opened in 1903, has a luxurious interior of marble and classical friezes that was legendary even by the standards of the Broadway theaters of the time. The roof garden was turned into the Midnight Frolic supper club by Florenz Ziegfeld in 1915. In 1937 the theater was converted for movies and used that way until 1982.
"It is the crown jewel of all the theaters in the city," said Laurie Beckelman, chairwoman of the Landmarks Commission. "Nothing was left to chance -- here was fantasy all around you."
 
Promises of Assistance
 Disney's live shows at the New Amsterdam will include both adaptations of Disney movies and original productions for the stage.
But Mr. Eisner specified that Disney could not have proceeded without the public loans. Both Mr. Tese and John S. Dyson, the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, said similar packages would probably be available for other companies.
Already, owners of Broadway theaters have won a promise from city and state governments to assist in refurbishing their houses, though details remain to be worked out. Ron Silver, who as president of Actor's Equity Association was active in that battle, hailed the Disney deal yesterday as "a much-needed public-private initiative to revitalize our commercial theater."
Preliminary studies indicate that the renovation could generate 490 jobs, $16.8 million in wages and salaries and $1.8 million in city and state tax revenues. After the theater opens, the studies suggest, 385 jobs will be generated, 185 of them at the theater.
Total economic activity from the theater is estimated at $53.1 million annually, plus money spent for shopping and dining nearby. Projections show the theater generating $4.1 million a year in city and state taxes.
Ms. Beckelman called the New Amsterdam "one of the most astounding monuments we've ever built to entertainment."

HEADLINE: Vietnam and U.S. Businesses Eager to Trade

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Welcoming reports that the 19-year-old United States trade embargo against Vietnam is nearly over, Hanoi joined with American businesses today in predicting a surge of new investment in a nation that is growing rapidly economically but still suffering from the effects of the Vietnam War.
In Hanoi, the Vietnamese Foreign Ministry said it had not received any formal notification from Washington, but the Government's chief spokesman said in a statement that the lifting of the trade embargo would be "good news not only for the two peoples -- the Vietnamese and the Americans -- but also for the world community." 
 "We welcome American companies and companies from all countries that want to do business and invest in Vietnam," the spokesman, Ho The Lan, said.
Reports that President Clinton would lift the embargo within the next few days circulated quickly in Hanoi, the Vietnamese capital, with Vietnam Government officials and the representatives of American corporations sharing faxes and telexes carrying the latest news and rumors from Washington.
The reaction to the reports from American businesses was one of relief that they would finally be able to enter one of the world's fastest-growing markets, one that their Asian and European competitors have been able to exploit for years.
As Communism was collapsing in Eastern Europe in the late 1980's, Hanoi abandoned Marxist economic theory and embraced the free market. Although Vietnam is still regarded as a poor country, the economy has enjoyed something of a boom since the economic switch, growing last year alone by 8 percent.
"This will be an excellent development for the United States and for Vietnam," said James Rockwell, managing director of Vatico, a Hanoi-based consulting concern that represents the Chrysler Corporation and other large American companies who are expected to seek a market in Vietnam.
"The timing is good," Mr. Rockwell said. "The Vietnamese like and respect Americans. I don't know why. It's just a fact. They see us as fair and trustworthy and they want to do business with us. But if the embargo had gone on another six months to a year, there would have been trouble. Americans would have been very, very small players in Vietnam."
The Hanoi representative of Citibank, Frank Hawke, said that while some American investors seemed to believe that they had already "missed the boat" because so many competitors had already moved into Vietnam, the truth is that "there are lots of boats out there -- some of them missed, some of them not."
"The Vietnamese are emphasizing key infrastructure areas such as petrochemicals, telecommunications, transportation and power generation, all areas where U.S. companies excel," Mr. Hawke said.
 
Embargo Began in 1975
 The United States imposed an economic embargo on Vietnam in 1975, when the American-backed Government of South Vietnam was toppled by the invading North Vietnamese Army. Washington has since used the embargo as a way of persuading the Vietnamese to cooperate in the effort to determine the fate of more than 2,200 Americans missing from the war.
As Hanoi has expanded its cooperation to account for the missing, the United States has gradually eased the embargo, most recently last July, when President Clinton lifted an American veto that had blocked billions of dollars in loans and aid from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
While American corporations are now allowed to open offices in Vietnam and to bid on large infrastructure projects underwritten by the World Bank and the I.M.F., they are still barred under the embargo from selling their products in Vietnam and from conducting other types of business.
The many American products that do reach the Vietnamese market -- from Coca-Cola to Apple Computers to American Tourister luggage -- are sent in by foreign middlemen who rake off profits that would otherwise go to American manufacturers.

HEADLINE: White House Memo;
Clinton Is Still Tiptoeing Round the Vietnam Mines

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
If anyone had forgotten just how skittish Bill Clinton can be when it comes to Vietnam, there could be no better evidence than his public insistence today that he has not made up his mind on whether to lift the American embargo on Hanoi.
It has been more than a month since his top deputies signed off on a recommendation to restore trade relations with that former enemy, a step they would never have taken without a keen sense of the boss's wishes. Aides had been saying for weeks that he was moving irrevocably in that direction, and they said Tuesday and again today that there would be no turning back. 
 In addition to a vague yet pervasive sense in Washington that the embargo has lasted long enough, Mr. Clinton has been driven to this point by cold political calculation. He and his aides know a healthy economy is crucial to his political health. A healthy economy requires the creation of more jobs, and that in turn requires expanded foreign trade. So the President backed the North American Free Trade Agreement and extension of the world trade pact and he will open the potentially rich Vietnamese market to American business.
 
A Very Cautious Approach
 Still, he has moved exceedingly cautiously.
A refrain common to every White House press office is that no decision has been made until the President announces it. By today, however, when news reports quoted senior officials saying the end of the embargo was a done deal, most other administrations would have conceded the impossibility of protecting what was no longer a secret.
But Mr. Clinton's wariness of giving ammunition to those who will not forgive him for having avoided the draft in the Vietnam War era has left him determined to make no commitments until he must. Even as his aides planned quietly today for an announcement by the end of the week, Mr. Clinton stuck to his plan to line up support and assuage critics before he himself takes a public stand.
At a photo session this morning, he would say only that he would reach a decision "in the next couple of days." But later he dropped a less than subtle hint of where he was heading, noting that many prominent veterans favored ending the embargo.
The White House has long known that an announcement of an end to the embargo would infuriate the American Legion and other groups whose criticism of his conduct in the Vietnam era helped to make his path to the presidency so treacherous.
 
Soothing the Critics
 But rather than confront the issue head on, Mr. Clinton and his aides have counted on others to do it for them, relying in large part on the Senate vote last week recommending an end to the embargo to make the case to the American public.
"What's being decided now is how they do it and who meets with whom," a White House official said today of the scramble to soothe the most likely critics, who include the families of those still missing in action from the Vietnam War.
As the White House had feared, the national commander of the American Legion dispatched a letter to Mr. Clinton angrily warning that the step would amount to a betrayal of American veterans. Separately, the National League of Families of American Prisoners and Missing in Vietnam urged Mr. Clinton to postpone any decision until it could determine whether its Government had indeed made progress in providing information about missing Americans.
White House officials said tonight that Mr. Clinton was determined at least to explain to those groups the reasons for his decision before announcing it publicly.
A White House official said tonight that it was likely that Mr. Clinton would meet with some of the critics on Friday before announcing his decision on Saturday at a ceremony to be attended by veterans who support his action.
 
An Unpleasant Prospect
 What leaves his aides most anxious, of course, is the prospect that an announcement by Mr. Clinton calling an end to the embargo will call attention to the steps he took to avoid the draft and to his college-age protests against the war.
Bruce Thiesen, the American Legion national commander, did not make that point directly in his letter to Mr. Clinton. But the strong language he employed made clear that he and other critics regard the decision as one involving much more than the President's judgment on whether Vietnam has made sufficient progress in aiding the United States with information about P.O.W.'s and M.I.A.'s to be rewarded with restored trade ties.
"If you decide to lift the embargo this week as is rumored," Mr. Thiesen said, "you will have not only broken your promise, but you will also have betrayed the missing servicemen, their families, members of the active military services and millions of Vietnam veterans who feel very strongly about their brethren who have not been accounted for."

HEADLINE: Nominee Seeks Strategist's Role In Pentagon Job

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
In three hours of generally friendly questioning today, William J. Perry, President Clinton's nominee for Secretary of Defense, sought to portray himself as not just a talented technocrat but as a global strategist and a forceful leader, saying the United States would seek to contain North Korea's nuclear program and support Russia's economic and political reforms.
Mr. Perry, who would succeed Defense Secretary Les Aspin if confirmed, appeared before the Senate Armed Services Committee, which will vote on Thursday on whether to recommend him for confirmation. A full Senate vote is expected soon after. 
 Mr. Perry, a 66-year-old former engineering professor at Stanford University, is widely respected as a manager and an expert on high-tech issues. But some lawmakers have raised doubts about his ability to step up from his current position as Deputy Defense Secretary into the Pentagon's top job, where he would confront broader international security issues and a looming military budget crisis that could imperil the combat readiness of American forces.
In response to friendly questioning from Democrats and Republicans on the panel today, Mr. Perry gave clear and careful answers to issues ranging from America's role in international peacekeeping operations to revamping the cumbersome system the Pentagon uses to buy $50 billion in new weapons every year.
 
Quick Confirmation Predicted
 Mr. Perry won nearly universal praise in the relatively short hearing, and Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, the committee's chairman, predicted that the full Senate would confirm Mr. Perry by week's end.
Weighty issues aside, the nominee also flashed a glimpse of the wry humor his close friends attribute to him. "The press has observed that a principal deficiency I had for this job was being soft-spoken, and I will work very hard to overcome that problem," Mr. Perry said.
Mr. Perry, who is no stranger to the panel, noted that this appearance was his fourth before the committee for confirmation -- twice for Pentagon jobs in the Carter Administration and again for his current post. But today he clearly tried to dispel any notion that he is a novice on foreign affairs or broader leadership challenges.
Much of the hearing focused on North Korea's nuclear program, and Mr. Perry reiterated the Administration's aim to encourage North Korea to comply with international monitoring of its nuclear sites. Most American intelligence analysts say there is a better than even chance that North Korea already has nuclear weapons.
 
Nuclear Arms Race Feared
 "We are very concerned about the possibility that North Korea has even one nuclear weapon," Mr. Perry said, because it could set off a nuclear arms race among Japan, South Korea and Taiwan. "We see a very dangerous proliferation ahead of us."
Responding to what were some of the only pointed questions of the session, from Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, Mr. Perry said the United States should pursue "aggressive diplomatic means" that would use "both carrots and sticks" to persuade North Korea to negotiate inspection procedures with the International Atomic Energy Agency.
Mr. Perry said he would not object to offering North Korea economic incentives to end the impasse, and added, "I'm not anxious to precipitate the use of sticks."
He said he concurred with the recommendation of Gen. Gary E. Luck, the senior American commander in South Korea, to send Patriot antimissile batteries to troops there. The President has signaled that he will send the Patriots, and Mr. Perry said the decision could be reached soon.
The nominee told the committee that he planned largely to follow the course set by Mr. Aspin, who coaxed Mr. Perry into joining the Pentagon team after Mr. Clinton's election. "It's fair to say our management styles are different because our personalities are different," Mr. Perry said. "But our philosophy and objectives are very similar."
Mr. Aspin, who resigned under pressure in December, stayed on as the President nominated Bobby Ray Inman, a retired admiral and former Deputy Director of Central Intelligence. Mr. Inman withdrew last month.
 
Policy Shop Shake-Up
 Mr. Perry did identify one area for a shake-up: Mr. Aspin's vaunted policy shop, headed by Under Secretary of Defense Frank G. Wisner, that is responsible for the Pentagon's contributions to policy debates on Haiti, Bosnia and Somalia.
"We have some outstanding people in that area, but we have an ineffective organization," Mr. Perry said.
Senators also bored in on Mr. Perry's acknowledgement that the Pentagon faced a $20 billion shortfall in its long-term budget from 1996 to the year 2000, and attributed it to inflation estimates. The nominee said there was no problem in the budget for the fiscal year 1995, which the Administration will make public next week. The Pentagon will review the long-term shortfall later this year, he said.
Mr. Perry, who has founded or advised several high-technology companies and military contractors, said he had severed ties with the companies and sold stock he held in them when he became Deputy Secretary. He promised to recuse himself from any decisions involving Stanford University, where he plans to return after his Pentagon service, and a handful of small, privately owned companies.
"I have no conflicts of interest which would in any way inhibit my ability to do this job," Mr. Perry said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: William J. Perry, nominee for Defense Secretary, during his confirmation hearing yesterday before the Senate Armed Services Committee. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
France Pledges Subsidy To Aerospace Group

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 2

 BODY:
The French Economy Ministry said today that it would pump two billion francs -- $341 million -- into the money-losing, state-owned aerospace group Aerospatiale.
The decision to increase the capital of Aerospatiale S.A., which has been losing money for two years because of falling commercial-aircraft orders and declining military contracts, appeared likely to renew the debate between the United states and Western Europe on subsidies in the commercial aircraft business. 
 Aerospatiale owns 37.9 percent of the European aircraft consortium Airbus Industrie, a leading rival of the Boeing Company. The Clinton Administration says the subsidies give Airbus an unfair advantage.
The last time Aerospatiale received an injection of French Government money was in 1987, when the Government pumped 2.5 billion francs into the company.
Andre Bloch, a spokesman for Aerospatiale, said the company was pleased with the Government's decision. He disputed reports that Aerospatiale had asked for three billion francs, or $512 million.
 
French Rationalization
 A statement from Economy Minister Edmond Alphandery and Defense Minister Francois Leotard said: "This decision by the state will allow Aerospatiale to benefit fully from a gradual recovery in aerospace markets, notably through new projects like the Airbus A330 and the Airbus A340."
Louis Gallois, Aerospatiale's chairman and chief executive, said last month that while the company had hit the "bottom of the wave" after two years of losses, he did not expect it to be profitable in 1994. In the first six months of 1993, Aerospatiale lost 870 million francs, after losing 2.38 billion francs in 1992. The company said last month that it expected to return to profitability by 1995.
The center-right Cabinet of Prime Minister Edouard Balladur has suggested that it would like to privatize the company, but this notion is regarded as farfetched as long as Aerospatiale continues piling up losses.
Mr. Bloch, the Aerospatiale spokesman, said part of the new state funds would be used to reduce the company's debt, which now stands at about 13 billion francs, or $2.2 billion. The rest would be invested across the range of the company's activities to help prepare for privatization.
The Airbus A330, a large, wide-bodied, twin-engine plane that carries about 300 passengers, is a rival to Boeing's new wide-body 777. The first delivery of the new Airbus was made in December to Air Inter, the French domestic airline, part of the Air France Group. But the plane has been grounded because the main landing gear failed several times to retract after takeoff. The first A340, a long-haul, four-engine plane, was delivered to Lufthansa a year ago.
The statement by the ministers underscored that the French Government is providing money to help Airbus programs that are directly competitive with Boeing and other United States aircraft manufacturers. Airbus says Boeing and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation benefit from indirect subsidies in the form of Pentagon and NASA contracts.
The argument between Airbus and Boeing was eased by an agreement reached in 1992 limiting both direct and indirect subsidies, but bickering has continued. Last year President Clinton called on European governments to "quit subsidizing" Airbus.
John Dern, a spokesman for Boeing, said, "Any infusion of state aid must conform with the 1992 agreement." The accord said direct government aid for any aircraft program must be limited to 33 percent of development costs, and indirect support held to 4 percent of the sales of any aircraft company.
Aerospatiale also builds missiles and satellites, assembles the Ariane satellite launcher and is a partner in a European helicopter concern.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Louis Gallois, chairman and chief executive of Aerospatiale, has said the company should not turn a profit in 1994. France promised yesterday to increase the state-owned company's capital by $341 million. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Overhaul Effort Clinton Seeks 'One Stop' Assistance Centers for the Jobless

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Calling for a major restructuring of the nation's unemployment and welfare systems, President Clinton said today that he would ask Congress to consolidate scores of benefit programs and create "one-stop-shopping" centers where unemployed workers could pick up assistance checks and receive job training and placement help.
Courting an audience of about 300 job-training specialists and graduates of some of the nation's most innovative jobs programs, the President smiled and joked, hoarsely, with several people who shared stories about moving from the unemployment lines back into the work force. He then dismissed the existing system, saying it was weighted down with "yesterday's programs" and needed an overhaul. 
 "The welfare office ought to be a work office," Mr. Clinton said. "It ought to be the job-training office."
The President pledged to eliminate at least 100 Government programs and make cuts in at least 300 more to "squeeze the money" needed to retrain unemployed workers and move them toward new jobs in business and industry. He said he would propose these cuts in the budget that will go to Congress on Monday. But Labor Department officials said they did not expect the budget to include specific linkages between changes in the welfare program and any overhaul of the unemployment system.
Proposed cuts are likely to focus on job-training plans that cover only small segments of the work force, short-term training that the Labor Department says has not helped disadvantaged young people, and a jobs program that gives tax credits to employers. Labor Secretary Robert B.. Reich has dismissed such credits, which took effect in 1982, as a misguided plan that rewards employers for hiring workers they would likely hire anyway.
Warning that welfare itself will need to be changed, Mr. Clinton today expanded on a refrain from his State of the Union Message, saying the Government must replace hand-out programs with local programs that can find jobs, provide training and then get jobless people back to work.
 
Reich Commands the Stage
 The President's comments came at the close of a daylong conference and panel presentation in which Secretary Reich combined the stage skills of Oprah Winfrey, the evangelical fervor of Buckminster Fuller and the oratory of a small-town preacher to sell the message that the nation can stop a "downward trajectory" among the unemployed only by combining aid with hope.
Despite a general brightening of the employment picture, which has included the creation of 1.6 million jobs in the last year, "we are not out of the woods at all," Mr. Reich said.
The conference, held to showcase Mr. Reich's plan to transform the unemployment system and provide a human frame for the President's proposed changes, dwelt on the successes achieved by several privately backed job programs. Those that work, several panelists said, combine practical job training with essentials like baby-sitting, transportation, letter- and resume-writing and, sometimes, a helping hand with the purchase of a pair of shoes or a new outfit to wear to job interviews.
Mr. Reich began the program with a catalogue of failures. Using charts and a CBS News television segment that dubbed the unemployment system a "Byzantine nightmare" he outlined an unwieldy if well-intentioned program that had grown too large and too complex to work.
"Everybody," he said, "is caught in the same web."
To illustrate those points, Mr. Reich picked out panelists and members of the audience, as members of his staff moved up and down the aisles with microphones while video cameras caught the speakers' slightest facial expressions.
 
Job Success in Louisville
 Turning to a panelist who had lost a $26,000-a-year job and then found herself unable to support her family, the Labor Secretary said: "Now, let me be clear about this. How much time did you have before you lost your job?"
The woman thought a moment and then said with a shrug, "About 60 seconds."
Mr. Reich rocked forward and then lifted his microphone to reply: "Wow. A whole 60 seconds so you could formulate your strategy."
Both the second panel and a third one presided over by the President dwelt on programs that work.
Alma Willis, a 31-year-old clinic worker who was helped by a Louisville, Ky., program called Job Link, said she lost her car, her telephone and almost her house before finding help.
"I had a problem," Ms. Willis said. "My husband wouldn't let us go onto food stamps. But I couldn't qualify if we weren't on food stamps, so I went behind his back."
Once in the program, she said, staff members provided her with a telephone, helped her write letters of application and even bought her a dress. She found a job after telling the clinic staff she would work without pay for a month, just to prove that she could do the job.
She did not have to do that. "They said they really liked my letter," Ms. Willis told the audience. "Now, I'm missing two days of work to be here. And they said that was O.K. But I had to be here. I think this is really fantastic."

LENGTH: 635 words

HEADLINE: Scam Artists Turning Cold Into Profits

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 2

 BODY:
With icy Arctic air threatening to make this one of the coldest winters on record, state consumer protection officials warned today that a variety of scam artists were at work, including bogus oil-burner repairmen who prey on the elderly.
In the last few weeks, officials said, several young men posing as oil company repairmen have approached elderly homeowners on Long Island, entered their basements, taken apart their heating-oil burners and demanded cash in advance for unnecessary repairs. 
 The bogus repairmen have also been helping themselves to pocketbooks, loose cash and other items in the homes of their victims, all of whom are 80 years old or older, said Richard M. Kessel, executive director of the New York State Consumer Protection Board.
"These men are predators, preying on innocent consumers, and they seem to have a special affinity for senior citizens," Mr. Kessel said.
 
Call Dealer First, State Says
 "If someone at the door says they have come to service your heating system, we recommend that you don't open your door unless you call up your oil dealer and confirm the repairs are legitimate," he said.
Mr. Kessel said the scheme was this winter's worst example of unscrupulous people's taking advantage of customers as a result of the cold weather. He said his office was also checking on complaints about price gouging for rock salt and antifreeze, and excessive charges by plumbers to repair frozen or burst pipes.
In Connecticut, consumer protection officials said they had been flooded this winter by complaints from automobile owners whose car batteries failed and who were then told by mechanics that they needed to replace not only the battery but several other parts.
Despite such complaints, customers are receiving a break in one area. A generous supply of home heating oil has served to keep prices relatively steady, said Kevin Rooney, executive director of the Oil Heat Institute of Long Island.
 
Oil Supply Is No Problem
 He said this was the case throughout the New York metropolitan area, where the price of fuel delivered by a full-service dealer has remained at $1.14 a gallon.
"Even with the increase in demand, the supply has never been a problem," he said. "And if you look at the entire heating season, we tend to forget the fact that October, November and early December were actually warmer than normal."
And since more people are staying at home keeping warm by the radiator, there are fewer drivers on the road. As a result, the American Automobile Association reports a lower demand for gasoline. This in turn has driven gasoline prices down.
The association says prices for self-serve regular unleaded gasoline averaged $1.06 a gallon nationwide on January 19, compared with $1.10 a gallon a year ago. The auto club says that when inflation is taken into account, gasoline has not been this cheap in 20 years.
 
Flowing From Siberia
 Winter, however, is far from over, and the colder-than-average weather is expected to continue through February, said Lee Grenci, a meteorologist at Pennsylvania State University. "And February is traditionally a fairly active month."
"Right now, the pattern still continues to be air flowing from Siberia, across the North Pole and Canada and into the continental United States," Mr. Grenci said.
"We expect to experience another big blast of Arctic air beginning in the middle of next week, and it could rival the last record outbreak," he said.
This morning's lows ranged from 3 degrees Fahrenheit in White Plains to 17 degrees at La Guardia Airport.
Mr. Grenci said that the figures were not yet in for January, but that preliminary indications were that when temperatures and snowfall were combined, "it may rank as one of the coldest, if not the worst January on record."

HEADLINE: Global Issue By China

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
China issued $1 billion of its first global bonds yesterday, and they were snapped up as analysts endorsed the country's economic reform efforts.
"The People's Republic of China's borrowing is a signal that they are moving more toward integration of the world economy," one bond market participant said. 
 The 10-year bonds, guaranteed by the Chinese Government, were selling well in the United States, Europe and Asia, according to a Wall Street official who co-managed the offering with Merrill Lynch & Company.
The 6.5 percent bonds were priced to yield 6.583 percent, or 85 basis points more than 10-year United States Treasury securities. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percent. Proceeds will be used to finance infrastructure projects and other Chinese Government spending.
Fitch Investors Service rated the bonds investment grade, at A-, while the Standard & Poor's Corporation assigned a BBB rating.

HEADLINE: Havana Journal;
On the Street, Cubans Fondly Embrace Capitalism

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAVANA, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Less than a year into major economic changes that have opened the way for foreign investment and freed many Cubans to work for themselves, life in this city is being transformed by a new ethic: the frantic search for dollars.
Although Cuba's Communist leadership has often sought to rein in the changes, repeatedly reminding the people that it has not chosen capitalism as a solution to the country's grave economic problems, almost everywhere one looks these days private enterprise is filling voids left by an exhausted Government. 
 In special shops once reserved for diplomats, Cubans with dollars earned in small private businesses or sent by relatives abroad line up to buy basic imported goods, from bath soap to over-the-counter medicines, that failing Government enterprises can no longer supply.
Although these shops are owned by the state, and therefore are not examples of private enterprise, echoes of capitalism can be heard in the hum of activity around them.
Each of the diplo-tiendas, as the special stores are known, has spawned an outdoor market where, from the paid bicycle parking lot and carwashes to the fevered trading in home-grown produce, clothing and handicrafts, Cubans who have abandoned Government jobs now fend for themselves.
 
Embargo Limits Americans
 While capitalism is most evident in the street-corner flowering of petty commerce, Havana's biggest moves toward it involve foreign investors. At the International Center of Havana, a private business consulting concern that opened last fall, each month brings a handful of new European or Latin American companies hoping to get in on the ground floor of the transformation of a Cuban economy with enormous needs but also considerable potential.
Because of a 33-year-old United States embargo on trade with Cuba, which was recently toughened to prevent even foreign affiliates from doing business with the country, American companies have been limited to informational missions.
"Things here are changing month by month," said Arturo Rodriguez, the Cuban director of the center and a former economics professor, referring to Cuba's economy and business climate. "Sometimes it can seem like watching a television serial. Each episode closes leaving you in suspense until the next week's show."
Foreign business people here say the most important changes are in the attitudes of Cuban officials toward international investment.
"When I came here in 1990, things were still very closed and officials looked askance at foreign business people with the idea that they had come to exploit the country," said Carlos Lluna, a Spaniard whose company, Intectur Holding, is involved in sectors ranging from computer consulting to construction. "Today, it is almost a complete turnabout. The Cubans are showing enthusiasm toward us, and reaching agreements on terms has become vastly easier."
 
'We Need Partners'
 The Cuban Government refuses to give the volume of foreign investment in the country, saying only that there are currently 120 joint ventures with foreign companies and that more are being signed by the month.
"The investments which meet our needs are the ones we will greet," said Reynaldo Taladrid, deputy minister of the state committee that oversees new private investment in Cuba. "We need partners and we need foreign exchange."
But even as they have opened the door to foreign capital, Cuban officials, fearful that things may be getting out of hand, have recently stepped up warnings that the Communist Party leadership, far from embracing capitalism, intends to retain a Communist economy.
At a year-end session of the National Assembly at which the Government pulled back from some of the changes that allowed Cubans to work for themselves, President Fidel Castro made this point energetically, calling his feeling for capitalism "a loathing."
On the street, this ambivalence has meant increasingly halting steps in opening up new sectors of the economy to Cuban entrepreneurs. Five months ago the Government began to reverse a 1978 decision that nationalized virtually all economic activity in the country by allowing practitioners of dozens of small trades, from tire patchers to restaurateurs, to set up their own businesses.
The response, so enthusiastic that it caused serious absentee problems in state jobs and clogged downtown streets with petty merchants, persuaded the National Assembly to pare down the list of authorized trades. Each afternoon on the streets of central Havana the police can now be seen rounding up those believed to be engaged in unauthorized activities.
 
A Pragmatic Approach
 Experts in Cuban economic matters say the hesitation in opening up the economy reflects a continuing debate among leaders over how to steer the economy out of a crisis caused by the sudden disappearance of more than 80 percent of its foreign trade, brought on by the collapse of the Soviet Union and Communist governments in Eastern Europe.
"There is agreement among the leadership that things must change, but that they must not change in a disordered way," said Pedro Montreal, an economist with the Center for the Study of the Americas, a Cuban research group. "There is a good deal of uncertainty about the future shape of the economy. There are all kinds of proposals going around."
Ultimately, business executives and economic experts here say, Cuba will be guided by pragmatism. In November, the Government invited a two-member team from the International Monetary Fund to advise it on transformations under way in Eastern Europe and to make suggestions on Cuba's own changes.
According to the fund's summary report on the visit, the Government has concluded that without major changes the economy will inevitably collapse, "with all the accomplishments of Cuba's political and social model disappearing in the wreckage."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The eagerness with which some Cubans have embraced private enterprise can be seen in the outdoor markets that have sprung up around so-called diplo-tiendas, shops once open only to diplomats but now frequented by Cubans with dollars to spend. Outside one, a parking lot for bicycles did a brisk business. (Angel Franco for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Transcript of Giuliani Budget Speech

 BODY:
The following are excerpts from a transcript of the budget statement by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani as recorded by The New York Times:
To restore balance to city finances we need to act. We need to confront our budget crisis head on. Simply put, the crisis is this: as of July 1 New York City doesn't have enough money to meet its expenses. Our expense budget is short by $2.3 billion, arguably the biggest deficit any administration has ever inherited. 
 Without decisive action now, that gap will grow to $3.4 billion by 1998, which would be a calamity for the people of New York City. I don't intend to let this happen.

 	 	 		. . .	 	First, we're going to cut the size of government so we live within our means. For the first time since the 1970's we'll propose an expense budget that actually decreases spending in real dollars.
Second, we're going to cut taxes to attract jobs so our people can work.
Third, we're going to consolidate or eliminate city departments and introduce competition with the delivery of services as part of our program to reinvent city government.
And finally fourth, we're going to work with Governor Cuomo and the State Legislature to assure that the city gets a fair share of state revenue.
The biggest part of our budget reform, however, is payroll reduction. Right now city government is too big.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Our first sign of friendship is to join with Governor Cuomo to reduce the hotel occupancy tax, the tax that drives away tourists and depresses economic activity. I'm also calling for reduction of the commercial rent tax.

 	 	 		. . .	 	We've begun the process already of restructuring the way the city delivers services. Some confusion has arisen about this, especially in regard to city-owned hospitals.
We are not significantly reducing the spending for our hospitals and we are not closing hospitals. What we're doing instead is trying to improve the delivery of health-care services to those who can least afford it. New York City taxpayers are the most generous in providing health care for the indigent. Yet too often the service provided is grossly inadequate. Over the last 4 years, 5 of the 11 New York City acute-care hospitals have lost some accreditation or been placed on partial suspension or suspension.
 
. . .
 New York City will continue to provide service to its poor. But it will provide that service more efficiently, using good management techniques as its guide.
This is the kind of innovation and boldness I expect from all city agencies. Where agencies are performing overlapping functions, we're going to have the courage to combine them.
In other instances, the city will competitively bid out services formerly delivered only by government.
The city will also get out of businesses where the city has no rational connection. Would you believe that the city now owns and operates more than 500 gasoline stations, only a portion of which are used to fuel emergency vehicles? To start with, we're going to close at least 85 of them.

 	 	 		. . .	 	To show that responsibility starts with me at the top, I've cut the budget of the Mayor's office by more than 15 percent. I'm not asking any department or agency to take a cut as deep as the one I've imposed on the Mayor's office in this fiscal year.

 	 	 		. . .	 	This budget will allow New York City to again claim its title as business center of the world and give New Yorkers jobs and opportunities that have long eluded them.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani after delivering his budget statement yesterday in City Hall. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Fiscal Plan Could Curb Services, as Well as Deficit

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Although Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has promised to avoid painful service cuts in his overhaul of New York City government, the financial plan he laid out yesterday includes some bitter medicine that the average New Yorker would feel immediately, from shrinking money for museums to fewer pickups of recyclable garbage to delays in the renovations of subway stations.
And if a financial plan reflects a Mayor's vision and priorities, then Mr. Giuliani's plan envisions a hard-bitten but financially solvent city where welfare recipients are fingerprinted to avert fraud, where streets are allowed to be a little dirtier and where the city spends less to create new housing. 
 The Mayor's plan calls for cuts to programs aimed at stopping lead poisoning and controlling pests. He proposes to eliminate programs that help the indigent obtain food stamps and that provide legal advice to the disabled, people with AIDS and people facing eviction.
He also wants to stop city contributions to Headstart, a Federal program that provides day care to poor toddlers. Officials contend that because more Federal subsidies are available, day-care centers will not be hurt, but day-care advocates are worried that the extra Federal money will not materialize.
 
Dozens of Small Cuts
 These cuts would occur while the Police and Fire Departments continue to grow to record levels. The growth in the Police Department was required by a 1991 state law earmarking some property taxes.
Saying New Yorkers were overtaxed and losing jobs, Mr. Giuliani has put his faith in about $35 million in tax cuts in the fiscal year that begins in July, predicting this supply-side approach will stimulate the local economy and raise tax revenues. But in the short term, his plan includes dozens of small cuts to services that, taken together, represent a significant shift from the liberal vision of government that characterized the previous administration.
"We have got to realize we are in a different era, a different period," Mr. Giuliani said. "We have this city on the path of financial disaster."
"The economy is finished if the only growth we show is in government employment," he added.
Some of Mr. Giuliani's heaviest cuts would fall on the Board of Education, where he has proposed cutting 2,476 positions, including half of the full-time administrative employees, a quarter of assistant principals and part-time workers.
 
'A Scattershot Approach'
 Calling the school bureaucracy "bloated," the Mayor maintained that the cuts, which total $291 million, will not affect teachers or classes. But even some critics of the unwieldy bureaucracy worried that the cuts would be too deep, too fast. Yesterday opposition to the cuts was already building within the school system, which has final say over what it does with the city's contribution to its budget.
Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines said through a spokesman yesterday that the plan rests on "unrealistic assumptions and appears to take a scattershot approach to the budget problems."
Union leaders predicted that the cuts would spill over into the classroom. "There is certainly a lot of top-heaviness in the administration, but with the magnitude of this cut there is no way it will affect only administration," said Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers.
On another front, Mr. Giuliani's call for a sharp cut in the city's contribution to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's capital budget brought sharp criticism from the authority's chairman, Peter E. Stangl. The Mayor has said the city would give the authority only $250 million by 1996, a quarter of what was originally promised. The capital budget is financed through the sale of bonds, but by avoiding additional debt, the city frees up tax money for other purposes.
"While I understand that the city is facing budget problems, I cannot accept a proposal that threatens to put the T.A. back in the cycle of disinvestment that brought the system to the brink of ruin," Mr. Stangl said.
In two other cuts to the capital budget, Mr. Giuliani has imposed a moratorium on a planned reconstruction of Kings County Hospital Center, which was to cost $887 million, and has canceled a plan to spend about $250 million to build a new police academy in the Bronx, beginning in 1996. Instead, Mr. Giuliani has proposed a renovation of the old academy in Manhattan in the next fiscal year.
Another proposed reduction seemed to run counter to the Mayor's statement that he considers the arts an economic engine vital to the city's recovery. Mr. Giuliani has suggested trimming 5 percent of the $88 million budget of the city's Department of Cultural Affairs, which would mean the city's subsidies to more than 430 museums, theaters and other groups would decline by $4.1 million.
The reduction would affect funds for cultural programs as well as the money used to maintain the city's museums, zoos and botanical gardens. Seeking to urge greater contributions from other sources, Mr. Giuliani has said in his plan that he will restore the subsidy if the cultural institutions can raise $15 million in private donations or additional state aid.
Some advocates for the homeless were disappointed by the Mayor's plan to reduce capital spending for the Housing Preservation and Development Department's loan program that creates housing for single adults. Mr. Giuliani has cut the amount available for loans from $121 million annually to $75 million, which would mean 932 fewer units of housing would be built than projected.
In the Department of Social Services, Mr. Giuliani has also proposed several cuts that upset advocates for the poor. Among them are plans to cut a $400,000 program that finds people who are eligible for food stamps and tells them how to apply for the program, and a $1 million legal services fund for people being evicted, the disabled and people with AIDS.

"FINANCIAL PLAN: The Mayor's Proposed Tax Reductions"
 
HOTEL TAX -- The city tax would drop on Dec. 1, 1994, from 6 percent to 5 percent. The state's proposed repeal of its hotel occupancy tax of 5 percent would result in a combined projected savings to taxpayers of $7 million, growing to $16 million in 1998.
 
COMMERCIAL RENT TAX -- It would be reduced in steps, until its elimination in 1997 in all boroughs except Manhattan, where it would remain in effect only south of 96th Street. The projected tax savings to businesses grows from $28 million in 1995 to $114 million in 1998.
 
SALES TAX ON CLOTHING ITEMS UNDER $100 -- Elimination of this 4 percent tax would take effect in 1996, with a projected savings to consumers of $105 million. It would grow to $218 million in 1998.
 
INCOME TAX SURCHARGE -- The 12.5 percent surcharge would be eliminated in 1997, with projected savings to residents of $160 million. It would grow to $400 million in 1998.
 
UNINCORPORATED BUSINESS TAX -- The tax credit would be raised from $600 to $1,000 over two years beginning in 1996, affecting 19,000 businesses with a projected savings to them of $12 million. It would grow to $29 million in 1998.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Rally Despite Inflation Hints

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Long-term bond prices rallied yesterday, shrugging off possible hints of future inflation that normally hurt bonds and instead found fresh buying ahead of tomorrow's report on employment in January.
There was some speculation that the Federal Reserve might raise short-term interest rates if the report was particularly strong. But many economists doubt the Fed will act, since the employment figures are subject to revision and might be skewed by unusually cold weather in much of the country and the California earthquake. 
 A number of economists expect the Labor Department to announce that the unemployment rate in January was around 6.9 percent.
 
Increase in Rates?
 The Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, indicated on Monday that the central bank would take pre-emptive steps to thwart inflation in the economy, which many bond strategists interpreted as signaling a looming increase in short-term interest rates.
Many economists expect the Fed will wait until the spring before pushing short-term rates higher, although its policy-making body -- the Federal Open Market Committee -- is scheduled to meet today.
The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond finished 16/32 of a point higher, or about $5 for every $1,000 in face value, while its yield fell to 6.28 percent, from 6.31 percent on Tuesday.
Economic data released yesterday included few surprises, with the index of leading economic indicators rising seven-tenths of a percent in December and new-home sales gaining 11.4 percent in December.
The signs of economic growth could have been interpreted as a signal of looming inflation, but bond traders plowed ahead and bought long-term securities.
 
Size of Auction Set
 Also, the Treasury announced the size of next week's quarterly refunding auction. The Government plans to issue $17 billion in new 3-year notes, $12 billion in 10-year notes and $11 billion in 30-year bonds.
The size of the refunding was largely within expectations.
Short-term Treasury securities were unchanged to 5/32 of a point higher, while intermediate maturities rose 6/32 to 7/32 of a point.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, rose 1.57, to 1,308.76.
The discount rate on three-month Treasury bills rose three basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 3.06 percent. The discount rate on six-month bills rose one basis point, to 3.21 percent. And the discount rate on one-year bills also rose one basis point, to 3.44 percent.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 10413/32 , down 1/32 from Tuesday. The average yield to maturity was 5.43 percent, unchanged from Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Who's Afraid of the Fed?;
Prospect That Short-Term Rates May Rise Is Being Accepted With Absence of Alarm

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
The prospect that the Federal Reserve may nudge up short-term interest rates soon has captured headlines, but the people who usually complain about such a move -- auto dealers and home builders whose customers commonly rely on borrowed money -- are uncommonly relaxed.
"If this is a tempered move to keep inflation at or below 3 percent, this is probably a positive event," said James R. Irvine, a home builder in Portland, Ore.. "I'm not saying I'm applauding this, but I don't have the concern." 
 Dave Arnolds, the general manager at the ABC Nissan car dealership in Phoenix, is equally unworried. "The rates are so low now, the confidence is so high," he said. "A quarter percent really wouldn't have a real impact."
The absence of alarm reflects a common assessment among economists and business executives that when the Fed does decide to tighten monetary policy, possibly at a meeting here on Thursday and Friday, it will increase the shortest-term interest rates that it controls, but not by much. Rates on medium-term debts, like car loans, do not vary much with the so-called Federal funds rate, for money lent overnight between banks.
The broad consensus of economists now seems to be that the Fed will raise the target for the Federal funds rate by an eighth or a quarter of a percentage point in the coming weeks or months. The Fed's target has been 3 percent since September 1992.
Andrew F. Brimmer, a former Fed governor, said that such changes in the Federal funds rate were aimed mostly at reassuring financial markets that the Fed was still fighting inflation.
"Symbolically, it's important, but it carries very little importance in the short run as far as the real economy is concerned -- it's more than smoke and mirrors, but not much more," he said.
Small increases in the Federal funds rate might actually hold down or even reduce interest rates for long-term debts, like home mortgages -- if lenders view them as a sign that the Fed will not allow a revival of inflation.
President Clinton and his aides have indicated repeatedly in recent weeks their willingness to accept a small increase in short-term rates so as to keep long-term rates low. Small increases now could also forestall the need for politically difficult increases shortly before the 1996 elections.
Such amiability has been rare in past administrations. "I cannot recall the White House and Fed ever before being so in touch and in agreement on conservative policy prescriptions," said David C. Munro, a Manhattan economist, in his daily credit market newsletter.
Over the course of many months, changes in the Federal funds rate can have some effect on the economy by limiting the availability of bank loans and raising interest rates slightly for these loans. This effect will be felt first by such borrowers as stores that take out short-term loans to stock their shelves and repay the loans with the proceeds from the sales.
Interest rates for Treasury securities with a maturity of several years, which influence car-loan rates, already appear to anticipate a change in the Federal funds rate and have not moved much. "I don't think that will have any big effect on car sales," said Martin B. Zimmerman, the chief economist at the Ford Motor Company.
Fewer and fewer Americans finance their homes with one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, choosing fixed-rate mortgages instead that are not affected by changes in the Federal funds rate, said David F. Seiders, the chief economist at the National Association of Home Builders. "If it's gradual then we're going to be fine," he said. "In the past, any thought of Fed tightening would have sent the guys through the roof."
But some people dissent from the general optimism about the effects of a rate increase.
"Sure, it would hurt," said John Rank, the vice president at Rank & Son Buick in Milwaukee. Very cold weather severely hurt the dealership's sales last month, he said, and he fears that higher interest rates might scare away customers.
Some academic economists contend that a small move in interest rates would make a difference because it could signal the beginning of a series of similar moves. "By itself, a quarter-point increase in the Federal funds rate means little unless it signals the beginning of a larger turn in monetary policy, in which case it would be quite significant," said Michael J. Boskin, who was the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Bush Administration.
But he said that few people seemed to expect a long series of rate increases right now, so investor reaction to an initial increase would likely be muted.
