HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The Economic Motive

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
"Like everything else," Foreign Minister Shimon Peres said, "the economy is a matter of psychology." And the psychology of peace, he said -- the belief that the conflict between Israel and its neighbors is at last coming to an end -- has set off an Israeli economic boom.
"Israel is going through one of its best periods economically," Mr. Peres told a press breakfast in Boston. "It has 7 percent growth, I think the best figure in the West. The impact [of peacemaking with the P.L.O.] has been very positive." 
 Reports from Israel confirm the picture of a boom. Business people there, and investors, had reckoned that Israel could never be a real part of the new world economy without stability in the region around it. Now a stable region seems possible, and investors are responding.
But what are the prospects for the current negotiations with the P.L.O.? reporters asked Mr. Peres. The breakthrough last September was supposed to lead to a detailed agreement by December, but the talks are still going on.
"Most of the complicated issues are behind us," Mr. Peres said. But it is a difficult negotiation, involving as it does "Palestinian dignity and Israeli security. And what we call security they call dignity."
He ducked a question about whether a final agreement could be reached by next week. But whenever it was, he said, it could be carried out quickly. The original target was for implementation by April, with the Palestinians then taking over administration of Jericho and the Gaza Strip.
Mr. Peres's tone was optimistic, more upbeat than I have ever heard him. He foresaw great changes in the Arab world, with countries moving toward more modern economies and more open societies.
"Dictatorship is a tremendous waste of money," he said. "Only rich countries can afford it."
Among the costs of autocracy he listed censorship, the cutting down of individual enterprise, corruption and the maintenance of the cult of personality. He said people everywhere were less willing to pay the price, and to live in misery, because they now could see how others in the world live.
"What brought down the Soviet Union was not a political party or a military coup but the winds of information. And that is happening everywhere."
One reason President Hafez al-Assad has moved, he said, is that Syria has an emerging middle class and has young people who see television and compare their lives with others'. The other reason is that the Soviet Union is gone, and President Assad needs new relationships.
"I wouldn't say that he's drawn all the necessary conclusions," Mr. Peres said; that must be tested in the resumed talks between Syrian and Israeli negotiators.
The problem for Israelis and Arabs and everyone, he said, is the psychological one of adjusting to a new world. "People usually prefer to remember than to think."
He rejected what a questioner said was strenuous opposition from some Orthodox Jews to the idea of peace with the Palestinians. We are determined, he said, "not to become a dominating nation -- something we have never been in history."
Readers of the Bible might raise an eyebrow at Mr. Peres's history, since many passages celebrate military victories. But what matters is the attitude of the present Israeli Government. "We must decide on our destiny," he said, "and the Palestinians on theirs."
He said Israel was trying to "build a regional economy, one that will help Arab countries even more than us." Israelis understand, he said, that poverty is destabilizing.
Mr. Peres mentioned one concrete example of regional cooperation that he said had already been agreed: a plan by Jordan, Israel and Egypt to connect their electrical grids. That could save the three countries billions of dollars in generating facilities because their peak hours of energy use are different.
The vision of peace may still founder on the rocks of memory. But the import of Mr. Peres's words is that peace has something stronger than hope going for it now. That is expectation. People on all sides will surely struggle to keep alive the vision on which they have begun to build.

HEADLINE: Vietnam Welcomes U.S. Decision on Embargo

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam, Feb. 4

 BODY:
In the crowded streets of a city still better known to the world as Saigon, there was a sense today that the war was finally over, the last battle concluded half a world away in the corridors of the White House.
The news that President Clinton had decided to lift the American trade embargo against Vietnam reached here today shortly before dawn, and by breakfast it was the only topic of conversation to be found in much of Ho Chi Minh City, the city that the Americans had to flee in humiliation a generation ago. 
 "A heavy burden has been lifted," said Lam Thanh Sy, a 38-year-old high school mathematics teacher who recalls the boyhood terror of rushing into a bomb shelter with his parents. "We in Vietnam have felt that we were not allowed to participate in the world as full citizens because of the embargo. Now at last we are allowed to forget the war."
 
A Matter of Perspective
 He was standing in the shadow of a large statue of Ho Chi Minh, the Vietnamese revolutionary leader, in a small, well-tended public park near city hall. A few feet away, a photographer, Hoang Hon Thanh, was snapping pictures of happy families posed beneath the statue.
"Me? I'm happy too," he said. "And I'm happy for a simple reason. Five years ago, I bought a Polaroid. Now that the embargo is lifted, I can finally buy some film for it."
The Vietnamese Government said in a statement released in Hanoi today that it was thankful to President Clinton for his decision to lift the embargo. The statement by Deputy Foreign Minister Le Mai pledged Vietnam's continued cooperation in determining the fate of 2,200 Americans still missing from the Vietnam War, the issue most often cited by the United States in keeping the trade embargo in place for so long.
"This decision meets the desire of the American and the Vietnamese peoples," Mr. Mai said, praising the President for having opened "a new page in U.S.-Vietnam relations." He called on Washington to consider establishing full diplomatic relations with Vietnam.
 
Fast-Growing Market
 American corporations have been planning for years for the moment when they would be allowed back into Vietnam, a market of nearly 71 million consumers that even with the American embargo in place has emerged as one of the fastest-growing and most dynamic in Asia.
And so only hours after they heard the announcement from Washington, Americans began marching back onto the streets of Ho Chi Minh City, this time armed with checkbooks and marketing plans and wearing suits and ties.
Vietnam remains one of the world's poorest countries, with a per capita annual income of less than $500, but economists agree that with its diligent, well-educated work force and untapped natural resources, Vietnam has the potential to catch up with its booming Southeast Asian neighbors.
In a country where smuggled Coca-Cola is the most popular drink, Pepsi was the first to act. This morning, Pepsi began legitimate distribution for the first time since the 1970's, handing out bottles free to passers-by. This weekend, Pepsi says, television viewers here will see a new commercial featuring Miss Vietnam, 18-year-old Ha Kieu Anh, one of Vietnam's most popular celebrities.
Other American companies were not far behind in the battle to make their presence felt here. Coca-Cola announced that it would spend $45 million in Vietnam over the next five years. American Express said that Vietnam's foreign trade bank had agreed to accept the American Express charge card, making it the first American card to return to Vietnam since 1975. United Airlines reported here that it would soon begin service to Ho Chi Minh City from Los Angeles under a route authority it purchased in 1986 but, because of the embargo, had not been able to use.
In the streets of Ho Chi Minh City, many Vietnamese reacted to the lifting of the embargo with a sort of giddy excitement. There was for some the thought of renewing ties to an old, prosperous friend, the United States.
"My mother told me that when the American soldiers were here, there was lots of candy and many television sets and nice cars," said Tran, the 8-year-old son of a factory worker. "I think it will be fun to have the Americans here."
The end of the American embargo only made worse the usual crush today at the international airport in Ho Chi Minh City, once the American-run Tan Son Nhut Air Base.
 
Anxious to Return
 Nineteen years after they joined the panicked evacuation out of what was then Saigon, large American corporations were struggling today to get their salesmen and marketing executives on the first flights heading back into the city.
John R. Guy, director of international sales at Briggs & Stratton Corporation, a Milwaukee-based manufacturer of gasoline engines, arrived in Ho Chi Minh City on a flight from Bangkok, Thailand, and went immediately to work. He is here to search for a Vietnamese partner.
His enthusiasm about his first trip to Vietnam was tempered by worries about his competitors, Asian and European manufacturers that were not hobbled by the American embargo. Some have been at work in Vietnam for years. "All of my major competitors are Japanese," he said. "And they are already in Vietnam."
Can Briggs & Stratton hope to catch up with the Japanese? "It's my job to make sure that we can," Mr. Guy said with some confidence. "This isn't impossible." Briggs & Stratton, he said, thinks that Vietnam could become the company's major Asian market within four years.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Free Pepsi-Cola was served on the streets of Ho Chi Minh City yesterday as American companies tested a market opened by President Clinton's lifting of the United States embargo on trade with Vietnam. (Reuters)(pg.1); Construction workers using a hand cart and an old steamroller for road work in suburban Hanoi yesterday, the day after the American trade embargo on Vietnam was lifted. Caterpillar, one of the American companies expected to benefit from the move, estimated that road, bridge and airport construction there could create a $500 million market for earth-moving equipment in the next five years. (Associated Press)(pg.5)

HEADLINE: Fetal Test Focuses the Health-Care Debate

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
Jeannie Evans was pregnant last year and had no reason to expect her child would be born with any problems.
She was 28 years old, and her risk of having a baby with a birth defect caused by abnormal chromosomes was 1 in 435 -- too low, according to standard medical opinion, for her to undergo an amniocentesis test and court an even greater chance that the procedure might cause a miscarriage. 
 But that logic was illogical to Mrs. Evans, a social worker who lives in Manhattan. "I didn't feel the trauma of losing a pregnancy was the same as the trauma of having an abnormal baby," she said.
With the support of her doctors, she had amniocentesis and joined a rapidly growing number of younger women who, health-care professionals say, are ignoring the medical standard that only women over 35 or those with a history of genetic abnormalities should risk a miscarriage by having the test, which detects chromosomal disorders in fetuses.
The rise in use of the test among young women -- reported in interviews by doctors, genetic counselors and insurers across the country -- has triggered a heated debate over whether it is a wise use of existing technology or a waste of health-care dollars that are sorely needed elsewhere.
The controversy is freighted with questions about medical risk, patient autonomy, national policy and the moral questions of abortion and reproductive technology and is an emblem for some of the most perplexing questions facing the country as it tries to control health-care costs.
"This issue has all the ethical considerations in health-care reform now," said Dr. John Larsen, director of the Wilson Genetics Center at George Washington University Medical Center. "It's about the confluence of technology and personal choice and social responsibility and financial liability. And the debate will only expand as our ability to test for more genetic problems expands."
Many younger women -- and indeed many doctors -- are challenging the notion that the emotional and financial costs of having to raise a seriously disabled child are in any way comparable to the costs of losing a pregnancy.
"Even 1 in 1,500 is not a very comforting risk if you're that one," said Mrs. Evans, whose son, Ryan, is now 5 months old. "I don't think that I'm equipped to handle a baby with a severe disability. As it is there's enough stress raising a wonderful healthy child."
Doctors designated 35 as the benchmark for having amniocentesis because at that age the risk of giving birth to a baby with such problems -- 1 in 192 -- is greater than the risk of miscarriage due to the procedure -- 1 in 200.
But many doctors, genetic counselors, health economists and women question that reasoning, saying that the evaluation of risk is very personal and differs from woman to woman. A woman in her 40's with a history of infertility might fear a miscarriage more than having an affected child, while a woman in her 20's, having a second child, might dread more the burden of a severely handicapped baby and decide to have an abortion.
"It doesn't take a rocket scientist to realize there's no logic in this standard," said Dr. Keith A. Eddleman, the director of prenatal diagnosis at The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, who has seen a sharp decline in the age of women having the test. "They are unequal risks."
 
<If Nothing Else, A Little Preparation
 Many young women who had the test and discovered their babies were normal said they were not sure what they would have done if the results had shown an abnormality. Most said that their decision to continue with the pregnancy or to have an abortion would depend upon the severity of the disorder. All said that even if they chose to have the baby, they would want to be prepared.
"In my case, there was no way the baby would have lived for more than a week," said one 29-year-old woman, who did not want to be named, who had an abortion after discovering through an amniocentesis that her fetus was missing most of its brain. "It was the worst thing I have ever gone through, but I can't even imagine what it would have been like if I hadn't had the test and didn't know."
The test is performed about the 16th week of pregnancy. Using ultrasound as a guide, doctors insert a needle into the mother's abdomen to withdraw a sample of amniotic fluid that is later studied for chromosomal abnormalities, the most common being Down Syndrome. The test, which costs from $1,000 to $2,500, cannot detect all birth defects or even all genetic disorders. About 2 to 3 percent of all babies born in this country have some major birth defect.
Some obstetricians argue that younger women who undergo the procedure are needlessly endangering what in all likelihood are normal pregnancies, although no studies have measured whether more young women have miscarried because they had the test. And just because the technology is available, these doctors and some health economists say, does not justify its blanket use.
"If we are ever going to get costs under control, we are going to have to make some hard choices, like limiting who is covered for this test," said Alain Entoven, a health economist at Stanford University. "We must not go on acting as if such things are free. We are diverting money from programs that are important to the life, health and well-being of people."
But that reasoning examines just "the base dollars and cents," said Dr. Mark I. Evans, director of the Center for Fetal Diagnosis and Therapy at Wayne State University-Hutzel Hospital in Detroit, who has for more than a decade used age 30 as his standard for recommending the test.
"The test may cost about $1,000, but a reasonably conservative estimate is that it costs $100,000 for just the first year of a Down Syndrome baby's life," he said. "How many people would I have to test to balance the lifetime cost? And then there are economic considerations nobody knows how to factor in, like the number of women who would have to quit their careers to care for these babies."
Where the medical establishment sees risk, many women said, they see peace of mind. "The technology exists, why not take advantage of it," said Chagit Cohen, who was 25 four years ago when she had the test before her daughter, Natalya, was born. "We take advantage of technology in all kinds of other ways that are less important."
Diane J. Loder, a marketing consultant from Alameda, Calif., who is now 33, did not have amniocentesis in 1991 when she became pregnant with her daughter, Alexandra. She regretted the decision. "I worried during the whole pregnancy, and I think I became obsessed with it," she said. When she became pregnant again, she said, "I knew the day I took the home pregnancy test that I would get an amnio.
"I didn't care if I wasn't in a high-risk group," said Mrs. Loder, whose son, Joshua, was born last year. "I didn't care if the insurance wouldn't pay for it. It was my right, and I wanted it done."
Not only are more younger women requesting the test, but many doctors across the country said that increasingly they are offering it.
"I feel very strongly committed to informing every pregnant patient about the testing options available and about the statistical risks for chromosomal problems at her age," said Dr. William Walden, an associate professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the Cornell Medical College. "And I will be very emphatic that no matter what age, she is not immune. In the last few months alone I have been aware of three women under 29 who had babies with Down Syndrome. When you see things like that it makes you much more conscious."
 
For Opponents,Waste or Immorality
 But Dr. Bill Weise, chief of obstetrics at North Texas Medical Center in McKinney, a small city in the countryside about 30 miles north of Dallas, said he rarely recommends amniocentesis because he is morally opposed to abortions and would object if a patient used information gained through such a test in deciding to end a pregnancy.
And Dr. Dorwin T. Moore, an obstetrician in Manning, S.C., a town of 4,000 in the eastern part of the state, said he thought screening "indiscriminately" was wasteful and so he closely follows the traditional guidelines in deciding when to offer amniocentesis.
Doctors are often too quick to make such decisions for their patients, said Arthur Caplan, the director of the Center for Biomedical Ethics at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis.
"If there is a test that can yield information that can be relevant to a patient, you should offer it to the patient," said Dr. Caplan, who has studied ethical issues in genetic counseling. "There is no morally defensible reason not to offer even a 25-year-old woman the opportunity to have amnio and leave the decision to her."
All the insurers interviewed said the test is covered uniformly for women over 35 and when a physician determines it a necessity, but that the younger the patient the more likely that the insurance company will challenge a doctor's decision.
Under the proposed Clinton health care plan, amniocentesis will be covered when it is "medically necessary and appropriate," with 35 remaining the standard recommended age, said Dr. Susan J. Blumenthal, the deputy assistant secretary of Health and Human Services for women's health.
Doctors and insurers said that doctors often list "maternal anxiety" as the reason why a woman younger than 35 needed the test, and often, the insurance companies pay. Some doctors acknowledged confidentially that they felt so strongly that all women should have the test that they sometimes falsely report that a woman has a family history of abnormalities, to assure coverage.
The trend among younger women began with and is strongest among professional, highly educated women, who are familiar with medical technology, doctors and genetic counselors said. "Their lives revolve around control and information," said Dr. Albert L. Brooks, the president of the medical staff at Alta Bates Medical Center in Berkeley, Calif. "So when they embark on a pregnancy they want control and information."
But the practice, said Dr. Evans of Hutzel Hospital, has "moved down the socio-economic ladder," with working-class and poor women also seeking its reassurances.
Dr. Lillian Hsu, the director of the Prenatal Diagnosis Lab of New York City, a nonprofit center where 80 percent of the patients are on Medicaid, said that younger women there are increasingly asking for the test, but that few can afford it when Medicaid denies payment.
The public policy and economic concerns in guaranteeing such coverage to all four million women who become pregnant in the United States each year are too vast to dismiss so easily, said Dr. Sharon L. Dooley, an associate professor of obstetrics and gynecology at Northwestern University in Chicago and chairwoman of the maternal and fetal health committee of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
"Dear God, we have an enormous job providing all women with basic prenatal care," she said. "To spend money encouraging women who don't need it to have amnio would not be good public-health policy. I think age 35 is still the best standard."

HEADLINE: Unemployment Is Put at 6.7% By New Method

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Severe winter weather crimped the expansion of business payrolls in January as the Government's new method for sampling the nation's households showed an unemployment rate of 6.7 percent, the Labor Department reported today.
But while the job figures were difficult to interpret, analysts said they regarded the data as consistent with an economy still moving briskly ahead in the early weeks of the year after unsustainably rapid growth of 5.9 percent in the final three months of 1993. 
 "The economy is in a very strong cyclical upswing," said Walter M. Cadette, a senior economist at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. While the latest figures may be "a mixed bag," he added, "what counts is not so much the month-to-month readings, but the trend."
 
Survey Is Changed
 The unemployment rate in December was 6.4 percent, but the Bureau of Labor Statistics stressed that the number could not be compared with the January rate because of a major revamping of the population survey on which it is based. The January report was the first to use the new method, which had been under development since the Reagan Administration.
But the Bureau of Labor Statistics also made some supplementary calculations using a reduced sample of data adjusted by a computer to give a rough comparison. If the old method had been applied to the January survey, the result would have been 6.3 percent.
Shortly after the job figures were published, the Federal Reserve announced that it was raising short-term interest rates in an effort to prevent a revival of inflation. Analysts said the labor market report was in some respects stronger than it appeared. They said the Fed, though probably not alarmed by any aspect of it, had concluded that the economy was strong enough to withstand a small increase in rates.
In January, payrolls expanded by 62,000 over all, a gain only about a third as large as the private-sector consensus had expected, but the number reflected extremely cold weather, said Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics. This was the case even though the week used for the survey preceded icy weather and snowstorms on the East Coast and the earthquake in Southern California, she said.
"The weakness in the payroll survey was quite concentrated in weather-sensitive industries" like construction and amusement parks, Ms. Abraham added, "while other industries continued the pattern of moderate growth that has prevailed for some time."
On the other hand, some private analysts noted that the Bureau of Labor Statistics had assumed that businesses too new to be included in the survey created 112,000 jobs, a number considerably higher than what the Labor Department was using last year.
The payroll survey was unaffected by any of the changes made this month, the first major shifts since 1967, in the survey of households.
The Clinton Administration, which had actively sought to prevent any rise in the January employment rate from being characterized as a weakening of the job market, expressed satisfaction with today's report.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the President's chief economic adviser, pointed particularly to a 26,000 rise in factory payrolls, the fourth consecutive rise. "We may well have turned the corner" in this important sector, she said.
 
A Few Surprises
 The results of the revamped household survey, which is conducted by the Census Bureau on behalf of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, were generally within official expectations, though some surprises emerged.
One surprise was that under the new survey method, the jobless rate for New York State declined, to 7.1 percent; it had been thought that the state's rate would rise from the 7.6 percent level that prevailed in November and December. Conversely, the rate for California jumped 1.3 points, to 10.1 percent, when a decline had been expected.
To address anxiety expressed by Congressional Democrats and the White House, Ms. Abraham's statisticians agreed to make various supplementary calculations. They hoped these would take the sting out of what was expected to be a jump of about five-tenths of a point between the December and January jobless rates; the jump turned out to be three-tenths of a point.
If the new method had been applied to December, for example, the unemployment rate for the month would have been 7 percent, according to a computer model for the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
"In either approach, the unemployment rate declined," Ms. Tyson told a White House briefing attended also by Robert B. Reich, the Secretary of Labor, and Lloyd Bentsen, the Secretary of the Treasury.
 
Flaws Seen in Questions
 The redesign of the household survey reflected various deficiencies in the questions asked of some 60,000 households every month and an effort at the same time to use laptop computers throughout the survey process.
The January results also incorporate figures from the 1990 census, which had the effect of raising the month's jobless rate by a tenth of a point. These results would normally have been added two years ago but were put off pending the outcome of a debate over whether they should be adjusted for an undercount, which in the end they were.
One main problem with the survey was what the department called a bias against women, because of a presumption that those interviewed at home were homemakers -- who are not deemed part of the work force.
Instead of asking women "What were you doing most of last week, keeping house or something else?" the revamped survey asks, "Last week, did you do any work for pay?"
With more women now reporting at least half-hearted efforts to find jobs, their unemployment rate rose to 6 percent, compared with 5.7 percent under the method used in December.
 
Shades of Joblessness
 Similarly, the survey is now better able to distinguish between people who really consider themselves unemployed and are diligently seeking work, and people without jobs who may do no more than scan newspaper ads. Another change seeks to distinguish better between workers laid off but expecting to be recalled and those who suffer permanent job loss.
By changing the definition of re-entrants to the work force -- any previous work is now counted instead of a minimum of two weeks of full-time experience -- the proportion of re-entrants is markedly higher and new entrants are a smaller component of the jobless.
And the number of people classified as part time for economic reasons, who must now explicitly state a desire for full-time jobs as well as availability to take them, dropped to 5.2 million last month from the range of 6 million to 6.5 million that had prevailed since mid-1991.
Yet another change was a tightened definition of discouraged workers, who must now have looked for a job within the last year. Their ranks were put at 600,000 last month, barely half the 1.1 million that have been reported for the last two years.
One of the more interesting figures from the overhaul shows that 6,756,000 million people, or 5.6 percent of the employed, held more than one job last month. Typically, for both men and women, the primary job was full time and the secondary job part time, but 920,000 women had two part-time jobs (nearly twice as many as men) while 174,000 men had two full-time jobs (more than twice as many as women), the report showed.

HEADLINE: Federal Reserve, Changing Course, Raises A Key Rate

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
After five years of falling interest rates that helped pull the American economy out of recession, the Federal Reserve nudged short-term rates higher today with the aim of prolonging the current economic expansion by preventing a short, unsustainable burst of growth.
The Federal Reserve increased the rate for overnight loans between banks by a quarter of a percentage point, to 3.25 percent. This reversal in monetary policy will scarcely affect the interest rates that Americans pay on home mortgages or car loans, economists and business executives said, nor is it likely to have any immediate effect on the health of the economy. But it set off a strong reaction in the stock market, which fell sharply after the Federal Reserve announcement. 
 Economists said that if further increases followed -- which would depend on trends in the economy and inflation this spring -- the economy's strong recent growth could be trimmed slightly.
 
Further Increases Possible
 "The economic impact of such a small move is negligible, but the important point is that this is the first act of a play that is probably going to have many acts," said John P. Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers.
The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 96.24 points, to 3,871.42, or 2.43 percent, its biggest single-day drop in more than two years, and in the bond market, Treasury prices fell more than half a point. [Page 37.]
Showing a new level of political sophistication for an agency increasingly under attack for its obsessive secrecy, the Federal Reserve startled investors and money managers around the world by making a public statement of its move, something it has never done before in its 80-year history, Federal Reserve officials said.
 
Avoiding 'Misunderstanding'
 Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, said in the statement that the agency's monetary policy committee announced the action immediately "so as to avoid any misunderstanding of the committee's purposes, given the fact that this is the first firming" of overnight interest rates since early 1989.
Mr. Greenspan's announcement did not specify how much the short-term rate would rise, but by announcing publicly that the Federal Reserve would push this rate higher, he departed from usual Federal Reserve practice. Typically, the Federal Reserve quietly pushes the short-term rate higher or lower, and it is left to market analysts to announce that the Federal Reserve has changed its monetary policy.
To raise rates, the Federal Reserve sells Government securities to banks, decreasing their reserves and curbing their lending. To lower rates, the Federal Reserve buys back bonds, increasing the reserves. By the time the Federal Reserve was done selling bonds today, the Federal funds rate had risen by one-quarter of a percentage point.
Mr. Greenspan's statement coincides with political pressures on the Federal Reserve. Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who heads the House Banking Committee, has been waging a campaign to end the secrecy surrounding the Fed's monetary policy decisions, contending that the secrecy has shielded the Fed and its enormous power from public scrutiny. But Joseph R. Coyne, the Fed's chief spokesman, denied that political pressures had made any difference and said that today's announcement did not necessarily mean that any more statements would follow.
The Fed essentially tried today to slow down the economy slightly by limiting the ability of banks to lend money to individuals and companies.
As banks find themselves paying more to borrow money, they tend to raise interest rates for the loans that they issue. This means that fewer people and companies can afford to take out loans and buy goods and services, so the economy slows slightly. This reduces the competition for scarce resources like skilled labor or factory space, so prices -- and inflation -- rise less quickly.
Although the rise in short-term interest rates is expected to slow growth, the Federal Reserve hopes it will prolong the current economic expansion by cooling possible inflationary pressures, thus allowing longer-term rates to remain low.
Many banks never cut their loan rates deeply to match the fall in the Federal funds rate in recent years, preferring instead to pocket the widening difference between the interest rates that they pay to borrow money and the interest rates that they charge for loans.
That trend was reversed today, when few banks responded to the higher Federal funds rate by raising their prime rates, which are charged to corporate customers with good credit records.
The Harris Trust and Savings Bank, a large regional institution in Chicago, raised its prime rate to 5 3/4 percent from 5 1/2 percent, but most other banks had never cut their prime rates below 6 percent and did not change them today.
But the Federal funds rate is the only interest rate in the financial markets that the Fed directly controls. Interest rates for maturities longer than one night tend to move at different paces over which the Fed has much less influence.
Treasuries maturing in three years or five years are used to set interest rates for car loans, and the interest rates for these securities did not move up as much as the Federal funds rate. Treasuries that do not mature for 30 years, which influence the interest rates for fixed-rate mortgages, rose five one-hundredths of a percentage point today, to 6.35 percent.
Long-term rates depend mainly on expectations of inflation. So by raising the Federal funds rate and confronting inflationary pressures, the Fed acted today in a way that tends to hold down long-term rates. In testimony before a Congressional panel on Monday, Mr. Greenspan expressed concern that the large gap between short-term and long-term rates was a sign that while inflation might be low now, it might return.
 
Signals From Clinton
 A succession of Administrations has joined home builders and car dealers over the years in asking the Fed to postpone rate increases. Although President Clinton did call on the Fed three months ago to hold down rates, his aides have sent numerous signals in recent weeks that they were prepared to accept some increases.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, who heads President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, even acknowledged the likelihood of at least one more similar increase this year. The President's budget for the fiscal year 1995, scheduled for release on Monday, will be based on a forecast that short-term interest rates will rise by half a percentage point this year, she said in an interview this afternoon.
Some Clinton Administration officials had even quietly hoped for a rate increase now, reasoning that such increases were better now than in 1995 or later, when they might slow down the economy during the next Presidential elections.
In the early 1980's, home builders angry about high interest rates took the aggressive step of mailing two-by-fours to the Fed. But Tommy N. Thompson, a home builder in Owensboro, Ky., and the president of the National Association of Home Builders, said today, "If we could choose, we wouldn't raise these rates, but we don't view this move as a threat to the housing market."
Roger Hogan, the general manager at Toyota of Orange, in Orange, Calif., said that an increase in short-term rates might help bring a few extra customers into his showroom who had been hoping that car loan rates would fall even lower. But Mr. Hogan expressed concern that if car loan rates did bob up slightly in the coming months then he could lose some buyers.

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Seeking Tougher Embargo Despite the Strain on Haiti's Poor

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Despite growing concern that the embargo on Haiti is not working and is badly squeezing that nation's poor, the United States said today that it would ask the United Nations Security Council next week to impose tougher sanctions on Haiti.
The proposed new sanctions, which aim to show Haiti's military leaders that the world will not back down in its campaign to force them to restore democracy, would broaden the current embargo on fuel and arms to include almost everything except food and medicine. 
 Haiti's military leaders have been hopeful that the sanctions would eventually end in response to the growing hunger in Haiti, thus enabling them to maintain their hold on power.
"Haitian military authorities believe sanctions were on the verge of being removed, and that our resolve was weakening," a Clinton Administration official said. "This is a signal that we're in this for the long haul."
Acknowledging that the embargo has hurt Haiti's poor, Administration policy makers said they were seeking to tailor the tougher sanctions so that they bring maximum pressure on the military and its supporters, without increasing the suffering of the poor.
Some United States officials said they were optimistic that with the fuel embargo already biting hard, a tightened embargo might force the military to cede power within two or three months to the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, who was ousted in September 1991.
 
U.S. Seeks Mandatory Embargo
 At a meeting on Governors Island in New York City last July, Haiti's military leaders agreed to give up power and allow Father Aristide to return by last October. But after a dispute over an amnesty for the military leaders who overthrew Father Aristide, and an outbreak of street violence that was fomented by the military and intimidated its opponents, the military refused to step down and Father Aristide still remains in exile in Washington.
The United States, working in conjunction with Canada, France and Venezuela, plans to ask the Security Council to make the embargo mandatory for all nations. It is now voluntary.
The Clinton Administration also plans to ask the United Nations to ban all flights, except commercial, scheduled ones, to and from Haiti, a move intended to stop Haiti's military leaders and their rich supporters from buying provisions from abroad to skirt the embargo. This flight ban, officials said, also aims to prevent Haiti's military from making money in the narcotics trade. Officials said airports around the world would be informed of this flight ban and told not to accept unscheduled flights from Haiti.
American officials said the chances were good that the Security Council would approve the tougher sanctions, but they said there could always be complications.
In another move to put pressure on Haiti, the Administration plans to ask other countries to stop granting visas to about 600 military officials, as well as to freeze their bank accounts and refuse to process their financial transactions.
The United States is asking France, Britain and other countries to take these steps voluntarily, rather than asking the United Nations to impose them, because some countries have laws that do not allow for international financial sanctions to be imposed.
 
U.S. Denies Malnutrition
 The decision to tighten the embargo comes after a wave of reports about a surge in malnutrition in the most destitute parts of Haiti. United States officials deny that there is serious malnutrition and cite figures that international relief groups are feeding more than 850,000 Haitians a day.
"Haiti has been at the bottom of the hemisphere's income scale even before there were sanctions," a senior Administration official said. "It's gotten worse since the military came in, and then sanctions have had a further debilitating effect. But to give the impression that the sanctions are doing all this is unfair. The military is putting out stories that the embargo has created hardship in Haiti."
Representatives of Father Aristide applauded the proposal to tighten the embargo.
"We have favored the tightest possible sanctions for the shortest possible time," said Michael Barnes, a former Maryland Congressman who is Father Aristide's top American adviser. "We have advocated a total embargo with humanitarian exceptions for food and medicine. We believe that that, coupled with clear resolve from the international community, can result in a swift resolution of this crisis."
American officials say the pain created by the embargo has created some cracks within the military's united front, and they hope the tighter sanctions would increase those divisions. While top military officials have yet to be hit hard by the sanctions, some officials concede, many soldiers resent the sanctions because they are being squeezed badly.
"We're hoping that tightening the sanctions will cause these splits to grow," an Administration official said.
Many human rights groups have been ambivalent about the embargo, quietly favoring the sanctions because they should in theory help restore democracy, while at the same time worrying that they could cause starvation.
Administration officials said the exact scope of the broadened embargo has not been worked out, but that it would probably exclude food, medicine, diplomatic traffic, newspapers and educational materials.
One subject under debate is whether the embargo should cover raw materials and components that are needed to maintain the operation of some of Haiti's factories. American officials say they are concerned that if such components are placed under the embargo, those factories will close forever, doing lasting damage to Haiti's economy.

Rightists Demonstrate in Haiti
 PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 4 (AP) -- More than 2,000 rightist dem onstrators demanding an end to inter national sanctions and a replacement for Father Aristide blew horns and beat drums today in a parade through the Haitian capital.
 The demonstration, in which protest ers waved the flag of the former Duva lier dictatorship, was organized by a far-right paramilitary political group and was backed by rightist parties that supported the 1991 coup that ousted Father Aristide. They have called for new presidential elections so that he can be replaced.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Economy
The Federal Reserve nudged short-term interest rates higher. But economists said the move would not raise the rates that Americans paid on home mortgages or car loans, and was not likely to have an immediate effect on the health of the economy. [Page 1.] 
 The U.S. unemployment rate was 6.7 percent in January as severe weather crimped the expansion of business payrolls, according to the Government's new method for sampling the nation's households. Analysts said the data were consistent with an economy that was still moving ahead briskly in the early weeks of the new year after growing 5.9 percent in the final three months of 1993, which was considered too rapid to sustain. [1.] The New York City unemployment rate rose, while rates for New York State and New Jersey declined slightly. [48.]
 The Clinton Administration is promoting a technology that makes it possible for law enforcement agencies to intercept telephone and computer communications, even if they are in code. [1.]
 Government security experts warned that unknown intruders had broken into government, corporate and university computers connected to the global Internet communications network. [37.]
 
Markets
The Fed chilled stock and bond markets. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 96.24 points, or 2.43 percent. Treasury bond prices fell, raising the yield of the 30-year issue. [37.]
 Gold and silver futures prices weakened. [47.]
 The dollar surged to a two-and-a-half-year high against the German mark, and rose against other leading currencies. [47.]

Companies
Rupert Murdoch will sell The Boston Herald to its publisher, clearing the way for Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation to buy back the local Fox television station, which he sold in 1989. [39.]
Herman's Sporting Goods reached an agreement with its creditors on a reorganization plan. [39.]
 William M. Shinker resigned unexpectedly as the head of the adult trade division at HarperCollins. [39.]
 G.M. defended its electric vehicle program, saying it was trying to develop a vehicle consumers would buy but needed more time. [39.] Chrysler recalled its Neon subcompact for the second time since it went on sale last month. [10.]
 International
American and European media companies are watching the new commercial television station in the Czech Republic. [37.]
 Anthony F. J. O'Reilly bought nearly 25 percent of the parent of The Independent and The Independent on Sunday for $27.6 million, intensifying the fight for the innovative British newspapers. [37.]

Your Money
Investors are moving into investments with shorter maturities and less volatility in light of higher interest rates. [34.]
 Investing an inheritance can be daunting because of complicated issues about money values and long-term goals. [34.]
 Depositors can make tidy sums in the conversions of mutual savings banks through stock ownership. [34.]
 Specialized stock funds that invest in only one sector of the market captured the limelight in the first two weeks of 1994. [34.]

HEADLINE: Unemployment Edges Up To 10.8% in New York City

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The New York City unemployment rate rose last month, while the rates for New York State and New Jersey declined slightly, the United States Labor Department said yesterday.
The figures, however, rely on a new method of collecting data, which makes comparisons with previous months' jobless rates less meaningful, said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, commissioner for the New York region of the department's Bureau of Labor Statistics. 
 Joel Naroff, an economist with First Fidelity in Philadelphia, said, "I hate to say it, but we're in a statistical quagmire right now."
The unemployment rate for New York State was 7.1 percent in January, and in New Jersey it was 6.8 percent, Mr. Ehrenhalt said. In December, under the old survey method, the unemployment rates were 7.6 percent in New York and 7 percent in New Jersey.
Connecticut is not among the states for which the Government provides monthly figures.
In New York City, the unemployment rate increased to 10.8 percent under the new survey method, from 10.5 percent in December. The city rate, Mr. Ehrenhalt said, "kind of dampens the story for New York State as a whole because New York City is such a big part of it."
In New Jersey, Mr. Ehrenhalt said, "we're seeing signs of improvement, but job recovery has yet to hit its stride." Construction and services were leading the rebound, he said, with manufacturing still weak.
Richard M. Stein, an economist at Corestates Financial in Philadelphia, estimated that under the old system, New Jersey's unemployment rate would have shown a slight increase in January, to about 7.1 percent, to reflect sluggish growth in the labor force. But he added that he was still trying to understand the new system.
Economists said it would take several more months of collecting data before the new system could be used to provide an accurate picture of employment trends.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Sale Is Set For Boston Newspaper

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Rupert Murdoch said today that he would sell The Boston Herald to its publisher of the last 10 years, Patrick J. Purcell.
The sale will clear the way for Mr. Murdoch to buy back the local Fox television station, WFXT, Channel 25. He was forced to sell the station in 1989 by the Federal Communications Commission, which prohibits companies from owning two media outlets in the same market. 
 In New York, where Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation owns the Fox television station, WNYW, Channel 5, he was able to repurchase The New York Post last year by getting a waiver to the Federal rule when no other suitable owner could be found for The Post.
 
Leaving Other Jobs
 Mr. Purcell is also the publisher of The New York Post and the president and chief executive of News America Publishing Inc., part of Mr. Murdoch's media empire. He will resign those posts on Feb. 14 when he takes over as owner of The Herald.
"One thing we do not have any more are the deep pockets and the safety net of Rupert Murdoch's corporation," he said at a news conference today at the Herald building. "We are going to have to make it on our own."
The terms of the sale were not disclosed, and Mr. Purcell would not describe the financial health of The Herald except to say, "We're in the black."
Mr. Murdoch said in a statement that "it will be good for Boston to have the commitment of a local publisher." The Herald's rival, The Boston Globe, was bought by The New York Times Company in October.
The competition between The Herald and The Globe has been fierce in recent years. The Herald's circulation, as of September, was 321,715 on weekdays and 213,985 on Sundays, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations; The Globe's circulation was 507,647 on weekdays and 814,036 on Sundays.
"We know that Boston needs and can support two daily newspapers," Mr. Purcell said at the news conference where he shared the stage with his wife, his children and his parents.
The Herald is known for aggressive local reporting on politics and crime. After Thomas M. Menino, the Mayor of Boston, praised the sale at today's news conference, he said jokingly to Mr. Purcell, "Some of your reporters I'll talk to you about later on."
 
Different Points of View
 The Globe includes more national and international news and places a greater emphasis on writing style than does The Herald. The Herald's gossip columnists, Gayle Fee and Laura Raposa, like to refer to their rival in print as "the Boring Broadsheet."
Rick Gulla, a spokesman for The Globe, said, "We wish Mr. Purcell well."
One of the more famous moments of the rivalry occurred in 1992, when The Herald was running one of Mr. Murdoch's trademark Wingo contests to raise circulation. The Herald sent a photographer to stake out the house of The Globe's editor, Matthew V. Storin. As Mr. Storin left his house, the photographer stuck a "Wingo" sign into his arms and snapped his picture. Thus The Globe's editor appeared in The Herald promoting its contest.
A leading newspaper analyst said it would be difficult for The Herald to fight The Globe without Mr. Murdoch's financial help. "The history of second newspapers in this country is kind of a grim one, and usually depends on someone with deep pockets," said John Morton, an analyst at Lynch, Jones & Ryan, a brokerage firm in Washington.
"I understand that since the recession, it hasn't been making any money," he said. "I don't want to be shooting at lifeboats. I hope Mr. Purcell has some strategy to keep it going."
Mr. Purcell, a native of Queens whose first newspaper job was filling glue pots in the advertising department of The Daily News in New York, said in an interview that he would refurbish the paper's press units, find more efficient ways of producing pages, and put new features in the Sunday paper.
"I have been the leader of this newspaper for the last 10 years," he said at the news conference. "I have had almost complete autonomy."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Patrick J. Purcell, publisher of The Boston Herald, announcing he would buy the paper from Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Inmate Fears Death Because Prison Won't Finance Transplant

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA 

 BODY:
If DeWayne Murphy were not in Federal prison, he would be on a waiting list for a heart transplant or might even have had one by now.
But the Federal Bureau of Prisons, which is responsible for his medical costs, does not pay for organ transplants, so the 33-year-old Mr. Murphy is living in a medical ward at the Rochester Federal Medical Center in Minnesota, agonizing over his case. One prisoners' rights advocate argues that by not financing a heart transplant for Mr. Murphy the Bureau of Prisons has converted his four-year sentence to a death sentence. 
 Mr. Murphy says his health is rapidly deteriorating as his heart fails. He says that he is weak and short of breath and that he must sleep sitting up, with an oxygen mask over his face. His mother, Pat Murphy of Liberty, Mo., says her son is afraid to fall asleep at night.
Mr. Murphy's case, ethicists and lawyers say, raises troubling questions about access to health care for those in the criminal-justice system.
 
A Host of Questions
 Should the nation provide expensive care and scarce organs to convicted felons? Can it justify a system in which an estimated one in four employed Americans cannot have a transplant because they are uninsured or underinsured, yet ask the Bureau of Prisons to provide them for prisoners?
If the Bureau will not pay for a transplant, should it pay for a quadruple bypass? Or, looking at it another way, should a nonviolent criminal like Mr. Murphy get a heart, but a murderer or rapist not? What about someone convicted of a white-collar crime, like tax fraud? Where, if at all, should society draw the line?
Esther Benenson, a spokeswoman for the United Network for Organ Sharing, the national group that allocates organs for transplant, said 2,856 Americans were waiting for heart transplants on Jan. 26. She said about half the people on heart-transplant lists eventually received organs.
Mr. Murphy was arrested in March 1991 for possession, with intent to sell, of about a pound of methamphetamine. It was his first Federal offense and he pleaded guilty. He was already desperately ill with cardiomyopathy, a progressive weakening of the heart muscle.
 
A Longer Sentence
 Before his arrest, he had been evaluated at St. Luke's Hospital in Kansas City, Mo., where he was told that he was a candidate for a transplant. But instead of going on the transplant list, he went to prison. And now that his health has deteriorated, he must be re-evaluated before he can be put on the list.
Mr. Murphy, perhaps naively, never expected to serve a long prison term. "Everything considered, I figured I would get maybe six months or home confinement or something similar to that," Mr. Murphy said in a telephone interview. But Federal mandatory sentencing laws resulted in a four-year sentence, with no chance of early release, beginning in January 1992.
Before he was arrested, Mr. Murphy had Medicaid coverage because he was unemployed and Medicare coverage because he was disabled. Both pay for transplants. To be eligible for Medicare a person must be disabled for two years. In Mr. Murphy's case, the disability that made him eligible for Medicare was not heart disease but Lyme disease. He says the cardiomyopathy is a result of the Lyme disease, although experts say most cardiomyopathy is of unknown origin.
A public information officer at the Bureau of Prisons, Gregory Bogdan, said that the bureau provided "essential, basic, health care that is consistent with community standards" but that it did "not ordinarily pay for transplants."
 
Out of Options
 The bureau says it would permit him to leave on medical furlough to have the transplant if he had a way to pay it. But because Medicare does not cover Federal prisoners and because Missouri Medicaid will not cover him because he is now out of state, he has no options.
A heart transplant costs about $123,000, said Dr. Roger Evans, the director of health services evaluation at the Mayo Clinic; moreover, transplant patients must take immuno-suppressive drugs, which cost $5,000 to $6,000 a year, for the rest of their lives, he added.
"Every convicted felon has a right to health care," Dr. Evans said. Still, he acknowledged that transplanting a heart into a felon at public expense "sends a perverse message to people considering organ donation."
"There's going to be another person waiting on that list who potentially could be returned to productive capacity," he said. If a heart goes to a prisoner, Dr. Evans said, "we're essentially paying twice."
"We're paying to house them and then we're incurring a substantial cost for their medical care," he said.
 
A Death Sentence
 But John Boston, a lawyer who is project director for the Prisoners' Rights Project of the Legal Aid Society of New York City, said that by refusing to provide Mr. Murphy with a new heart the Bureau of Prisons is essentially giving him a death sentence. Mr. Boston, who had not heard of Mr. Murphy's case until he was asked about it this week, said he thought it would not stand up a challenge under the Constitution's Eighth Amendment, which prohibits cruel and unusual punishment.
Dr. Arthur Caplan, director of the Center for Bioethics at the University of Minnesota, said he believed that there was no ethical justification for denying organs to prisoners on any basis other than failure to meet medical criteria. "For me, it's open and shut," he said. "It's absolutely wrong to make judgments about past behavior, criminal conduct, moral worth, indictments, charges or convictions."
Dr. Nancy Dubler, the director of the division of bioethics at the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, said that the case reminded her of the early days of artificial kidney machines, when citizen committees, often referred to as "God squads," decided which patients with kidney failure would have access to the scarce machines -- in essence, deciding who would live and who would die.
 
The Worthiness of a Life
 Ethicists and the public eventually found it so distasteful to rate the worthiness of a human life that, Dr. Dubler said, "the clear movement since then has been to establish rigorously abstract criteria so that the worth of an individual is not factored in" when deciding who should get organs or other lifesaving medical treatments.
Dr. Caplan said he understood the argument that it would be galling to give a new heart to a felon when many working Americans could not have a heart transplant because they have no health insurance; but, he said, that is a problem of health insurance in America. "The answer is not to kill DeWayne Murphy," he said.
Mr. Murphy said he just hoped he lived long enough for his case to be resolved. "I've been here 11 months and my health has deteriorated," he said. "If it deteriorates any more, I'll be on life support. And there's only one thing left after life support."
"All I'm asking for is a chance," Mr. Murphy pleaded. "This was my first offense. I was never in trouble before this. I think I've learned my lesson."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Organ transplants are not covered in Federal prisoners' medical care. The case of one inmate, DeWayne Murphy, suffering from cardiomyopathy at the Rochester Federal Medical Center in Minnesota and in need of a new heart, is raising questions from ethicists and lawyers about the policy. (Steve Woit)

HEADLINE: New Orleans Mayor's Race Heats Up

BYLINE: By FRANCES FRANK MARCUS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Mardi Gras is fast approaching, with its usual excesses in tow, but this year New Orleans is grappling with more serious concerns as well.
Voters here are trying to choose a new mayor who can cure an excess of ills: high crime, blighted housing, an economy still coughing from the collapse of oil prices, a loss of faith in City Hall, and middle-class flight to the suburbs. And just around the bend, there will be the need to cope with a giant casino planned for downtown. 
 Along with all the other excesses, there is also an abundance of candidates: four black men and three white men who will compete in a nonpartisan primary on Saturday among an electorate that is 59 percent black.
"It's a very serious election because the city's basically going down the tubes," said Dr. Edward Renwick, director of Loyola University's Institute of Politics, offering a blunt assessment of the problems confronting New Orleans. "It's got to be turned around."
 
Priority on Crime
 He went on: "The issues are crime, crime, crime -- and the economy. You have to stop the flight out of the city of both races. And if the crime problem isn't arrested, it's going to impact tourism, which in turn is going to affect gambling, which both the city and the state are saying will be the savior."
But at least there will be a lull before the start of gambling in what is touted as the world's largest casino and the first to be built in a major American city. A lawsuit challenging the right of the city to lease the land where the casino would be built has delayed construction of the big casino, which has a gaming area of 200,000 square feet, as well as the opening of a smaller, interim casino in the Municipal Auditorium.
Gambling has begun on a boat on Lake Pontchartrain, however, and a Mississippi riverboat will begin gaming operations downtown next week.
The city's problems are neither new nor unique, but voters seem to think they are worsening. According to a recent poll by the University of New Orleans, 80 percent of 781 people surveyed said the quality of life here was declining. In 1986, only 25 percent believed the quality of life was declining.
Their pessimism centers on crime. Last year there were 389 murders in New Orleans, a record here. In 1992 there were 279, and the year before that, 346. According to 1990 census figures, the population dropped to 496,938, from 557,515 in 1980. Nearly a third of the people live below the poverty level.
The issues are being driven home with unusual force because there are so many candidates. But Carnival offers some diversion. On Saturday, the day of the primary, New Orleans will be distracted by five parades, in advance of Mardi Gras on Feb. 15. A runoff election will be held on March 5.
Mayor Sidney Barthelemy, who cannot run for a third term, is backing Councilman Lambert Boissiere, but his support may actually hurt the candidate. The Mayor has lost favor among blacks and whites alike, especially in the aftermath of a dispute involving scholarships at Tulane University and political patronage. Many people were outraged last year to learn that the Mayor had granted a scholarship to his son. Mr. Barthelemy subsequently withdrew it.
Recent polls show the front-runners to be State Senator Marc Morial, the 36-year-old son of the late Mayor Ernest N. (Dutch) Morial, and Donald Mintz, a 50-year-old lawyer and civic leader who ran a strong campaign for mayor four years ago and entered this race early. Both are Democrats.
Mr. Morial, a lawyer, said at a forum at Dillard University last week that the race was between him and Mr. Mintz, and suggested that votes should not be "wasted" on the other candidates.
But the polls also show that many people are undecided: 33 percent in a survey of 558 voters directed by Susan E. Howell, a professor of political science at the University of New Orleans. Mr. Morial received 24 percent of the vote, Mr. Mintz, 22 percent. The poll had a margin of sampling error of four percentage points.
Mr. Mintz has written a book, "Turning New Orleans Around." Indeed, he has made that phrase the theme of his campaign, as he did four years ago. He talks about the need to diversify the city's economy, which has become more and more dependent on tourism. And he has been endorsed by the editorial page of The Times-Picayune, the city's major newspaper.
For his part, Mr. Morial has emphasized strong leadership, a trade mark of his father, the city's first black mayor who gained a reputation for being effective and arrogant in his eight years in office in the 1980's.
State Representative Mitch Landrieu, 33, the son of former Mayor Moon Landrieu, is a distant third in the University of New Orleans poll.
 
'Two Agents of Change'
 "Voters' preferences are really crystallizing around Mintz and Morial," Dr. Howell said. "No candidate here is clearly the agent of change -- we have two agents of change, Morial and Mintz." In a hypothetical runoff, Dr. Howell added, "it's dead even." Her poll shows the vote to be divided along racial lines and, to some degree, by age. "Older black voters are evenly divided between Mintz and Morial," she said, while some younger white voters are attracted to Mr. Morial.
This week the hardball tactics that accompany all elections here focused on the front-runners. Mr. Morial has been taunted for not divulging his medical records, which, his enemies hint, would show he has been treated for drug abuse. Mr. Morial has denied the rumors.
Mr. Mintz's enemies say his campaign has engaged in dirty tricks by distributing racist and anti-Semitic fliers that attack him and create the impression that he is the target of vicious opponents. Mr. Mintz, who is Jewish, says he is not responsible for the fliers. A state grand jury today indicted one of Mr. Mintz's unpaid advisers, Dr. Napoleon Moses, a college professor from Mississippi, on a misdemeanor charge of distributing anonymous fliers. Dr. Moses said afterward that he had "done nothing wrong." Mr. Mintz appeared voluntarily before the grand jury earlier in the day.

HEADLINE: Beliefs;
The Funniest Rabbi Contest: when it comes to stand-up comedy, most should sit down.

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
There may be a lot of witty rabbis around, but two out of three have no future as stand-up comedians. That rule emerged on Monday from Round 2 of the Funniest Rabbi in New York Contest.
The contest is the idea of Cary Hoffman, the owner of Stand-Up N.Y., a comedy club at West 78th Street and Broadway in Manhattan. He has organized competitions for the Funniest Lawyer, Funniest Wall Streeter, Funniest Taxi Driver (English-language division) and Funniest Police Officer. He has also done Funniest Unemployed Person, a particularly handy category since it includes most stand-up comedians. 
 Mr. Hoffman admits failure at finding recruits for Funniest Undertaker, but he has a surplus of contenders for Funniest Accountant.
His own accountant gets more than a chuckle when the competing rabbis appear, however, because they usually swell the crowd with loyal members of their congregations. And rabbis are a favorite category with Mr. Hoffman himself. "Jews have a special relationship to humor," he said, and "rabbis are comfortable on stage compared to other professions."
At least that was what he said before Monday night's session.
The club was, indeed, filled with rabbinical family members and friends, and with faithful congregants. A contingent of students from Ramaz, an Orthodox Jewish private school on the Upper East Side, had come to root for their Talmud teacher, Rabbi Moshe Rothchild.
So bring on the rabbis.
Well, no: three of the club's regular comics went first, while the master of ceremonies, Todd Barry, tried to parry the growing impatience. When one rabbi contestant volunteered that this was the "the most important day of my life since my bar mitzvah," Mr. Barry snapped back, saying that "it is the most painful day of my life since my circumcision."
Finally, it was the rabbis' turn. Within a few minutes, one sensed a wave of nostalgia for the house regulars. In keeping with the Talmudic principle of "al talbin pnai haverkha barabim" -- don't embarrass your friend in public -- the first two contestants shall remain nameless.
They displayed a minor talent for colorful description but none, alas, for punch lines. Worse, they slipped from stand-up into sermonizing. When the second rabbi introduced his closing remarks by saying, "I may not be the funniest rabbi in the world," no one protested.
The profession's honor was rescued by Rabbi Rothchild. He took the stage amid the general hilarity of his students. "I've only got five minutes," he told them. "Laugh quickly."
"Anyone here not Jewish?" he asked, then reworded the query to be politically correct: "I mean, Jewishly challenged?"
Rabbi Rothchild had been so nervous, he said, that he called his mother earlier in the day. "Don't worry," she reassured him, "no one will laugh at you."
The 26-year-old Talmudic teacher was the clear winner of Round 2. Eventually, he will face Rabbi Neil Fleischmann, who won Round 1 a week earlier. Rabbi Fleischmann, who is 31, teaches Russian Jewish immigrants the basics of Judaism at the Academy of Jewish Education's branch in Washington Heights.
Much of the rabbinical humor on Monday was surprisingly generic, rather than specifically Jewish. Where were the grand themes of guilt, worry, assimilation, Jewish mothers, denominational battles, Talmudic logic, anti-Semitism, the tarrying of the Messiah?
It was Sam Greenfield, not a rabbi but one of the professional comics, who said he always kept the three major Jewish holidays: Rosh ha-Shanah, Yom Kippur and the Academy Awards.
And it was Dave Attell, another of the regulars, who noted that "in the Bible we're the chosen people -- in the gym class we are the last-chosen people." He also expressed his admiration for Israelis: "They're tough, they're cocky -- they're almost like Italians."
There was only one example of really biting religious humor. Rabbi No. 2 recalled being called a Christ-killer at the age of 5. "At first it bothered me," he said. "Then I felt empowered."
That was up to current comedy-club standards of offensiveness but still proportionate to the nastiness of the accusation.
Three years ago, when Stand-Up N.Y. held its first Funniest Rabbi competition, the contestants drew heavily on Jewish life. The winner, Rabbi Robert Harris, offered recollections that ranged from his working on a dairy farm kibbutz near Nazareth (someone suggested naming it Cheeses of Nazareth) to the first synagogue services he conducted: "Very often I outnumbered the congregation."
Rabbi Harris is not defending his title. Although he has done occasional gigs since his victory, he found stand-up comedy to be time-consuming and distracting from his family life, rabbinical responsibilities and doctoral studies at the Jewish Theological Seminary.
Besides, he recently formed a rock band, with a Jesuit-educated Catholic businessman on bass guitar and a rabbi friend from the East Village on drums. Lead guitar is played by Eve Weiss, a classical musician who says she always had fantasies of being a rock star.
The group, known as Shake Rabbis and Roll, will give a benefit performance tonight at the Jewish Center in Pelham Manor, in Westchester County, Rabbi Harris's synagogue.
Both finalists in this year's competition are Orthodox rabbis and are friends from the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary of Yeshiva University.
"At age 12 or 13 I used to write my own plays and movie plots and perform at synagogue," Rabbi Fleischmann said. "But I put it on hold when I got more serious about religion."
"I try to do this with dignity," he continued. Rather than involving any mockery of religion or Judaism, he said, "this is part of my spiritual side."
The two finalists have something else in common, too: Both use their humor in the classroom. Rabbi Rothchild said, "The Talmud has advice for people who want to teach something: 'Begin with a joke.' "
At Stand-Up N.Y., Mr. Hoffman has not set a date for the finals. He is still hoping for more rounds and more finalists. For publicity, he has the cooperation of The Jewish Week, a New York City newspaper whose recently appointed editor, Gary Rosenblatt, made a stab at stand-up comedy in the early 1970's. ("That's why I went into Jewish journalism.")
But Mr. Hoffman has even greater hopes. Funniest Minister! Funniest Priest! And why not Funniest Zen Master or Funniest Ayatollah (although he didn't mention it)?
Finally, he envisions a grand interfaith playoff: the Divine Stand-Up Comedy!
Perhaps Father Guido Sarducci could serve as judge.

HEADLINE: Japan's Crisis Delays Economic Plan

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Even after agreeing to drop a bitterly disputed tax plan in a hail of criticism, Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's coalition Goverment grew more divided today, delaying the completion of a critical package of measures for reviving Japan's recession-battered economy.
The delay disappointed business executives, who had hoped that after achieving a measure of success in a major battle last week over reforming the election system, the Government would quickly take steps to get the faltering economy back on track. 
 "We have no time to spare," said Gaishi Hiraiwa, chairman of Keidanren, Japan's most influential business lobbying group, in urging the Government to finally take action.
 
Could Effect Trade Accord
 The turmoil today could also eliminate a vital element in a broad trade agreement that the Government has been struggling to conclude with the United States in advance of a meeting in Washington next Friday between President Clinton and Mr. Hosokawa.
One of the few areas on which the two Governments have agreed is that Japan should take bold measures to stimulate its economy after two years of recession. More rapid growth would be likely to draw in more imports, reducing Japan's annual trade surpluses with the United States of more than $50 billion.
Mr. Hosokawa's tax proposal, which involved a $55 billion income tax cut this year and then a huge increase in the national sales tax after three years, was central to a planned $138 billion economic stimulus package. Its rejection makes it difficult if not impossible for Mr. Hosokawa to bring to Washington the one clear sign that Japan is serious about reducing its surpluses.
Within Japan, perhaps the most damaging aspect of the turmoil was the fact that the criticism of Mr. Hosokawa's tax plan grew very personal today.
 
Leadership Questioned
 The plan's defeat, just one day after it was proposed, was described not as a sign of the fractious nature of the governing coalition, but as a failure of leadership, a perception that could limit Mr. Hosokawa's room to maneuver in Washington next week.
The Clinton Administration has placed most of its hopes for resolving some of the gnawing trade disputes with Japan on Mr. Hosokawa's personal ability to override the Japanese Government bureaucracy and the opposition in Parliament.
"Even if he manages to ride over the crisis through compromises this time, his prestige has been undermined and the mutual trust among the coalition partners irreparably damaged," the Asahi Shimbun, a leading daily newspaper, said in an editorial.
Mr. Hosokawa's supporters insisted that the damage would not be long-lasting, but admitted that the defeat had taken a worse toll than the battle over election reform and the opening of Japan's rice market to imports.
"I admit his credibility was damaged, but I don't think the damage will be serious or permanent," Kazuo Aichi, the head of the Defense Agency, said in a telephone interview today.
Mr. Hosokawa took many here by surprise, including some members of his ruling coalition, by announcing on Thursday that he had decided on the income tax reduction and the subsequent sales tax increase.
The idea was to use the income tax reduction, much of which was retroactive to Jan. 1, to revive consumer spending. Once the tax cut and heavy public works spending had helped trigger a recovery, the thinking went, the big increase in the sales tax would offset the earlier loss in income tax revenues. The aim of that approach, pushed relentlessly by the Finance Ministry, was to avoid incurring long-running Government budget deficits.
To make it easier to sell the idea, Mr. Hosokawa decided to call the increased sales tax a national welfare tax, saying that the proceeds would be used to cover some of the expenses of providing pensions, health care and other benefits to Japan's aging society.
But Mr. Hosokawa refused to write into the law a provision that would have reserved the money from the tax for such welfare spending. He further alienated some of his coalition partners, particularly the Socialists, by refusing to reconsider the size of the sales tax increase and its timing.
"My ministry is in charge of welfare affairs, but it is strange that the national welfare tax surfaced without any advance consultations with this ministry," said an angry Keigo Ouchi, the Minister for Health and Welfare.
 
Partners Threatened to Quit
 Mr. Hosokawa was forced to back down after the Socialist Party, along with some of his closest allies, threatened to resign from the Cabinet and push the coalition toward collapse.
The episode exposed the deep suspicions that many Cabinet members have of the bureaucrats who formulated government policy during the 38 years of Liberal Democratic Party rule, which Mr. Hosokawa ended last summer. It also pushed to the surface the growing tension between two of Mr. Hosokawa's key allies, Ichiro Ozawa, a conservative who favored the tax increase, and Masayoshi Takemura, the chief Cabinet secretary, who has generally been more sensitive to public opinion.
Mr. Hosokawa continued to press for his plan today, even after the defeat, insisting that it had been "frozen," not scrapped.
Others in the coalition agreed. "Starting with a clean slate does not mean we have scrapped everything," Mr. Aichi said. "I'm hoping personally for a consensus somewhere along the same lines as what Mr. Hosokawa proposed."
