HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Precious Metals Weaken On Move to Check Inflation

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold and silver futures prices weakened yesterday after the Federal Reserve raised a key interest rate for the first time in five years.
Analysts expect the Fed's move to calm fears about inflation. If that is the case, the recent rally in gold may lose much of its steam because gold is still seen by some investors as an inflation hedge. 
 The move toward higher interest rates also worried silver traders, who see reduced industrial demand for silver if the economy cools.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for April delivery, the most actively traded futures contract, fell 80 cents, to $388.30 an ounce. March silver ended 4.8 cents lower, at $5.427 an ounce, after trading as high as $5.51, a four-year high.
Analysts were not sure how the metals would react on Monday to yesterday's plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average of 96.24 points, or nearly 2.5 percent. The stock market was down only about 50 points when the precious metal markets closed.
 
Surprised at Size of Drop
 "I'm just sitting here, polishing my Japanese sword, getting ready to commit hara-kiri if I can't call the market right for my company on Monday," said James Steel, precious metals analyst for Refco Inc., the giant futures trading firm.
He said he was a little surprised that gold had not fallen more sharply in response to the quarter-point increase in the Federal funds rate, the interest banks charge one another on overnight loans, to 3.25 percent. The higher rate is likely to lead to higher business and consumer rates.
The Fed's move also shocked and destabilized the stock market, which caused some panic buying of gold, Mr. Steel said. In addition to its appeal as an inflation hedge, gold is also perceived as a safe haven in times of financial turmoil.
"There's a lot of big money flying around on both sides," said Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst at Paine Webber Inc.
Mr. Savaiko was skeptical of gold's value as a hedge against a stock market collapse. During the 1987 and 1989 market collapses, many investors had to sell assets, including gold, to raise cash to meet margin calls, he said.
"All you can say is that higher interest rates and a low inflation climate are not supportive for precious metals," Mr. Savaiko said. "Whichever way we go from here is likely to be a big move. I don't necessarily think it's going to be on the up side."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Surges on Increase In Short-Term Rates by Fed

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar surged to a two-and-a- half-year high against the German mark yesterday in a broad rally after the Federal Reserve said it was tightening monetary policy. It also rose against other leading currencies.
The Fed usually subtly reveals monetary policy through open market operations. But yesterday it took the unusual step of announcing that it would tighten credit. The move nudged short-term money market interest rates upward for the first time in five years and jolted financial markets. 
 While the Fed said it announced the increase to avoid market confusion, the disclosure sent stocks and bonds lower and the dollar soaring. "It was pretty explosive," said Paul Yarden, Bank of Montreal marketing representative, referring to the reaction in currency markets. "People were just scrambling for dollars against all the other currencies."
The dollar reached a two-and-a-half-year trading high of 1.7640 marks before giving back a bit of ground. In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.7590 marks, up sharply from 1.7412 marks on Thursday. It also rose to 109.30 Japanese yen, from 108.23 yen.
Higher American interest rates usually strengthen the dollar, since better yields on dollar-denominated assets make it more attractive.
 
 
Traders Caught Off Gauard
 Dealers said many participants had been caught off guard by the Fed's move, particularly after the release of January's payrolls report, which fell below expectations.
"The market was surprised by the Fed," said Jim Phoenix, a dealer for CIBC. "I would say people were expecting the Fed to add reserves at Fed time and for Fed funds to trade down to 3 percent. Obviously, the Fed had their minds made up before the employment numbers."
The dollar virtually ignored disappointing news on the trade front with Japan, as the Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, Jeffrey E. Garten, said the United States and Japan remained far apart in their efforts to reach a trade deal.
While the news would have normally put pressure on the dollar versus the yen, it had limited impact yesterday because of the market's preoccupation with the Fed.
Meanwhile, the British pound eased in New York to $1.4765, from $1.4880 late Thursday.

HEADLINE: Chia Journal;
Where Did the Don Get His Fortune?

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHIA, Colombia

 BODY:
With steaks sizzling on charcoal, the waiters in cowboy hats, a band playing "ranchera" country music, and Colombian walking horses prancing through the dining room, La Margarita del Ocho steakhouse has become the latest popular family outing for Bogota residents.
But helping to pack the parking lot of the 700-seat restaurant 15 miles north of the capital is the star quality of the restaurant's new owner, Fabio Ochoa Restrepo. 
 Settling into a red velour armchair every weekend, the 69-year-old "Don Fabio" presents a portrait of a traditional Latin American patriarch: barking orders at waiters and ranch hands, inspecting his purebred horses, and holding court for horse buyers and the diners who flock around him, eager to share his limelight.
No diner ever speaks about what they all know: Don Fabio acquired his fame largely because of his sons, three of South America's most successful cocaine smugglers.
Perhaps only in Colombia, where hard questions are rarely asked about mysterious fortunes, could an excursion to La Margarita del Ocho be considered a wholesome family outing.
 
Hundreds of Tons to U.S.
 Starting in the 1970's, the three Ochoa brothers shipped hundreds of tons of cocaine to the United States. In their heyday in the 1980's, they helped make the Medellin cartel the world's most powerful drug trafficking organization. The oldest brother, Jorge Luis, regularly landed on Forbes's list of world billionaires.
Although the police assigned to the drug trade say Mr. Ochoa's horse-breeding business did not begin to boom until his sons began to rise to the top of the cocaine-trafficking world, the Ochoa clan patriarch insists that he never benefited from his sons' illicit activities.
"I have had all this since I was born," the restaurateur said about his herd of 1,200 purebred horses, worth an estimated $25 million.
Mr. Ochoa's popularity is one of many signs of how comfortable Colombia has become with an economy that benefits from the drug trade.
In Cali, home to the nation's strongest drug cartel, a multimillion-dollar construction boom, financed from mysterious sources, is transforming the skyline of the formerly workaday provincial capital. In Bogota, now shunned by tourists because of the violence and urban congestion, 33 construction projects now under way are doubling the city's hotel capacity.
Explaining how he acquired his fortune, Mr. Ochoa skips over the fact that his wife and five daughters bused tables at a family restaurant in the mid-1960's. Instead, he traces his money back to horse-breeding stock acquired by his grandfather in the 1920's.
In his autobiography, "My Life in the World of Horses," published by a vanity press, Mr. Ochoa writes, "Fabio Ochoa is to Colombia's horse world what Garcia Marquez is to Colombia's world of letters or what Fernando Botero is to Colombia's world of painting."
The Government apparently has not made a vigorous search to find out the truth. Aside from a brief detention 10 years ago over a pistol permit violation, Mr. Ochoa has never been arrested. After desultory investigations for illicit enrichment, prosecutors decided not to lodge any charges against him. Police officers who stop by for free steaks and sodas respectfully greet him as Don Fabio.
Legal clouds are also lifting from his sons, who surrendered three years ago to face trial for drug trafficking and for illicit enrichment. Two sons, Fabio and Jorge Luis, have negotiated terms under Colombia's new plea bargaining system that could allow them to leave jail by the end of of next year in return for good behavior and payment of $4.5 million in fines. The third son, Juan David, is to start negotiating his sentence soon.
 
The Ultimate Offense
 Mr. Ochoa moved here last year from Antioquia, where Medellin is situated. But it was not embarrassment over his sons' activities that led him to leave the state that had nourished his family since the 18th century.
"There is a lot of violence in Medellin now -- hired killers, robbers, kidnappings," he said, seated on his informal throne in his restaurant. Dozens of family photographs were visible behind him and throughout the restaurant's interior. To his right, a table was cluttered with a sample of the 5,000 trophies he said he has won in a lifetime of breeding Colombian walking horses. A few weeks ago, he said, he turned down a $1.2 million offer for his most prized horse, Atrevido, a 5-year-old black stallion.
He said that for a horse breeder the ultimate offense in the Medellin area came six months ago. Members of a rival drug trafficking group kidnapped a $1 million stallion that belonged to a member of the Escobar branch of the Medellin cartel. Then the horse was castrated, returned and tied to a tree.
So, on a highway running through Bogota's savanna, with a verdant mountain as a backdrop, Mr. Ochoa opened what he called, with a touch of nostalgia, "a consulate of Antioquia."
Painted in the red and green colors favored in rural Antioquia, the restaurant serves its regional specialties -- roasted beef, black beans and arepas, or corn muffins. As a charcoal haze collects under the burlap-lined roof of the open-sided dining room, guests eat at wind-slapped tables, separated by post and rail fences from a steady parade of ponies, Percherons and Colombian walking horses.
On a recent afternoon, Mr. Ochoa's eyes lighted up with special pride when a gentle black mare called Pomposa walked in the restaurant. Perched on her back was Daniela, Mr. Ochoa's 3-year-old daughter.
With a little prodding, the patriarch, who describes himself as "the family trunk," conceded that it was more than Medellin's violence that caused him to leave home.
Seven years ago Mr. Ochoa's wife had looked the other way when he fathered a daughter out of wedlock. But when the young woman had a second daughter, Daniela, Mrs. Ochoa called a clan meeting in the jail near Medellin where her three sons are imprisoned.
"The boys all took the side of their mother, and I guess they were right," he said with a hint of sheepishness as he tried to explain something new to traditional Latin patriarchs: divorce.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Fabio Ochoa Restrepo says his fortune came from his purebred horses, not from the illicit activities of his three sons, who were among Colombia's richest cocaine traffickers. (Zoe Selsky for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Ruling Is Seen as a Threat To Preferences in Bidding

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
By invalidating a New York City program that gives preferential treatment to women and members of minority groups who bid on municipal contracts, a State Supreme Court judge may have undermined incentive programs for other businesses in the city, regardless of the race or sex of their owners.
On Monday Justice Walter B. Tolub ruled that the city's affirmative action "price preference" violated a state law that requires government agencies to accept the lowest bids in awarding contracts. The preference, allowing women and members of minority groups to bid up to 10 percent higher than their competitors, is one provision of a broader two-year-old program intended to increase the participation in city contracts of companies that have often been excluded. 
 To many officials the court decision seemed anticlimactic, since Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had repeatedly criticized the affirmative action price preference and signed an executive order to eliminate it only days before Judge Tolub's ruling.
But since Monday, as the court ruling has circulated at City Hall and among lawyers, many have concluded that the ruling raises serious doubts about the validity of two other price preference programs. The larger of the two, known as the local preference, allows city agencies to accept bids as much as 5 percent higher than the lowest bids on contracts, so long as the winning bidder is based in the city.
 
An Appeal Is Considered
 "As it stands, the reasoning in this case might be read in a way that makes other preferences vulnerable," said Jeffrey D. Friedlander, a lawyer on the staff of the New York City Corporation Counsel. Although the city's legal staff says it has grounds for an appeal, he said, no decision had been made on whether to file an appeal.
Whether to appeal may raise difficult political questions for the Giuliani administration, since it could mean defending the principles of a program the Mayor has abolished to save another that is widely supported among businesses in the city.
A spokesman for the Mayor, Forest Taylor, said yesterday that Mr. Giuliani "generally supports" the local preference program. "It has traditionally been part of the city's economic development initiatives to support locally based enterprises," Mr. Taylor said.
Legal experts said the other price preference program, which the city adopted in 1991, would also be vulnerable because of Justice Tolub's ruling. In that program, far smaller than the local preference program, a 5 percent preference is given to companies that sell the city paper and other products that are recycled.
Although it has won favor among New York City construction companies, suppliers of computer equipment and a broad spectrum of other companies that do business with the city, the local preference program has also drawn some of the same criticism that the Mayor has lodged against the affirmative action program, mainly that it wastes money.
"We always are troubled by price preferences," said Constance Cushman, executive director of the city's Procurement Policy Board, an agency established as part of the revision of the municipal charter in 1989 to monitor contract awards and procurement policies.
Although the Procurement Policy Board has no power to change city policy, it has consistently criticized the local preferences. According to an analysis it released in January 1993, the most recent available, the city had spent $1.5 million more since 1984 by giving its preferences to local companies than if it had simply accepted the lowest bids.
The repercussions of the local preferences have extended beyond New York City, where, through much of the late 1980's, business people and government officials cried foul.
 
In New Jersey, a Penalty
 New Jersey was the first to retaliate, in 1991, when it adopted what it called a Golden Rule for dealing not only with New York City, but also 18 states and 6 other cities that imposed various forms of local preference. According to the New Jersey rule, which is still in effect, businesses in the cities and states with local preferences will be penalized by the same preferences when they bid for business with New Jersey agencies.
Next, in 1992, came Nassau County. Its policy, still in effect, is to grant a 10 percent price preference to its own resident businesses. But Nassau has avoided a direct confrontation with New York City, since it extends the same preferences to businesses in the city, as well as in Suffolk County.
Judge Tolub's ruling on the affirmative action price preference made no mention of the other two price preference programs in New York City, and lawyers familiar with the decision said its impact was for now a matter of legal conjecture. Even if the ruling is not appealed, it is not known whether anyone will seize upon its language to challenge the other preferences.
The case before Judge Tolub was brought in a lawsuit by Seabury Construction Corporation, a Yonkers company that had been bypassed by the city in a $1.7 million bid to repair water treatment plants. The work was awarded to three joint ventures that bid slightly higher but had been certified as having sufficient minority ownership to receive a preference.
In his ruling the judge said that since it revised its charter in 1989, New York City was governed by a 1953 state law requiring it to accept the lowest responsible bids for municipal work. Before charter revision, the city's powerful Board of Estimate, now abolished, had been shielded from the state regulations and had been given almost complete authority to sit in judgment over contracts, regardless of who had the lowest bids.
In defending the affirmative action price preference, lawyers for the Corporation Counsel argued that in revising its charter, the city had retained enough legal discretion in awarding contracts to offer preferences intended to promote social advancement. The judge ruled that it had lost such discretion.

HEADLINE: In Fishkill, a New Team Steps Up to the Plate;
Minor-League Club Excites Baseball Fans in the Economically Ailing Hudson Valley

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FISHKILL, N.Y.

 BODY:
It may be buried under 16 inches of snow and studded with evergreen, pine and birch trees, but when Skip Weisman drives past the 20-acre field wedged between Route 9D and Interstate 84, he sees baseball.
"The lights are on and a game is going on," Mr. Weisman says, conjuring the daydream he has each night as he heads home from work. "The scoreboard's lit up. There's a packed house. There's green grass. There's brown dirt." 
 Mr. Weisman is not the only one with such visions these days. Ever since his minor-league baseball franchise, the Erie Sailors, announced in late November that it was leaving Pennsylvania for this Dutchess County town, the economically ailing Hudson Valley has found itself cheered by a refreshing case of baseball fever.
 
The Renegades
 When Mr. Weisman, the team's general manager and part owner, asked residents of the area to suggest a name for the franchise, more than 5,000 entries streamed in. Late Friday, the team announced that it would call itself the Hudson Valley Renegades.
Already, more than 400 individuals, families and businesses have bought season tickets to the team's 38 home games, at $225 a seat. The Class A team, affiliated with the Texas Rangers, is expected to open its 76-game season in mid-June in a 4,000-seat ball park now under construction. The season ends Sept. 3.
The appeal of the national pastime in one of its purest incarnations, free of million-dollar salaries and matching egos, has fueled much of the excitement. So has talk that the team could contribute upward of $1 million a year to the slumping local economy, what with the souvenir caps and T-shirts it would sell, and the services, like printing and hotel rooms, that it would purchase.
But this is also the heart of I.B.M. country, and people here say that baseball is just the ticket to lift their spirits after the computer manufacturer's retrenchment, which saw thousands of Hudson Valley residents lose their jobs last year at the company's three nearby factories.
"I don't know about anyone else, but I'm planning my summer vacation around the season," said Marsha Rozales Gordon, the president of the Greater Southern Dutchess Chamber of Commerce, which is raising private donations to pay for part of the $4.95 million stadium. "Someone invited me to a wedding on June 24 and my first thought was, 'I hope there's not a game that night.' "
Jaime Giannetta, a 28-year-old lawyer from Wappingers Falls, about 10 miles north of here, said she bought two season tickets, one for herself and the other to be shared with her father and assorted friends.
"I think the feeling is that we've got something else to do in the Hudson Valley, something that's ours," said Ms. Giannetta, who works for the Legal Aid Society in Putnam County. "I guess it's the way people in the Bronx feel, like they have the Yankees. It's such a morale boost."
Until Friday the hottest game in town -- other than wondering how the team will fare against such New York-Penn League opponents as the Pittsfield (Mass). Mets and the Burlington (Vt.) Expos -- had been guessing what the team would be called.
After scanning the reams of entries to the "Name the Team" contest, Mr. Weisman put all speculation to rest and announced that the team had settled on the name Renegades, bypassing three other top submissions: the Hudson Valley Vipers, the Hudson Valley Venom and the Hudson Valley Hawks. One idea that was rejected out of hand was the Jailbirds, an allusion to the nearby Fishkill Correctional Facility.
"The nickname Renegade conveys a strong sense of the unconventional," Mr. Weisman said in a statement, "the team that will hit and run or steal third when it is least expected, and take the opponent out of its own game plan."
He added, "It flows nicely with the geographic name of the Hudson Valley."
The woman who suggested the winning name, Yvette Cruz, 31, of Gardiner, N.Y., will receive two free box seats for the season and be the guest of honor on opening day, Mr. Weisman said.
The Renegades will join two other new teams in the New York region, the Trenton Thunder, an affiliate of the Detroit Tigers, and the New Haven Ravens, a farm club of the Colorado Rockies. Both will be in the AA Eastern League, a step up from the Hudson Valley team's league.
 
Financing Is Questioned
 The key to bringing the team to Fishkill, after the owners were unable to reach agreement with Erie officials on a lease for a proposed new stadium, was a 27-8 vote by the Dutchess County Board of Legislators last month to lend $2.5 million to the private company that will build the ball park here.
But that deal has not set well with everyone, particularly Woody Klose, a County Legislator who voted against it. Mr. Klose said he was concerned that the company formed to build the park, the Dutchess County Entertainment Corporation, planned to pay back much of the loan with private contributions and a grant of more than $2 million from the State Urban Development Corporation that it has not yet been awarded.
Mr. Klose said he doubted that the stadium builders would be able to reach their goal of collecting more than $1 million in donations from corporations and individuals to house a team three notches below the major leagues.
"It is one step above college ball," Mr. Klose said. "You're not going to see Dwight Gooden. You're not going to see Mickey Mantle. You're not going to see Joe DiMaggio."
Supporters of the team brand Mr. Klose a killjoy. They say they are eager to get a front-row glimpse of the baseball stars of tomorrow, some of whom may be in the major leagues within three years.
The Texas Rangers will determine the roster of team players about four days before opening day, Mr. Weisman said. The players, who will be paid $850 a month, will be drawn from other Ranger farm teams and from a draft of college players.
Local officials say they are confident that the team's spending, on everything from automobiles to apartments for players to hotel rooms for visiting umpires, will help the economy.
"I went to my local physical therapist and he asked me if they are interested in a team doctor," said Jack Dexter, 62, a one-time prospect of the Cleveland Indians who is president of the Dutchess County Old-Timers' Baseball Association, a hall of fame. "My local optometrist was saying that if a player strikes out 18 times in a row, maybe his eyes are bad and he can help out."
 
'Solid and Optimistic'
 But the team's most important contribution, its fans say, may be helping the Hudson Valley redefine itself as something more than I.B.M.'s backyard, particularly when the relationship between the computer giant and its neighbors has frayed.
"Nothing is more solid and optimistic than, what do they call it, the boys of summer," said Roger Akeley, the Dutchess County Commissioner of Planning and Development.
Captivated by that optimism, Matt Schlossberg, who runs a magazine distributorship in Poughkeepsie, was first in line to buy season tickets when sales began earlier this year. He bought four: for himself; his wife, Marcia; his 15-year-old son, Josh, and his 12-year-old daughter, Rachel.
"You've got your own team in the area now, something you can root for," he said. "Without getting corny about the whole thing, I just enjoy being around baseball."

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
With Fed Raising Rates, Bond Review Is in Order

BYLINE: By Francis Flaherty

 BODY:
WHEN the Fed announced that it was moving to raise short-term interest rates yesterday, the nervousness of already high-strung bond investors went up a notch. But even before the announcement, their duty was clear: ease out of long-term bonds, gratefully pocketing the run-ups of recent years.
On the details, of course, advisers differ. James B. Stack of Investech Research in Whitefish, Mont., sees short-term rates rising "up to 1.5 percent" by the end of the year; with 60 percent of his model portfolio already in cash, he urges others to make quick exits. "There's no rush," countered Mary Malgoire, a financial planner with Malgoire Drucker in Bethesda, Md. 
 Quickly or slowly, though, all these planners are walking to the same place: investments with shorter maturities and less volatility. Steve Janachowski, a financial adviser with Brouwer & Janachowski in San Francisco, likes bonds with maturities of 5 to 12 years. They yield 5 to 6 percent, compared with 6 to 6.5 percent for longer maturities, and have less risk from rising rates.
"If interest rates rise 1 percent, with a 20-year bond you could lose principal of 12 percent," he warned.
Among Mr. Janachowski's fund picks are Pimco Low Duration, yielding 5 percent, and Fidelity Intermediate Bond, yielding 5.1 percent. Ms. Malgoire favors three-year to five-year bonds as long-term substitutes, and for her money "Vanguard has the best bond funds around," she said. She also suggests phoning funds to determine current average maturities. "You can't pick that information up from a prospectus," she said.
Mr. Stack prefers cash. "If interest rates rise just 0.5 percent in the next six months, no bond fund -- short, intermediate or long -- will outperform money markets," he said.
Many investors, however, resist not only these specific strategies but also the general wisdom to go lighter on long bonds. Nearly 55 percent of all bond fund assets are still in long-term offerings, Mr. Janachowski said. And in December alone, those funds had a net increase of $2 billion.
Why this flight toward an increasingly perilous investment? "People are blindly buying yields," Mr. Janachowski said. This behavior, he and others say, stems from the traditional income orientation of bond investors, but also from the aging bond bull market. With most bond funds returning a total of 70 to 80 percent since 1989, people have just grown used to great gains.
But "what you learned to love, you now must learn to hate," Ms. Malgoire said. "And that's very hard." Even advisers who disagree on strategy agree on the power of this emotional attachment. "Bonds have done little else but go up for a decade," Mr. Stack said. "Investors forget, or don't want to remember, they can go the other way."
Still, knowing investors' income needs, advisers suggest some ways to tease bond portfolios for higher returns. John Rekenthaler of the Morningstar newsletters points to short-term global income funds, like the Scudder fund of that name, which turned in 6.74 percent in 1993. "Better than cash, right?" he asked.
But he emphasized the currency risks of foreign investing, and others noted that falling foreign yields might no longer justify those risks. Germany's three-month rates have fallen to 5.8 percent from 8.5 percent since last year, while Italy's have dropped to 8.5 percent from 12.9 percent. Also, as rates rise here, so will the dollar's value against other currencies -- bad news for Americans who invest overseas.
What about high-yield funds? They can juice up returns, advisers say, and as the economy gathers steam, their primary risk -- corporate default -- declines. The junk market is prone to panic, though, and to counter that tendency Mr. Rekenthaler suggests a very big fund, the $2 billion Vanguard Fixed-Income High-Yield Corporate, or a very conservative one, Nicholas Income. The latter is "a junk fund, but barely," he said; in 1990, it lost only 1 percent when the average high-yield fund dropped by 10.3 percent.
It is somewhat late in the day for junk funds, though advisers diverge on the exact time. "It may be 4 P.M. for these funds, but it's not 9 P.M.," Mr. Rekenthaler said. Mr. Stack's watch is faster. "The funds have done well for three years," he said, including an 18.89 percent return in 1993. "A lot of the gain has already been realized."
Truly adventurous bond investors may want to make a contrarian move -- into long bonds. They will be betting that the Fed's move will pre-empt inflation and bolster long-bond prices.
Most advisers, however, see these alternatives as risky and marginal. The main event is moving to shorter maturities, and for that "the cautious investor will just have to sit and take his hit," Mr. Rekenthaler said.
But, just as some investors find it hard to leave long bonds, others accept that prospect but insist on an alternative investment of equal profitability. Believing every problem has a solution, they search high and low for a long-bond replacement -- whatever the risk.
'People equate action with doing the right thing," said Harold Evensky, a planner in Coral Gables, Fla. Mr. Janachowski's take is only slightly different. "Everybody," he said, "wants to do something."

HEADLINE: Vietnam Welcomes U.S. Decision on Embargo;
Hanoi's Response Subdued

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Government officials welcomed President Clinton's lifting of the United States trade embargo on Vietnam in measured terms today.
But even though this capital, unlike Ho Chi Minh City in the south, has never known what it is like to have the United States as a trading partner, many ordinary Vietnamese here greeted the American action as a significant boost to the festive mood building up for Tet, the lunar new year holiday beginning on Thursday. 
 In a news conference punctuated by bursts of exploding Tet firecrackers in the surrounding streets, Deputy Foreign Minister Mai voiced the Government's satisfaction at the lifting of the ban. But Mr. Mai, one of the principal architects of Vietnamese-American reconciliation, took pains not to jubilate. Asked about his personal feelings about the end of the embargo, he replied: "I think that Vietnamese matters have created many emotional issues in the United States. We, the Vietnamese, are less emotional."
"I think the lifting of the trade embargo may bring about many new things, or maybe very few new things, or maybe nothing new," the Deputy Foreign Minister said, and he indicated Vietnam's irritation at Mr. Clinton's remark, in announcing the end of the ban, that his action was "reversible."
"No nation in the world," Mr. Mai said, "has the right to impose a trade embargo on another nation or to threaten to reimpose an embargo."
 
Pledged Cooperation
 But in comments obviously designed for concord with Mr. Clinton's emphasis -- that he lifted the embargo for the sake of advancing the search for evidence of the 2,238 Americans still officially listed as missing in action -- Mr. Mai pledged Vietnam's full cooperation.
"We will continue to cooperate fully with the United States under any political circumstances," he said. "The Vietnamese people have themselves suffered sorrow and grief and share the concern of American families whose loved ones are still listed as missing from the war."
In a conversation before the lifting of the embargo was announced, Mr. Mai said on Thursday that many Vietnamese held unrealistic hopes for quick economic changes once trade with America became possible.
 
Fear of Inflation
 Indeed, a staff member at the History Museum voiced caution today that the end of the embargo might bring such an inflationary economic boom that the low wages of civil servants might not keep up with a rise in prices. Most Government employees earn no more than $30 a month.
But she also saw the value of the broadening of Vietnam's relations to include the world's leading power. "It will protect us against invasion from the north," said the woman, a combat veteran of the war in South Vietnam. Her fear of China is widely shared throughout this nation.
Tu Giay, founder and former chief of the National Institute of Nutrition, a 73-year-old veteran of the war against France and a longtime Communist, was philosophically Buddhist in welcoming the end of the embargo.
"We come into the world only once," he said. "We don't know when we can come back, because we must die before we can return. Why spend this short life quarreling? So the event is a happy one -- but a little late."

HEADLINE: U.S. and France to Form Bosnia Working Group;
9 Killed Waiting for Food

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Mortar shells slammed into a line of people waiting for food today, killing 9 people, 3 of them children, and leaving at least 15 wounded.
Relief workers were measuring out portions of flour just before noon on a spring-like day that brought crowds out into the sun when the first round landed in Dobrinja, a neighborhood that has suffered particularly heavy damage during the 22-month Serbian siege of the city. 
 Moments later, as neighbors and soldiers rushed to help the wounded, two more shells landed in the small courtyard set among battered high-rises, catching some of those giving first aid.
 
Area Housed Olympic Athletes
 Much of Dobrinja was built to house the athletes of the 1984 Winter Olympics. The mountains looking down on it hosted the ski and bobsled events then; now they hold Serbian artillery. A makeshift cemetery holds the bodies of residents killed by the shelling and sniping in a neighborhood where a magnificent view has turned into a dangerous exposure.
Shelling and sniping have been increasing here in recent days, as they almost always do when the battling Bosnian, Serbian and Croatian leaders prepare to head to Geneva for another session of the seemingly endless peace negotiations. The next round of talks is scheduled to begin on Thursday.
The Croatian Government met in emergency session in Zagreb today to consider a warning from the United Nations Security Council to withdraw the regular army troops it has sent into Bosnia to bolster the militia of the Bosnian Croats.
The message sent by the Security Council on Thursday is the sternest warning to Croatia since fighting broke out between the Bosnian Croats and the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government last spring. United Nations officials estimate that from 3,000 to 5,000 regular Croatian Army troops have been across the border. Bosnian officials say the number is as high as 20,000.
The possibility that the Security Council could impose sanctions on Croatia is greatly feared by the Zagreb Government of President Franjo Tudjman, who has watched the ruin of the Serbian economy under economic sanctions imposed in May 1992.

HEADLINE: Opening to a New Vietnam

 BODY:
President Clinton did the right thing for the United States this week in ending the 19-year-old ban on Americans' doing business with Vietnam. For Mr. Clinton, it was an act of political courage. Had his predecessors been able to take a larger view of American interests, they would have lifted the embargo years ago.
Vietnam has been changing dramatically for nearly a decade. Most of the differences that drove Hanoi and Washington to war in the 1960's and 1970's and kept them at odds through the early 1980's have disappeared. 
 In fact, almost all have been resolved in America's favor. Vietnam's troops are out of Cambodia. Its markets are open to the world. And it has turned away from what remains of the Communist bloc to seek new links with the Association of South East Asian Nations, formed during the Vietnam War as an anti-Communist bloc.
Vietnam is still a one-party state with an appalling human rights record, but so are some of America's best friends and trading partners in Southeast Asia. What has kept Washington at arm's length from the new Vietnam is, of course, the legacy of an old war.
Only a small part of that legacy was substantive. While every single case of a soldier lost without remains or information is a family tragedy, the number of Americans still unaccounted for is unusually small given the scope and duration of American involvement.
The war's larger legacy has been political and psychological. The dead and the missing were not, as in past wars, redeemed by an American military victory. For many Americans this was humiliating; for some, even dishonorable. Refusing to acknowledge Hanoi meant refusing to certify Washington's defeat. As the years passed, and Vietnam found the trade and aid it needed elsewhere, making the embargo pointless, only a minority remained irreconcilable. But successive Republican Presidents indulged this minority, while successive Democrats feared provoking them.
It is thus remarkable that Bill Clinton, whose own opposition to the war and avoidance of the draft made him especially vulnerable to attack on this issue, became the President who finally recognized reality and acted in the national interest.
Hanoi made it easier for him with its vastly improved cooperation in recent years on searching for remains of missing Americans. So did American business leaders clamoring for a share of the growing economic action before European and Asian countries locked any more of it up for themselves. And Mr. Clinton has prudently held back on such steps as diplomatic recognition and special trade and aid agreements, holding them out as inducements for further Vietnamese cooperation and human rights progress.
But give this President the full credit he deserves, for at last ending America's self-imposed, self-punishing exile from the new Vietnam.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: HOME ENTERTAINMENT;
Awards Honor Leading Designs

BYLINE: By HANS FANTEL 

 BODY:
CHARLES IVES, America's crankiest composer, once scoffed, "Awards are merely the badges of mediocrity." Audio manufacturers think otherwise. To them, the Grands Prix for outstanding design in sound equipment represent a coveted distinction. Awarded each year by an independent jury convened under the auspices of Audio-Video International, a leading trade journal, these prizes are the audio equivalent of a Pulitzer.
The awards cover different classes of audio equipment, from minimal table-top models to semiprofessional sound gear. Here are some winners that combine musical merit with reasonable cost. 
 Among full-sized, floor-standing loudspeakers, awards went to the Definitive Technology BP-10 ($1,100 a pair), the Boston Acoustics T1030 ($1,000) and the KEF 103/4 ($1,800). The Definitive Technology design differs from the others by radiating sound both forward and backward to attain unusually spacious sound distribution. Various models differ in their tonal shadings, and each has a distinct sonic character. Yet all cover the entire audible range and handle even massive symphonic passages with generous ease.
Smaller bookshelf speakers also ranked among the winners, with the PSB Alpha, at $199 a pair, being the lowest-priced. This design was cited for its high efficiency, that is, the ability to generate ample sound even from relatively modest wattage. This attribute permits the speaker to be used with low-powered receivers, making it even more economical.
Other winners among bookshelf speakers included the Paradigm Titan ($200), the Advent Baby III ($229) and the Boston Acoustics AD9 ($340). Predictably, these small speakers lack the deep sonority and power of their larger counterparts. But their sound is well balanced and -- especially in music of a lighter texture -- thoroughly enjoyable.
Winning stereo receivers included Yamaha's RX-770 ($549), which was cited for its ability to exceed its nominal power rating of 85 watts per channel to accommodate brief loud moments. The jury also praised the tuner section, which allowed the receiver to separate closely neighboring FM stations on the dial.
Prizes were handed out even among bargain-basement receivers. Kenwood's KR-A5050 garnered laurels for delivering a hefty 100 watts per channel at a modest $229.
Among CD players, honors went to Sony's CDP-X303ES ($730) for its distinctive circuit used for deciphering the digital signal and an elaborate memory device that remembers the listener's preferred selections on as many as 184 CD's.
Other winners in this group -- Rotel's RCD965LE and Denon's DCD-1290, both priced at $550 -- achieve outstanding performance by contrasting means. Rotel converts the digital data to a musical signal by means of the newly popular single-bit decoding method, while Denon relies on a 20-bit decoder.
All three CD players are single-play models. The jury noted that many listeners find single-play designs easier to use than CD changers. Even so, awards were given to CD changers holding several disks, including the Denon DCM-550 ($500), the Onkyo DX-M505 ($430) and the Sony CDP-C601ES ($420).
Listeners in search of a high-quality cassette deck can also pick among Grand Prix winners. The most elaborate is Harman-Kardon's TD4800 ($1,199), which is a virtual compendium of clever refinements. Additional winners among tape decks included Sony's TCK909ES ($750) and Nakamichi's DR-1 ($879). All are three-head designs that allow the tape to be monitored while recording, so faulty adjustments can be rectified instantly.
All the winners mentioned here were victors in a tight race. Given the competitiveness of the audio business, judges must spot small distinctions among strong contestants in a close and crowded field. The prizes go to entries leading the pack by a nose.

HEADLINE: RADIO;
A Radio Talk Show That Doesn't Run on Vitriol

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Ray Suarez, THE NEWEST, least likely and perhaps fastest-rising figure in talk radio, says his show is not aimed at an elite audience. It is a little tough at first to manage a straight face at this.
Mr. Suarez, after all, works in the nation's most pointy-headed city, in a studio six blocks from the White House. He sports a beard and a rumpled sweater. He likes to muse about stuff like the "enormous consequences" of the global rise of the money-commodity economy. 
 If this were not enough, his two-hour program, "Talk of the Nation," is on National Public Radio, the goose-liver pate network in an otherwise braunschweiger medium. But he is insistent. "We're anti-elitist," he said. "If anybody wants to listen to smart conversation with regular people, they'll see."
And in fact, a few hours' exposure to Mr. Suarez's slightly nasal, eminently reasonable moderation of "Talk of the Nation" is persuasive. Rush Limbaugh runs a boxing match of a program, and Howard Stern operates a peep show. Mr. Suarez, on the other hand, conducts a very democratic cocktail party. He sets out one or two eclectic issues, sort of like plates of strange-looking canapes, then spends the rest of the broadcast stoking the conversation, as if filling glasses and hauling out crackers.
When it works, everyone gets a little buzz, and nobody leaves hungry. Among recent shows, Mr. Suarez has opened phone lines to an astronaut aboard the space shuttle Columbia, spent an hour talking with callers about the legacy of the Trappist monk Thomas Merton and asked listeners -- in an especially curious year-end program -- to transport themselves to the year 2000 and phone in their lists of top stories of the 1990's.
"It's a much better approach to issues than a host who's trying to shove his opinion or an idea down someone's throat," said Ross Reynolds, the program director at the Seattle public-radio station KUOW-FM. "Ray really provides a safe place for listeners who aren't sure how they feel about a subject to try out their ideas."
Indeed, Mr. Suarez's genially Socratic manner and the bizarre menu of topics are main ingredients of the show's success since he became the host in April. In Seattle, ratings show the number of listeners has grown by about 25 percent in the last six months, a trend NPR officials say is being repeated most places the program is heard.
"Talk of the Nation" claims more than a million listeners, enough to give NPR something it has always lacked: a strong midday program between its two news hits, "Morning Edition" and "All Things Considered." Both those shows attract more than 6 million listeners a day, but both claim drive-time slots with captive audiences of commuters. And both are carried virtually nationwide, while "Talk of the Nation" is confined to about 80 of the network's 489 affiliates.
The success is all the more unusual because "Talk," while run by the network's news division, is a departure from its taped, slickly produced and not-very-abashedly highbrow companions. "NPR looked at live radio as something for the unwashed," said one veteran of the network who refused to be named. "Ray has really fought an uphill battle to make the show work, and he's established a real beachhead." (On Fridays, when the program is devoted to science issues, its host is Ira Flatow, NPR's science specialist.)
Mr. Suarez's special talent is to make listeners interested in topics that normally would send them charging for the "off" button. He does it by introducing the topics with brief essays, often lyrical and sometimes quite personal, that frame the discussion in ways that directly engage people.
Thus for a show on Burundi, he said, it was a matter of pointing out that Africa has 50 nations, many in the direst of straits, but that national sympathy tends to flow to a select few like Somalia. So the issue, he said, becomes: "We've got a United Nations that is stretched thin. We've got a plate so full that we can't do everything. What do we do?"
And a panel of theologians talking about Merton was pitched not as a religion lecture, but a dialogue about whether monastic ideals are achievable in an era when even the Pope and Mother Teresa are celebrities. A blurb at the end of that program offering a list of supplementary readings drew a response from listeners "in the four digits," a senior producer, Marcus Rosenbaum, said. "It blew our minds."
Mr. Suarez says he is pleased but not surprised by such responses. "I think if you pitch it right, you can have a show on almost any subject," he said.
At 36, Mr. Suarez is universally described as a very smart fellow with a quick wit and a voracious appetite for facts. Less apparent -- and all but smothered in his appeal-to-all radio persona -- is a hardened journalist with a surplus of self-confidence and a history of walking out over issues of principle, or ego, or both.
RAY SUAREZ GREW UP IN THE Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bensonhurst neighborhoods of Brooklyn, one of three sons in a family headed by a Navy man. Upon entering New York University in 1974, he went straight to the campus radio station.
Mr. Suarez rose to become news director, then took the first of several drastic career steps: denied the post of general manager, he quit -- "in a petulant teen-age fit," he said -- and moved to the campus newspaper.
Of course, it proved a wise move. Mr. Suarez became editor and gained an appreciation for good writing. After college, he bounced around New York, writing for trade publications like Paper Trade Journal (slogan: "The Newsmagazine of the North American Pulp and Paper Industry") until he decided he was adrift. So he moved to London with his soon-to-be wife, jobless but ready to freelance.
That was a wise move, too. "Eventually I was turning down work," he said. London led to Rome, where Mr. Suarez wandered into St. Peter's Square in 1981, moments after an intended assassin had shot Pope John Paul II. His coverage won him a radio-news job with CBS, which in turn led him to ABC.
But after a spell in what seemed make-work posts, Mr. Suarez heard that ABC was being sued for discrimination, and he concluded that his job was tied more to his Hispanic surname than to his ability. So he moved again, to Los Angeles and the infant Cable News Network. From there he joined Chicago's NBC affiliate, WMAQ-TV.
And there he seemed to thrive, earning a six-figure salary for five years. But after winning a journalists' fellowship at the University of Chicago, he began to chafe.
John D. Callaway, who headed the fellowship program, called him the most outstanding scholar in its history. "He brought the eye of an investigative reporter to history, and the soul of a poet to his writing," he said. "Anybody who's been around Ray for eight minutes knows he's ambitious. But for Ray to be in commercial TV today, particularly at the local level, where you're scrambling for audience in ways less than noble, is a contradiction in terms."
When he quit WMAQ last spring, Mr. Suarez infuriated his bosses with a public blast at local television news and its thirst for mayhem. Next stop: Washington and "Talk of the Nation."
By all accounts, he found a troubled operation. Soon after the program started in 1991, its first host and its inspiration, John Hockenberry, left for ABC News and the broadcast lacked direction for months. Mr. Suarez spent his first months learning talk-show tricks and scrapping for a place in NPR's tightly closed hierarchy.
After nine months on the air, he seems to have found it: as a literate, low-cal alternative to a network diet of BBC reports and insistent analyses of Federal bureaucracies.
"Ray's a valuable addition to the rarefied, tweedy image NPR has," said Rick Kogan, a former media critic at the Chicago Tribune. "He's not unfamiliar with the back alleys. He's a reporter. He's not a mannequin."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ray Suarez, host of NPR's "Talk of the Nation" -- "If you pitch it right, you can have a show on almost any subject." (Vincent Ricardel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Signs Signal Both Profit and Controversy

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
THE best-known 7,200 square feet along the East River in Hunters Point, Queens, have been under reconstruction recently in a factory on 12th Avenue in Manhattan, not far from the Hudson River.
What is being rebuilt is a 60- by 120-foot Pepsi-Cola sign, the unofficial landmark of Hunters Point, which dates to 1936. It rises over a Pepsi bottling plant immediately north of the site on which construction of the enormous Queens West project is to begin this year. 
 (With work still in progress, the sign read "epsi- ola" last week -- or "alo- ispe" from Queens.)
Rosina K. Abramson, president of the Queens West Development Corporation, sees the restoration of the sign as a helpful herald. "We're pleased if property owners are sprucing up," she said. "We think that the more positive attention is called to the site, the better it is for present users and future projects."
Big signs are not only big business, they are intimately tied to real estate in New York City.
They are, for example, a point of contention between state officials and the private developers of the 42d Street rehabilitation project. They generate profits -- or headaches -- for other owners around Times Square, where spectacular signs are required by law. For some buildings, they are the most important tenants.
In the form of advertising kiosks, illuminated signs are about to transform the streetscapes, a matter of concern to both the Real Estate Board of New York and the Municipal Art Society. And, like so many other properties, big signs have even been considered for landmark status.
That was in 1988, when the Pepsi sign came before the Landmarks Preservation Commission. The matter was never voted on, however, because there was not enough interest among commission members, said David F. M. Todd, a former chairman.
IN the years since, the sign has not fared well, having been buffeted by a nor'easter in December 1992. Looking tattered in daylight and scraggly at night, it reached the end of its life last year. The 50-foot-high Pepsi bottle, 44-foot-high "P" and "C" and the smaller letters were removed.
They have been replicated in the 12th Avenue factory of the Artkraft Strauss Sign Corporation, whose predecessor, Artkraft Signs, is said to have built the original.
Pepsi's property adjoins what is called the Gateway neighborhood, the first phase of the Queens West project. Although the Pepsi site is eventually to become a residential neighborhood as well, and although Pepsi is exploring the relocation of its bottling operation elsewhere in New York City, a spokeswoman said there was "no question that we would have renovated" the sign.
"It's a symbol of our trademark and our commitment to New York City," said the spokeswoman, Christine M. Jones. "It's only natural for us to want it in perfect working order." She would not discuss the cost.
Instead of sporting the streamlined blue, modern letters, the sign retains the ruby-red letter forms of the 1930's -- with swash letters, curlicues and Gothic spikes, outlined by a 15-millimeter strand of neon.
"To change that sign would mean losing a little bit of the texture of New York," Ms. Jones said. "It would be like modernizing the lions at the Public Library or putting a digital clock on top of Grand Central or covering Central Park with Astroturf."
Clearly, signs are a serious matter.
In fact, it is a key issue between the 42d Street Development Project Inc., a New York State Urban Development Corporation subsidiary, and Times Square Center Associates, the developers of the 42d Street crossroads. This is a joint venture of the Prudential Insurance Company of America and Park Tower Realty, headed by George Klein.
Independent of the Times Square Center project, it was announced last Wednesday that the Walt Disney Company would rehabilitate the landmark New Amsterdam Theater on 42d Street and reopen it in 1996.
Construction of the four Times Square Center office towers has been postponed until the real estate market improves. Meanwhile, existing buildings are to be rehabilitated as stores, restaurants and tourist attractions, following guidelines drawn up for the state by Robert A. M. Stern Architects and the design concern of M & Company.
Among the key underpinnings of the guidelines is that 42d Street's "unique tradition of bold signage and lighting displays" must be "retained and enhanced with ever-evolving signage adding to the daily drama."
"We want to make sure that 42d Street remains an entertainment street," said Vincent Tese, the chairman, president and chief executive of the Urban Development Corporation. "We want signage. We think signage is important. And there will be signage."
WITH enough signs, pedestrians would be drawn to the street, adding traffic for the retail and entertainment tenants. "They're interesting and people want to see them," said Paul Whalen, a partner in Mr. Stern's office. "Just by the fact that there is a critical mass of signs, the value of the properties where they are put goes up."
But the developers are wary. "What we're being asked to do is have signs that are different than existed there before and might not make commercial sense today," said Brian P. Murphy, senior vice president of the Prudential Realty Group.
"During the interim period we will maintain signs that are equivalent to what was there in 1992," he said. "That's the understanding we have. We agree to do that as a minimum." That includes maintaining such "spectaculars" as the green, white and red Fuji sign at Broadway and 43d Street.
Noting that Times Square Center Associates had "invested close to $300 million to purchase these sites for the purpose of building office buildings" and that any other use was temporary, Mr. Murphy said, "We cannot have the tail wag the dog."
"It is absolutely essential," he said, "that we have the ability at any time to take over a complete site when a tenant steps forward, even if it's within a month. The advertisers who would want 'spectacular signs' might require a minimum period of three to five years, or longer, to establish their 'sign presence' and recover the cost of those signs."
(It would cost about $1.5 million to build Fuji's 4,500-square-foot neon spectacular, said Jason Perline, the chairman of Van Wagner Communications.)
Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Development Project, said: "We are looking for signs that show cleverness and imagination. They don't have to be $5 million spectaculars to be memorable."
Mr. Tese said state officials were beginning to feel apprehensive about the "long delays" with which any suggestions were met by Times Square Center Associates, as well as the developers' "inability to really start advancing the ball."
"T.S.C.A. is tall on buildings and short on signage," Mr. Tese said. "We're going to come up with more suggestions but T.S.C.A. knows this is a priority with us, and they've got to start getting real."
Sign requirements have been part of the Times Square landscape since 1987, affecting new buildings on Broadway and Seventh Avenue, from 43d to 50th Street.
These regulations call for at least one illuminated sign for every ground-floor establishment, larger signs along the "street wall" (the part of the facade that rises straight up from the sidewalk, before a setback) and "super signs," up to 12,000 square feet in size, as high as 120 feet above the curb.
"THE way the old signs were laid out was chaos," said Jonathan Starr, chief operating officer of Artkraft Strauss. "Now, what's happening is that chaos has become part of the content that's being administered."
"That is the only case in history that any municipality mandated that you can't build a building unless there are signs on it," Mr. Perline said. "Of course, these buildings, for the most part, didn't want signs."
The only developer who openly embraced the requirements was Jeffrey Katz of Sherwood Equities, builder of the trapezoidal tower at 47th Street, Broadway and Seventh Avenue. It houses the Ramada Renaissance Times Square Hotel. Even more notably, its southern prow has a 310-foot sign tower, stacked with spectaculars: Coca-Cola, Suntory whisky, Samsung electronics.
"Economically speaking, the signs are a benefit to us," Mr. Katz said. "Our benefit derives from the uniqueness of our location, at the head the square, together with the design that John Schiff came forward with."
"But they are not a benefit to any other building; they're a burden," Mr. Katz said. "They're a net plus to the city but they're not a plus for each individual project."
The Katz project represented something of a departure from the way landlords typically dealt with outdoor advertisers.
"It used to be that we would lease space, pay the landlord a net sum, and everything after that, we pocketed," Mr. Perline said. "Because of the huge cost and value of the new buildings, the owners looked at the signage as a profit center -- although, in context, a small profit center. But they said: 'Hey, it's not a nuisance. There's a profit to be made.' It became, frankly, more difficult for us to do a standard deal."
Instead, Van Wagner acted as agent for Mr. Katz, working for a percentage. In the case of 1540 Broadway, at 45th Street, Van Wagner entered into a joint venture with the developer, Ian Bruce Eichner, which continues with the new owner, Bertelsmann Inc., the media conglomerate. Even before Bertelsmann moved in, there were two giant signs on the building. Two more have been added, with two to come. In purchasing 1540 Broadway, Bertelsmann "liked the signage that was all around here because it's lively and goes well with the entertainment industry we operate in," said Christian Alpers, senior vice president.
"I would not say the signage on our building had a major role," he said. "It did not make or break the deal."
Two buildings of contemporary vintage from which signs are conspicuously absent are 1585 Broadway, between 47th and 48th Streets, and 750 Seventh Avenue, at 49th Street. That is because the requirements are not triggered until an owner applies for a temporary certificate of occupancy for more than half the building. Neither 1585 Broadway nor 750 Seventh Avenue, which were developed by Solomon Equities, have ever reached that level of occupancy.
"Signage has been a marketing obstacle to many new buildings," said William G. Cohen of Newmark Real Estate Services, leasing agents for the consortium of banks that now owns 750 Seventh Avenue. "People don't want the responsibility for it. They don't know what to do with it."
However, Mr. Cohen said, there was "great interest in the tenant community" in the possibilities afforded by illuminated displays along 49th Street and the Broadway side of the black, ziggurat-like tower.
A block away, the silvery 1585 Broadway skyscraper was purchased last August by the Morgan Stanley Group and will be filling up in the next year and a half. "We haven't made any decisions about the new signage," a spokeswoman for Morgan Stanley said.
Warren Wechsler, first senior vice president of the Real Estate Board, asked: "What does an investment banking house do with signage like that? It's got to define a use that's consonant with the tone it wants to strike in the marketplace."
Mr. Katz ventured an answer. "I think what they'll end up doing is something compatible with their image," he said. "That may not be commercial, but decorative."
But signs will be part of the bargain.
"Our position is that there is nothing discretionary in this," said Geoffrey W. Baker, deputy chief urban designer in the City Planning Department. "They are required to comply with the regulations."
"People understand that they can make money off these things and contribute to the quality of the area," Mr. Baker said. "I think you're going to see some signs on buildings that don't have to meet these requirements."
In fact, a neon spectacular for Hertz has recently been added to the north tower of the Marriott Marquis Hotel, at Broadway and 46th Street, next to the vast Kodak display. More signs may be coming to the hotel, which leases the sign space to Spectacolor Inc.
HAVING been built before the sign requirements took effect, the hotel is not compelled to install them. However, George N. Stonbely, the president of Spectacolor, said: "They do feel strongly that the building is part of the area and that signs are part of Times Square. They also enjoy significant revenues."
"We looked for clients that would be in sympathy with the business of the hotel: travelers, tourists, conventioneers," he said.
Spectacolor is also exploring ways to restore the illuminated 20-foot glass globe and four-sided tower clock atop the landmark Paramount Building, on Broadway, between 43d and 44th Streets. The clock was installed in 1926 and has not worked in many years.
A sponsor is being sought who would "want to be identified with the maintenance, relighting and operation," Mr. Stonbely said.
"If there were a discreet identification on the face of the clock," he added, "as you would see on a watch face, that might suffice."
Jeffrey R. Gural, president of Newmark & Company Real Estate, the managing and rental agent at the Paramount Building, said a restored clock and globe would be a "big benefit," attracting attention as the lighting does at the Empire State Building.
There are buildings where signs are more than icing on the cake; they are pretty much the cake itself. That is the case at One Times Square Plaza, at 42d Street, where the Sony Jumbotron screen and Minolta and Pepsi spectaculars are installed. The building filed for bankruptcy protection in 1992.
"The signs are the economic rationale for the building, at this point," said Mr. Stonbely, whose office is in the tower.
Mr. Perline, of Van Wagner, echoed the sentiment. "Signage is the best potential for income on that building," he said.
None of the big sign operators -- Van Wagner, Artkraft Strauss and Spectacolor -- would discuss the specific terms of their leases. However, Mr. Starr, of Artkraft Strauss, said rents can reach $100,000 a year.
"The value is determined by visibility, as well as size," said his sister, Tama Starr, who is the president and chief executive of the company. "When they are lower to the ground, they are worth more than if you have to crane your neck."
It is precisely at a lower level of altitude that New Yorkers will be seeing the next generation of illuminated advertising, in the form of cylindrical advertising kiosks that are meant to finance new public toilets.
The toilets would be built, maintained and operated by a private company, which would finance them by charging admission and by erecting two kiosks for every toilet it provided. The kiosks could rise 20 feet, as high as a two-story building, and would not have to be near the toilets.
Two-thirds of the display space could be used for paid advertising, in illuminated panels. One-third of the space would be set aside for public services: telephones, newspaper vending machines, maps, recycling bins or interactive video terminals, for example.
The City Planning Commission approved the proposal last month and sent it to the City Council, whose zoning and franchises subcommittee will consider it tomorrow. With approval from the Council, the Transportation Department could issue a request for companies to install the toilets and kiosks. The first phase calls for 40 toilets and 80 kiosks, with a final total of 800 structures.
PERHAPS the likeliest contractor is JCDecaux, a French company that says it supplies and maintains 4,000 toilets in 550 cities. Edward C. Wallace, a lawyer for JCDecaux USA, said that to meet the $39,000 annual cost of operating each toilet the company would need at least three kiosks for every toilet it provided.
Concern about the kiosks has been expressed by the Real Estate Board and the Municipal Art Society, who are not usually on the same side of the fence.
"First of all, there's the matter of traffic flow," said Mr. Wechsler, of the Real Estate Board. "You've got a huge office building, valued in the many millions of dollars. How will the arrival of one of these amenities affect people's access to the entrance, the ease with which they can move in and out?"
And what, Mr. Wechsler wondered, would be the impact of kiosks "whose presence, if not inimical, might pose a marketing problem" -- such as a Benetton billboard in front of a building whose principal retail tenant was a Gap clothing store.
A lawyer for the Municipal Art Society, Douglas N. Cogen, said, "We want public toilets, but you've got to ask at what price."
"If the move is to constantly create these new vehicles for advertising," he said, "eventually you reach the saturation point where nobody sees any of it. In the end, you lose the sense that there's some public commons that's not paid for by Absolut or Gap."
Brenda Levin, one of the planning commission members who voted for the proposal, did so with this guidance: "The shortest, the smallest, the fewest -- the best."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Fairfield in the Van of Commercial-Market Recovery

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
IN just five years, Fairfield County's commercial real estate market took one of the worst tumbles in the New York metropolitan region -- from a 17.5 percent vacancy rate in 1987 to 25.4 percent in 1992.
But today it is in the forefront of Connecticut's recovery, with space being consumed at an accelerating rate. 
 The Stamford-Greenwich vacancy rate is down to 21 percent from the 25 percent that persisted from 1991 through mid-1993. But most real-estate brokers believe that, given the overbuilt supply of offices and widespread corporate retrenchment, there will be no single-digit vacancies until late 1995.
"The northern and eastern parts of the state still suffer from defense industry cutbacks," said Owen J. Brown, manager of Cushman & Wakefield commercial realtors in Stamford. "Stamford and Greenwich will be fine, Hartford and New Haven too, eventually."
But he said he believed that Danbury and Waterbury would be hampered by their distances from I-95 and that Bridgeport had "a long way to go" to overcome its economic and image problems.
Fairfield County continues to benefit from proximity to New York.
"In 1992, 48 companies moved in, leasing 662,000 square feet," said Joseph Ercolano, vice president of the Stamford Area Commerce and Industry Association. "In 1993, 31 firms took 820,000 square feet, continuing a trend toward larger leases, from an average 6,700 square feet in 1990 to 14,800 in 1993."
Major reductions in the county vacancy rate for 1993 are attributable to the leasing by Witco Corporation, the chemical company, of 258,000 square feet in Greenwich and Dun & Bradstreet's taking 94,000 in Westport.
Office rents are firming up and concessions are dwindling, according to John H. Rostenberg of Rostenberg-Doern Company in Stamford. His company is marketing 10 Stamford Forum, one of the last major downtown buildings for sale.
Built in 1979 by the F. D. Rich Company, the 244,000-square-foot, half-vacant building was taken over by Prudential six months ago. "The asking price is $16.5 million," said Mr. Rostenberg.
Carl Traub, vice president of Cushman & Wakefield's Hartford/New Haven region, articulated a view held by many realtors that "older buildings are having a problem." With prices down, first-class space is being snapped up, he said, leaving older buildings in the dust.
"The market is looking for well-located, well-managed, up-to-code space," he said. "New Haven has been stagnant. Nobody has been coming in and I.B.M. moved out."
WILLIAM KANE of Edward F. Heberger & Associates, a New England appraisal firm, said that apartments and shopping centers in suburban areas were moving well.
"The concept of power centers," he added, "or clusters of category-leader stores, is growing."
He cited Universal Drive in North Haven, with a Home Depot, Price Club, Sports Authority, Office Max and Coconuts Video; another on Federal Road in Danbury, with The Wiz, Staples and Linens 'n' Things; and Route 1 in Norwalk, with ShopRite and Barnes & Noble Superstores.
There have been complaints by some real estate professionals that many lenders are reluctant to deal with commercial projects.
But Ellen Davis, first vice president of the commercial mortgage department of People's Bank, with headquarters in Bridgeport, said:
"It is not true that there is no money for business loans in Connecticut. We closed on $58 million in construction loans in 1993, covering single-family homes, apartments, shopping centers and nursing homes in Hartford, New Haven, Bridgeport, Stamford and northwest Connecticut. We have financed sales and purchases of our own foreclosed properties and acquisitions of buildings. Our portfolio for the year grew from $100 million to $710 million."
"Typically," said Brian Dreyer, senior vice president of commercial lending for People's, "we negotiate one-, three- and five-year fixed-rate mortgage loans at rates based on credit quality, guarantors' strength, and market data. The most growth has been among small businesses with sales below $5 million."
People's does not lend for office buildings larger than 25,000 square feet "because we are not into speculative purchases where large vacancy rates prevail," Ms. Davis said. Among the ventures financed in 1993 were subdivisions for first-time home buyers in Shelton, Trumbull and Milford and retail centers in the Hartford region.
Commercial space users in downtown Hartford continue to move out to the suburbs.
"Farmington, West Hartford, Simsbury and Avon have good highway access, a strong retail base, and a lot of executives already live there," said Michael Puzzo, market analyst for the Farley Company, a Hartford real estate firm. "Downsizing of the insurance companies has put a damper on progress and without new jobs the downtown office market is not going to fill up again."
BUT on a brighter note the landmark Constitution Plaza, a complex of 640,000 square feet owned by GE Capital Corporation, has found a partner, Simons & Steinberg Interests of West Hartford, to update the 30-year-old complex. And plans are afoot to replace obsolete manufacturing plants in scattered industrial areas with 500,000 square feet of warehousing and distribution space..
Danbury Corporate Center, formerly headquarters of the Union Carbide Corporation, has 450,000 square feet to rent at a negotiable $21 a foot, constituting a large chunk of the city's 600,000 square feet of vacancies. Union Carbide and its subsidiaries occupy the rest of the 1.2 million square-foot complex, along with such concessions as several dining rooms, a health center, hair salon, newsstand, dry cleaner and gift shop.
Downtown Danbury is expecting a boost from the construction of a new Metro-North railroad station this year and a new performing arts and sports center, planned as a joint venture between the city and Western Connecticut State University.
"A retail anchor or two are needed downtown" to counter the draw of the Danbury Fair Mall, said Abel Carvalho, president of the Connecticut Association of Realtors' commercial division. Downtown rents range from $10 to $19 a square foot.
In New London, the Foxwoods Casino provided jobs but has not affected the real estate market, said Bruce Hyde, director of the city's development and planning department. Tourism, focusing on New London's seafaring history, the Groton submarine base and Coast Guard Academy, the gambling casino and Mystic's Seaport and Marinelife Aquarium, is perceived as the region's future.
New London's downtown retail district has been hurt by the Crystal Mall in Waterford, and offices "are renting up slowly, around $12.50 a square foot," said William Newman, a partner at Connecticut Commercial Realty.
Manufacturing and warehousing, laggards for decades in Connecticut's economy, are being revived even in Fairfield County, aided by aggressive state programs that offer tax abatements, credits and grants to incoming and existing businesses.
"Connecticut can take credit for doing an exceptional job in that regard," said Mr. Rostenberg.
