HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Subleases;
The Manhattan Sublet Market Offers Surprises

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
CLEARLY, NationsBank had to move when its lease expired. It loved being in the General Motors Building, on Fifth Avenue and 59th Street. But it was bursting out of its 10,000 square feet, and the space's asbestos problems made repairs too costly.
The bank got the best of all worlds. On Memorial Day, it moved into 13,000 square feet it had sublet for five years from Bank Austria, another tenant in the building. And last month it sublet 6,000 additional feet from the rival bank, this time for eight years, and plans to move in on March 15. 
 "I'm paying half of what I was paying on the old lease and we only have to do minor renovations," said Thomas E. McCaskill, a NationsBank senior vice president.
Logic would dictate that with rents starting to rise, the sublet market would be falling apart, as tenants rush to lock in tomorrow's space at today's prices. But reality is defying logic. According to RELocate, which tracks building vacancies, there were 12.9 million square feet of sublet space available in Manhattan at the end of 1991; two years later there were just 8.3 million.
The absorption is throughout the city. Cushman & Wakefield says more than 1.4 million square feet of sublet space was rented last year in the Plaza District, which the brokerage firm broadly defines as 47th Street to 65th Street, east of Seventh Avenue.
Less elegant areas are heating up, too. According to Williams Real Estate, sublet availabilities in the southern, less expensive, part of midtown dropped by almost 9.6 percent last year, to 1.19 million square feet.
Apparently, many tenants are following a bird-in-hand philosophy, rushing for short-term bargains now, even if it means risking sky-high rents when the subleases run out.
"Direct rents may be tightening, but sublessors are still willing to mark down space to get rid of it," said Michael C. Dailey, a Cushman & Wakefield executive director who negotiated for NationsBank.
The savings can be huge.
"If a 50,000-foot tenant saves $10 a foot on a sublease, that's $2.5 million over five years," said Barry Gosin, Newmark Realty's president. "That's worth rolling the dice on what you'll be doing five years from now."
In fact, some tenants use sublets to hedge their own bets. Michael T. Cohen, Williams Real Estate's president, is looking for a short-term sublet for a law firm that is opening its first New York office.
"If they can't get a foothold here, they don't want to be stuck with a lease," he said.
Others are subletting in buildings they otherwise cannot afford. Robert C. Martin, a senior managing director at Grubb & Ellis New York, helped C & A Insurance sublet about 43,000 square feet of Marine Midland Bank's space at 2 World Trade Center.
"They wanted to move to the center, but a direct deal was just too expensive for them," Mr. Martin said.
And still others want move-in-ready space. A publishing company has asked Joseph G. Genovesi, managing director of D. G. Hart Associates, to find it a 22,000-square-foot sublet equipped with furniture and phones.
"They just don't want to deal with architects, pick out furniture, go through all the time and expense involved when you lease direct," Mr. Genovesi said.
Actually, not all sublet deals are for as-is space. Sometimes a primary tenant will offer a wonderfully rich deal if it can get rid of all its space in one swoop, rather than carve it up for six or seven small tenants.
"You find a primary tenant with a big problem at the right time and you can really capitalize on it," said Jeffrey Lichtenberg, a partner in the Peter R. Friedman brokerage firm . Mr. Lichtenberg recently helped the Battle Fowler law firm sublet 105,000 square feet from the International Business Machines Corporation at 65 East 55th Street. He would not talk numbers, but others say the law firm is paying $25 a foot -- about half of I.B.M.'s rent -- and got 14 months of free rent and $50 a foot toward customizing the space.
I.B.M.'s lease still had seven and a half years left. For shorter leases, many primary tenants are asking their landlords to assure sublet tenants that they will not have to move out a few years after they move in.
When Chemical Bank wanted to sublease space at 600 Fifth Avenue, at 48th Street, its sublessee, the investment company Reich & Tang, balked at moving for just the six years left on the lease. So Rockefeller Center Management, the building's owner, agreed to give the new sublessee first rights of refusal on the space when the lease expired -- provided they would pay market rates at the time.
"We would have been less likely to agree to a future rent at numbers that reflected 1994 market values," said Alan L. Stein, Rockefeller Center's vice president of marketing.
AND when the Reid & Priest law firm needed to get rid of 50,000 square feet of sublet space at 520 Madison Avenue, near 54th Street, Tishman Speyer, its landlord, wrote a new 10-year lease for the subtenant, Kroll & Tract, another law firm.
"They agreed because they didn't have to pay anything to renovate the space," said Peter Riguardi of Koeppel Tener Riguardi, who represented Kroll & Tract.
More important, there was only a year left on the lease, said Geoffrey P. Wharton, Tishman Speyer's managing director. He makes no promises about how he will handle some longer-term sublet space that he expects will soon be available in the building.
"If they can find a high-quality tenant and make the economics work, we'll try to cooperate, but frankly, I'm skeptical that they will strike a deal that would meet our financial objectives," he said.
Sometimes landlords capitalize on a sublessor's rising panic and sublet the space back to themselves. A tenant that moved out of 60 Madison Avenue, near 27th Street, was on the hook for 14,000 square feet, at $30 a foot, for another three years. The landlord sublet the space from the tenant for less than $10, and rented it to another tenant, on a longer lease, for a rent in the high teens.
"The tenant couldn't have found a sublet for just three years, so he was happy to do it," said Mr. Gosin, who represented the landlord. "And the landlord got to pocket the differential on the rent."
Other times, landlords and sublessors jointly market their vacant spaces on the idea that, with large blocks of contiguous space getting scarce in midtown, the whole is worth more than its parts.
Deutschebank, for one, has asked Robert J. Alexander, a senior managing director at Edward S. Gordon Company, to find a sublessee for two floors at 1290 Avenue of the Americas, near 52d Street. Mr. Alexander and Olympia & York, the building's owner, are working out a deal under which O & Y would extend the Deutschebank lease, which has almost 10 years left, and let Mr. Alexander market it in conjunction with three other floors that may become vacant in the building next year.
"We have more flexibility if we can offer more space," Mr. Alexander said.
WHEN landlords will not cooperate sublet space must go at fire-sale prices. In a rising market, the value of empty space that can be leased directly from a landlord grows. But a sublease decreases in value with every passing day.
Most brokers say a sublease for less than eight years is a hard sell, and one for less than five years is nearly unmarketable. As the clock ticks, the deals get richer.
A couple of years ago, Chubb Insurance sublet space from Salomon Brothers at 1221 Avenue of the Americas, at 49th Street, when there was nearly 10 years left on the lease. A few weeks ago it sublet some more of Salomon's space, at a lower rent.
"Now there's just eight years left to go on the lease," explained Josh N. Kuriloff, a Cushman & Wakefield director who represented Chubb.
For almost two years Bertelsmann tried to find subtenants for 250,000 square feet at 666 Fifth Avenue, near 52d Street. Its lease expires in 2000 and the company, which has moved into its own building, 1540 Broadway at 45th Street, is getting desperate.
Recently it slashed the rent it was asking, and leased 150,000 feet. Mr. Lichtenberg, Bertelsmann's broker, says he is pretty close to getting rid of 75,000 square feet more. And he has sent out word that "we'll be extremely aggressive in making a deal" for the rest.
"We're dumping the space out at less than half of what we're paying, and we'll bearhug anyone who comes in now," he said.

LENGTH: 1338 words

HEADLINE: A New Session, an Uncertain Agenda

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
AN election-year budget fuss? A gun-control blunderbuss? Property tax? Spending whacks? Casino gambling off the tracks?
If Dr. Seuss were to write the script for this year's General Assembly session, there would probably be no more pratfalls, loop-the-loops and odd characters than what the lawmakers themselves will provide when the 12-week session convenes in Hartford on Wednesday. 
 Legislative leaders, lobbyists and others who watch the Capitol say that this year, even more than in some past years, the process will be subject to forces from beyond the inner circle.
From the Mohegan Indian tribe's hopes for Federal recognition and a second Connecticut casino, to the legal odyssey of Michael Ross, the convicted serial killer whose death penalty drama in the State Supreme Court will play out even as lawmakers are talking crime and punishment across the street, to the men and women who would be governor, major forces and events will be unfolding outside the Capitol. How those events are perceived by the public -- and how politicians further interpret those perceptions -- are the great unknowns.
"It's going to be a much different type of session," said the Speaker of the House, Thomas D. Ritter, a Democrat from Hartford. "The issues are far more complex."
Casino gambling is probably the perfect example of an issue that could sail into new spirals of complexity even as the session goes on.
Legislators say that after last year's crushing defeat, when casino promoters declined to even try a vote in the House or Senate after spending millions of dollars in lobbying and advertising fees, the momentum has clearly slowed. With Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. in the governor's chair for a last session and vowing a veto of any casino bill, even some of the most enthusiastic believers in gambling as an economic development tool say that building a casino in Hartford or Bridgeport to compete with the Mashantucket Pequot Indian tribe's Foxwoods casino in Ledyard is out of reach.
What could change everything, however, is the prospect of another Indian casino. The Mohegans, based in Montville, have indicated a readiness -- and the financial backing -- to get into the gambling business alongside the Pequots if their petition to the Federal Government for formal tribal recognition is granted. Two casinos, legislators believe, could shift the discussion.
 
Looking for Override Votes
 "Casino advocates in the legislature are looking for an opportunity to collect override votes," Senator William A. Aniskovich, a Republican from Branford, said in referring to the two-thirds majority needed to override a gubernatorial veto. "If the Mohegan reaction creates a critical mass of public opinion that could swing people, then they'll look to move quickly."
If the gambling issue heats up, the shift in focus could start to squeeze out issues like gun control or property-tax relief, both of which are expected to be included in some form in Mr. Weicker's State of the State speech on Wednesday.
Mr. Weicker -- who announced last year that he would not seek a second term -- has said he would use his last year in office to push an agenda to benefit children. It would include in particular a crime bill that would create a licensing system for gun owners akin to the driver's license and registration systems. The proposal would also create a new, higher hurdle for carrying a concealed weapon, and stiffer penalties for owners of guns used in violent crimes.
The bill has drawn criticism, especially from some Republicans concerned that individuals' rights to defend themselves from criminals could be weakened.
 
The Michael Ross Case
 One wild card in the discussion is Michael Ross.
Mr. Ross was sentenced to death six years ago for kidnapping and strangling four young women in 1983 and 1984, and on Feb. 15 and 16, the State Supreme Court will hear his appeal. The Ross case has been an emotional trigger point for years, and the court's consideration of the case -- during a session already earmarked by the Governor for the question of crime and its effect on society -- will be watched by the legislators for voters' reactions.
Among the proposals that could be buffeted by the Ross case are stiffer penalties for persistent offenders, including a measure that would require life in prison for a third felony offense or a second felony offense with a gun. Lawmakers in both parties locally and nationally are pushing the idea.
Behind everything, of course, is the budget, usually the main event in the legislature, and sure to be again this year -- if only by being ignored. Last year, under a new budget-writing law, the General Assembly passed the first two-year budget, intended to take the state through June 30, 1995 with only minor tinkering.
 
Who Defines What's Minor?
 The question is, who defines what is minor? Because of increases in the costs of Medicaid and of prisons in particular, the $9 billion budget for the year beginning July 1 is more than $160 million out of balance. Leaders in the House and Senate have said that keeping budget work to a minimum is a priority because of the precedent-setting value. Find a way to cut spending enough to fill the gap, the leaders say, but don't question the major priorities or the bottom line.
"This is the test of whether a biennial budget works or not," Mr. Ritter said. "How we conduct ourselves will set the tone for future legislatures."
But those priorities have not yet met reality. The Majority Leader in the Senate, William A. DiBella, a Democrat from Hartford, said that Mr. Weicker has informally indicated that he has some "new priorities" that he will introduce in his speech before the combined House and Senate.
 
Opening Up the Budget
 How much the budget actually gets opened up, Mr. DiBella said, will depend on what Mr. Weicker asks for, because to whatever degree the Governor wants new items in the spending plan, so too will everyone else want their revisions considered.
"He's basically going to set the stage as to where we're going to go on this issue," Mr. DiBella said.
And there is, of course, the issue that elections for governor and all the General Assembly seats are just nine months away, and that the Capitol will be packed with people intent on keeping their current jobs, or taking away someone else's, on Election Day.
 
Going After Higher Office
 In the Senate there are three candidates for governor: Senator Richard J. Balducci, a Democrat from Newington, Senate President Pro-tem John B. Larson, a Democrat from East Hartford, and Lieutenant Governor Eunice S. Groark, who presides over the chamber, and who is running on the third party ticket that Mr. Weicker created in 1990, A Connecticut Party. Another Senator, James H. Maloney, a Democrat from Danbury, is seeking the nomination for the Fifth District congressional seat held by Gary A. Franks, a Republican.
In the House, at least three people are seeking more prominent jobs. The Majority Leader, Representative Thomas S. Luby, a Democrat from Meriden, is also running for the Fifth District seat sought by Mr. Maloney; Representative Miles S. Rapoport, a Democratic from West Hartford, is running for Secretary of the State, and Representative Gene Gavin, a Republican from Westport, is running for Comptroller.
Other candidates will be close at hand and no doubt making their voices heard. Pauline R. Kezer, the Secretary of the State, and former United States Representative John G. Rowland are both seeking the Republican nomination for governor. Democrats outside the legislature include William E. Curry Jr., the state Comptroller, and Joseph P. Ganim, the Mayor of Bridgeport.
Democrats and Republicans agree that there is one key indicator to watch: how Mrs. Groark is treated. If polling indicates that her third party candidacy is taking votes from one party more than the other, she will become an ally to one and foe of the other.
"It's as basic as that," Mr. Ritter said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Abe L. Simeon testing the sound system last week in the Hall of the House at the State Capitol in Hartford. (Steve Miller for The New York Times) (pg. 4)

HEADLINE: Q and A

 BODY:

Who's Responsible For Drain Repairs?
 
Q. I live in a rent-controlled apartment. Recently, the landlord billed me for work done by an outside contractor to clear a bathroom drain of excessive hair. The landlord quotes from a two-year lease signed by us in 1962 as the basis for our responsibility. 
 May the landlord cite such an old lease and, if not, is the tenant indeed responsible for such repairs? . . . Lorraine Simmons, Manhattan
 
A. According to Michael Finder, a Manhattan lawyer, if the landlord is able to prove that the cause of the drainage problem was coming from the tenant's putting hair down the drain, then the tenant could be held responsible.
He added that the original date of the lease in this case was not relevant.
 
How Much to Spend To Buy a Home
 
Q. My husband and I are looking to buy a co-op. How can we figure out what we can afford? Is there a formula? We have an income of about $90,000 a year?
How much would be a reasonable down payment, mortgage payment, maintenance and tax payments? . . . P. Reed, Manhattan
 
A. According to Margaret S. Scott, president of the Mortgage Advisory Service, a mortgage broker in Manhattan, there are several simple ways to gauge how expensive an apartment you can afford, though the amount will also depend on the size of your down payment, maintenance and taxes on the property, your total liabilities and financial goals.
One of the easiest ways, and a method often cited by real estate brokers, is to double your annual income. In your case, that's $180,000.
Ms. Scott also recommended that you make a 20 percent down payment, or $36,000, not only to keep your payments lower but also to avoid paying mortgage insurance, which is the equivalent of adding .375 of a percent onto your mortgage rate.
You should also be prepared, Ms. Scott added, to pay about $2,500 in closing costs for a co-op and a higher amount if you buy a house or a condominium.
There is also, in New York City, a mortgage tax of 1.75 percent for houses and condominiums. In addition to closing costs, you should add any points that are part of your mortgage. (A point is equal to one percentage point of the mortgage.)
With a down payment of $36,000, you will need a $144,000 mortgage, which at 7.5 percent annual interest over 30 years, will cost you about $1,000 a month. Ms. Scott estimated that the average maintenance on such an apartment was about $750 a month, a portion of which is probably tax deductible. This maintenance includes your taxes and insurance. If you were buying a house, there would be no maintenance, but taxes and insurance would be additional. For a condominium, there are common charges that cover insurance but not taxes.
Thus your combined mortgage and maintenance is now $1,750, which is under the 28 percent limit of gross monthly income that is required by most lenders. They will also require that the $1,750 plus any installment debt you may have not exceed 36 percent of your gross income.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Will the Big 3 Stay on the Road To Success?

BYLINE: By Doron P. Levin

 BODY:
WHAT a difference a recovery can make in Detroit. Only yesterday, it seems, the Big Three chiefs and President Bush flew to Tokyo complaining about "getting our brains beaten in," to use Lee Iacocca's vivid expression.
Today the Big Three, exemplified by Chrysler's stunning turnaround, are selling cars almost as fast as they can build them. With improved American quality and Japan's higher prices, Detroit's models indeed represent superior value, a claim that is finally holding water. 
 The biggest factor in Detroit's revival, however, hasn't been better quality, but rather the steadily improving demand for vehicles, especially light trucks, that began last spring.
But the huge losses of a year ago are easily forgotten by those who bought General Motors, Ford and Chrysler shares during the past two years and now sit on nifty gains.
Now the mystery is not just how long the boom will last but what happens after sales peak.
Will the Big Three again lose stupendous sums? Will they have to scramble to replenish the capital they need for new models and research?
The test of a competitive auto industry won't be whether it can break out of its cyclical pattern -- it is, after all, a mature, not a growth, industry -- but whether it can maintain its health during a trough in sales. In market share, the Big Three haven't regained much of what they lost to Japan.
The companies still struggle with the fundamental puzzle of how to configure operations so they can remain profitable -- or at least less unprofitable -- with lower sales volume. "All the auto makers are improving but we can't really answer the question of their basic health until the next downturn," said Harvey Heinbach, an automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York.
When will the downturn arrive? Most economists agree that car sales should peak no sooner than 1996. Some say that stock prices tend to peak a year before sales do, so investors in Big Three shares may have another year or so of profit -- provided nothing like a war or a surge in gas prices scares car buyers in the meantime.
Wendy Needham, a Smith Barney analyst, noted that in Detroit, "management is reinvesting in products this time, not spending on acquisitions as they did during the 1980's." Beyond watching for a turn in the economy, Ms. Needham warned, investors need to keep an eye out "for an obvious flop of a new car or truck, something that could cause a stampede out of the stock." For now, she forecasts all three companies will appreciate at least to the range of $70 to $80 a share.
The American auto industry has been better at recovering from trouble than staying out of trouble. As Tom Gale, a Chrysler vice president, said: "Chrysler is terrific at adversity. We're not that good at success." Only the next downturn will tell if the pattern will be broken.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1530 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: January 31 - February 4

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
A Whiff of Inflation, and a Stampede Out of Stocks
Inflation continues to hover just off stage, a dragon that never actually appears but whose menacing noises still keep the on-stage actors jumpy. On Friday the Federal Reserve raised its Federal funds rate a notch -- to 3.25 percent from 3 percent -- and the financial markets acted as if someone had stolen their champagne. It shouldn't have been a surprise, though. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, said earlier in the week that such a nudge might be needed to head off long-term inflation, and many people shrugged it off, saying things were going so well that a small rise couldn't do much harm. But when the announcement came, bond prices fell and stocks tumbled, with the Dow industrials (after flirting with 4,000 earlier in the week) losing 96 points for the day, to 3,871 -- the eighth-biggest drop ever. So has the bull market stumbled, or will investors decide that 3.25 percent still isn't that high? It's a nervous weekend. 

Solid Job Data (Look Closely)
The job numbers should be crisp, clear guideposts, but you needed a fine-print user's guide to read January's report, out last week. Yes, unemployment was 6.7 percent, up from December's 6.4. But: the survey's been redesigned (the old one was missing too many women looking for work), so it's apples vs. oranges. All things being equal, the Government says, the job picture's improving. And, yes, payrolls expanded by just 62,000, a third what was expected. But: blame the cold weather. The bottom line, economists say, is an economy still moving solidly ahead. This time, we'll have to take it on faith.
 
Buying Cars, Even in January
Americans must really be primed to buy new cars these days. Neither sleet nor snow nor ice (nor even more ice) nor collapsing freeways held them back in January, as sales surged 13.8 percent, beyond even the rosiest forecasts. The dealers' main worry now is just having enough cars and trucks to sell. Why the stampede? Clearly, with employment, income and confidence up, Americans are looking hard at their dented, sputtering antiques -- the average vehicle is now nearly eight and a half years old, the highest since the early 50's. And one dealer came up with a grim tidbit of optimism: Because so many cars were totaled on January's ice, sales are bound to stay strong.
 
New York Women, Catching Up
Women already know the bad news: men earn more than they do. But the good news is that the gap is shrinking -- and especially so in New York City. If you're a woman and a high school graduate, New York was the place to be in the 80's. A study out last week says women in the city who worked full time in 1989 earned 77.5 cents for each man's dollar, up from 71 cents in 1979. Nationwide, though, the '89 number was just 66 cents. The study, done by Columbia's Teachers College, also showed that by 1990 women had become a majority in the city's labor force -- no doubt because manufacturing jobs are on the decline. Progress, yes, but for the city's women the next question has to be, "O.K., what about that other 22.5 cents?"
 
The Perils of Messing With Milk
The food industry has tinkered with nature for ages -- adding preservatives, dyes, who-knows-what -- but rarely has there been such an outcry. Perhaps milk is different -- sacred, somehow -- for there's been a gut reaction against this round of tampering. Last week a growth hormone designed to increase cows' output made its debut -- a hormone born of biotechnology -- and several big food companies quickly moved to limit its use. The F.D.A. insists it's safe, but stores are balking not for safety reasons but out of fear of what customers will say.
 
Volunteering for Emission Limits
If California can do it, so can we! That seemed to be the thinking of 12 Eastern states last week when they asked the E.P.A. to impose California's stricter auto emission rules. The governors of the states -- from Maine to Virginia -- wanted the rules, but if they get Washington to make them do it, they'll have less rebellion from state legislators, who tend to have lobbyists banging on their doors.
 
Does Sculley Know Best?
What is John Sculley up to? A lot of people would love the answer. When the former Apple chairman made his puzzling decision to join Spectrum Technologies, had he lost his senses or was he privy to some information about Spectrum's glittering future? Initially, investors bet on the latter, and the stock soared. But then came word that top Spectrum executives, who would surely know of any pots of gold, cashed in a lot of stock after Mr. Sculley joined. To top it off, the company faces an S.E.C. inquiry, and there was talk of a spat between Mr. Sculley and Spectrum's president. So last week the company went out of its way to say Mr. Sculley was busy, busy, busy with acquisitions and joint ventures.
 
BMW, With a British Accent
Like water in adjacent (leaky) pools, European industry is finding its own level. Germany's auto makers are known for high quality -- but also for high labor costs, and that's hurting. Seeking a better balance, BMW last week agreed to buy the Rover Group for $1.2 billion. For BMW, it was the best way to get an efficient small-car maker, because in addition to big, trendy Range Rovers, the British company makes cars like the Metro and Mini. And, more to the point, British labor costs are roughly half of Germany's. So the sun has clearly set on one empire: Every big British auto maker is now under foreign control.
 
I.B.M. and Intel, Drifting Apart
In 1981, mighty I.B.M. bestowed on Intel the right to supply the microprocessors, the "brains," for its personal computers. But Intel has grown mighty itself and now dominates this highly profitable market, turning into an I.B.M. rival. So last week I.B.M., as part of its effort to redefine itself, pulled back from its ties with Intel, moving toward making its own type of microchip.
Intel was already turning part of its attention to lower-tech pursuits. The next day it said it would sponsor the Professional Chess Association, founded by Gary Kasparov, the world champion. At tournaments, Intel will use computer graphics and giant video screens to "bring the ancient game of chess into the 21st century." It might have made it anyway.
 
Networks Seek Better Ratings
The television folks aren't satisfied with a population that spends most of its waking hours in front of the tube. No, they want the precise who, what and when of this national addiction. Nielsen ratings try to provide this, but networks have long said Nielsen is inaccurate. Last week they ran out of patience, starting a multimillion-dollar search for another way. The main complaint: Nielsen undercounts some viewers, costing networks millions of ad dollars. "It is simply unthinkable," said an NBC executive, "to be locked into yesterday's methods." With "people meters" out of favor, is tomorrow's method a spy in every household?
 
A Whispered Hello to Vietnam
President Clinton is dying to tear down trade walls, but when his finger came to Vietnam as he worked down the list, an emotion-charged past flooded in -- right up to the "draft dodger" cries regularly hurled at him. American business, eyeing a possible $6 billion market, wanted to end the war-era trade embargo, and many others just wanted to close that painful chapter. But veterans' groups balked. So when Mr. Clinton ended the embargo last week, he tiptoed up to it -- and went right to the point on everyone's mind by vowing that the move "offers the best way to resolve the fate of those who remain missing."
 
A French Aircraft Subsidy
Europe's commercial aircraft subsidies have been a touchy subject on both sides of the Atlantic for some time now. The way Washington sees it, an Airbus kept aloft by Government largess is an unfair rival to Boeing and its cousins. Nonsense, says Airbus: Pentagon and NASA contracts for American plane makers are just subsidies by another name. France did nothing to cool this tension last week when it said it would chip in $341 million to prop up the state-owned Aerospatiale, which owns more than a third of Airbus. Of course, the Airbus A330 has been slow to rival Boeing's 777 -- the first A330's have been grounded by a landing-gear defect.
 
The Americas, United in Trade
After passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement, the rest of Latin America looked at Mexico and said, "What about us?" Washington welcomed the question, because Latin America is devouring American exports, and the Clinton Administration's diplomatic tool of choice is trade, not aid. So last week the Administration said it was drafting a plan for a Western Hemisphere free trade zone. (Great: Now that we've got "Nafta," we face "Whftz" -- pronounced, presumably, "Whoofts.") It won't be quick -- 10 to 15 years, probably -- because Latin nations must first get their economies in order by deregulating markets and taming inflation. Chile, whose economy has come the furthest, will be the first in. And if the rest follow, there'll be a single tariff-free market of 750 million people.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 14; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1207 words

HEADLINE: Nuclear Roots Grow Into an Argentine Silicon Valley

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH

DATELINE: LLAO LLAO, Argentina

 BODY:
TUCKED into a dense stand of evergreens, a group of low, whitewashed buildings with corrugated metal roofs give little indication of the activities within. Maybe a conservation group. Maybe a national park office. The only clue is the parabolic dish on top of a red-and-white radio tower.
But inside the shaded compound, an elite team of Argentina's electronic and nuclear engineers are working, not exactly secretively, but with a very low profile. In newly built "clean rooms," their primary project is a $7 million research satellite for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration of the United States, to be launched in mid-1995. 
 Some 15 miles east, in the city of Bariloche, inside a two-story sandstone-colored building that looks like a home, computer programmers are working on robotics and software for just-in-time manufacturing, as well as designing small but highly advanced nuclear reactors. There are no signs outside the structure to indicate the advanced work within.
These are the offices of Invap S.E., Argentina's tiny version of a Silicon Valley company. It has 300 employees and sales of no more than $40 million a year. Its shareholders are the provincial Government of Rio Negro and the Argentine Government through the National Atomic Energy Commission.
Though tiny compared with leading international high-tech companies, Invap has found that in certain market niches -- like building small research reactors -- it can compete with international giants like General Atomics of San Diego and Babcock & Wilcox of New Orleans.
The project with NASA, the first time a satellite has been built in Argentina, is providing training for Argentine engineers and transfers of American technology that would have been impossible just four years ago, because Argentina was considered a threat to nuclear proliferation.
"We are mainly nuclear engineers and physicists, and what the people from NASA told us was that they were surprised how quickly our engineers switched into space technology," said Hector E. Otheguy, general and technical manager of Invap. "Though small, we find that at least in some areas we can compete."
In the first part of this century, Argentina was among the world's richest nations, yet today it has only a tiny home-grown technological capacity. Its failure to keep up is sobering testimony to decades of intense nationalism, isolation from the industrialized world and association with often unstable third-world governments. Argentina developed its own reactor technology -- and thus the potential to build an atomic bomb -- as far back as the 1960's, through its atomic research center in Bariloche. But from the start it refused to let international monitoring agencies inspect its operations.
Successive Governments argued that permitting international controls was the equivalent of giving the industrialized world the right to manipulate the nation's technological future and its growth.
In many ways, Invap was one of the main instruments for Argentina's nuclear program. Founded in the early 1970's by scientists from the atomic center to use the technology they had developed, Invap, under the guidance of the National Atomic Energy Commission, built small reactors for third-world countries like Algeria, Peru and Iran, as well as for the Argentine Government itself.
MOST of the work was done in almost total secrecy, including a uranium enrichment plant 40 miles east of Bariloche, begun in the early 1980's to supply Argentina's research reactors with fuel in case the international community cut off supplies. The plant, which has cost the Government $300 million, places Argentina among a select group of nine countries that have the capacity, at least in theory, to enrich uranium to a grade that nearly approaches that used in bombs.
Although its nuclear program was remarkably advanced compared with those of most third-world countries, Argentina found itself on a list of nations prohibited from receiving transfers of new computer and electronic technology. The prohibition stemmed from an effort to stop proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.
That has changed, however, under the Government of President Carlos Saul Menem, who has opened all of the country's nuclear operations to international controls and inspection, and renounced nuclear proliferation.
For Invap, it has meant drastic changes -- in particular, shedding its tradition of secrecy -- as well as a brush with near-bankruptcy two years ago.
IN the mid-1980's, Invap signed a contract with Iran to build a purification plant for enriched uranium. Under a second contract, a pilot plant was to be built that would produce fuel rods for Iranian research reactors.
In late 1991, when its first shipment of equipment was ready to leave port, the company received instructions from the Foreign Ministry -- at Washington's request -- to halt it. The reasoning was that Iran, though it had signed the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, was a potentially unreliable signatory that at any time could decide to develop nuclear weapons. Breaking the contracts meant a loss of $25 million in income.
"It was a blow for Invap, and we didn't know if we could recover from it," Thomas Buch, an official of the company, said. "We were shipping things we bought off the shelf -- tubing, valves, lathes -- and argued they in themselves did not contribute to proliferation. But the Foreign Ministry reasoned that anything that increased Iran's capacity to develop nuclear weapons should be stopped."
Since those bleak first months, the company seems to have more than recovered.
In addition to being given the contract with NASA, many say as American compensation for having broken the two Iranian contracts, it has won a $60 million deal to build a research reactor in Cairo and is on the short list of finalists for an even larger reactor for the Government of Thailand; two of its competitors for the Thai deal are General Atomics and Babcock & Wilcox.
In addition, informal talks are under way with General Atomics on joint ventures.
Invap is considering taking the design of its small-reactor technology even further. With Argentina's explosive economic growth over the last three years, and anticipation of continuing growth through much of the decade, the country's electrical power needs could almost double over the next decade.
While Invap does not pretend to build giant nuclear power stations with the capacity of 600 to 700 megawatts, it is working on designs for small plants in the 25-to-50-megawatt range. The smaller plants could be built in much less time -- about two years -- eventually using a type of assembly-line technique if enough were built. That would allow greater economies and enable nuclear power to compete in price with gas and hydroelectric plants.
Jorge Marticorena, former president of Invap, argues that not only do the smaller plants use simpler cooling technologies and are thus safer, but that Argentina would be using its large uranium reserves as well as its home-grown high-tech know-how.
"It cost us a lot politically and economically to get where we are, and it makes sense to use the technology we have developed here in Argentina," he said.

HEADLINE: Profile;
From Brooklyn, Around the World, To Mobil's Top Job

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

DATELINE: FAIRFAX, Va.

 BODY:
Lucio A. Noto, who will soon replace Allen E. Murray atop the Mobil Corporation, is not typical of the men who have risen to the top of international oil giants. He's the Brooklyn-born son of the leader of a union local comprising mostly Italian immigrants. He rose through the ranks at Mobil in planning and marketing, rather than winning acclaim with big finds in the exploration division. And he made his reputation not in this country but overseas.
Little-known at headquarters here until recent years, he was until last year a dark horse in the race to run the $64 billion company that is the nation's fourth-largest. 
 But with Mobil looking abroad for an increasing share of its business, Mr. Noto's accomplishments were hard to overlook. He helped build Mobil's operations in Japan, then Italy, then Saudi Arabia. He gained a reputation for financial savvy, detailed knowledge of operations, social skills and sensitivity to other cultures. All won him friends among the foreign officials and executives with whom Mobil needed to work.
Now, Mr. Noto, who is 55, has a broader challenge. His predecessor refocused the company on its core businesses, shedding Montgomery Ward and the Container Corporation, and began cutting costs in a big way, reducing the work force by about 15,000 over the past five years to 62,000. Mr. Noto is obligated to continue that streamlining -- weak operations in France might be among the first to go -- but also to strike deals to develop new reserves in politically perilous places like Vietnam, Russia and Kazakhstan as Mobil's major fields begin to run dry.
He also must find enough customers to justify the company's $8 billion effort to develop one of the world's largest gas fields, in Qatar, at a time when other companies are also hurrying to bring on gas production.
And he must execute such risky plans while continuing to satisfy shareholders, who have become accustomed in recent years to rising dividends and stock prices. In the past five years Mobil shareholders have received a pre-tax annual return (combining dividends and stock increases) of about 17 percent, compared with an average of 13.5 percent among the major oil companies.
Mr. Noto, already the president and chief operating officer, will take over from Mr. Murray as chairman and chief executive on March 1. The two men differ in style. Whereas Mr. Murray avoided the limelight, gave few interviews and disliked informal politicking, particularly in Washington, Mr. Noto feels at home in such roles and might be more aggressive and outspoken in pursuing the interests of the industry. He can be expected to communicate in person what Mobil has been saying in its print advertising campaign since 1972.
He says he is not daunted by the position. "Some people say, 'Well, the glory days of this industry have passed,' " he said. "I say no to that."
Like his oil-industry counterparts, Mr. Noto is faced with low prices for oil and gas and stricter environmental requirements for gasoline in many nations. That will raise operating costs. His challenge is to make his company the low-cost operator in all phases of his business.
At the same time, Mobil, whose United States reserves are past their peak and which now has nearly two-thirds of its production abroad, must find new reserves in foreign lands.
New technology for exploration and drilling, plus the eagerness of many nations to bring in major oil companies to find new fields, has made Mobil's job abroad easier. Still, the dangers are high of sinking a lot of money into a country whose government might change, and where chances are slim of finding major deposits.
For example, Mobil has received permission from Vietnam to drill in a promising area called the Blue Dragon in its territorial waters, near the area where the company had drilled before abandoning its efforts after the Vietnam War. Now that President Clinton has lifted the Government's post-war trade embargo, that project can proceed. Yet one of Mobil's own experts, after reviewing the plan recently, said there is only a 20 percent chance of finding oil or gas in the region.
"And that's hot -- that's not a bad prospect, 20 percent," Mr. Noto said.
The Qatar gas project is another tough one. It includes a huge plant to liquefy the gas and an investment in giant tankers to carry it to customers in Japan and other countries. Mobil still has to line up long-term customers, like utilities in Japan, and persuade banks and other investors to put up the billions in financing to see through the project. Mr. Noto wants at least 50 percent of the money to come from outside the company. The first gas will not flow from the project until about 1997.
Mr. Noto also said that Mobil may have to get out of some markets in Europe. He would not say which, but Constantine Fliakos, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said Mobil had a weak position in France and may decide to sell its refining operations and gas stations there.
LUCIO NOTO grew up in Bensonhurst, a tough neighborhood in Brooklyn to which his parents had moved with their parents from Sicily early in the century. His father became active in the labor movement, and was later Secretary General of Local 89 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, an Italian-speaking unit.
Mr. Noto, who pushed hand carts and packaged clothing during the summer as a teen-ager, remembers the day in 1945 when his father packed everyone in his 1938 Oldsmobile, filled canteens with water and drove across the George Washington Bridge to Englewood Cliffs, N.J., to look for a house. They bought the old Victorian where Mr. Noto grew up.
A quick mind that could recall details and figures got him into a private high school, St. Regis, run by Jesuits in Manhattan. Mr. Noto went on to the University of Notre Dame, where he studied physics and played catcher on the baseball team. Then came Cornell University, where he got his M.B.A. in 1962.
Out of school, he joined Mobil's planning group and began to court his future wife, Joan.
By 1968 he was in Tokyo, overseeing teams of Japanese workers that began to bring Mobil a significant share of the gasoline market there. He learned some Japanese and made friends, and this could help him in Mobil's current attempt to win customers for the Qatar project.
In 1973, he was sent to Italy, as an executive vice president of Mobil Oil Italiana. He had learned Italian from his grandparents but, he recalls, his Sicilian dialect was so heavy that he had to take lessons so that Italians could better understand him.
IN 1979 he went to Saudi Arabia to coordinate Mobil's joint ventures there. He helped set up a petrochemical plant and refinery with the Saudis, who have the biggest oil reserves in the world. He made a lot of allies and friends and caught the eye of Mobil headquarters.
He also made contacts elsewhere in the Middle East. "Lou has close relations with the Middle Eastern governments which could help the company to open doors," said John D. Hervey, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Mr. Noto's abilities in entertaining foreign government and industry people were often crucial to sewing up a deal or easing through a project. He also credits his wife's skills.
Brought back to New York by Mr. Murray in 1985, Mr. Noto was made vice president of planning and economics. He became the front-runner for the top job last year, when he was elected president and chief operating officer.
He credits his rise to the top partly to good fortune. "I was lucky to be in countries where there were issues that got a lot of attention, so I got a lot of attention," he said.
He also said that his many years in joint-venture projects, as opposed to projects solely owned by Mobil, helped keep him thinking of ways to do things better. "When you have to go into a joint-venture board every month and convince them that this is the right way to go, it generates a different kind of skill set that I think is pretty good," Mr. Noto said.
He likes to meet occasionally with recently hired young employees, who ask him how he made it to the top. He tells them: "There are many ways to get to the top. And I tell you one of the best ways in my opinion is not to worry about what's going to happen next. Worry about what you're supposed to do today."
He is not one to keep long hours and to pressure other executives to toil late. After exercising at home, he gets to work in his Toyota Land Cruiser at about 7 A.M. By 6:45 P.M. he is generally on his way home. "I get tired," he said.
Outside Mobil, Mr. Noto moves easily among writers, artists and the social set, as he demonstrated last October at the Lotos Club in Manhattan. An Absolut on the rocks in hand, he worked the crowd and gave a small speech honoring a Slovak writer, Martin Simecka, with the company's Pegasus Prize for a work in a language other than English.
Colleagues recall that when Mr. Noto was stationed in Italy, he and his wife helped sponsor the Spoleto arts festival. He is also an avid collector of abstract art and has made friends with artists, including the British painter Albert Irvin.
Yet Mr. Noto also likes to show his Brooklyn roots. He seems comfortable with working people. He kids employees at all levels and last week enjoyed some razzing from Calvin Pugh, a maintenance man who is a Dallas Cowboys fan, about the defeat of the Buffalo Bills in the Super Bowl.
A car buff who lights up when he recalls the orange Maserati he picked up for a song in Italy and drove on the autostrada when there were no speed limits, Mr. Noto still likes to get his hands in the tool chest. He tinkered with a Datsun 240Z but botched the job so badly that he had to bring it to the shop to finish the work. He has no such plans for Mobil.
 
LUCIO A. NOTO
 
 Born: April 24, 1938, Brooklyn.
 
 Education: B.A., University of Notre Dame; M.B.A., Cornell University.
 
 Family: Wife, Joan; five children aged 15 to 28.
 
 Drives: 1958 Lancia, 1972 Datsun 240Z, Toyota Land Cruiser.
 
 Hobbies: Collects and works on cars; collects paintings; golfs.
 
 Ideal escape: driving an Italian sports car on the autostrada to lunch at a restaurant in a small Italian city.

HEADLINE: Technology;
For 'This Old Field,' a Costly Renovation Project

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
WHEN Phillips Petroleum brought Norway into the oil industry by discovering the Ekofisk field 180 miles off the country's southwest coast in 1969, Phillips figured it might be able to continue production through the 1990's. And certainly, Phillips officials thought at the time, they would phase out production many years before 2011, when its oilfield development license from the Norwegian Government would expire.
But now, thanks to technologies that promise to keep the North Sea oil flowing from Ekofisk into the 21st century, Phillips is thinking about investing an additional $3 billion to $4 billion in the field -- if the terms are right. 
 "This old field is doing better than we ever dreamed," Phillips's chairman, W. W. Allen, crowed in a recent interview.
And so, in late December, the company made a proposal to the Norwegian Government to extend its license to the year 2031, pledging to meet stricter safety and environmental rules as it drills new wells and updates Ekofisk's production and transport facilities. To justify the investment, Phillips has proposed exempting any new wells from royalties to the Norwegian Government, which currently run about 10 percent of the price of every barrel of oil the company extracts.
The Norwegian Parliament is expected to take up Phillips's proposal in the spring. It's a significant issue in Norway because Ekofisk, accounting for 12 percent of all oil produced from Norwegian fields, provides 8,500 jobs onshore and offshore. The Ekofisk complex also serves as a transportation hub for 250,000 barrels of oil and 1 billion cubic feet of gas a day from fields operated by other oil companies such as British Petroleum, Amoco and Statoil, the Norwegian national oil company.
The surprising staying power of the North Sea fields in general has been the result of diverse technologies -- drilling horizontal offshoots of wells from existing platforms, for example -- in recent years. In October, the North Sea produced a record 4.94 million barrels a day and the rate is expected to reach about 5.3 million barrels daily by the end of this year.
Because a surplus of even 100,000 barrels a day on the world market can have a big impact on the price of oil, some analysts say that such an increase from the North Sea could further erode the ability of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to control crude oil prices, which have been below $16 a barrel lately.
The greater North Sea flow, much of which is finding its way to the United States, has put OPEC on the defensive and prompted some of its members to petition the British and Norwegian Governments to pressure major producers to cut back, as they did about five years ago, to prop up crude oil prices.
So far this time, OPEC's efforts have been rebuffed. Indeed, instead of exercising restraint, Phillips and the other big North Sea producers have sought to extend the life of existing fields and bring on what production they can. (The expensive search for new fields is on hold.) And the story of Phillips's Ekofisk complex, one of the North Sea's biggest and oldest gas and oil fields, may provide the best illustration of this trend.
WHEN Phillips discovered petroleum in 1969 in Norway's part of the North Sea, it was in shallow water (about 200 feet), below which lay oil-saturated chalk. Drilling wells as deep as 15,000 feet, Phillips's engineers soon realized they had something big -- reserves estimated at more than 1 billion barrels. But they expected to be able to extract only 20 percent or so of that before the natural pressure of the formation subsided and oil would no longer flow to the surface.
Phillips named the field Ekofisk, coining a Norwegian-based word to mean "echo fish," in reference to the undersea seismic readings by which engineers found the deposit.
By 1971, oil from Ekofisk was being shipped by tankers. But severe weather in the region -- prodigious North Sea waves commonly exceed 40 feet -- meant tankers often had trouble getting through. So Phillips that same year used six tugboats to tow a 215,000-ton storage tank to the field. The tank could hold 1 million barrels of oil, and the platform supporting it also became the site of Ekofisk's central processing operation.
In 1972, Phillips began laying a 34-inch-diameter, 220-mile pipeline to Teesside, England, which has subsequently become a major transportation hub for North Sea oil. Phillips opened the Teesside processing terminal in 1975, and two years later opened a natural-gas processing terminal in Emden, Germany, connected to Ekofisk by a 275-mile pipeline.
In those days, the field's life was estimated to be 20 to 30 years. "By the end of the 1990's, we expected production to slow down and we would start abandonment," recalled Rolf Wiborg, deputy managing director of the Phillips Petroleum Company Norway.
Through the early 1980's that forecast seemed to be holding up. Production, which hit a peak of 624,000 barrels a day in January 1980, sank below 150,000 barrels a day by 1986. "We started going downhill," Mr. Wiborg said.
By this time, the company had the most highly developed field in the North Sea -- a constellation of 26 drilling platforms linked by pipeline to the central storage tank and on-shore terminals.
Even though production was dwindling, however, Phillips engineers reached the happy realization that as oil was extracted, the porous chalk tended naturally to suck up water, displacing further oil for recovery. To assist this natural process, Phillips in 1987 began injecting hundreds of thousands of barrels of water a day deep into the field, to maintain a constant pressure that would keep the oil flowing to the wellheads.
The value of water injection had long been known in the oil industry, but this was the first time it had been tried in an offshore chalk formation. Subsequent fine-tuning of the process, like adding hydrochloric acid to the water to help dissolve the flow-hindering calcium carbonate of the chalk, has further increased the expected recovery rate, to as high as 40 percent -- double the rate originally expected.
But the extraction of oil and gas had also created a problem, which was discovered in 1984: The sea bed was sinking. At the central Ekofisk complex of nine platforms and the huge storage tank, the subsidence had dropped the structures more than seven feet closer to sea level.
To keep the whole complex from being swamped, Phillips spent the summer of 1987 -- and more than $400 million -- using 100 hydraulic jacks to raise six of the platforms by some 20 feet. Because the huge storage tank could not be raised, Phillips spent more than $300 million to erect around the tank a concrete wall, rising like a 35-story building from the seabed, to keep the waves off.
Today, production from the Ekofisk field has rebounded, averaging about 270,000 barrels a day. Phillips to date has spent about $2 billion on water injection, and there are now plans to increase injection capacity from 500,000 barrels a day to 820,000 -- which could extend the life of the field into the 21st century.
"Ekofisk is the model of finding the secret of being able to sustain production," Mr. Wiborg said. It will remain the model, however, only if Phillips can persuade the Norwegian Government to accept its proposal -- more precisely, one of two proposals -- aimed at solving the problems of rising operating costs while meeting stricter environmental and safety standards.
One of the major problems is the walled-in storage tank and processing center. The wall has created safety risks by reducing natural ventilation, meaning a gas leak would be more likely to result in a massive explosion.
Phillips has proposed two solutions.
The most comprehensive and expensive, costing up to $4 billion, would be building three new operation and processing platforms that would have no wells drilled immediately below them, making them less vulnerable to sinking. Because the pipelines have long since eliminated the need for the giant storage tank -- although not the installation containing the tank -- once the processing operation was moved to the new platforms, the walled-in site could be abandoned.
TO make this solution feasible, Phillips wants the Norwegian Government to extend its license to produce oil through the year 2031 and forgo royalty payments on new wells. (Although the Norwegian Government would continue to assess corporate income taxes, which can exceed 70 percent.) Another condition set by Phillips is that the expensive removal of abandoned platforms be put off until after the current license term expires in 2011.
By that time, Phillips and other operators in the North Sea would all be needing to scrap many of their original platforms, and Phillips expects that their joint effort -- and new salvage technologies -- will make the job easier and more economical.
If the Government does not approve this first proposal, Phillips has suggested a less expensive -- perhaps $2 billion -- alternative intended to extend the useful life of the current Ekofisk installation. A new processing platform would be built, linked to the existing storage tank platform, which would be used primarily as a hub for the transport of oil and gas through existing pipelines.
Abandonment of "this old field," it seems, keeps moving farther away.

HEADLINE: Quality: High. Price: Low. Big Ad Budget? Never.

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
"MOM," says the boy in a cartoon in the supermarket journal, enjoying a President's Choice cereal, "is it possible that a cereal without its own TV commercial could taste so good?!!"
President's Choice may or may not be better than Kellogg's, but there's no question that this upscale private label, now appearing on cereal boxes and hundreds of other products in North America, has been a resounding success for its owner, the Loblaw Companies, Canada's biggest supermarket chain. 
 In the process it has fired the rebellion of consumers and retailers against highly advertised, and therefore pricey, national brands. And the products have already found their way into more than 1,200 stores in the United States, in chains like D'Agostino's in New York, Jewel in Chicago and Lucky Stores on the West Coast.
President's Choice's American sales volume rose 127 percent last year, while overall North American volume increased 37 percent, making Loblaw what J.P. Morgan Securities calls "the most developed North American private brand retailer."
Loblaw got a big lift in the United States two years ago when it made a deal to help Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, generate what are now some 600 private brand items.
Loblaw's secret: It took house brands that had been around for a long time but were inferior to the national brands and raised quality to levels equal to or above the national brands.
David A. Nichol, the man behind this transformation at Loblaw, explained that the products could still be sold for less than the national brands because they had no "brand tax." In other words, their profit calculations did not need to include the tens of millions of dollars that the big guns spend every year on advertising, promotion and product introductions.
"There are not many Canadian ideas that you can export," said John Winter, a Toronto food consultant, "but that definitely was one with some legs."
The impact of President's Choice on American retailing promises to be dramatic. It's had an "extraordinary ripple effect," said Brian Sharoff, president of the 1,700-member New York-based Private Label Manufacturers Association. The label already has imitators here, but it will probably take a long time for them to catch up.
As the battle intensifies for space on the supermarket shelf, "President's Choice raises the standards by which every retailer who has a private label program will have to judge the competitiveness of that program in terms of quality and price," Mr. Sharoff stressed.
PIGGYBACKING on President's Choice, Loblaw has come a long way. In the 1960's the Toronto-based chain -- which is 77 percent owned by George Weston Ltd., a giant Toronto-based food processing and distribution company -- was racking up yearly losses of tens of millions of dollars.
"Loblaw quietly went to sleep," according to the assessment in one of its own publications, "as growth in a number of stores stopped."
In stepped Mr. Nichol, son of a railway station agent from Chatham, Ontario, who by zeroing in on quality in the generics did something that no one in North America had really tried before.
The payoff is clear. Loblaw's North American sales were an estimated $9 billion (Canadian dollars, currently worth about 75 United States cents each) last year. Of that, $1.2 billion came from cereal, spaghetti sauce, cookies, frozen pizza, cola and other products with President's Choice on the label, up from $500 million three years earlier.
"Bottom-line benefit is the key," says Gabe Lowy, consumer products analyst for Oppenheimer & Company in New York. "The stores can afford to price President's Choice below the national brands and still make more money."
Besides D'Agostino, Jewel and Lucky, Lower 48 outlets include National Supermarkets in St. Louis and New Orleans, Acme Markets in the mid-Atlantic states, Star Market in Boston, Tom Thumb in Dallas and Smitty's Supervalue in Phoenix.
While President's Choice products now sell in 34 states, Loblaw's biggest prize is the deal with Wal-Mart, which had $73 billion in sales in 1993. Mr. Nichol reports that Wal-Mart's volume last year on Sam's American Choice and Great Value lines, also developed by Loblaw, was up 300 percent.
Wal-Mart has just announced its own invasion of Canada, acquiring 120 of the 142 Canadian Woolco stores from the Woolworth Corporation. It plans to reopen them as Wal-Mart stores this summer.
Under its agreement with Loblaw, Wal-Mart cannot sell in Canada the private-label line that Loblaw helped it develop for the United States. But, Mr. Nichol says, "It may be that Loblaw and Wal-Mart would want to work together in Canada" on a line similar to President's Choice.
He also suggests that the two might work together on putting Loblaw supermarkets next to Wal-Mart's Canadian stores. "That's really a 1-plus-1-equals-3 situation," he observed.
The fate of President's Choice, though, will no longer be in Mr. Nichol's hands. He has been president of Loblaw's International Merchants unit, which develops the private label products. But Loblaw announced recently that he is leaving to pursue other business interests. He remains on the board, however, of both Loblaw and Weston.
Loblaw said in a statement that he will become a consultant "specializing in the development of retailer-controlled brands around the world."
The 53-year-old executive said that after 20 years at Loblaw, "It would be interesting now to have the experience of being an entrepreneur." Among his future pursuits: a wine distribution company. He and his wife, Terri, own a vineyard in California's Napa Valley called Dave Nichol's Memories of Napa.
Any doubts about what private labels have done for Loblaw are dispelled by a look at share prices. Despite Canada's extended recession and the crimp on consumption from 11 percent unemployment, Loblaw's stock has more than doubled since 1989 on the Toronto Stock Exchange, reflecting steady growth in sales and earnings.
For the nine months ended Oct. 9, its latest reporting period, Loblaw earned (in Canadian currency) $67.3 million, or 76 cents a share, on revenues of $7.17 billion, compared with $51 million, or 55 cents a share, on revenues of $6.87 billion in the 1992 period.
Mr. Nichol's work at Loblaw has spawned inevitable imitators. The upscale house labels of other big supermarket chains include Safeway Select and A.& P.'s Master's Choice. Kroger uses the Kroger name.
Although it will take a long time for any of them to catch up to where President's Choice is today, big store wars loom. Mr. Nichol confidently predicts that within 10 years private labels will account for 40 percent of the food market in North America, up from 18 percent today.
"Retailer-created and -controlled brands are the most efficient way of delivering a product to the North American consumer," he says with missionary fire.
Although many brand name manufacturers, like Heinz and Campbell, use some of their capacity for private labels, all face tougher battles for shelf space.
"Those that are No. 3 and 4 on the shelf have a lot to worry about," says Stephen A. Greyser, professor of consumer marketing at the Harvard Business School. The "core implication" of the trend, he adds, is that "national manufacturers must work harder to add value to their brands."
Some brand leaders are already reacting. Procter & Gamble has a telephone network advising customers how to use its brands more effectively and has switched from sales promotions and coupons to "everyday low prices" to avoid big price swings and make production costs more consistent.
"Once a national brand provides more value," said Robert Kincaide, managing director of the Hazelton Group, a marketing firm with offices in Toronto and Greenwich, Conn., "the private-label merchants will have a tougher time, too."
AS for the man who fired the revolution, at one time he wanted to be a law professor. But after Mr. Nichol earned a law degree from Harvard, he was immediately recruited by McKinsey & Company, where he spent three years helping companies like Heinz turn around some divisions.
Earlier, as an undergraduate at the University of Western Ontario, he had met W. Galen Weston, the grandson of George Weston, who in 1882 established the Toronto bakery that became the base of the Weston empire. After Mr. Nichol's tour with McKinsey, Mr. Weston invited him to join Loblaw and help turn it around.
Mr. Nichol actually developed two private-label lines, the upscale President's Choice and No Name, whose quality is said to be on a par with national brands but is priced 20 to 30 percent lower.
Loblaw came out with No Name in 1978 and now sells 2,000 products under that label, mainly through its No Frills chain in Canada. No Name products are not distributed in the United States, but it and President's Choice's 1,000 products together racked up sales of $2 billion (Canadian) last year, or nearly a quarter of Loblaw's total sales.
President's Choice was born in 1984 and landed running with Decadent chocolate chip cookies.
Nabisco's dominant Chips Ahoy had 24 percent chocolate chips and used vegetable oil. Mr. Nichol, who says he is "food-obsessed," took the Decadent to 40 percent chips, used 100 percent butter -- and sold the cookies for less than Chips Ahoy.
Although the Decadent was being sold in the mid-1980's in only 17 percent of the stores in Canada, compared with 98 percent for Chips Ahoy, it fast became Canada's best-selling cookie.
"When that penny dropped," says Mr. Nichol, "we realized what kind of potential we had." Now, the Decadent is also in the United States.
 
 
 
JUST THE FACTS ON FOOD? NOT LIKELY
 A MIX of Mad Magazine and Consumer Reports, zaniness and food tips, wrapped up in a comic book format -- that's the offbeat way that Loblaw's pitchman, Dave Nichol, romances his President's Choice customers.
"Grapes as big as golf balls," $1.49 a pound, notes one shopping suggestion in the latest issue, next to a golfer whose swing at the tee has just gone "SPLAT!" To promote deep-dish meat pies, an elephant is on a stew pot. Recipe: "Cut elephant into bite-size pieces. This should take approximately two months."
Insider's Report, as it is called, has been coming out quarterly for 10 years, stuffed into newspapers as special advertising supplements and into the racks at thousands of checkout counters.
A few years ago the print run was 7 million. Now, with expansion into the United States, it's up to 10 million, making this probably the most widely distributed food publication in the world. Georgie Girl, one of Mr. Nichol's French bulldogs, appeared on the cover with him on every issue until last summer, when she died at age 12. Now he's shown with her bronze statue.
Combined with his appearances on Loblaw's television commercials, Insider's Report has made Mr. Nichol a widely recognized Canadian personality. A Toronto Sun cartoon captures some of the flavor. A woman is watching the evening news, saying to herself: "Why can't they just let Quebec be distinct, dump the Senate, lower the G.S.T. [Goods and Services Tax], end the recession, and let Dave Nichol run the country."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Big Rewards Abroad, and Big Risks

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
BILLIONS of mutual fund dollars are flying across the Atlantic and Pacific in search of better returns, and investors have profited handsomely. International stock funds gained 38.3 percent, on average, in 1993, compared with 12.6 percent for domestic stock funds.
This red-hot performance, though, may be blinding investors to some awfully big risks. Because when foreign markets fall, the drops are often as sharp as the gains. 
 Much of this can be traced to the volatility of foreign economies, but the sheer volume of outside money cannot be ignored. With mutual fund companies urging investors to move overseas, total assets of international funds rocketed from $22.4 billion to $110 billion during 1993, said Robert Adler, president of AMG Data Services, an Arcata, Calif., company that tracks mutual fund money.
This volume has pushed the markets to artificially high levels, said Richard Schmidt, a money manager and editor of The Risk Report, in Naples, Fla., who is warning clients and subscribers to get out of foreign stocks and mutual funds.
When investments "start becoming the rage," he said, "it's a signal to sell."
Investors got a taste of the risks abroad when the overheated Hong Kong stock exchange lost 10 percent of its value last month. Shareholders yanked nearly $2 billion out of Asia-Pacific Rim funds, the first time in more than a year that the funds showed a net outflow, according to AMG Data.
There's also a lesson in Japan, whose stock market roared through the 1980's so forcefully that the Merrill Lynch Pacific Fund took second place among all funds for the 10 years ending in both 1989 and 1990.
But when the Tokyo market crashed later in 1990, Capstone Nikko Japan, the purest play on the region, lost 37 percent. Even a conservative fund like Scudder Japan lost more than 16 percent in 1990, according to Morningstar Inc., fund researchers in Chicago.
With that in mind, and so many regions showing such terrific gains, investors should probably brace for losses.
One risk factor is a lack of liquidity, Mr. Schmidt says. While more than half of Americans participate in the domestic equity markets, the numbers are far smaller overseas. The lack of liquidity that helped propel the markets upward will push them down, too.
Mr. Schmidt also worries about the lack of information about many overseas issues, which will exacerbate selling pressure.
To be sure, not all investment advisers are so gloomy. The huge number of dollars flowing abroad cannot be considered speculative, said Mark W. Headley, director of international investments for Litman/Gregory, investment advisers in San Francisco.
"When you look at all the money flooding out the door last year, it was just the beginning to pull U.S. equity investing up to an appropriate level," Mr. Headley said.
Looking ahead, "international markets don't have as compelling price differentials as they had because of last year's strong performance, but there are still so many good investing stories," he said.
Among other positive factors, he cites falling interest rates in Europe and Japan; the ongoing restructuring in Europe, Japan and Latin America as controlled economies are replaced with free market ones; and tremendous growth in Asia. Fund investors should participate in all these markets, Mr. Headley said, allocating 10 to 50 percent of equity portfolios overseas, depending on how comfortable they are with the risk and how long they plan to hold shares..
He advises commitments of at least three and preferably five years, "because you get shocks that don't hit the U.S. markets, like the oil scare around Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990 that caused 30 percent drops in the Asian markets."
He does concede the danger that individual investors may pull money out at the first signs of trouble, causing volatility, especially in smaller markets. But that should be balanced by the huge amounts of pension money flowing abroad; that trend, which began a few years ago, is gaining momentum, he said.
Mr. Headley says Japan is a "tough call," and advises only minor exposure there. He likes Warburg Pincus International, a diversified fund with only 25 percent of its portfolio invested in Japan.
In other areas abroad, Mr. Headley likes Europe, which is just starting to come out of recession. Because small-capitalization stocks are cheaper than large ones there, he recommends Tweedy Browne Global Value, which is 90 percent invested in small European stocks.
While he admits that the emerging markets are expensive today, "they are still the best long-term growth story available." Right now he prefers Latin America over Asia, because Asian markets may tumble in the next 6 to 12 months, he said.
To reduce risk, stay with diversifed emerging markets funds, Mr. Headley said. He likes Templeton Developing Markets Trust, which has the longest track record in the region, though it carries a 5.75 percent sales charge. Among no-loads, he prefers the Montgomery and Fidelity Emerging Markets Funds.
Norman Fosback, editor of the Mutual Fund Forecaster in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., also says diversification is the best bet for most American investors. He recommends 20th Century International Equity and Fidelity International Growth-and-Income.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5; Column 1; Week in Review Desk
