HEADLINE: Coke Wars

BYLINE: By Brent Staples; Brent Staples writes editorials on politics and culture for The New York Times. His memoir, "Parallel Time: Growing Up in Black and White," will be published this month.

 BODY:

COCAINE TRUE COCAINE BLUE
Photographs and text by Eugene Richards.
Additional reporting by Edward Barnes.
Illustrated. 153 pp. New York:
Aperture. $40. 
 ON June 2, 1884, Sigmund Freud sent what was for him a salacious letter to his fiancee, Martha Bernays. "Woe to you, my Princess, when I come," he wrote. "I will kiss you quite red and feed you till you are plump. And if you are froward, you shall see who is the stronger, a gentle little girl who doesn't eat enough or a big wild man who has cocaine in his body."
Freud was 28 years old, in love with Martha and under the spell of cocaine. His first scientific paper, "Uber Coca" ("About Cocaine"), also published in 1884, gushed about the drug as if it were fire stolen from the gods. Cocaine, Freud said, was good for all that ailed us, including fatigue, asthma, indigestion, emaciation, morphine addiction, alcoholism, depression, autism and especially lack of sexual appetite. When a rival psychiatrist described cocaine as the "third scourge of mankind" (morphine and alcohol being scourges No. 1 and 2), Freud leapt to his baby's defense, vigorously denying that the drug was dangerous or habit-forming.
Freud was wrong. Cocaine, particularly the smokable form, crack, offers one of the most dangerous addictions known to man: heart attacks, stroke, seizures and arrhythmia are common. Long-term use leads to cocaine psychosis, a bizarre state of being in which body and mind are rapidly destroyed. Cocaine psychotics get horrendous sores from picking at the imaginary insects they feel beneath their skins and may even poison themselves by spraying their wounds with bug killer. Cocaine psychotics are also acutely paranoid, obsessed with the idea that they are being watched and plotted against. Heroin addicts do us the favor of nodding off to sleep; cocaine psychotics are hyperactive beyond control. Even weekend binges have ominous effects on brain chemistry. The afterword to "Cocaine True Cocaine Blue" tells us that a quarter of those who die in traffic accidents in New York City have used cocaine within 48 hours of death. Those who killed themselves with guns are said to be twice as likely to have used cocaine as those who killed themselves by other means.
The view that cocaine was a harmless pick-me-up -- a candy for the nose -- dominated popular consciousness for nearly a century after "Uber Coca." As recently as 17 years ago, in a song about cocaine, the rock guitarist Eric Clapton repeated Freud's praises virtually unchanged: "If you got bad news, you wanna kick them blues, cocaine / When your day is done and you wanna run, cocaine / . . . If your thing is gone, and you wanna ride on, cocaine . . ./ She don't lie, she don't lie, she don't lie, cocaine." But that was 1977, before cheap, smokable and super-addictive crack invaded America's cities. By now Mr. Clapton's song seems almost grotesquely lighthearted.
America is dancing to the tune of cocaine. Prostitutes trade sex for it, drug warriors murder for it, and parents surrender homes and children for it. An entire generation is being sacrificed to it.
"Cocaine True Cocaine Blue," by the photographer and journalist Eugene Richards, is a record of the carnage as it is carried out in North Philadelphia, the East New York section of Brooklyn and the Red Hook housing project, also in Brooklyn. Mr. Richards studied with the photographer Minor White and went on to a distinguished career of his own. Like most of his kind, Mr. Richards is a voyeur, obsessed with the grisly. He is a master of the brutal image, though his is a cold, distant brutality that whispers instead of shouting. Though he is primarily a photographer, his works cannot be called picture books. He arranges his images to make what amount to visual novels, which he augments with pungent stretches of reflection, dialogue or description.
Notable among his accomplishments is "Exploding Into Life," a book that documents the mastectomy and eventual death by cancer of his lover, Dorothea Lynch. But the book on which his reputation rests -- and in
which his taste for the grisly is most clearly seen -- is "The Knife and Gun Club," a record of a tour of duty in a Denver emergency room. He first visited it on assignment for a magazine. "I saw cuts, burns, broken limbs, heart attacks, and then, what's inside the human body," he writes. "When a man's chest was cracked, I saw his heart floating in the pool of blood like a drowned puppy." One suspects that the "drowned puppy" seduced him. His assignment completed, he stayed on taking pictures until the hospital's management asked him to leave. If they had let him, he'd probably have stayed forever.
"Cocaine True Cocaine Blue" takes its title from the popular notion that cocaine brings with it a transcendent reality. The book jacket shows a close-up of a woman named Mariella, a wild-eyed addict clenching a hypodermic needle between partly toothless jaws. Take note of the needle; it could well be one of those that Mr. Richards says he bought Mariella because the ones she owned were too dull for proper use. Note also that Mr. Richards smoked his share of crack to get a feel for the subject.
The pictures in the book show Mariella's fellow addicts in various states of depravity, shooting up cocaine or smoking it on rooftops and in basement drug dens. The most lurid one shows a prostitute preparing to perform fellatio, presumably for crack money, while her toddler clings to her back. (Fortuitously or by plan, the scene of "The John, the Mother and the Child" is bracketed by pictures of Malcolm X and Martin Luther King Jr. on the wall behind them.) Riding herd over the dissolute, the dead and the dying are young men with guns who run the street trade and who are themselves on the fast track, bound for the grave.
THE photographs are sensational enough, but the only thing that's new in them is crack. For 30 years, Americans have been treated to pictures of addicts shooting up, of young men wielding guns, of prostitutes plying their trade, nearly always with black folks as the subjects. What makes this book stunning is the text that attends the pictures. Mr. Richards and the reporter Edward Barnes do an extraordinary job of bringing us what the camera cannot. The voices of the addicts and their families come through in high fidelity; the narrative is icy and clear. The methodical accretion of detail reminds one of the lawyerly poet Charles Reznikoff.
No photograph could match this scene of the crack den: "Their basement apartment resembled a military bunker or a bomb shelter. There were no windows. The entryway was seven steep, narrow stairs below the sidewalk. . . . You stepped down through a storm door, then a second sturdier door into a kitchen, which was airless and dark, lit only by a trembling, dying fluorescent tube. Almost every night the users who huddled there created piles of litter, burnt matches, bloody cotton balls, scraps of toilet paper, bent needles. This morning, because it was still early, the table was swept clean."
Listen to Rita, who cares for her grandchildren because their mother, Joyce, is lost in crack: "I cry. I walk the floor. I cry. Joyce is gone . . . this generation is gone. . . . There is no more neighborhood here. I don't do coke, but now I dance to the music of drugs too. My grandkids, I tell them I sell weed. 'It's not the right thing to do, but Grandma has to take care of you, because the welfare check will not.' I explain this is how they get to private school, to keep them out the public school. It costs me $1,780 a year to get my grandson into a Christian private school. Same thing with my granddaughter.
"So who's left out here on the streets with me? My grandmother used to have a saying that when hell full up, the dead will walk the earth. We're seein' it now. They are the dead. Look at 'em."
Here's the last word from an addict named Joe: "What keeps you from dying is you run out of money."
Reading and looking, I couldn't help wonder: why are nearly all of the people in these photographs black? The vast majority of drug addicts in America are white. This could be said of any phenomenon in the United States, of course, but why is the white aspect of drug addiction so consistently invisible?
The drugs that flood impoverished neighborhoods certainly don't originate there. Where are the faces of those who import them, the well-to-do chemists who earn piles of money by turning out the product? Couldn't Mr. Richards have found a setting where most or at least half of the drug addicts were white? The Hartford Courant did, in "Streets of Despair," its series two years ago about drug addiction in its city. Courant staff members say that readers were surprised to see that 70 percent of the addicts depicted were white. Bombarded for years with images of black depravity, they had come to believe that drug addiction was a black problem exclusively.
I'm not alone in wondering why nearly all Mr. Richards's addicts are black. African-Americans in New York were incensed when some of these pictures appeared in December in the pages of The New York Times Magazine. A small demonstration was staged at The Times's door.
The book's afterword anticipates the criticism, but the attempt to dismiss it fails: Dr. Stephen W. Nicholas, an AIDS specialist at Harlem Hospital in New York, urges readers not to accuse Mr. Richards of "reinforcing negative images of the urban poor" or discounting the effects of joblessness and economic decline. Dr. Nicholas suggests that the photographs force us to "understand something about the degenerative relationship between drug addiction and poverty." But that's impossible. Photographs can shock and dismay, but are useless to explain such complicated matters as economic decline.
Dr. Nicholas tells us that throughout America, about half of all men and women who are arrested have cocaine in their urine. Certainly drugs are a scourge in the African-American community. I am not asking for equal-opportunity representation of drug abuse. Nor am I saying that Mr. Richards should have written a different book. The point is larger than that. When the culture focuses on black addiction alone, we miss the breadth of the danger and confine the problem to "those people" over there.
"Cocaine True Cocaine Blue" will invariably be spoken of in Dantesque terms. But understand that the lowest reaches of hell are reserved, not for addicts, but for the tortured souls of drug traffickers. Not the two-bit dealers who pedal five-dollar bags until their heads get blown off, but the Colombian drug lords and Mafia princes who command murder, addiction and misery on a monstrous scale. The deepest reaches of hell in the 1990's would be home to the soul of the Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar Gaviria who, until his assassination last December, was one of the most successful cocaine producers in the world. Places next to Escobar would be held ready for law enforcement officials who were sworn to thwart the drug trade but abetted it instead.
"Cocaine True Cocaine Blue" is a powerful concoction. One of the things it shows is that pictures can't tell it all.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: THE HUB;
Police Academy Fades Away

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
The Koch administration announced it in early 1989 as the anchor of an ambitious plan to revitalize the South Bronx. The Dinkins administration delayed it, because of concerns about its cost.
Now, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has announced that the construction of a new eight-story police academy just southeast of Yankee Stadium at 153d Street and Park Avenue will be scrapped altogether to help close the city's $2.3 billion budget gap. 
 The decision, included in the Mayor's preliminary financial plan unveiled last week, surprised many Bronx officials who had counted on the $247 million project for years, not only to create as many as 400 construction jobs but also to foster a new law-and-order image for the bustling commercial area known as the Hub.
Borough President Fernando Ferrer said he first learned the project was in jeopardy on Jan. 28, when a reporter called to ask about rumors that Mr. Giuliani planned to table the project in favor of a $50 million renovation of the existing academy near Gramercy Park.
Cristyne Lategano, a spokeswoman for the Mayor, said it would have been impossible to call every office for which cuts were being planned. "When you get less than a month to put together a budget plan, not every category is going to be defined until maybe a day before the plan comes out," she said.
Mr. Ferrer said he and several business leaders did not plan to let the project go without a fight. "It's something the Bronx has waited very patiently for for several years," he said. "This was to be the Bronx's turn."
He cited the construction of the $1 billion Metrotech Center office complex in downtown Brooklyn and the 50-story Citicorp Tower in Long Island City, Queens.
"If you think about the price tags on all those projects," he said, "we were pikers by comparison."
The academy was to be built on the outskirts of an area that after more than 25 years of decline, is rebounding with new housing development that is, in turn, attracting new merchants and businesses.
Joseph Wuensch, the Police Department's deputy commissioner for management and budget, said he was disappointed that the academy would have to make do with its present building, which is overcrowded.
"But we're pragmatists," Mr. Wuensch said. "We understand the nature and severity of the reductions. If the city came back and said, 'We have additional resources. What would you recommend?' I'll tell you that a new building is No. 1 on our list."
Richard A. Kahan, chairman of the steering committee for the Bronx Center, a major redevelopment plan in the South Bronx that includes more than 2,000 new units of mixed-income housing, said he believed that the academy would eventually be built.
"This is something that has survived two administrations," Mr. Kahan said. "We're going to make every effort humanly possible to convince the Mayor not to do this. It's that critical, not just to the Bronx but to the city of New York." RANDY KENNEDY

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: THE HUB;
A Multicultural Marketplace With Health Care Upstairs

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
Hoping to build on a nascent increase in housing and commerce in the bleak neighborhood surrounding the Hub, city officials have given a development company conditional approval for an international marketplace at 149th Street between Brook and Bergen Avenues.
Envisioned as the centerpiece of a plan to transform 100,000 square feet of city-owned lots that have been vacant since the late 1970's, the marketplace would be a two-story building with restaurants, food stores and kiosks on the ground floor and a walk-in health clinic above, said one of the developers, Daniel Gerard. 
 Mr. Gerard, who is also involved in a commercial redevelopment project in Bushwick, Brooklyn, that is scheduled to get under way in the fall, said he and three other builders had been watching the Hub with interest for years.
"It's an area that looks kind of daunting to some people, especially to some retailers," he said. "It still has such a stigma attached to it. But frankly, we think the South Bronx has been coming back. It's just a great time to get involved."
Conditional approval means that the developers will be in negotiations with the city's Economic Development Corporation for several more months about the final shape of the marketplace. The developers have also just begun to try to attract merchants to the site.
But Mr. Gerard and another partner, Jeffrey Stern, who is also involved in the Bushwick project, said their initial plans were in keeping with what the city wants -- a sleek, interior mall on the triangular 56,000 square-foot lot, with businesses representative of the neighborhood's diverse culture.
"Right now, we're thinking about Caribbean food, Haitian, Jamaican, Afghani," Mr. Gerard said. "The possibilities are quite exciting." R.K.

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Debates Quake Aid for Illegal Aliens

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5

 BODY:
As the city struggles to pull itself together after last month's earthquake, its social fissures have re-emerged in an angry debate over whether relief aid should be provided to illegal immigrants.
Coming on the heels of a proposal by Gov. Pete Wilson to deny health and education benefits to undocumented aliens as one way to cope with the state's lingering economic slump, advocates for immigrants are complaining that these residents are again being made scapegoats for widespread hardships in a time of trouble. 
 But such restrictions are receiving considerable public and political support in a time of economic distress and tight budgets. In Washington, the House Appropriations Committee passed a measure that would permit emergency relief to illegal immigrants, but would also deny them 18-month housing vouchers being issued by the Department of Housing and Urban Development and other long-term aid.
 
Conflicting Feelings
 "My heart goes out to them, and I'm not in any way trying to bash them," said Representative Ron Packard, Republican of California, who sponsored the amendment. "But when it comes to the spending of taxpayers' dollars, I cannot turn my head and treat undocumented aliens like citizens."
The Census Bureau has estimated that there are about 1.3 million illegal immigrants in California, most of them from Mexico, and in recent months Democrats and Republicans have spoken out for curbs on their continued entry. The two Democratic Senators, Diane Feinstein and Barbara Boxer, have offered proposals to tighten controls on the porous, 2,000-mile border.
Supporting the thrust of the amendment to the aid bill, Senator Feinstein said, "I'm one who believes that emergency help such as food and clothing should be provided to all victims, but that Section 8 vouchers, with a rent subsidy for 18 months, and small-business loans and grants, should be reserved for legal residents."
Opponents of such restrictions say they may be largely symbolic, since illegal immigrants are not eligible for Small Business Administration loans and considerable documentation is already needed for the housing vouchers. They say there is no straightforward way to check on legal residence and that efforts to do so will create a bureaucratic bottleneck.
 
An Ugly Symbol
 And as a symbolic act, they say, the message of the restrictions is ugly, painting a nation that has been generous with disaster aid around the world as petty and miserly when people within its own borders are in need.
"What kind of message does it send when we're trying to segregate earthquake victims?" asked City Councilman Richard Alarcon, a Democrat. Charles Wheeler, the directing attorney of the National Immigration Law Center, said the notion of imposing controls in the midst of a disaster was fraught with technical problems.
For one, there is the question of how to treat the many undocumented residents whose American-born children are citizens. Mr. Wheeler said immigration requirements might frighten many illegal aliens away from applying for emergency assistance.
Even Republican city officials, who are dealing with the day-to-day hardships wrought by the earthquake, oppose the requirements because of the added problems they would create.
 
'Bureaucratic Nightmare'
 Noting the nation's continuing difficulties with trying to control illegal immigration, Mayor Richard J. Riordan, a Republican, said in a letter opposing earthquake-aid restrictions that the restrictions would create a "bureaucratic nightmare" for Federal, state and local agencies, as well as for the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
Laura Chick, a Republican City Councilwoman from one of the hardest-hit areas in the San Fernando Valley, said that while she favored controls on immigration there was "no system in place today to allow for people to be identified as legal citizens."
"It's a process that has to be put in place, but a disaster is not the time to do it," she said.
 
Debate in the Lines
 The debate over assistance was similarly lively in the long lines awaiting disaster relief.
"We all work hard, but now they don't want to give us anything," said Maria Elena Sauledo, a 22-year-old illegal immigrant from Mexico who shared a government shelter with 19 other relatives. The men of the family work in gardening and landscaping, while the women sew clothing part-time for garment factories. "We are all human beings," she said, as her mother-in-law cradled Mrs. Sauledo's infant, an American citizen. "We all have rights. Everybody needs help."
Laura Bahena, an illegal immigrant who said she had moved here after a 1985 earthquake that devastated parts of Mexico City, called the talk of restrictions racist. "The earthquake did not ask for paperwork," she said.
But Phyllis Holliman, 23, who is unemployed and now homeless after the earthquake, voiced what seemed to be the prevailing sentiment as she waited for food. "L.A. is just too overcrowded," she said. "I know it's hard where they come from, but they're making it hard for us. We can't get jobs."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 12, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about aid to illegal immigrants affected by the Los Angeles earthquake misstated the party affiliation of Laura Chick, a City Council member from the San Fernando Valley. She is a Democrat.

HEADLINE: North Korea's Huge Military Spurs New Strategy in South

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON with DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
While the world is focused on North Korea's program to develop nuclearweapons, an equally serious buildup in conventional troops and equipment in the North has prompted United States military commanders to overhaul their plans fordefending South Korea.
 Over the last year, North Korea has used its huge array of artillery andtroops near the heavily fortified border to try to intimidate the United States and its Asian allies from dealing too sternly with it on its nuclear weaponsplans. 
As recently as Thursday, the state-run North Korean press agency issued one of its most explicit warnings, saying: "The United States must not miscalculate our will and determination nor underestimate our might. It had better behavewith discretion, knowing well our people and People's Army."
 
A Revised Approach
 Despite the bombast, American military commanders both in the Pacific and inWashington, say that the combination of the North's nuclear program,conventional arms buildup and concentration of forces close to Seoul and to the South's vital economic centers has made Pyongyang the paramount threat for thePentagon.
 "North Korea will be the critical, major military threat for the next fewyears," said Lieut. Gen. James R. Clapper, the head of the Defense Intelligence Agency.
 That threat, and other military and political developments, have led Americancommanders to revise their approach in the event of a North Korean attack on theSouth.
 Rather than simply driving the North's troops from South Korea, the new plan provides for a fierce counteroffensive intended to seize the North's capital,Pyongyang, and try to topple the Government of Kim Il Sung, American officialssaid.
 The Administration has also confirmed it is planning to send Patriotantimissile systems to help protect South Korean airfields and ports from North Korean missiles. The commander of American forces in Korea, Gen. Gary E. Luck,has requested still other steps in the event that the negotiations overinspections of the North's nuclear sites break down and Washington and itsallies impose economic sanctions. The North has said it would consider sanctionsan "act of war."
 
Diplomatic Initiative Urged
 Even if the nuclear issue were settled and the immediate crisis defused, thethreat to the South would remain.
 Reflecting this concern, the Pentagon is pressing for a new diplomaticinitiative to persuade Pyongyang to move its artillery and forces back from the front lines in exchange for diplomatic recognition.
 But despite Washington's planning, the steadily expanding threat has led to abroad debate over whether the Clinton Administration is being forceful enoughwith the North Koreans and is taking adequate military precautions.
 Brent Scowcroft, who was national security adviser to President George Bush, said he thought that Washington should consider moving an aircraft carrier tothe region and deploying more Air Force fighter planes there.
 "I would be ostentatiously strengthening my position," he said.
 
The North's Power
Allied Forces Outnumbered 2 to 1
 Like the balance of Western and Warsaw Pact forces in the cold war, thedeployments on both sides of the Korean divide have as much political asmilitary significance.
 Much of the North Korean force consists of aging weapons, but with a strengthof 1.2 million, the North Korean military is enormous and outnumbers the allied forces in South Korea by about two to one.
 In recent months, North Korea has taken steps to camouflage the planes itwould use to drop commandos behind American and South Korean lines in a war and has increased to 47 from 5 the number of antiaircraft guns around its Yongbyong nuclear installation.
 The North, which already has Scud and Frog missiles, is also trying to expandits missile power. Last May, it tested its new medium-range Rodong missile offthe Japanese coast. The Rodong is intended to have the ability to strike westernJapan. According to intelligence reports, the North Koreans may also be tryingto develop an even larger missile with a range of 1,800 miles, although theevidence is fragmentary.
 
On the South's Doorstep
 More important, over the last several years the North has positioned much ofits striking power virtually on South Korea's doorstep. According to intelligence officials, North Korea has stationed more than 8,400 artillery pieces and 2,400 multiple rocket launchers within 60 miles of the border. The demilitarized zone is marked by minefields, tank traps and observation posts, and much of the artillery is so close to the zone that Seoul, which is about 30 miles from the border, is within firing range. A recent visit to the heavily guarded border evoked memories of some of the toughest fighting the American military has ever faced.
 The North Korean military has its weaknesses. Some Pentagon officials say that fuel shortages have limited large-scale training, and they question whether North Korean commanders could effectively coordinate such an attack in the face of allied air superiority.
 The United States has stationed five advanced radar tracking systems in South Korea to pinpoint North Korean artillery fire and would also use spotter planes to direct air strikes.
 Still, because so much of the North's artillery and other forces are already close to the border, American and South Korean forces might have as little as 24 to 76 hours warning of an attack, an American military official said.
 The American high command says that in the event of a war, the North Korean military strategy would be to thrust deep into South Korea in an attempt to seize the entire peninsula before reinforcements arrived.
 
20 Tunnels Believed Built
 Along the demilitarized zone, North Korea's artillery would fire a barrage to dislodge the defenders and sow confusion and panic in Seoul in the hope that refugees would clog the roads and prevent allied reinforcements from reaching the front.
 As the bombardment continued, infiltrators would try to sneak through the 20-odd tunnels the North is believed to have dug beneath the demilitarized zone, some of which have been discovered and sealed in recent years. Infantry units would try to create gaps in the defense. Then armored forces would try to burst through the American and South Korean defenses.
 Meanwhile, North Korea would try to place commando units in the rear areas of the South in helicopters, small boats and the North's fleet of mini-submarines, and fire missiles at airfields and ports that the United States would use to reinforce its troops. American intelligence estimates that the North has almost 100,000 special forces.
 "This is a front-loaded attack plan organized to propel the invasion into the heart of the Republic of Korea," Gen. Robert W. RisCassi, the former commander of American and South Korean forces, said of the North's battle plan.
 
The South's Defenses
Vital Areas Face Devastating Attack
 Preparations to foil a North Korean attack are part of everyday life in South Korea. Specially designed concrete overpasses span critical highways. If the North launched an offensive, the South Koreans would set off explosives to collapse the overpasses so that huge chunks of concrete would block the attack routes. Other stretches of highway have been cleared of dividers and posts so that they can be used as runways by allied planes.
 While the ability to repel a North Korean attack has been a matter of considerable debate within the Pentagon, the dominant view is that it would only be a matter of time before an invading North Korean Army would be routed in the face of more superior allied forces.
 But it would be virtually impossible to prevent North Korea from destroying much of the heavily populated and economically vital South Korean territory near the border, senior American officials say.
 A ranking Pentagon official said war games indicated that a war would inflict hundreds of thousands of casualties on each side, not including civilians, and would probably last three to four months.
 "You are talking about a very bloody, largely ground war," he said.
 Nonetheless, the American military has sought to improve its ability to deter an attack and limit the damage if one should occur.
 
New Army Doctrine
 Developed by General RisCassi and refined by his successor, General Luck, the American military's new plan for the defense of South Korea reflects some important changes.
 Drawing on the experience of the Persian Gulf war, in which the United States sent in its best armored and air units instead of husbanding them in case trouble broke out elsewhere, the military has revised the list of reinforcements.
 The timely dispatch of reinforcements would be critical since the United States has only about 35,000 troops in Korea. Only one of the three Air Force squadrons there is equipped with a special targeting pod that allows pilots to fight effectively at night and to deliver laser-guided "smart" bombs.
 The plan also embodies the new Army doctrine, which emphasizes aggressive counteroffensives instead of static defenses. Under the five-phase plan, the American and South Korean force would try to slow Pyongyang's ground assault north of Seoul, buy time while reinforcements pour in, and then repulse the invaders. But the major change is in the next step of the contingency plan: American and South Korean forces would cross into North Korea after beating back the North's forces and occupy Pyongyang.
 "It would be unconscionable if there was not some penalty for starting a war," a senior American officer said. "The aggressor should not be able to get off scot-free in the sense of loss of territory."
 In developing the plan, American officials studied the Korean War, where Gen. Douglas MacArthur's march to the Yalu River induced the Chinese to intervene in the fighting. But planners concluded that American-Chinese relations had improved so much since then, and North Korean relations with China had so soured, that Beijing would not intervene now.
 
A Go-Slow Approach
 Still, with an eye to Chinese sensitivities, the Pentagon has not decided whether American forces should go much farther north than Pyongyang or whether the allies would pursue if the Government fled toward the Yalu, asenior Administration official said.
 President Clinton met with Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and the departing Secretary of Defense Les Aspin to discuss Korea. A senior official said the new plan was not the main order of business but was discussed. The United States, however, is only one part of the equation.
 South Korea, which has 655,000 troops, has advocated a go-slow approach on the nuclear issue, hoping to avoid a military confrontation. But if a war broke out it would be so devastating that the South Koreans would be unlikely to settle for the restoration of lost territory, Western diplomats say.
 "Whether American forces crossed the border or not is irrelevant," a senior Western diplomat in Seoul said. "The fact is that there would be no stopping the South Koreans."
 
The U.S. Role
Is Administration Doing Enough?
 The immediate issue is not whether war would damage the South, but whether the Clinton Administration is making adequate military preparations to dissuade the North from attacking and to defeat it if it does.
 Reflecting the Administration's caution, Adm. Charles Larson, the commander of American forces in the Pacific, said Washington should move deliberately to strengthen its military forces if sanctions were imposed.
 "You get into a fine balance that certain things you could do could also be provocative," Admiral Larson said in an interview at his headquarters in Hawaii.
 "So it would be very important to raise our levels of readiness and, by and large, have most of it be in the benign category," he added. "Where we go from there depends on their reaction."
 
Bigger Intelligence Effort
 After some delay, the White House has agreed in principle to a request from General Luck to dispatch Patriot antimissile systems to South Korea, but it has yet to send them.
 The United States has also increased intelligence efforts and is following through with earlier plans to dispatch Apache attack helicopters and a new Army surface-to-surface missile to South Korea. According to a senior Pentagon official, some new types of munitions have been quietly moved into the region in recent months.
 General Luck has also requested other military steps in the event that the Administration seeks economic sanctions.
 Publicly, the Clinton Administration has not ruled out a preemptive attack on North Korea's nuclear installations. But fearful of the North Korean ability to destroy Seoul, and with no firm intelligence on where Pyongyang may have hidden a bomb, senior Pentagon officials maintain such a raid would be fraught with risk.
 But outside the Clinton Administration there is considerable debate about Washington's approach. Some former Bush Administration officials assert that Washington is right to offer North Korea economic and political benefits for giving up its nuclear program but argue that the Clinton Administration should be taking more military steps to strengthen the United States hand in the negotiations, protect American forces against an attack and keep open the option of a preemptive attack against the North's nuclear installations, a move they say would prevent the North from producing more plutonium for nuclear bombs.
 As tense as the situation is now, it will become worse if it becomes clear that the North has developed nuclear weapons, as most American intelligence agencies believe.
 "Everybody says we might do something that makes them attack. But we should not behave in a way that signals to the North Koreans that we are afraid of our own shadow," Mr. Scowcroft said. "If the situation is serious enough that they are contemplating an attack, it is better that we find that out before, rather than after, they have nuclear weapons."

HEADLINE: Nuclear Roots Grow Into an Argentine Silicon Valley

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH

DATELINE: LLAO LLAO, Argentina

 BODY:
TUCKED into a dense stand of evergreens, a group of low, whitewashed buildings with corrugated metal roofs give little indication of the activities within. Maybe a conservation group. Maybe a national park office. The only clue is the parabolic dish on top of a red-and-white radio tower.
But inside the shaded compound, an elite team of Argentina's electronic and nuclear engineers are working, not exactly secretively, but with a very low profile. In newly built "clean rooms," their primary project is a $7 million research satellite for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration of the United States, to be launched in mid-1995. 
 Some 15 miles east, in the city of Bariloche, inside a two-story sandstone-colored building that looks like a home, computer programmers are working on robotics and software for just-in-time manufacturing, as well as designing small but highly advanced nuclear reactors. There are no signs outside the structure to indicate the advanced work within.
These are the offices of Invap S.E., Argentina's tiny version of a Silicon Valley company. It has 300 employees and sales of no more than $40 million a year. Its shareholders are the provincial Government of Rio Negro and the Argentine Government through the National Atomic Energy Commission.
Though tiny compared with leading international high-tech companies, Invap has found that in certain market niches -- like building small research reactors -- it can compete with international giants like General Atomics of San Diego and Babcock & Wilcox of New Orleans.
The project with NASA, the first time a satellite has been built in Argentina, is providing training for Argentine engineers and transfers of American technology that would have been impossible just four years ago, because Argentina was considered a threat to nuclear proliferation.
"We are mainly nuclear engineers and physicists, and what the people from NASA told us was that they were surprised how quickly our engineers switched into space technology," said Hector E. Otheguy, general and technical manager of Invap. "Though small, we find that at least in some areas we can compete."
In the first part of this century, Argentina was among the world's richest nations, yet today it has only a tiny home-grown technological capacity. Its failure to keep up is sobering testimony to decades of intense nationalism, isolation from the industrialized world and association with often unstable third-world governments. Argentina developed its own reactor technology -- and thus the potential to build an atomic bomb -- as far back as the 1960's, through its atomic research center in Bariloche. But from the start it refused to let international monitoring agencies inspect its operations.
Successive Governments argued that permitting international controls was the equivalent of giving the industrialized world the right to manipulate the nation's technological future and its growth.
In many ways, Invap was one of the main instruments for Argentina's nuclear program. Founded in the early 1970's by scientists from the atomic center to use the technology they had developed, Invap, under the guidance of the National Atomic Energy Commission, built small reactors for third-world countries like Algeria, Peru and Iran, as well as for the Argentine Government itself.
MOST of the work was done in almost total secrecy, including a uranium enrichment plant 40 miles east of Bariloche, begun in the early 1980's to supply Argentina's research reactors with fuel in case the international community cut off supplies. The plant, which has cost the Government $300 million, places Argentina among a select group of nine countries that have the capacity, at least in theory, to enrich uranium to a grade that nearly approaches that used in bombs.
Although its nuclear program was remarkably advanced compared with those of most third-world countries, Argentina found itself on a list of nations prohibited from receiving transfers of new computer and electronic technology. The prohibition stemmed from an effort to stop proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.
That has changed, however, under the Government of President Carlos Saul Menem, who has opened all of the country's nuclear operations to international controls and inspection, and renounced nuclear proliferation.
For Invap, it has meant drastic changes -- in particular, shedding its tradition of secrecy -- as well as a brush with near-bankruptcy two years ago.
IN the mid-1980's, Invap signed a contract with Iran to build a purification plant for enriched uranium. Under a second contract, a pilot plant was to be built that would produce fuel rods for Iranian research reactors.
In late 1991, when its first shipment of equipment was ready to leave port, the company received instructions from the Foreign Ministry -- at Washington's request -- to halt it. The reasoning was that Iran, though it had signed the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, was a potentially unreliable signatory that at any time could decide to develop nuclear weapons. Breaking the contracts meant a loss of $25 million in income.
"It was a blow for Invap, and we didn't know if we could recover from it," Thomas Buch, an official of the company, said. "We were shipping things we bought off the shelf -- tubing, valves, lathes -- and argued they in themselves did not contribute to proliferation. But the Foreign Ministry reasoned that anything that increased Iran's capacity to develop nuclear weapons should be stopped."
Since those bleak first months, the company seems to have more than recovered.
In addition to being given the contract with NASA, many say as American compensation for having broken the two Iranian contracts, it has won a $60 million deal to build a research reactor in Cairo and is on the short list of finalists for an even larger reactor for the Government of Thailand; two of its competitors for the Thai deal are General Atomics and Babcock & Wilcox.
In addition, informal talks are under way with General Atomics on joint ventures.
Invap is considering taking the design of its small-reactor technology even further. With Argentina's explosive economic growth over the last three years, and anticipation of continuing growth through much of the decade, the country's electrical power needs could almost double over the next decade.
While Invap does not pretend to build giant nuclear power stations with the capacity of 600 to 700 megawatts, it is working on designs for small plants in the 25-to-50-megawatt range. The smaller plants could be built in much less time -- about two years -- eventually using a type of assembly-line technique if enough were built. That would allow greater economies and enable nuclear power to compete in price with gas and hydroelectric plants.
Jorge Marticorena, former president of Invap, argues that not only do the smaller plants use simpler cooling technologies and are thus safer, but that Argentina would be using its large uranium reserves as well as its home-grown high-tech know-how.
"It cost us a lot politically and economically to get where we are, and it makes sense to use the technology we have developed here in Argentina," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 6, 1994, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Feb. 6 about Invap S.E. incorrectly described the company's relationship with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Invap is not building a satellite for NASA; it is building one with the help of NASA engineers for the Argentine Government. The article also mistakenly included Iran among countries for which Invap has built experimental nuclear reactors; it has built no such reactor for Iran. The article also described incorrectly the type of purification plant Invap built for Iran; the plant purifies uranium, not enriched uranium.

HEADLINE: 10 Men Put 300 Years at I.B.M. to Use

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
IS there life after I.B.M.? Yes, say 10 former I.B.M. executives who together have had almost 300 years of experience at International Business Machines. Now they have joined forces and built a business of their own.
Their business, Multinational Market Services Group, is a high-tech marketing-consulting concern in White Plains specializing in helping companies anticipate and manage market changes, said Stanley Freid, the 65-year-old founder of the group who during his 31 years at I.B.M. held positions ranging from international business manager to senior manager of direct marketing. 
 In explaining how the company came into being, Mr. Freid said the idea came to him when he was taking a course given by an outplacement company.
"The outplacement perk was part of my retirement package from I.B.M.," he said. "I took early retirement in 1988 but only after I agonized over it for three months. I felt I was too young and had too many good ideas to retire. But at the time, I.B.M. was offering us such a great financial package it was hard to resist it."
Mr. Freid said he began talking to other I.B.M. executives with extensive international experience, all of whom were in their 50's and 60's and were taking early retirement.
 
Traveling the World
 "When I queried everyone I knew in the same position as I was and found out all of them were planning to do something after retiring, I thought we could forge an innovative team," he said. "In the 31 years I spent at I.B.M., for instance, I had had 9 different careers. The others also had multiple careers. I.B.M. was a great college and training ground for all of us. We had a lot of autonomy. Yet, all of us were curious and anxious to test our theories and our skills in the real world."
One member of the group, Victor Wakefield, 67, a native of Britain, started his career with I.B.M. in his homeland in 1960, managing market research.
"I was asked to come to the United States in 1967," Mr. Wakefield recalled, "and since 1967, I had five different careers with I.B.M. -- in market research, new business opportunities -- and all of them in I.B.M.'s World Trade Corporation." He added that he traveled the world over for I.B.M., setting up international inventory management systems. "I made more than 50 lengthy trips abroad in 25 years, literally touring the Pacific Rim for weeks at a time. It really was a lot of fun, and fascinating, and I wasn't keen on retiring. But in 1988, I.B.M. made me such a good offer I felt I had to take it, and I took the package."
Mr. Wakefield said that at that point he and his wife, Celia, decided to go back to Britain.
"But when we got there, we found that Britain had changed, or maybe it was we who had changed," he said. "So we came back to Chappaqua and decided to become American citizens. I started examining a number of proposals. I felt I had amassed so much knowledge during my career with I.B.M. that I should really do something with it."
 
Experience and Flexibility
 One of the things Mr. Wakefield did was start a time-management business with his wife, designed to teach people how to achieve greater efficiency. Another was to go back as an outsider to I.B.M., to run a two-day seminar on international inventory management for sales executives.
"I gave the seminars a couple of times and what became clear to me is that in the wake of downsizing, corporations are going to call more and more on the service of outside consultants to replace managers that have gone," he said.
"So I liked Stan's concept from the beginning. As consultants, we are a large enough group to have in-depth experience and knowledge, and we are small enough to be flexible and move fast, which is very important in today's economic climate. Collectively, our track record covers successful projects in over 100 foreign companies as well as projects here in the United States, so we have a global perspective and a worldwide network of contacts at our disposal."
Very little capital was needed to establish the multinational group, Mr. Freid said. "We also added other professionals including my wife, Constance. Constance was formerly director of economic development for Westchester County, and she played a key role in forming the Westchester Business Partnership."
 
Sensing Customer Fickleness
 Emphasizing that helping clients build competitive strategies starts with the premise that everything begins by listening to the customer, Mr. Freid said, "Drawing on the experience of every member of our group, we developed a proprietary new marketing and management tool we call the Customer Intelligence System, and we use it to measure a business's bottom line by sensing and responding to change faster than the competition."
What makes the Customer Intelligence System different, he said, is its ability to analyze and monitor why customers change what they value and what they expect a company to provide in the future.
"The technique has been around for years," Mr. Freid said. "What we did that was different was to put it together in one package using advance computer models and analytical techniques, which enable us to collect, monitor and evaluate data that link customers' preferences with outside forces -- such as emerging technologies and economic trends -- that shape their values. What it actually is is a continuous surveillance system that generates market intelligence needed to make strategic business decisions."
Citing the experience of Reebok International, the athletic-shoe manufacturer, Mr. Freid said: "What happened was that in 1993, Reebok brought out a new sneaker they expected to be a winner. It was white, trimmed in blue, and the retail price was $130. But it didn't do well at all.
"Had Reebok the system we have designed, they would have been able to track styles and anticipate market changes and then react quickly by bringing out what had been a more successful seller, which was a black-on-black sneaker selling for under $100."
 
Joining the Client's Team
 Each member of the group has a specialty. Allen L. Morton, the former director of the I.B.M. Corporate Technical Institute and director of the I.B.M. Systems Research Institute, now focuses on strategic development and redesign of business processes.
"Technical advances can't take place in isolation," Mr. Morton said. "The role of communication and trust in building teams is essential to this process."
Project teams of four and five members work directly with clients.
"We will go into the client's officeand work there as if we were part of his company," Mr. Freid said. "Our client list is broad based, ranging from accounting firms, banks, publishers, to the Government of Turkey. We bill on a daily or project basis. Most assignments are for projects that can last from a couple of weeks to several months. They can cost anywhere from $10,000 to $100,000. At the end of the year, we deduct our fixed expenses and divide the profits among the members of the group."
One client, John F. Sitar, who is also a former I.B.M. executive, founded his company, Corstar, in Elmsford, 15 years ago. Corstar supplies computer hardware and software to industry. Mr. Sitar said he believes Multinational has the ability to put the finger on the pulse of changing values in the marketplace. "What they basically give us is an early-warning system, so that we can supply our Fortune 100 customers with the right business product."

HEADLINE: IN SHORT: FICTION

BYLINE: By David Murray 

 BODY:

WORLD WAR II NOVEL
LOVE AND INFAMY
By Frank Deford.
Viking, $24. 
 Cotton Drake, the son of missionaries who came to Japan in the years after World War I, grows up as a near-brother to a Japanese boy named Kiyoshi Serikawa. As adults, they resume their relationship, even though Kiyoshi works in an international shipping firm and Cotton has himself become a missionary. Then Kiyoshi, who has served in the company office in Honolulu, is recruited as an intelligence officer by Admiral Yamamoto, who is, without the Imperial Army's knowledge, planning an assault on the American fleet at Pearl Harbor. When Cotton learns about all this, he tries to convince American officials of the threat. Not surprisingly, the plot of "Love and Infamy" races ahead toward the inevitable conclusion, but in his sixth novel Frank Deford manages to keep the suspense going. He has a good story to tell, creates believable and complicated characters, and has done his research on the harrowing political and economic conditions of prewar Japan. And yet the reader begins to lose interest because Mr. Deford has most of his Japanese characters speaking in American slang, including all the more familiar and tiresome vulgarities and obscenities. It is extremely difficult to imagine Admiral Yamamoto, predicting after the Pearl Harbor raid that the war ahead will not be easy, saying, even in jest, "There's no such thing as a free lunch."
 DAVID MURRAY

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: A Time to Ponder Where Blacks Stand

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
LAST Sunday, Anni Moss the black singer and actress known to audiences by her first name -- kicked off Black History Month on the local weekly radio program Dreamsounds by playing "Stand for Something," a rap song recorded by the National Civil Rights Museum in Memphis. In choosing the song -- which invokes the names of black heroes like the slave leader Nat Turner and the educator Mary McLeod Bethune -- the WRTN-FM radio host sounded one of the keynote themes for the month of celebrations, lectures and workshops that began last week throughout the county.
 
A Continuing Struggle
 "Now more than ever, blacks need to take control of our destiny," said Anni (pronounced ah-NEE). "We have to take the initiative and not wait for others to call on us." 
 For many of the county's black residents, who, according to the 1990 census numbered 120,195 and represented about 13 percent of the total county poplulation of 874,866, the yearly celebration, which is being observed nationwide as well, has become a time to reflect on gains made and tasks that lie ahead. In interviews last week, black leaders in business, the arts and government voiced their concerns on the 25th anniversary of Black History Month in Westchester.
While they agreed that the achievements among well-educated middle- and upper-class blacks had been significant, they said that poor blacks continued to struggle.
Many of those interviewed cited the need for more economic opportunities for young adults and for outreach efforts by successful blacks to younger members of the community who needed role models to follow. They also spoke about the importance of better education in public schools in low-income black and Hispanic neighborhoods.
"It's like 'A Tale of Two Cities,' " said County Legislator Ernest D. Davis, a Democrat representing Mount Vernon. "Two-thirds of us have been able to make strides, but things are much worse for blacks on the bottom. Their attitudes have hardened, so for us as a group it continues to be a mixed bag.
"It is in our best interests to help, because if we don't, they will revisit us as wards of the municipalities and as faces of anger on the street."
Mr. Davis, chairman of the Legislation Committee and one of three black lawmakers on the County Board of Legislators, said that his agenda as a local government leader included aid for small minority-owned businesses, continued financing for early-intervention day care and Head Start programs and efforts to recruit "better teachers who believe that all children can learn."
 
Equal Education Still a Goal
 Yvonne D. Jones, president of the 1,000-member White Plains-Greenburgh chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said her organization was also concerned about equal education for all students.
"Certain civil rights gains have been secured," said Ms. Jones, referring to the Federal school desegregation lawsuit in Yonkers during the late 1980's. "But there continue to be pockets of blacks throughout the county, and as a result we still get some mostly white and mostly black schools. The quality of education is not even throughout."
Another Board member, Herman Keith, a Democrat from Yonkers and chairman of the Minority Affairs Committee, said his legislative agenda would include curriculum changes in higher education as well. For one, he is recommending that Westchester Community College institute courses in entrepreneurship to target young blacks who want to start businesses.
"If they become the rebuilders of our urban communities, they will be less likely to tear down those areas," said Mr. Keith, who represents low-income neighborhoods on the west side of Yonkers.
 
17 Organizations Represented
 Like other leaders interviewed, Mr. Keith said he was concerned about increased violence among many black youths and statistics that showed that far more blacks than whites spend time in jail.
In Mount Vernon, Mr. Davis said that with "so many Afro and Latino males behind bars, 11-year-old boys are becoming heads of families, and that cannot happen without dire consequences."
At the offices of the African American Federation of Westchester, the chairman, Fred Campbell, agreed that the economic and political strides made by many members of his race were being undermined by problems among poor blacks in the county -- including the growing number of the homeless.
"These problems represent serious setbacks for us," said Mr. Campbell, whose umbrella organization represents 17 groups, including local chapters of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
There are no statistics showing the racial breakdown in the county's homeless population because by law such figures cannot be tabulated, said Norman Shaw of the county's Department of Social Services.
But statistics from the County Office of Criminal Justice Services show that of 9,036 people in county jails in 1992, 37 percent were white and 59.5 percent were black.
And State Labor Department statistics show that throughout New York, the unemployment rate for blacks was 12.5 percent through the third quarter of last year compared with a 6.3 percent rate for whites.
"The economic hard times have exacerbated our problems and undermined our gains," Mr. Campbell said. "For one, many blacks have not had the time to accrue seniority, and the last hired have been the first fired."
 
Vowed to Help Others
 At the offices of the African American Men of Westchester, a 30-member service organization, Thomas L. Clark Jr. said his group was trying to address problems among poor blacks by providing strong role models for younger members of the community.
Mr. Clark, one of the founders of the organization and its current president, said members worked with youths through programs at local community centers. "We tell youngsters you have an alternative to deviant behavior, and you have a tremendous responsibility to your community," said Mr. Clark, who is deputy superintendent of banks and secretary to the Banking Board of the State Banking Department.
In New Rochelle, a businessman, Rob L. Garris, said his recently opened Mackadocious All-Seasons Maintenance Service will hire "brothers coming home from jail and rehab and give them their first job."
Mr. Garris, who also owns Mackadocious Hairstyles in New Rochelle and is a member of the city's Youth Council Committee, added, "I was your average street kid growing up in foster homes, and I said to myself that if I ever got my life together, I would help others."
Black women leaders who were interviewed said they were most concerned with helping younger members of their race move ahead in government. At the offices of the Westchester Black Women's Political Caucus, the president, Sheila Morris, said: "There is a need for women already in office to act as mentors for those who are coming along. We are setting our sights on political empowerment."
The organization represents 400 members in chapters in Greenburgh, Mount Vernon, New Rochelle, Yonkers and Peekskill.
One of its charter members, County Legislator Lois T. Bronz, a Democrat representing parts of Greenburgh, White Plains, Scarsdale and New Rochelle, said that black women who have achieved a "relatively high profile in public and professional life" needed to help younger women who were struggling to balance raising families with their careers.
 
Less Stereotyping Observed
 "A lot of us were single mothers," Ms. Bronz said, "and we have something to share with our young sisterhood, who in many cases don't have a support system to help show them the way."
At the Open Cage Theater in Mount Vernon, the director, Tina Sattin, said that, looking back at the history of women in the arts, she was seeing less stereotyping.
"We are finally playing professional people," she said. "For men and women, TV took a long time to catch up with us."
But for many blacks, the stereotyping persists, and Kenneth W. Jenkins, president of the Yonkers chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. said, "It's with us still, even in the little things like going to the store and having people look at us as though we are going to steal something."
Throughout the month, there will be art exhibitions, lectures, films, concerts, dances, readings of literature by black writers and special events for children. A copy of the calendar of events can be got through the Office of Cultural Affairs; the phone numbers are 285-2922 or 785-6709.

HEADLINE: When Fascism Was in Flower

BYLINE: By Eugen Weber; Eugen Weber's most recent books are "My France" and "Movements, Currents, Trends."

 BODY:

THE BIRTH OF FASCIST IDEOLOGY
From Cultural Rebellion to Political Revolution.
By Zeev Sternhell with Mario Sznajder
and Maia Asheri.
Translated by David Maisel.
338 pp. Princeton, N.J.:
Princeton University Press.
$29.95. 
 FOR the last 15 years, Zeev Sternhell, a professor of political science at Hebrew University in Jerusalem, has battled to affirm the ideological significance of Fascism: it was not a flash in the pan, but the expression of political and cultural positions no less interesting than liberalism or Marxism. Fascism, Mr. Sternhell says in "The Birth of Fascist Ideology" (as he has said before in earlier works), is not racism, biological determinism or anti-Semitism (there were many Fascist Jews). It is not a defensive reaction of the bourgeoisie, the last gasp of capitalism on the ropes or a mere byproduct of World War I. It is, rather, a synthesis of the two most forceful ideologies of the 19th century, nationalism and socialism, which leaders of the French radical right had coupled before that century ended, soon to be imitated by Italian syndicalists and nationalists.
The jump shift, Mr. Sternhell suggests, was in the cards. On the one hand, nationalism that views the nation-state as an organic whole could tolerate neither class oppression nor class conflict. On the other, the social opportunities and justice that socialism demanded appeared a natural part of a functioning nation. So national socialism made sense. But, Mr. Sternhell argues, there was more. The closing 19th century suffered from an acute sense of cultural (and physical) degeneration, degradation and disintegration. The eagles that so many dreamed of had come home to roost in the guise of chickens. Democracy seemed a delusion, pacifist internationalism irrelevant, natural rights a dream, equality a fantasy hatched by lachrymose humanists. In the 1890's, intellectuals of the left, already ranged against bourgeois hedonism and parliamentary corruption, often turned against social democracy as well.
As socialist politicians accepted the rules of liberal and democratic games, Mr. Sternhell says, hopes that many had placed in Marxism withered, the rationalist utopias of the Enlightenment looked less convincing. Capitalism appeared selfish, hence antinational; socialism seemed bureaucratic, hence parasitic and counterproductive. Masses were no more amenable to reason than classes. Psychology took precedence over economics: intuition, energy and energizing myths were what counted -- and moral, not social or economic, reform.
The children of the Enlightenment had been materialistic and utilitarian, argued these radical rightists from the left. Now it seemed as if essential questions were not material but cultural and emotional. People's lives could be altered without touching economic structures. It followed that class analyses were snares, and that the true force of the modern world was not the proletariat but the nation. Class struggle, abolished within the national community, would be transferred onto the international plane. The true revolution was war, and war apparently proved the protofascists right.
By the time the bloodletting of 1914 to 1918 was over, social democracy in many places was intellectually bankrupt, and parliamentary democracy discredited; only Communism and Fascism seemed to offer ideological prospects to the brightest and best. To those for whom optimism, humanism and universalism did not wash, who regarded economics as secondary to politics and found material forces less appealing than moral ones, Fascism had to be the ideology of choice. In catastrophic times, it proposed a heroic society led by self-selected elites, an egalitarianism of the meritocratic, a revolutionary idealism to replace historical materialism and a militant, modernizing revolution that challenged the delusive dreams generated by the rival revolution in Russia. To his admirers in the 1920's (Freud and Churchill among them), Mussolini -- the Italian labor leader who, years before the war, had replaced "proletariat" with "people" and with "nation" -- offered not an alternative to revolution but an alternative revolution just as violent, as nonconformist, as avant-garde as that of the left.
Mr. Sternhell and his collaborators, Mario Sznajder, a scholar of Italian revolutionary syndicalism, and Maia Asheri, a student of early Italian Fascism, make clear that the compromises, incoherences and contradictions of Mussolinian Fascism were no greater and no more opportunistic than those of liberalism or socialism. Victory and compromise go hand in hand. Was Bolshevism in practice any different? We know that platforms are made to run on, not to stand on. That does not make them less effective while they last, or even (as the press reminds us) when they have been discredited and allegedly abandoned.
Eloquent, repetitive, uneven in style and insistent in argument, "The Birth of Fascist Ideology" (in a workmanlike translation from the French by David Maisel) will not convince the unconvinced, and it will raise hackles Mr. Sternhell likes to see raised. But it deserves to be read and, whatever one's reservations, to be considered seriously. Its approach, in my view, is too deliberately and narrowly intellectual, shortchanging political and social factors. The authors make Fascism and the intellectuals who forged it in France and Italy bear a heavier ideological burden than they can sustain. But this book rectifies the stereotyped and narrowly derogatory image of a movement that was as representative and influential as its more acceptable contemporaries, and more original than many.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mussolini visiting a mass meeting of young Fascists in Rome, about 1931. (THE NEW YORK TIMES)

HEADLINE: California Quake Is Lifting Hopes Of the Governor and a Challenger

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6

 BODY:
The deadly earthquake that moved mountains and toppled buildings here last month also changed the political landscape of California, shifting the terrain in a crucial race that will pit an unpopular Republican Governor against one of two Democratic challengers for his job.
There is widespread agreement that the earthquake on Jan. 17 breathed new life into the political fortunes of Gov. Pete Wilson. The quake also jump-started the underdog primary campaign of John Garamendi, the state's Insurance Commissioner, and raised questions about whether Kathleen Brown, the California Treasurer and Democratic front-runner, is the inevitable winner she once seemed.
 
$8.5 Billion Windfall
 The main beneficiary of California's latest calamity, political experts in both parties agree, is Mr. Wilson, a veteran at coping with disasters and whose job performance ratings improved in the weeks after the earthquake, according to a statewide poll. 
 The Governor, who has issued disaster declarations for fires, floods, riots, toxic spills and droughts in 56 of the state's 58 counties since taking office in 1991, was a reassuring presence in the days after the quake as he toured the devastated areas in his trademark windbreaker and promised to press the Clinton Administration for all the help this battered state needs.
And now it seems that California is on the verge of a Federal windfall, with a record-breaking $8.5 billion aid package already approved by the House of Representatives. The bill is expected to clear the Senate this week and be signed by President Clinton.
Tony L. Coelho, a Californian who is a former Democratic leader in Congress, is one of many political analysts who gives Mr. Wilson high marks for his recent performance and points to an upswing in his ratings, which inched back last week to where they had been before protracted budget battles in Sacramento two years ago.
According to the latest Field Poll, the Governor gets a good or excellent job rating from 30 percent of Californians, up from 25 percent just two weeks ago. And 34 percent now grade him as poor or very poor, down from 40 percent before the quake. The survey of 525 adults, conducted Jan. 27-31, has a margin of sampling error of five percentage points.
And Mr. Wilson's job approval rating could get better, Mr. Coelho said. "The slate can easily be wiped clean if people perceive him to be aggressively interested in helping them solve their current problems," he said. "It isn't even necessary that he have all the answers or deliver the goods. It's an attitudinal thing."
The other political winner in the aftermath of the earthquake seems to be Mr. Garamendi, who trails Ms. Brown by 15 points in the polls. Mr. Garamendi, who characterizes himself as the bull in the china shop of government, attracted attention after the quake by calling for tax increases to pay for rebuilding, while the other candidates were more cautious.
 
Establishing an Identity
 "Because John is carving out a unique position, that helps him flesh out his identity," said Steve Merksamer, a Republican strategist who was chief of staff for Gov. George Deukmejian in 1989, when an earthquake hit the San Francisco Bay Area. Mr. Deukmejian, otherwise adamant about holding the line on taxes during his first six years in office, took quick action after that disaster by raising the sales tax one-fourth of a cent for 13 months, which yielded $800 million for reconstruction. Mr. Deukmejian did not seek re-election in 1990.
Mr. Garamendi is urging a similar approach, calling for a temporary increase in the sales tax to rebuild, particularly schools, and a temporary increase in the gasoline tax to repair the damaged freeways and upgrade others to protect against future quakes.
The state sales tax is now 7.25 percent, and higher in some localities, including Los Angeles at 8.25 and San Francisco at 8.5 percent. The state gasoline tax is 18 cents a gallon.
Mr. Garamendi's call for new taxes contrasts sharply with Mr. Wilson's and Ms. Brown's wait-and-see recommendations.
The Governor is pressing the Federal Government to reimburse the state for the entire cost of rebuilding, and says he prefers bond issues to taxes if more money must be raised. Ms. Brown says it is premature to call for new taxes until a full accounting of damages is made, which is expected this week. In the meantime, she has combed the books in the Treasurer's office and identified $1.3 billion available for reconstruction, from bond issues approved by voters but not sold, and from bridge loans.
 
When Times Were Different
 Publicly, aides to both Mr. Wilson and Ms. Brown say that taxes that were appropriate after the 1989 earthquake are not appropriate today. The state was booming then, they say, but is mired in recession now. Governor Deukmejian had not raised taxes earlier in his administration, but Mr. Wilson presided over a $7 billion tax increase during his first year in office. And the state sales tax was raised by referendum just a few months ago, while the gas tax has been inching up since a voter initiative in 1990.
But privately, aides to both Mr. Wilson and Ms. Brown say they believe a temporary tax increase may be necessary in a state with a huge budget deficit, a depleted emergency reserve fund and many costly problems. But only Mr. Garamendi has said that in public forums and in a barrage of radio advertisements that began last week.
"If a governor or a wannabe isn't willing to say that at a time of crisis, then they're telling the public they don't want to lead," Mr. Garamendi said in an interview.
His provocative strategy could backfire in California, where the nationwide tax revolt began in 1978, particularly if he makes it to the general election in November. But in the short run he has upstaged Ms. Brown and earned media recognition he could not afford to buy.
 
Winning the Headlines
 Many political analysts here pointed to simultaneous appearances by Mr. Garamendi and Ms. Brown last week. While he was at the Hollywood Chamber of Commerce declaring that only "a fool or a liar" would say it is possible to rebuild Los Angeles without new taxes, she was delivering a long-winded economic position paper at the Commonwealth Club in San Francisco.
Mr. Garamendi won the headlines that day. "John is more adept at taking advantage of these opportunities," Mr. Merksamer said. "Let's say he's a news hog."
Campaign strategists for Governor Wilson and Ms. Brown sought to portray Mr. Garamendi's call for taxes as one of his typically reckless acts.
"People in California are looking for several qualities in their next governor," said Dan Schnur, a spokesman for Mr. Wilson, "but unfortunately for John Garamendi, hysteria isn't one of them."
Michael Reese, a spokesman for Ms. Brown, agreed. "It goes to the fundamental flaw in his candidacy," he said.
 
She Who Hesitates . . .
 But many political analysts here say that even more characteristic than Mr. Garamendi's grandstand play is Ms. Brown's hesitant approach, a habit that some experts say is corroding her candidacy.
Ms. Brown, who plans to declare formally that she is running on Tuesday, remains 15 points ahead of Mr. Garamendi in several recent polls, all taken before the earthquake, but she has seen her lead against the Governor shrink. In October, according to the Field Poll, Ms. Brown led Mr. Wilson by 17 points in a head-to-head race. In mid-January, that lead was down to 8 points.
"Increasingly, there have been questions in Democratic circles about whether there's a core to Kathleen, a core of beliefs, a core of knowledge," said Bruce E. Cain, a professor of political science at the University of California at Berkeley. "She has an unwillingness to take strong positions until other people are already in the fray. It's always, 'Well, I have to think about it.' "
 
The Nature of the Job
 Mr. Coehlo agreed. "People are taking a second look," he said. "Those questions were already being asked, and they have more currency now."
Ms. Brown says it is unreasonable to expect decisive action from her about earthquake recovery when her job is so removed from the process. "Let's be real here," she said in an interview. "I am not the governor. I am not involved in insurance claims. There is a very fine line between doing your job and using disasters to court publicity."
She is not alone in insisting that the perception of the candidates since the earthquake has in large measure been a function of their office. "It's the uniforms the three are wearing," said Mervin Field, director of the Field Poll.
Mr. Field and others also note that there is a long way to go before the election and that current perceptions could have a short half-life. They cite the surge in popularity for Art Agnos, who was Mayor of San Francisco in the 1989 earthquake, and then his shocking defeat two years later to Frank Jordan, who was a political amateur.
In the months to come, Mr. Field said, Mr. Wilson will be held accountable for the grinding inconveniences that Angelenos will continue to suffer, the struggle to pay for rebuilding, and the state's others problems, which are likely to be aggravated by the quake. And Mr. Garamendi will be held accountable for the performance of the insurance industry.
"I don't think these bumps last too long," Mr. Field said of the current political landscape. "There's plenty of time for everything to switch around."
