HEADLINE: H.M.O.'s That Offer Choice Are Gaining in Popularity

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Addressing one of the thorniest issues in the debate on health care, employers across the country have found a way to tame rising costs while still allowing their employees the freedom they covet to choose their own doctors and hospitals.
Often called open-ended H.M.O.'s, or point-of-service plans, such plans have gone from a little-used option to become the fastest-growing type of health plan in the nation. Open-ended plans gained more than 3.4 million members from January 1992 to June 1993, including half of all people who joined health maintenance organizations in that period. The country's largest H.M.O., Kaiser Permanente, started offering an open-ended plan to some of its members just last month. 
 The plans have also made their way into the Clinton Administration's health proposals and, if adopted, would be offered to every American. Both the White House and private insurers are pressing for the open-ended approach as an inducement to win over skeptical consumers who fear they may lose control of their health care if they join an H.M.O.
 
Escape Hatch from H.M.O.
 The plans are hybrids, combining the economic discipline of an H.M.O. with some of the free-wheeling latitude of a traditional health plan. The hybrid plans have the tight restrictions common to H.M.O.'s, which offer treatment from a network of doctors and hospitals. But there is an escape hatch. Members can ignore the network at any time and go to any physician or hospital, if they are willing to pay extra for the privilege.
It can be expensive to switch back and forth. Instead of the usual $10 charge for an office visit in the network, a patient seeing an outside physician typically pays the first several hundred dollars of the bills, and then 20 to 50 percent of the remainder, up to a maximum of about $1,200 a year. The employer pays the rest.
Lauren Johnson, who recruits employees for Resource Bancshares Mortgage Group, a financial services company in Columbia, S.C., said she paid the first $400 a year and then 30 percent of each bill to visit her general practitioner, who charges about $40 for a basic visit and is not in her company's open-ended network.
"A lot of times money isn't the factor," she said. "I've been going to him for so long that I really didn't want to change."
But Mrs. Johnson pays only $10 a visit when she sees her obstetrician-gynecologist or takes her daughter to a pediatrician, both of whom are in a United Healthcare Corporation H.M.O. "You get the best of both worlds," she said. Services provided by plan doctors and hospitals are not subject to a deductible.
Though only about 20 percent of the people in these plans ever use the escape hatch because of the expense, they still want the freedom to choose. It is this sense of control that is making the plans, which were introduced a few years ago, so popular.
"There's a segment of people who have a claustrophobic feeling about being locked into a health program," said Mike Israelite, an assistant vice president of Cigna Healthcare, which operates a big network of open-ended H.M.O.'s. "These plans break through that psychological barrier."
Although some managed-care experts deprecate the effectiveness of the hybrid plans, saying the choice is often a delusion for low-income employees who cannot afford to pay for extras, advocates say their role is crucial as the country moves toward managed care.
 
A Favorite in Washington
 The Federal Government has been promoting H.M.O.'s since the Nixon Administration, contending that disciplined groups of doctors following certain rules of practice can slow the upward medical cost spiral and improve the quality of care. But H.M.O.'s that are not open-ended still cover only about one in four insured Americans.
There have also been less rigorous attempts to manage health care. Many traditional plans now require doctors to get approval from a designated expert before expensive treatments. And loosely managed networks of physicians and hospitals, called preferred-provider organizations, accept reduced fees from employers, who pass the savings along to their employees as an incentive to use the doctors in the organization.
Under the Clinton health bill, every health plan would offer a hybrid H.M.O. along with other types of managed care. It would also offer traditional insurance, in which patients could choose any doctor and pay 20 percent of the charges.
"Patients will be able to go see the providers of their choosing," said Dr. Arnold Epstein, a senior White House health care adviser. "People tend to think of the point-of-service plans as the best of both worlds."
The membership of the hybrid plans has tripled in the last two years, said Jon Gabel, benefits research director of KPMG Peat Marwick, the accounting and benefits consulting firm. He said traditional insurance had lost ground, dropping to 42 percent of health plan members last year from 53 percent in 1991.
The loosely managed physician networks also seem to be losing favor, and Mr. Gabel said a growing number had changed into hybrid health plans. They are adopting features similar to those of H.M.O.'s, sometimes paying doctors a fee for each patient, instead of for each service, and increasing the network's control over the way its doctors practice medicine.
Stanford University, for example, abandoned its discount network last month. It offered its 9,500 employees new choices that Barbara Butterfield, a university vice president, described as "pretty close to what the Clinton Administration is hoping for."
Stanford employees have three choices, with graduated payments. An H.M.O. is the least expensive, while going outside the H.M.O. to a Blue Shield-approved doctor costs a bit more. The most expensive choice is consulting any doctor and paying a $500 deductible and 40 percent of the cost.
Southern California Edison is also planning to drop its version of the discount networks. Its 17,000 employees will have to choose between a hybrid H.M.O. or one without the escape hatch, Margaret Jordan, an Edison vice president, said.
New enrollment in hybrid plans provided half of the increase of nearly 7 million people, to 47 million, in all types of H.M.O.'s from December 1991 to June 1993, according to the latest survey by the SMG Marketing Group, a market research firm.
These hybrid plans had 6.8 million members last June, up from 4.9 million in December 1992 and 3.4 million in the beginning of 1992.
Nearly all large health maintenance organizations offer a hybrid program, according to the Group Health Association of America, an H.M.O. trade group.
The latest is Kaiser Permanente, which announced last month that it was offering a hybrid plan to some of its 6.6 million H.M.O. members.
Managed-care experts said large employers that offered the hybrid plans included A.T.& T., Chevron, Marriott, Mobil, Procter & Gamble and Rockwell International.
Most employers say these plans cost them no more than ordinary H.M.O.'s because the few employees who use the escape hatch end up paying the difference in higher charges by outside doctors.
"It's cost-neutral for us," said Sean Healy, a spokesman for Allied Signal, a diversified manufacturer, which started one of the first big hybrid H.M.O.'s in 1988.
At Advanced Flex Inc., a printer of circuit boards, which has 300 employees, "no one has ever chosen to go out" and bear the extra cost, said Mary Pat Pearson, corporate manager of human resources.
But David F. Simon, a senior vice president of the U.S. Healthcare Corporation, a large H.M.O., said the hybrid plans could be deceptive. Although U.S. Healthcare has its own hybrid plan, he said that some companies' versions were "incredibly limited" by the high charges.
Still, the United Healthcare Corporation, a big diversified managed-care company, based in Minnetonka, Minn., said the hybrid H.M.O.'s appealed strongly to small and midsize employers.

HEADLINE: In Rate Move, Fed Tries to Address Fear of Future

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Behind the Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates on Friday -- and its precedent-shattering decision to announce the move -- lies a striking phenomenon: despite years of slowing inflation, the American people do not believe that prices will stay fairly stable and that interest rates will stay low.
The evidence for this sentiment can be found not in polls but in the decisions that millions of Americans make on consumer credit every year. Consider home loans. Four-fifths of all home buyers take out fixed-rate mortgages, even though such loans have interest rates nearly twice as high as those for one-year adjustable-rate mortgages. 
 In other words, Americans are so sure that interest rates will rise in coming years that they choose not to save themselves a lot of money at the outset. As recently as the mid-1980's, two-thirds of American mortgages were adjustable-rate mortgages.
When Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, testified before a Congressional panel last Monday, he made no secret of his concern about Americans' persistent expectations that inflation would return. He highlighted the fact that long-term interest rates for Government bonds have been much higher this year than short-term rates.
 
 
Fed Under Attack
 Yet fear and skepticism over the future have come at a politically awkward time for the Federal Reserve, the nation's central bank. On the one hand, it is in charge of holding down inflation -- and indirectly long-term interest rates -- by raising short-term interest rates when the economy appears to be growing too quickly. On the other, the Treasury Department and some powerful members of Congress are trying to shear the Fed of some powers, and interest-rate increases are seldom popular in Congress.
The Treasury wants to take away many of the Fed's powers to regulate banks, while Representative Henry B. Gonzalez of Texas, the Democratic chairman of the House Banking Committee, is seeking to curb the Fed's secrecy and autonomy.
The Fed managed on Friday to address the fear and skepticism without antagonizing Congress much or the Administration at all. It did so by raising interest rates for overnight loans between banks by a modest quarter of a percentage point while announcing the move, something the Fed had never done before in its 80-year history.
 
 
Same Effect as a Half-Point Move
 The result was that investors took notice, and the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 96.24 points on Friday. John P. Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said that by announcing the quarter-point move, the Fed had the same effect on the financial markets as if it had raised short-term interest rates by half a percentage point without an announcement.
"They were able to get the markets' attention, in a rapt way, with the most modest move they could have considered," he said.
Fed officials said the decision to announce the interest rate increase was made without regard to the politics of the issue. "Chairman Greenspan decided to announce this action immediately so as to avoid any misunderstanding" of the Fed's intentions, given that the Fed had not tightened monetary policy since early 1989, the agency said in a statement.
But few people on Wall Street or on Capitol Hill believed the Fed this weekend. Representative Jim Leach of Iowa, the ranking Republican on the House Banking Committee and the Fed's closest ally in Congress, said politics had indeed played a role in the Fed's decision to announce the rate increase.
"I think it was a factor, but probably not the dominant factor," Mr. Leach said in a telephone interview today, while hastily adding that Fed officials had not asked his advice on the announcement despite frequent meetings with him.
In any case, the Fed did manage to forestall most criticism. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, who waged a personal campaign this winter to try to strip the Fed of most of its bank regulatory powers, avoided endorsing the Fed's move when he appeared on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" this morning, but was complimentary all the same.
"We want to see a long-term, sustained growth for our country's economy, with modest inflation, and that's what we're striving for, and I think the Fed is, too," Mr. Bentsen said.
Mr. Leach said, "I personally think it's an appropriate thing to do."
Mr. Gonzalez issued a carefully worded statement on Friday that applauded the Fed for its prompt disclosure while including his customary criticism of any restriction on the growth of bank reserves, which is how the Fed raises short-term interest rates.
"Slow money growth will drag down the economy -- not a wise or compassionate move when millions of Americans are in dire straits and nearly 7 percent of the labor force is unemployed," he said.
But Mr. Gonzalez was unusual in publicly reacting to the Fed's actions. Most members of Congress have abstained from such a step, at least as long as a rate increase does not cause the stock market to collapse.
A few economists attributed the Fed's moves on Friday simply to a bureaucratic interest in reassuring markets that it was still alert to the risks of inflation even though it had not changed short-term interest rates in nearly a year and a half.
"The Fed apparently came to the conclusion that it had to demonstrate to the public that it was alive," Milton Friedman, the noted economist and historian of the Fed, said.

HEADLINE: Storm Warnings on Health Care

 BODY:
President Clinton's health care bill was roughed up several times last week. Splashy opposition came from three business groups. But the more damaging blow came from the state governors, who adopted principles strikingly different from the President's.
Debate is raging at two levels. There is dispute over purpose: Should every American be guaranteed coverage? And there is dispute over architecture: How should health care institutions be configured? The President promised to veto any plan that fails to provide universal coverage, but will negotiate over architecture. He learned last week that two powerful constituencies have not accepted either part of the bargain. 
 It might seem odd that the Business Roundtable, an organization of 200 of the largest corporations, voted in favor of Representative Jim Cooper's bill over Mr. Clinton's. Mr. Cooper's bill would raise taxes on these corporations because they provide workers with expensive coverage, whereas Mr. Clinton's bill offers them a bribe by promising to absorb their huge costs of insuring early retirees.
True, Mr. Cooper would not require employers to buy insurance for their workers as Mr. Clinton would. But these Fortune 500 companies do not fear employer mandates because they, unlike many small companies, already cover their workers.
The Administration attributes the Roundtable decision to pressure by pharmaceutical and insurance firms. But that explains few votes. More likely, the mostly Republican C.E.O.'s preferred Mr. Cooper's more market-based approach to the President's price controls and heavy-handed regulation. Whatever the reason, the business group most likely to embrace Mr. Clinton's bill turned its back.
But the Roundtable at least voted for something constructive -- even though Mr. Cooper's bill does not provide universal coverage. By contrast, the Chamber of Commerce, which represents many small businesses, rejected every bill in sight -- putting short-term profits above solving the nation's foremost domestic problem. The National Association of Manufacturers also rejected Mr. Clinton's bill, but with more conciliatory language.
Mr. Clinton might be able to survive business opposition. Not so the governors. Washington will find it hard to overhaul one-seventh of the economy without the states' enthusiastic support. Though the governors embraced some key principles of the President's bill, they rejected price controls and what they feared would be job-threatening employer mandates.
And bravely, the governors sided with Mr. Cooper in calling for tax hikes on expensive health care policies -- the best way to compel buyers to pay attention to costs and raise money for subsidizing the poor.
The President can work with the governors and groups like the Roundtable, which are willing to back responsible alternatives. His first task is to heed the call to strip away numbingly complex and needlessly regulatory provisions. In return, he can push his critics to move all the way to universal coverage. With that strategy, last week's setbacks need not derail eventual victory.

HEADLINE: Racketeering Ruling Leaves Some Uneasy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"When Is Protest Not Protest? When You Call It Extortion" (The Week in Review, Jan. 30) lists Greenpeace as co-signer of a friend-of-the-court brief for respondents in National Organization for Women v. Scheidler, on anti-abortion protests. Greenpeace made no submission to the Supreme Court in this case. 
 The question presented to the Court (does the Federal racketeering statute require economic motive?) did not require consideration of First Amendment issues of nonviolent, peaceful protest. As expected, the Court did not address those issues.
In a concurring opinion, however, Justices David Souter and Anthony Kennedy gave voice to the fear of many who filed briefs that racketeering actions "could deter protected advocacy." The Justices cautioned "courts applying RICO to bear in mind the First Amendment interests that could be at stake."
As an organization that has never condoned violence or destruction of property, Greenpeace does not expect the Supreme Court decision to affect its own peaceful, nonviolent protests against environmental degradation. We would be foolhardy, however, not to recognize the potential for serious harm that polluters and others could inflict simply by burdening with racketeering suits those who protest their destructive activities, while First Amendment issues are still being sorted out by the lower courts.
Congress may well want to reconsider what its broad racketeering law may reap.
 
CAROL MCC. BOOKER
General Counsel, Greenpeace U.S.
Washington, Jan. 31, 1994

HEADLINE: Where Three-Strikes Plan Takes Us in 20 Years

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is disheartening to see intelligent political figures like President Bill Clinton and New York's Gov. Mario M. Cuomo embracing with shameless enthusiasm the "three strikes and you're out" proposal. 
 Despite the broad public appeal of it, these leaders must surely realize that locking up three-time violent offenders for life would do nothing to control crime, would wreak havoc on our prison systems and would result in squandering huge amounts of government resources.
In New York State, such a proposal would affect 300 offenders a year. In the short term it would have no effect on crime or prisons because these people will be incarcerated under existing laws anyway. But the long-term consequences would be calamitous. In 20 years, for example, New York would have in custody 6,000 people who would have to stay confined, at state expense, not only past, say, 40 years old, by which time virtually all of them will have aged out of any inclinations to additional violence, but also for their entire lives.
Prison officials would be charged with running geriatric institutions, instead of correctional facilities, for thousands of inmates no longer dangerous to public safety, and taxpayers would be picking up the tab involving billions of dollars in operating and construction costs.
So, of course, less money would be available to support measures that actually stand a chance of reducing crime, ranging from drug rehabilitation and community policing to economic development programs. It should also be noted that most jurisdictions already have on their books mandatory sentencing statutes that will send three-time felony losers away for a long time.
"Three strikes and you're out" represents extension of a policy that has proved a failure: prison expansion. Since 1973, New York's prison population has grown more than 500 percent, from 12,500 inmates to 64,500 today. But can anyone argue that the streets are safer, or that drug abuse and violence are less a threat to the quality of our lives?
It is time for the American public to see past the pandering of political leaders and understand that tough-sounding baseball metaphors are no substitute for smart, effective anti-crime policies.
 
ROBERT GANGI
Executive Director, Correctional Assn. of New York
New York, Jan. 28, 1994
